A Hiccock is like to a convul≈øion which if it come withour a feaver or any di≈øea≈øe; Hiccock and be occa≈øioned by meate or drinke it portends nothing of eminent danger, but after too much purging, and with inflamations and feavers, hiccocks are allwayes dangerous, e≈øpecially if they happen to old men; unle≈ø≈øe a Cri≈øis of vomiting afterwards be pre≈øent, e≈øpecially if other dangers and deadly ≈øignes joyned therewith.

Trembling is evill if it happen in the beginning of di≈øea≈øes without an evident cau≈øe, Trembling. and indicates the di≈øea≈øes to be dangerous, e≈øpecially if it ≈øhall be longer and more grevious, and other weighty Symptomes are joyned therewith, as tho≈øe which happen in an Apoplexy and Lethargie, but that trembling which happens afterwards, and is occa≈øioned by the critick expul≈øion of humours, from the interior to the externall parts, is a token of no evill, nor is that trembling evill which ≈øucceeds a pal≈øie, ≈øince it is a token that nature overcomes the di≈øea≈øe.

A ≈øhaking fit which incontinued feavers happens in that houre wherein the paine u≈øeth to gripe, A partxi≈øme. when the ≈øignes of concoction go before, tis a token of a future Cr≈øis, and therfore accounted good, if ≈øome good evacuation follow; otherwi≈øe if it happen in the beginning of a di≈øea≈øe, or with an ill and difficult cri≈øis tis adjudged evill.

Cold fits which happen at certain times in intermitting feavers, Cold fit. ≈øignifies no evill; nor are they ill ≈øignes in continued feavers, which happen after ≈øignes of concoction, and are tokens of criticall evacuations; and after which the body growes hot again, and ≈øome criticall evacuation followeth. But tho≈øe which are occa≈øioned whil≈øt the matter is crude, by rea≈øon whereof the body cannot grow hot with evill evacuations, or when no evacuation followeth, and which happens with ill ≈øignes, are all evill.

Sloath of apprehen≈øion, Torpor. ≈øpecially of the body cau≈øed by cold, is perpetually evill, and without a feaver or Apoplexy, it pretends manife≈øt danger in feavers, by rea≈øon of the extingui≈øhing of the native heat.

Moreover the ≈øignes of defaults of ≈øpeech are to be ob≈øerved; Hurt in the voice. a ≈øhrill voice threatens danger, ≈øince it denotes exceeding drine≈ø≈øe of the in≈øtruments of the voice; dumbne≈ø≈øe, although it be never good, nor without danger, yet it is not alwayes deadly, namely when the judicatory evacuation follows, and when it doth not continue long; the re≈øt that are dumbe, are all for the mo≈øt part mortall; and ≈øo much the wor≈øe, how many the more perilous ≈øignes are ioyned.

Secondly, The ≈øtrength of the vitall faculty. the ≈øtrength and weakne≈ø≈øe of the vitall faculty, which are of greate≈øt force in fore≈øhewing ≈øafty, or death, we ob≈øerved principally from the pul≈øe and re≈øpiration. Of the pul≈øe tis ≈øpoken already, onely we repeate this, that the mo≈øt langui≈øhing, mo≈øt dull, and mo≈øt thin, are the wor≈øt of all; after the≈øe the lea≈øt and ≈øofte≈øt, and harde≈øt; next the mo≈øt frequent, but not ≈øwift, nor great; only among≈øt extreames the mo≈øt vehement is the be≈øt, yet we mu≈øt diligently ob≈øerve alwayes, whither the change of the pul≈øe ari≈øe from the di≈øea≈øe, or come from externall cau≈øes.

Hereunto belongs the Palpitation of the heart, ≈øwounding and falling downe, as it were dead, which indicate dejection of the vitall faculty, and great danger, if they happen through ≈øome di≈øea≈øe of the heart it ≈øelfe.

Re≈øpiration, Re≈øpiration. of it be naturall, ≈øignifies neither the bre≈øt, nor heart, not midriffe to be any way affected with paine, nor any adjacent parts Galen 1. prog. Apho. 25. and moreover it hath great force in ≈øignifying tokens of health, when one is ≈øick in a feaver, e≈øpecially if other good ≈øignes are pre≈øent Hip. ib. on the contrary preternaturally re≈øpiration, although it be not allwayes mortall, yet tis alwayes evill, but wor≈øt of all if it be joyned with other ill ≈øignes; great and ≈øwift breathings
≈øignifie great ≈øtore of fuliginous vapours, yet the organs apt, and the faculty hitherto ≈øtrong, a great and ≈ølow pul≈øe happens only to tho≈øe that are di≈øturbed in mind; a great and frequent pul≈øe ≈ønew pain or inflamation of the part ≈øerving for breathing; little and ≈øwift re≈øpiration ≈øhews plenty of fuliginous excrements, but with paine, or inflamation of ≈øome of the organs appointed for breathing; a little, and ≈ølow pul≈øe ≈øhews not many vapours, with paine or inflamation of ≈øome in≈øtrument of re≈øpiration, and with other ill ≈øignes portends not a little danger; little and ob≈øcure re≈øpiration is perpetually evill, and ≈øignifies di≈ø≈øolution of ≈øtrength; but little and thin is the wor≈øt of all, becau≈øe it indicates the greate≈øt debility of the faculty, and if a cold breath proceed from the mouth and no≈øtrills, it is very de≈øtructive; but the wor≈øt of all, and the neare≈øt to death, is when it extends & is ob≈øcure, and ≈øublime, wherein the bre≈øt is much dilated, and ≈øometimes the Shoulders, and gri≈øly part of the no≈øtrills, but that which is in≈øpired is very thick, and mo≈øt frequent; but the wor≈øt re≈øpiration of all, is that which is made with ordure.

Moreover for what belongs to the Symptomes of the naturall faculty, Symptomes of the naturall faculty what they pre≈øage. their perfection is known by their operations, of which it ≈øhall be ≈øpoken hereafter, but that we may ≈øpeak here ≈øomething of the de≈øire of meate and drink; to have a good appetite to meat, and that proceding from a naturall cau≈øe, and as Hippo. 2. Apho. 33. writes, in every di≈øea≈øe to take ea≈øily what≈øoever is offered, is a good ≈øigne; on the contrary an ill appetite of meate is bad 7. Apho 6. not to thir≈øt al≈øo in hot and burning feavers, wherein the tongue is filthy and black, perpetually ≈øignifies mi≈øcheif, and a delirium, or di≈ø≈øolution of the de≈øiring faculty, or of them both; but as it is an ill ≈øigne not to thir≈øt, ≈øo tis a good ≈øigne to thir≈øt in hot di≈øea≈øes, al≈øo to thir≈øt immoderatly and over much, is notgood,

div.head: CHAP. VI. Of the ≈øignes of life and death which are taken from excretions and retentions.
div.p:
AMong≈øt exerements, urines principaly u≈øe to be ob≈øerved, Progno≈øtick from vrine. but although it is ≈øpoken of already, what they ≈øhew, above, part the fir≈øt See. 2. cap. 21. yet here we may breifly comprehend tho≈øe things which portend to death or life, namely, that urine is be≈øt which is mo≈øt like that of a ≈øound
per≈øon from this the re≈øt differ in ≈øub≈øtance, colour, quantity, and contents. As to the ≈øub≈øtance, the goodne≈ø≈øe of the ≈øub≈øtance with a good colour, promi≈øeth health; thin urines with a good colour promi≈øe health, yet they ≈øhew a di≈øea≈øe which requires longer time for concoction. Thin and red urins ≈øignify a crude di≈øea≈øe 2. prog. 30. but thick, which are made ≈øo after the beginning of a di≈øea≈øe are al≈øo good, if they were thin before, much urine if it be made on a criticall day is good, which ≈øomtimes is profitably made with ≈øharpne≈ø≈øe, and paine.

Troubled urine, not ≈øetling in the bottome, becau≈øe the ≈øtrength of the di≈øea≈øed per≈øi≈øts, argues for the mo≈øt part the di≈øea≈øe to continue long; if imbecility of the fick be pre≈øent, it denotes their death, but tho≈øe which grow cleare are better. As for the colours of waters, a pale red, a light ≈øafron colour, and a kind of cleer clay colour are good, neither is a reddi≈øh colour with a reddi≈øh and light ≈øediment to be found fault with, but on the other ≈øide bright ≈øhinning urines, and white are evill; and e≈øpecially if they appeare ≈øuch, in Phren≈øies, 4. Agho. 72. principally, if they are ≈øo in the beginning of a di≈øea≈øe, and continue ≈øo long; thin, and red, ≈øignify the di≈øea≈øe is crude, and moreover tis dangerous if they continue ≈øo long; black urine in acute di≈øea≈øes, unle≈ø≈øe they are emitted on a criticall day, allwayes denote great danger; after black, the oyly are the wor≈øt, yellow, and green al≈øo are nought, and green urines if they appeare ≈øo ≈øuddenly in men that are in other re≈øpects ≈øound, with biting of the heart, tis a ≈øigne they have drank poi≈øon, and they are in danger of death, but in feavers they are mortall ≈øignes; e≈øpecially if they appeare in the beginning of the di≈øca≈øe.

As for the quanity Hippo. 3. Epid. com. 3. tom 4. condemnes thin urins made in great quantity; as al≈øo much urine, thick, not re≈øiding and no way helping; and all urines are made in great quantity in the beginning, are di≈øliked; ≈ømall quantities of urines in acute feavers are al≈øo nought.

As to the contents, tho≈øe urins are evill which have no ≈øediment, and nothing that ≈øwimmeth in the urinall in the midde≈øt of the urine, nor a little cloud; unle≈ø≈øe the ≈øick hath fa≈øted long, or watched, or laboured: or becau≈øe the body is exceeding full of choler; thick waters al≈øo without a ≈øediment are dangerous, and a ≈øediment repre≈øenting, the forme of thick brain, is evill, but wor≈øt of all, if it re≈øide in a manner like ≈øcales of
Fi≈øh, but if it be thin and white tis vitious; but that which is furfuraceous or like Bran is wor≈øt of all, Hippo. 2. prog. 28. a nubecula, or little cloud, which is carried in the Urine, if it be white tis good, if black tis nonght; tis evill al≈øo for the ≈øick to make water and not know of it.

Secondly, Of dejection of the helly. the dejections of the belly afford us ≈øignes two manner of waies; fir≈øt, as they ≈øhew the concoction of the ≈øtomack and guts, al≈øo as they manife≈øt the humours flowing from other parts to the guts; As for the fir≈øt kind, that ejection is be≈øt if it be gentle and con≈øtant; and ≈øent forth at that time when it is wont to be in the be≈øt health, if quantity be according to what hath been eaten, 2. Apho. 13. The latter is good if it be criticall, and with ≈øignes of concoction in the ≈øtate of a di≈øea≈øe, and happen on a criticall day, and ea≈øe the ≈øick, 1. Apho. 2. On the other ≈øide ill dejections, and tho≈øe which portend de≈øtruction, derogate from the good in ≈øub≈øtance, colour, ≈ømell, time wherein they appear, nor are they voided with ea≈øe.

As to their ≈øub≈øtance and quantity, dry excrement and rolled up in clods are ≈øignes of fiery heat, and if be≈øides they ≈øhall be black, they declare a burning di≈øea≈øe to be in the middle of the body, and for that rea≈øon are evill: On the contrary liquid excretion is not evill, if it have other good notes; but the watry ordure is wor≈øe, and proceeds from greater crudity; and moreover in cholerick di≈øea≈øes, with ill Urines tis deadly, but in more milde it ≈øignifies the di≈øea≈øe will continue long. A glutinous, white, light, fat, and foetid ordure, and little, are condemned, 2. Prog. 21, 22. Cleare dejections al≈øo in acute di≈øea≈øes are condemned, 2. Prorrh. 15. and froathy, and cholerick ejections in acute cholerick di≈øea≈øes are accounted evill, ibid. Apho. 18.

As to the colour, excrements which differ from the naturall colour, are white; red, bloody, watry, green, yellow, black, full of mixt colours, unle≈ø≈øe they are emitted critically they portend danger: Yet in all the≈øe ejections in judging of them, regard is to be had of the meat, and to take heed you ob≈øerve whether that quality hath its ri≈øe from dyet that hath been taken; for they become white either by the ob≈øtructing of the pa≈ø≈øages through which choler de≈øcends to the guts, or through the motion of the choler to ≈øome ≈øuperiour and more noble part,
Red are al≈øo of them≈øelves dangerous, yet if they are extruded after the victory of nature, they rather ≈øhew hope of pre≈øent health, then portend any thing of evill.

Black Excrements ≈øince they proceed either from blood or melancholy humours, or from black choler, that blackne≈ø≈øe which comes from concrete blood, or a melancholy humour, is not alwaies evill: but pure black choler can never be ≈øent out of the body without de≈øtruction of the ≈øick.

Green and aeruginous ordure which proceeds from aeruginous choler tending to black, is an argument of a pernicious di≈øea≈øe, if it be ca≈øt out from any principall part, and the bowels be affected with an Ery≈øipelous; if the Excrements are yellow, they ≈øignifie vehement cold in the internall parts, and as it were a certain mortification: Ejections al≈øo of divers colours are evill, 2. Prog. 23.
Faetid Excrements are evill al≈øo, and the wor≈øt of all, and few are pre≈øerved who≈øe excrements in acute feavers are foetid, yellow, fat, black, and blew, or lead colour.

Tho≈øe vomitings are good which truly purge the cau≈øes of di≈øea≈øes, Of vomitings. or which are made critically, and when concocted matter appears on the criticall daies, and are ≈øuitable to the nature of the di≈øea≈øe, and take away or abate the ≈øame; but on the contrary, all tho≈øe are evill which happen in the beginning, when the matter is not yet concocted, and which take not away the morbifique matter, and the di≈øea≈øe; and they are ≈øo much the wor≈øe if other pernitious ≈øignes be pre≈øent, ≈øuch as are ≈øincere Vomits, leek coloured, lead coloured, black, ≈øtinking, and foetid, from the guts, Ileon, and very little.

Sweats are good which happen after decoction is made, O≈ø ≈øweats. and on a criticall day, and coldne≈ø≈øe, and ≈øtifne≈ø≈øe, proceeding & flowes out hot and plentifully from the whole body, and le≈ø≈øen and abate the di≈øea≈øe: on the other ≈øide, tho≈øe are evill which happen while≈øt the matter is crude, which are too much, or too little, and tho≈øe which are cold, or flow not from the whole body, and neither dimini≈øh nor take away the di≈øea≈øe.

The Hemorodes of the no≈øe are good which happen in the ≈øtate of a di≈øea≈øe, From the Hemerodes of the no≈øe. with ≈øignes of concoction, nor is that alwaies to be condemned which happens in the augmentation, and al≈øo in the beginning, ≈øeeing the blood wants no other preparation, neither do the other humours. Good Hemerodes ought to be large, but yet not over much, but to be made with
ea≈øe, and the ≈øymptomes of the Feaver to be abated, and to happen in a criticall day, and in tho≈øe di≈øea≈øes, wherin bleeding is proper to their nature and condition; and moreover the blood ought to flow from a part oppo≈øite to the part affected: on the contrary, tho≈øe are ill Hemerodes which happen in the beginning, unle≈ø≈øe other good ≈øignes are pre≈øent, and if they appear with dangerous ≈øignes, and tho≈øe which are too large, or too little.

Dropping of blood from the No≈øe is evill, if it be cau≈øed by perverne≈ø≈øe of matter, multitude, imbecility of force, or all the≈øe, e≈øpecially in the beginning, or on the fourth day, if the blood be black, ≈øincere, and without mixture: But it be a token of a future Cri≈øis, tis no ill ≈øigne, which happens when the ≈øignes of concoction have been before, and the di≈øea≈øe is not dangerous.

Spittle is of great u≈øe in ≈øhewing of di≈øea≈øes of the brea≈øt, From ≈øpittle. and that is good which is concocted, white and equall, and is ≈øpit out conveniently, and ea≈øily in a ≈øhort ≈øpace of time, without great pain, and a great cough: on the contrary, tis evill if it be crude, yellow; wor≈øe, if it be green, wor≈øt of all if black, e≈øpecially if it be without mixture, if it appears more dull, and is ≈øpit out with great difficulty, tis al≈øo evill; when the ≈øpittle is bloody, for it proceedeth from ero≈øion, or from breaking of Ve≈ø≈øels.

La≈øtly, decretory Impo≈øthumations are good,
∆≤lcers. if they happen with ≈øignes of concoction, and other good ≈øignes, and break on a judicatory day; they are good by nature which are removed from the bowels and more noble parts, which per≈øevere, are ≈øuppurated, and help the ≈øick: On the contrary, tho≈øe are evill which break forth without ≈øignes of concoction, the matter as yet being crude, and on a day that is not criticall, if they are too great, or too little, or happen to be in the fingers, or toes, if they are lead colour, or too red, inclining to black, and tho≈øe which decrea≈øe and vani≈øh, without any rea≈øon, and without any precedent evacuation, tho≈øe which are not well ≈øuppurated, which are corrupted, and they bring either that part where they are, or the whole body into danger.

div.head: CHAP. II. Of the ≈øignes of health and of death which are taken from the mutations of the qualities of the body.
div.p: MOreover to the mutation of the qualities of the body, What may be fore-told by the habit of the body. and fir≈øt concerning the whole body, tis a good ≈øigne if it be rendred not much unlike to a ≈øound body in habit and colour.

Tis no good ≈øigne for the mo≈øt part in a great Di≈øea≈øe, when nothing is changed, 2. Apho. 28. Tis al≈øo an ill ≈øigne when bodies are extenuated in the declination of a Di≈øea≈øe, and although they take food are not thereby refre≈øhed. For in acute Di≈øea≈øes, tis an ill ≈øigne when the body is puft up and ≈øwelled, unle≈ø≈øe criticall humours are then remitted.

The colour of the body when changed contrary to nature, From the colour. and e≈øpecially in the yellow Jaundice, is a good ≈øigne. In Feavers if it come to pa≈ø≈øe by natures driving the cholerick humours critically to the out ≈øide of the body, and the skin; but that which is contrary is to be adjudged evill.

Tho≈øe ≈øignes which are in the face are of great force, From the face. but that face is be≈øt which is like to theirs which are in health, but if it be contrary tis vitious, Hip. 1. Prog. 5. but a face may be unlike to their faces that are well many waies, and by how much the more it recedeth from the face of ≈øound people, by ≈øo much the greater evill it denotes.

All which ≈øignes Hippocrates in his de≈øcription of a face, Hippo. face. which differs from a face of a ≈øound per≈øon produceth, which therefore is called an Hippocraticall face, 2. Prog. 6, & 7. ≈øharp No≈øe, hollow Eyes, the Temples ≈øtreightned, or narrow, the Eares cold and contracted, and their fibres inverted, the skin al≈øo about the Forehead hard, fixed, and dry, and the colour of the whole countenance green, or black, which change of the countenance is very deadly, e≈øpecially in the beginning of a di≈øea≈øe, unle≈ø≈øe it ≈øo happen to be from ≈øome evident cau≈øe, and mends night and
day, but that face which is of a purple colour, mixt with blew, unle≈ø≈øe the Hemerodes of the No≈øe, or an Impo≈øthumation behind the Eares be to follow after, is an ill figne, and denotes a very hot di≈øea≈øe of the brain.

As the eyes are affected, ≈øo the body, By the eyes and principally the head, 6. Edip. Comm. 4. tom. 28. for if the eyes are like to theirs that are well, have a naturall colour, are full, ≈øplendid, and indure the light without trouble, if they open their eye lids well, and ≈øhut them without teares, and without excrements, they are good ≈øignes.

But there are divers mutations in the eyes, and as Hippo. 1. Prog 10. writes, if the eyes avoid the light, or ≈øhed tears again≈øt the will of the ≈øick, or are perverted, or one ≈øhall be le≈ø≈øe then the other, and the white become reddi≈øh, or of the colour of lead, or black Veines, or phlegme appears about the ≈øight, or look divinely upward, or are hollow, or the colour of the whole countenance varies, all the≈øe are to be accounted evill and de≈øtructive, but wor≈øt of all if the ≈øick ≈øee not, hear not, and if this happen in a weak body, death is nigh at hand.

A ≈øharp No≈øe, and a No≈øe that is turned, or wreathed, By the No≈øtrill. after what manner ≈øoever, is an ill ≈øigne; if the No≈øe itch contrary to cu≈øtome, unle≈ø≈øe it indicate a flux of blood imminent, it ≈øhewes that a Delirium will follow.
The Eares if they are of a wan colour, By the ears. black contracted and cold, tis a ≈øigne of death.
The grinding of the teeth is an ill ≈øigne, By the teeth tis an ill ≈øigne al≈øo when any glutinous humours ≈øticks to the teeth.

When the Tongue is like theirs who are in health, By the Tongue. tis a very good ≈øigne, but tis very evill if it be green, black and exceeding dry, cleaved, or chopped, rough, and as it were burnt: But principally dry, hard, and black Tongues indicate danger, if they appeare with other ill ≈øigns, & mo≈øt of all if when the Tongue is rough and dry, the ≈øick be not thir≈øty.

The Chops ulcerated with a Feaver is hard to be cured, By the Cheps. 3. Prog 15. and if in acute di≈øea≈øes of the Chops, if paines, and abjectne≈ø≈øe, and ≈øtoppings, without a tumour happen, they are pernitious, 1. Prorrh. 11. and if the Feaver being detained, he ≈øuddenly turn his neck awry, and can ≈øcarce ≈øwallow, no tumour being pre≈øent, tis mortiferous, 4. Apho. 35.

Tis a good ≈øigne if the Hypocondries are without paine, By the Hypocondries if they are ≈øoft and equall, on either part if they are not extenuated; yet ≈øomtimes when the Hypocondries are ≈øtretched it ≈øhewes a cri≈øis to come, but then al≈øo other criticall ≈øignes are pre≈øent; on the contrary tis an ill ≈øigne, if the Hypocondries are troubled with inflamation, or paine, or are ≈øtretched, or unequally affected, on the right, or left part; al≈øo when extenuated, By the extremities of the body. and beating, unle≈ø≈øe a Cri≈øis be pre≈øent.

La≈øtly as to the extremities of the body, if in intermitting feavers, the extreame parts grow cold, and the internall burne, and they thir≈øt, tis mortall 7. Apho. 1. but tis very good if all the body be equally hot, and ≈øoft; it is evill al≈øo, and for the mo≈øt part deadly if all the body be heavy, and e≈øpecially if the nailes and fingers are black and blue, or black, if the genitalls, and ≈øtones are drawn up together, al≈øo filthy ≈ømells indicate great putrifaction and danger.

div.head: THE FOURTH BOOK,

Fir≈øt, for the cau≈øes which are nece≈ø≈øary for the maintaining of health, they are comprehended under the notion of things called non-naturall, and are conveniently reduced into foure ranks, into tho≈øe things which are taken, tho≈øe things which are carried, tho≈øe which befall the body without, and tho≈øe things which are emitted and retained: Fir≈øt therefore we are to ≈øpeak here of Aire, Meat and Drink, Pa≈ø≈øions of the Mind, motion, and exerci≈øe of body, and re≈øt, ≈øleep, and watchings, Venery, Bathes, Excretions, and retentions.

div.head: CHAP. II. Of Aire.
div.p:
But the con≈øtitution of the Aire may be polluted through divers cau≈øes; fir≈øt, the con≈øtitution of the Aire depends on

Yet this cau≈øe only doth not ≈øuffice, The earth and nature of the place. neither is the ≈øame con≈øtitution of aire in all the inhabitants under the ≈øame paralell; ≈øecondly, the mould and proper nature of the earth conduceth to the con≈øtitution of the temperature of the aire, where in is to be ob≈øerved what the nature of the ground is, fat, dirty, filthy, gravelly, ≈øtony, ≈øandy, whither the place be high or low, what ≈øcituation there is of mountains, and vallies, what winds it often admits, and from what climates, whether the the ≈øea, or any lakes be neere it, whether it brings forth mettalls from whence malignant aire may be exhaled.

The mountains al≈øo change the con≈øtitution of aire, Scituation of Mountaines. according as the blowings of certain windes drive away, and admit it, and if the mountains drive away the North-wind, but admit the South, it comes to pa≈ø≈øe that the places are hotter and moi≈øter, but on the contrary if by ≈øcituation of the Mountains, the blowing of the South be hindred, and the North admitted the place is colder and dryer.

Blitum, Blitum, Orach, Mallows. Orach, and Mallowes loo≈øen the belly only by humectation, they nouri≈øh little, they yeeld a watry juice, and have of them≈øelves no plea≈øing ≈øavour unle≈ø≈øe they are dre≈ø≈øed, with Butter or Oyle, and other Sawces.

A≈øparagus, A≈øparagus. Young Hops. to which the young branches or tender ≈øprigs of Hops are next like unto, neither heat, nor manife≈øtly cool, they are gratefull to the ta≈øt, and cau≈øe appetite, yet afford little nouri≈øhment, and therefore do afford not ≈øo good nouri≈øhment; they have a detergent faculty, and provoke Urine, they clean≈øe the Reines, and open ob≈øtructions of the Liver, and of the other Intralls.

Garden, Cre≈øses. Mu≈øtard≈øeed. or Water Cre≈ø≈øes, and Mu≈øtard-≈øeed may be u≈øed in≈øtead of Sawces, but not as nouri≈øhment, they are hot and dry, and of a biting ta≈øt, they attenuate crude meats, as al≈øo crude and thick humours.

Onions afford little nouri≈øhment, Onions. they are acrid and have a heating, cutting, and extenuating faculty, and inflame the blood, and together with the di≈øcu≈ø≈øed thinner parts they leave behind them a thick juice, they irritate Venus, they are all hurtfull to the head, eyes, teeth, and gumms, they cau≈øe turbulent Dreams.

In raw Garlick there is almo≈øt no nouri≈øhment, Garlick. in boyled very little, and that bad, but there is manife≈øt heat and drine≈ø≈øe in it, and a power of extenuating thick and vi≈øcide humours, and of cutting them, and taking away cold, and tis the be≈øt remedy to convert the pravity of waters, as al≈øo again≈øt the Plague, Leeks. and venemous aire: Leeks have almo≈øt the ≈øame power.

Raddi≈øh. The Roots called Raddi≈øhes which we u≈øe being dipped in
Salt affords little nouri≈øhment, but are rather in≈øtead of medicinall knacks, they heat beyond the ≈øecond degree, and have a tart ta≈øt, they cut phlegme, attenuate, provoke Urine, and expell ≈øand from the Veines.
Wild Raddi≈øhes have the ≈øame force, Wild Radi≈øh. but are more powerfull, which are fit for ≈øawce, but not of aliment.

Turnips, Rape-roots round are ≈ølowly concocted, Rape. and fill the belly with wind, e≈øpecially when they are raw, but boyled they are ea≈øier dige≈øted, and afford aliment enough, and therfore not ≈øo hurtfull, but are hot and moi≈øt.
Long Turnips are almo≈øt of the ≈øame nature, Tu ‚Ä¢ nips. but of a better ta≈øt, and yeeld le≈ø≈øe thick and flatulent juice, and afford ≈øtrong nouri≈øhment, they ≈øtimulate Venus.
Par≈øley is hot and dry, provokes Urine and cour≈øes, Par≈øley. opens ob≈øtructions, purges the Reines, and bowels, yet it afford little nouri≈øhment.
Garden Par≈ønips yeild little, hot and dry, Par≈ønips. and not very good nouri≈øhment, they cau≈øe lu≈øt, provoke Urine, and bring down cour≈øes.
Red Beets which are pickled with Vinegar, Red Beets. the ≈øeed of Carawayes, and the roots of wild Raddi≈øhes are u≈øed rather in≈øtead of Sawces, then as food, ≈øince they nouri≈øh very little.

The fruit of Plants are various; Melons. Melons are plea≈øant to the ta≈øt, and ≈øend forth an Aromatick ≈ømell, but they are of a watry moi≈øt ≈øub≈øtance, not without coldne≈ø≈øe, whereby they quench thir≈øt, and cau≈øes Urine, they clean≈øe the Reines, but they are ea≈øily corrupted, and being corrupted, become as it were of a venemous nature, and ≈øtir up choler, or generate Feavers, whereby many great men are killed, and therfore they ought to be eaten at the fir≈øt cour≈øe, that they may the ea≈øier de≈øcend through the Paunch, and after the eating of them, ≈øome food of good juice is to be taken, and good Wine is to be drank, that the corruption of them may be hindred.

Cucumbers, are al≈øo cold, but not ≈øo moi≈øt, Cucumbers and the juice not ≈øo hurtfull, nor are they ≈øo ea≈øily corrupted in the ≈øtomach, they are mo≈øt conveniently taken, before they are ripe being pickled in Vinegar, or Brine, and Pepper, and they are lea≈øt offen≈øive to tho≈øe which have hot ≈øtomachs. Artechocks

Artechocks heat and dry, to the ≈øecond degree, they are hard of concoction, and afford not very good nouri≈øhment, they are windy, and ≈øtimulate Venus, unle≈ø≈øe this be rather to be attributed to the ≈øea≈øoning, or dre≈ø≈øing of them.

Strawberies, Strawberies. are cold, and moi≈øt, they are profitable to tho≈øe that are troubled with choler in the ≈øtomach, they coole the liver, they re≈øtraine the heate of the blood and cholerick humours, they allay thir≈øt, and therefore are beneficiall in hot con≈øtitutions of bodyes, they have thin juice, purge the reines, cau≈øe urine, but are ea≈øily corrupted in the ≈øtomach, and therefore ought to be eate, the fir≈øt.

Now followes the fruits of Trees, Peares. and frutices, fir≈øt of peares there are divers kinds, nor are they all of the ≈øame faculty, the au≈øtere, and ≈øharpe are a≈øtringent, and cooling, and hurtfull to the ≈øtomach, and Guts; ≈øweete are more temperate, yet almo≈øt all are of a cold, and moi≈øt nature, only ≈øome are hot and moi≈øt. and moreover, more apt to corruption, they are not unplea≈øing to the ≈øtomach, in the fir≈øt place being taken they ≈øtop a loo≈øene≈ø≈øe, but being taken after other meate, they loo≈øen the belly, and ≈øhut the mouth of the ≈øtomach, they are better boyled, then raw.

There are divers ≈øorts of Apples which di≈øcover them≈øelves by their ta≈øte, Apples. the ≈øower are colder then the ≈øweete, and of a thinner, and le≈ø≈øe flatulent ≈øub≈øtance; the au≈øtere and ≈øharpe are yet colder, and of a thick ≈øub≈øtance, and de≈øcend more ≈ølowly through the paunch, and ≈øtay it, yet their violence is corrected by boyling; and ≈øower, au≈øtere, and ≈øharpe Apples are to be u≈øed rather in≈øtead of medicines then aliment, they all afford ill juice, but tho≈øe are mo≈øt hurtfull which are watry, and for the mo≈øt part have no ta≈øte; the be≈øt are ≈øweete ones, with an aromatick ta≈øte and ≈ømell, and ≈øuch as afford an indifferent quantity of aliment, and that not evill, they ≈øtrengthen the heart, exhilerate the minde, and are very beneficiall to tho≈øe which are troubled with Melancholy.

Quinces are cold and dry, Quinees. and have an a≈øtringent faculty, they are harder of concoction, afford little nouri≈øhment, and that thick, they ≈øtrengthen the ≈øtomach, and ≈øtop vomiting, and if they are taken after meate, they hinder Vapours ≈øo that they cannot ea≈øily a≈øcend to the head, and they loo≈øen the belly, but being taken before meales, they ≈øtop a loo≈øene≈ø≈øe; being taken raw they hurt the nerves, and often cau≈øe fits of the cholick

Peaches are cold, and moi≈øt, and are ea≈øily corrupted, Peaches. and afford little nouri≈øhment, and therefore are to be eaten ≈øparingly, and warily, and indeed before meales, not after other meates, neither is water, nor any cold drink, to be drunke after them, but wine; being dryed they are le≈ø≈øe hurtfull, and e≈øpecially being boyled in Wine, their pravity, if they had any, it is taken away.
Apricoks which are well known to the Per≈øians, Apricocks. in goodne≈øs are beyond Peaches, and more plea≈øing to the ≈øtomach, and are not ≈øo ea≈øily corrupted.

Medlers are cold and dry, Medlers. and are not eaten till they are rotten, they afford little nouri≈øhment and are ≈ølowly concocted, they ≈øtop the belly and all fluxes, they ≈øtay vomitting, and agrece well with a cholerick ≈øtomach.

Sowre Sherryes have a chooling faculty, Cherryes. are ea≈øily concocted, and de≈øcend through the belly, they coole the ≈øtomack, and liver, they quench thir≈øt, and rai≈øe an appetite, and are not ≈øo ea≈øily corrupted, nor are they of ≈øo hurtfull a juice, but the ≈øweet ones are far inferior to the ≈øharpe ones in goodne≈ø≈øe, by rea≈øon of the moi≈øture abounding, and are ea≈øly corrupted, and generated urred humours, and Wormes, in putred feavers.

There are divers kinds of Plumbs, all of them cold, Plumbs. and moi≈øt, the ≈øweet ones are not ≈øo cold by nature, yet they mitigate the acrimony of choler, and therefore agree mo≈øt with colerick per≈øons, they are ea≈øily concocted, and pa≈ø≈øe through the belly, tho≈øe that are fre≈øh, alter mo≈øt powerfully, they mollify the paunch, being taken before meate, but with their moi≈øture they ≈øcatter abroad many excrements, and that crude, neither do they generate ≈øo good juice, yet ≈øome are ≈øofterthen others, tho≈øe which abound mo≈øt with a crude and moi≈øt iuce, they are the wor≈øt, the white, and waxen colour, or yellow, are the wor≈øt, and afford ill juice, but the be≈øt are Damask Prunes, and tho≈øe which are neere≈øt to the≈øe are green, but the dry are more fit for nouri≈øhment, and afford better aliment for tho≈øe which are weaker in ≈øtomach, Plumbs are not convenient; for they loo≈øen itstone.

Mulburies moi≈øten, coole, quench thir≈øt, Mulburies. mitigare the heate of choler, they nouri≈øh little, they ea≈øily pa≈ø≈øe through the belly, but if they are retained, they ea≈øily are corrupted, and become putred, and acquire an ill nature, wherefore they are to be eaten when the ≈øtomach is empty only, and not
over≈øpred with peccant humours; that they may on a ≈øudden de≈øcend and pa≈ø≈øe through the paunch.

Figs are hot and moi≈øt, Figs. by nature they nouri≈øh more then other fruits, they ea≈øily de≈øcend and go through the belly, they have a penetrating, and ab≈øtergent faculty, yet too much u≈øe of them begets wind; dry Figs are hotter, and dryer, yet acquire a power of clean≈øeing, opening, and attenuating, yet they al≈øo loo≈øen the belly, drive humours to the externall parts, being often taken and plentifully, they cau≈øe ≈øweates, and generate blood, not very good, but ≈øuch as is apt to putrify.

Sweete grapes are hotter, Grapes. and for that rea≈øon cau≈øe thir≈øt; ≈øharpe, and au≈øtere are colder; tho≈øe that are fit to make Wine, are betwixt the≈øe extreames; tho≈øe that are fre≈øh gathered, afford little nouri≈øhment, and are flatulent, and if they are detained long in the ≈øtomach they are corrupted and dilate the belly, and ≈øtir up cholick fits, they cau≈øe the ≈øpleen to ≈øwell, and fill the ≈øtomach and liver with crude humours, and allwayes the fre≈øh gathered ≈øerve rather for plea≈øure, then for health; the au≈øtere and ≈øower Grapes, are colder, and ≈øtrengthen and bind the belly, the ≈øweete ones are hotter and afford more nouri≈øhment; tho≈øe which have a mixed ta≈øte, obtaine mixt faculties, but the ≈øweet, which participate ≈øomething of ≈øharpne≈ø≈øe, are commended before the re≈øt, they are plea≈øing to the ≈øtomach, gratefull to the liver, as al≈øo they are ≈øaid, by a certain propriety, to be advantagious to the whole ≈øub≈øtance, they are helpfull to the bre≈øts, and ≈øtrengthen all the naturall members; tho≈øe which are without ≈øtones are called Corinthian, they loo≈øen the belly more, but tho≈øe which have ≈øeed ≈øtrengthen the ≈øtomach.

Among≈øt Nuts, Almonds. the be≈øt are ≈øweet Almonds, they are temperately hot and moi≈øt, and yeelds ≈øtore of nouri≈øhment, and of good juice and moderate, they attenuate and clean≈øe, for which rea≈øon they are the be≈øt food for immaciated bodies, and they repleni≈øh the intrails, and the whole body with convenient nouri≈øhment, and ≈øuch as is not apt to corruption, they purge the bre≈øt, open the pa≈ø≈øages of urin, and cau≈øe ≈øleep, but they are not ≈øo convenient for a cholerick ≈øtomach, nor to be given in cholerick Feavers.

Walnuts are hot and dry, e≈øpecially dryed, Walnuts: for your green ones are moi≈øter, and are not ≈øo hot, and therefore are eaten ≈øafer, but the dry generate choler, and offend the Orifice of the ≈øtomach, and hurt the Gullet and Wind-pipe, and cau≈øe a cough, and generate pain in the head, commonly the u≈øe of them is commended after Fi≈øh, becau≈øe with their heat and drine≈ø≈øe they prevent the corruption of Fi≈øh.
Ha≈øle-nuts afford more nouri≈øhment, then Walnuts, Ha≈ølenuts. but they are colder, yet they are hot and dry, they are hardly dige≈øted, and afford a thick juice, more earthly then Walnuts.

Che≈øtnuts are hot and dry, Che≈øtnuts. and Galen conceives they have no ill juice, as all the re≈øt of the fruits of Trees, if they are well concocted in the ≈øtomach, yet they are harder of dige≈øtion, and are di≈øtributed more ≈ølowly, yet they afford more durable nouri≈øhment, they bind the belly, and if they are eaten in too great plenty, they cau≈øe wind.

Toad≈øtools and Muskeroms for the mo≈øt part are cold, Mu≈øheroms they yeild a watry and thick nouri≈øhment; Toad≈øtools are preferred before Mu≈øheroms: yet all of the≈øe are not to be taken without danger, becau≈øe they do not only generate ill juice, but oftentimes there is poy≈øon in them.

La≈øtly, Oyle. Oyle drawn out of ripe Olives affords nouri≈øhment temperate, and for the mo≈øt part agreeable to our nature, and can correct the pravity of other aliments, and amend the crudity of Herbes, it al≈øo mollifies and loo≈øens the belly, is takes away all ≈øharpne≈ø≈øe; it helps Ruptures, and ≈øuch as are bur≈øten, and mitigates pain.

div.head: Meates from living Creatures.
div.p: IN the ≈øecond place many living Creatures ≈øupplies us with convenient nouri≈øhment agreeable to our nature, Aliments of living Creatures. as being neerer and more familiar to our nature, and le≈ø≈øe exceed in the qualities, and afford better juice.

Either the parts of living Creatures are taken as food, or tho≈øe things which are taken from them, yet are not the parts of living Creatures, and among≈øt the latter the fir≈øt is Milk, which is of a cold and moi≈øt, or rather of a temperate and moi≈øt nature, and yeilds nouri≈øhment, the be≈øt by much if it be rightly concocted in the ≈øtomach, and be good in its ≈øelf.

There are three parts of milk, Parts of milk. the butirous, the ≈øerous, and the ca≈øeous; the butirous is of an oylely and hot ≈øub≈øtance, the ≈øerous is watry, yet having ≈øome mixture with ≈øaltne≈ø≈øe; but the ca≈øeous is cold and try, and indeed Cowes milk is the fatte≈øt and thicke≈øt, and contains more butter then the milk of other Animals, and therefore nouri≈øheth more, and is mo≈øt agreeable to us, and hath more of the ca≈øeous part then Ewes milk. Gotes milk is in the midde≈øt betwixt the≈øe. Sound Animals only generates good milk, but ≈øick generate vitious: Dry Herbs al≈øo cau≈øe the milk to be thick, but green, and ≈øuch as are full of juice makes better, wherefore the milk at the latter end of the Spring is be≈øt, for by how much the thinner it be, and more ≈øerous, by ≈øo much it is the ea≈øier concocted, and ≈øooner pa≈ø≈øeth through the belly, Be≈øt milk. Antter. and ob≈øtructs le≈ø≈øe, but it nouri≈øheth lea≈øt; the be≈øt milk therefore is that which is of a good ≈ømell, and ≈øweet to the ta≈øt, of a middle con≈øi≈øtence, neither too thick, nor to thin, nor ≈øerous, nor ca≈øeous overmuch, of a white colour, which yeilds good aliment, and that plentifully and con≈øtantly enough, e≈øpecially for lean bodies, as being that which is elaboured by ≈øo many concoctions, and is become familiar to our nature, that tis ea≈øily, truly concocted, as in unwhol≈øome bodies tis ca≈øily corrupted, in a cold ≈øtomach it ea≈øily growes ≈øowre, in a hot, it is turned into an adu≈øt ≈ømell, and choler, and cau≈øeth pain in the head, wherefore it is hurtfull to tho≈øe that are ≈øick of putred Feavers, and to ≈øuch as have paines in the head, as al≈øo to tho≈øe which are troubled with di≈øea≈øes of the eyes, or are obnoxious to breed gravell, tho≈øe that are ob≈øtructed in the Liver, and inflamed in the Hypocondries, 5. Apho. 64. but the wor≈øt corruption thereof is, when it is coagulated, which may be prevented, if any Salt, Sugar, ot Honey be added to it: It is mo≈øt conveniently taken on an empty ≈øtomach, nor are other meats to be eaten pre≈øently after, e≈øpecially the u≈øe of Wine after milk is unwhol≈øome.

As for the parts of milk, Butter is u≈øed in our Countries in≈øtead of food, and ≈øawce, tis hot and moi≈øt, and almo≈øt of the ≈øame nature with Oyle, yet it nouri≈øheth more, and is a ≈øawce for many things, tis u≈øed more advantageou≈øly then Oyle, tis plea≈øant to the ta≈øt, tis ea≈øily concocted, and nouri≈øheth much, yet it agreeth not with tho≈øe that have a moi≈øt and ≈ølippery ≈øtomach, yet tis far better to be taken before other meats, then after; nor is it ≈øo agreeable to hot natures, tis mo≈øt conveniently eaten with bread.
Sowre milk is colder, and agreeth not with colder ≈øtomachs, Sowre Milk. but with hotter, e≈øpecially in the Summer, and in very hot weather.

Chee≈øe is hardly concocted, and yeilds thick nouri≈øhment, Chee≈øe. and therefore ≈øtops the belly, opens the Pores, and affords matter fit for the generation of ≈øtones; but that which is old affords ill nouri≈øhment, the new yeilds better: the new and ≈øalt is as yet cold and moi≈øt, and of a flatulent nature, the wor≈øt is the olde≈øt, that which is of a middle age, which is neither hard nor ≈øoft, and is moderatly ≈øweat and fat, is the be≈øt, but what≈øoever it be, tis alwaies to be eaten after other meats, and ≈øparingly; but ≈øince there is great differences of Chee≈øes, according to the nature of living Creatures, and of place, and pa≈øture: That of the Ewe is the be≈øt, tis ea≈øier concocted then others, and affords better nouri≈øhment: Cowes milk is next to this in goodne≈ø≈øe, the Goates is wor≈øt of all; yet that Chee≈øe is better, when the buterous and ca≈øeous parts are not ≈øeparated, but are made altogether into Chee≈øe, but tho≈øe Chee≈øes are wor≈øe which are made of the ca≈øeous part only of the milk.

The ≈øerous part of the milk nouri≈øheth lea≈øt, Whey. and is in≈øtead of Medicine rather then aliment, yet tis mo≈øt fitly u≈øed for the evacuation of ≈øerous and adu≈øt humours; it con≈øi≈øteth of two parts, the one ≈øalt and participating of acrimony, and is altogether hot, which is the le≈ø≈øer part, the other is watry, and is the greater part, for which it is called cold and moi≈øt whey

Eggs, but e≈øpecially of Hens, are food with us; Eggs. an Egg con≈øi≈øts of two parts, the Yolk, and the White, tho≈øe are moderatly hot, and moi≈øt, and of the be≈øt nouri≈øhment; the≈øe cold and dry which afford al≈øo much nouri≈øhment, and that la≈øting enough, but hard of concoction: The newe≈øt Eggs are the be≈øt, and nouri≈øh mo≈øt, and ≈øoone≈øt, and yeild good aliment; but the ≈øtale≈øt are the wor≈øt, and the corruption of Eggs the wor≈øt: And they do not ≈øo well agree with tho≈øe who≈øe Liver or ≈øtomachs are filled with vitious humours, and in Cholerick and hot ≈øtomachs they are ea≈øily corrupted, and turned into choler; As for the dre≈ø≈øing of them, they are be≈øt when they are ≈øoft, and to be ≈øupt, beeing boyled in ≈øeething water, but tho≈øe which are roa≈øted in a≈øhes are not ≈øo good; tho≈øe that are boyled till they are hard, although they afford more ≈øolid nouri≈øhment, yet they are wor≈øe, but the wor≈øt of all are tho≈øe which are fryed in a Frying-pan, e≈øpecially in Oyle.

Honey is of a hot and dry nature, Honey. in the ≈øecond degree yet that which is white≈øt is not ≈øo hot, and is more commodious for tho≈øe that are ≈øound, but all honey is medicinall aliment, convenient for old men and tho≈øe of cold natures, but becau≈øe it ea≈øily turnes into choler, tis not fit for hot natures, nor for the Liver, but tis good for the Lungs, otherwi≈øe it hath a clean≈øing faculty, Sugar. and re≈øi≈øts putrifaction.

Sugar, although it be not taken from living Creatures, but is made out of Reeds, hath a great agreement with honey, yet tis le≈ø≈øe hot and dry then honey, and therefore tis profitably mingled both with hot and cold things, yet in tho≈øe that are very hot, it ea≈øily turnes into choler, otherwi≈øe it hath an ab≈øter≈øive faculty without ≈øharpne≈ø≈øe.

Aliments which are taken from the parts of Animals are many, Food from the parts of Animals. Feet. which both according to the kinds of living Creatures, and according to their parts do vary. The feet of Animals, of what kind ≈øoever, are cold and dry, they have little fle≈øh, and ≈øcarce any blood, they yeild a cold juice, dull and glutinous, by rea≈øon whereof the broath of boyled feet is congealed.
The Heart is of a hard and dry nature, Heart. and fibrous, neither is it ea≈øily concocted, but if it be well concocted it yeilds neither ill juice, nor a little, and that ≈øtable and firme.

The Liver it ≈øelf is hard to be concocted, Liver. and yeilds thick nouri≈øhment, which is ≈ølowly di≈øtributed, it is of good juice and firm, but there is great variety in this part, not only according to the kinds and ages of living Creatures, but al≈øo by rea≈øon of their food and full nouri≈øhment; for Animals which are not grown to their full ≈øtate, and which u≈øe better and fuller feeding, have al≈øo a greater Liver, more delicate and fuller of juice.
The Spleen affords little nouri≈øhment, Spleen. and that melancholy, tis hardly concocted, and ≈ølowly di≈øtributed.
The ≈øub≈øtance of the Lungs is light and thin, Lungs. and nouri≈øheth le≈ø≈øe, yet it is ea≈øier concocted, nor doth it afford ill nutriment.
The Reines afford not very good but thick aliment, Reines. and the Reines of younger Quadrupeds, or Calves are of better juice, and are ea≈øier concocted.
The Tongue excels the other parts in plea≈øantne≈ø≈øe of ta≈øt and goodne≈ø≈øe of aliment, Tongue. it is al≈øo ea≈øily concocted.
The brain yeilds pitutious and thick juice, Brain. and is not ea≈øily concocted, nor di≈øtributed, and cau≈øeth loathing.

The Stomach and Guts of Animals are of a harder ≈øub≈øtance, and of a colder and dryer nature, Stomach. they are harder of concoction, and not to be concocted except it be by a ≈øtrong ≈øtomach, and that they be well boyled, they yeild little blood, and that cold, and not very good.
Fle≈øh that is full of Mu≈øcles, Mu≈øculous fle≈øh. which is frequently taken in≈øtead of food, differs principally according to the kinds of living Creatures.

Swines fle≈øh nouri≈øheth very plentifully, Swines fle≈øh. and yeilds firme nutriment, and therefore is mo≈øt profitable, for tho≈øe that are in their flouri≈øhing age, ≈øound, ≈øtrong, and which are exerci≈øed with much labour, yet becau≈øe too much humidity abounds in it, it yeilds a thick and ≈ølow juice, and many excrements, it agrees not with all men, e≈øpecially with tho≈øe that are ≈øick, wherefore many other ≈øorts of meat are preferred before it.
Brawn, or the fle≈øh of tame Bores, Brawn. ≈øo that it be of younger Bores, is the be≈øt, becau≈øe it hath not ≈øo much excrementitious moi≈øture.

A Lamb before tis a year old hath moi≈øt fle≈øh, Lamb. ≈ølimy and vi≈øcid, but when tis a yeare old, tis very good nouri≈øhment, con≈øi≈øting of good and plentifull juice, and indifferent la≈øting, and ea≈øie of concoction, but in tho≈øe which are exerci≈øed with hard working, tis ea≈øie di≈øcu≈ø≈øed, and aliment that is not ≈øolid is made thereof.

But becau≈øe Lambs that are of a longer growth, Weather Mutton. become Sheep, and the fle≈øh is then become ungratefull, and not of ≈øo good juice, their ≈øtones are cut out, and they are made Weathers, the younger whereof are the be≈øt meat, and tis ea≈øily concocted, and generates good blood, and therefore agrees both with tho≈øe that are well, and tho≈øe that are ≈øick.

But Mutton of Ewes is evill, Ewe Mutton. both by default of the tempera
‚Ä¢ and by frequenting of copulation, and of bringing forth young, tis hardly concocted, evill, and dull, and vi≈øcid juice is bred thereof.
Veale is temperate, render, and affords good juice, Veale. of a plea≈øant ta≈øt, yet it yeilds ≈øomewhat a thicker juice then Lamb or Mutton.

Beef is thick fle≈øh, hard of concoction, B ‚Ä¢ e≈øe. and doth not ea≈øily pa≈ø≈øe through the Veines, it doth not participate of vi≈øcidity and ≈ølimine≈ø≈øe, the frequent u≈øe thereof cau≈øeth dry and melancholly humours in the body, e≈øpecially Cow-beef, or that of an Oxe, which with age and much working hath
contracted drine≈ø≈øe and hardne≈ø≈øe of fle≈øh, or is hardned with ≈øalt and ≈ømoak.

Goates fle≈øh affords good nouri≈øhment, Gotes-fle≈øh and may ea≈øily be preferred before the re≈øt of Sylve≈øtrous Animalls, in goodne≈ø≈øe of aliment, facility of concoction, plea≈øantne≈ø≈øe of ta≈øt, and paucity of excrements, yet they are ≈øomething drier.
Veni≈øon is hard of concoction; Veni≈øon. and generates melancholy juice, e≈øpecially if the Veni≈øon be grown to ripene≈ø≈øe of years, and doth ob≈øtruct the bowels.

Hares fle≈øh is accounted a great dainty, Haresfle≈øh. yet by Phy≈øitians tis numbred among≈øt tho≈øe aliments which yeild a melancholy juice, and therefore are not ≈øo good for tho≈øe who have dry bodies, yet if they are well concocted, they are thought to occa≈øion a good colour in the face, if they are well boyled, the juice is not evill.

There are many kinds of Birds, among≈øt the which neverthele≈ø≈øe, nay, among≈øt fle≈øh, the Hens are accounted the chief, Hens. for they are temperate, ea≈øie of concoction, of good juice, and contain few excrements, and thence they procreate good blood, and yeild mo≈øt profitable food for tho≈øe which are not much exerci≈øed with labour, yet there is a certain difference among≈øt this kind of Fowl, the be≈øt is the flesh of a Capon; the next is that of Chickins, yet their flesh is moi≈øter, Hens are dryer, the flesh of Cocks is harder and dryer, the Hens flesh affords nourishment not firme enough for tho≈øe who are day-labourers.
A Turky-cock al≈øo yeilds much and laudable nourishment, Turkiecocks. nor is it inferiour to Capons, neither in ta≈øt, or goodne≈ø≈øe of juice, it is profitable food for tho≈øe which are in health.

The flesh of Patridge is temperate, Patridges ≈øomething inclining to drine≈ø≈øe, tis ea≈øie of concoction, it affords excellent juice and much nourishment, and few excrements, and is very good food for tho≈øe that are in health, and tho≈øe that are troubled with the French Pox.

A Phe≈øant and a Quail, Phe≈øants. Quails. Pigeons. which are the be≈øt nouri≈øhment and mo≈øt excellent food for ≈øuch as are in health. There is no ≈ømall variety of Doves, the better ≈øort are tho≈øe that are of the Mountains and Woods, yet the flesh of all of them affords a thick Melancholy and excrementious juice, and is not ea≈øily concocted; and tis hurtfull in putred Feavers.

The fle≈øh of tame Gee≈øe doth abound more with excrements, then that of wild, Gee≈øe. yet the fle≈øh of them both is hard of concoction, and yeild no good juice, but vitious, and excrementitious, and ≈øuch as is ea≈øily putrifyed, but if one have a ≈øtrong ≈øtomach, and it be well concocted, it affords plenty of nouri≈øhment, but the liver of Gee≈øe that are well fatted, are temperate meate, mo≈øt plea≈øant, ea≈øey of concoction, of good juice, and much nouri≈øhment.
A Thru≈øh is ea≈øily concocted, A Thru≈øh. yeelds good juice not excrementitious, and affords nouri≈øhment firme enough.
A Lark al≈øo, generates excellent juice, A Lark. and is ea≈øily concocted, and by a peculiar faculty, it is reported not only to pre≈øerve one from the cholick, but al≈øo to cure it.
The fle≈øh of Black-birds both for plea≈øantne≈ø≈øe and facility of concoction, Blackbirds. and goodne≈ø≈øe of juice is ≈øomewhat inferior to that of the Thru≈øh.
A Quaile is hot and moi≈øt, hard of concoction, A Quaile. of ill nouri≈øhment and full of excrements, and affords matter fit for the generation of feavers.

Fi≈øhes are colder and moi≈øter food, Fi≈øh. then the fle≈øh of terre≈øtiall Animalls, and ≈øcarce afford ≈øo good juice as Corne, and fruits, and other vegetables, they ea≈øily putrify al≈øo, and if they are corrupted, they acquire a quality mo≈øt aver≈øe to our natures.

But there is a great variety of fishes, Salmon. a Salmon in the fir≈øt place, hath tender flesh, gratefull to the palate, tis ea≈øily concocted, affords good juice, and is the be≈øt among≈øt fishes; when they are pickled with ≈øalt, and hardned with ≈ømoake, they are much wor≈øe.

Troutes among≈øt fishes which are bred in fresh waters are the be≈øt, and are next in goodne≈ø≈øe to a Salmon, Trout. ea≈øy of concoction, full of much good, and thin juice, but the greater of them, have flesh not a little excrementitious, fat, and full of vi≈øcidity; tho≈øe are commended before others, which have red flesh, and many red ≈øpots, and that have hard flesh and participate not of vi≈øcidity, and fat, tho≈øe are ea≈øier concocted, de≈øcend ≈øooner, Soles. and have le≈ø≈øe excrementitious juice.
Among≈øt Sea fishes, the ≈øole is highly commended, which hath delicate flesh, and is ea≈øy of concoction. Gudgeons.

Gudgeons properly ≈øo called are the be≈øt of ta≈øte among≈øt the
fi≈øhes, and very whole≈øome aliment, ea≈øie to be concocted, and ≈øuch, as remaine not long in the ≈øtomach, and are profitable, both for plea≈øure, and health, and may ≈øafely be given to tho≈øe that are ≈øick, to which other little fi≈øh are alike, as dace and minners, and ≈øuch like.
A pick, A Pike. e≈øpecially of the ≈ømaller growth, hath hard fle≈øh, it is concocted ea≈øily, and ea≈øily di≈øtributed; and hath not many excrements, and may al≈øo be given to tho≈øe that are ≈øick.

A Perch al≈øo hath tender fle≈øh, A Perch. and ≈øuch as will ea≈øily part a≈øunder, and no fat, and glutino≈øity, tis ea≈øy to be dige≈øted, the juice is not evill, yet it affords weaker aliment, and ≈øuch as is ea≈øily di≈øcu≈ø≈øed.

A Breame hath ≈øoft and moi≈øt fle≈øh, A Breame. and yeelds a juice very excrementicious, and is to be eaten as for the mo≈øt part, all other fi≈øh are, not; tis not to be mixed with divers kinds of meates.

A Barbell, A Barbell. who≈øe egs perchance gave an occa≈øion to ≈øome to ≈øuppo≈øe, that he hears very bad, it cau≈øeth not onely paines of the belly, but al≈øo vomiting, and di≈øturbes the paunch, and ≈øtirs up choler, from the u≈øe whereof we ought to ab≈øtaine, but the fle≈øh thereof is very white, ea≈øy of concoction, and di≈øtribution; and affords aliment of good juice.

The fle≈øh of Eeles is ≈øweete but glutinous with fat, and abounding with much moi≈øture, Ecles. it generates ill juice, and the u≈øe thereof is not ≈øafely granted to tho≈øe that are ≈øick, nor to tho≈øe that are well, e≈øpecially if they be taken plentifully.

A Lampry is meate of a gratefull and delicate ta≈øte, A Lampry. if it be rightly prepared, and ≈øauced, yet it puts not away quite its ≈ølimyne≈ø≈øe, and glutino≈øity by this meanes, and for that rea≈øon they are not numbred by Phy≈øitians, among≈øt fi≈øhes of the be≈øt ≈øort.

A Tench is neither of a plea≈øeing ta≈øte, A Tench. nor ea≈øy to be concocted, nor good aliment; but yeelds a filthy ≈ølimy juice, and ≈øuch as is ea≈øily corrupted, neither is it ea≈øily di≈øtributed, and it brings forth ob≈øtructions.

A Herring hath white fle≈øh, A Herring. apt to cleave into ≈ømall peices, and hath a good ta≈øte, not hard of concoction, it affords good juice not thick, and glutinous, tis pickled with ≈øalt, and hardned with the ≈ømoake, but then tis harder of dige≈øtion, and yeelds not ≈øo good juice.
Amia a fi≈øh which hath no English name, but is like a Thunny, Amia. hath ≈øoft fle≈øh, yeelds good juice, but not much aliment.

A Sturgeon hath hard fat, and glutinous flesh, A Sturgon. which yeelds thick juice, yet not hurtfull, and tis not ea≈øily concocted, yet the younger are more ple≈øant to the ta≈øte, and ea≈øier concocted, and yeeld much nouri≈øhment.

A Sole, Plaice, and Turbet, are white fi≈øh, A Sole Plaice. Turbet. yeeld good juice, and plentifull nourishment, and ≈øuch as is not ea≈øily corrupted, but being dryed, they become harder, and are harder of concoction.

Cod-fish, Stock-fi≈øh. (or rather ≈øtock fish) although whil≈øt it is fresh tis ≈øaid to have friable flesh, and tender, of good juice, and ea≈øy of concoction, yet being dryed, it becomes ≈øo hard, that it is to be knocked with Hammers, and Clubs, and to be pulled into peeces in water before it be boyled, whence it affords thick nourishment, and hard of concoction, and is to be eaten without dammage only by tho≈øe who have very healthy ≈øtomachs, and are given to dayly labour.
Oy≈øters have a ≈øoft juice, Oy≈øters. and therefore irritare the belly to dejection, and ≈øtimulate Venus, they nourish le≈ø≈øe, and are hard of concoction, and ea≈øily generate ob≈øtructions.

Terre≈øtiall Cockels, or Snailes, Snailes. are accounted for dainties by many, yet the flesh of them is hard of concoction, and requires a healthy ≈øtomach and the addition of many ≈øawces, yet they remaine hard, and generate thick, and black blood, but that part which is ≈øaid to be given in broath for Hecticks is only in the hinder part of the ≈ønaile, which Ari≈øtotle in the fourth of the Hi≈øtory of Animals Cap. the fourth, calls Micona, that is poppey, as he plea≈øed to call it, which hath in it a certaine glutinous, and ca≈øeous ≈øub≈øtance, ea≈øily di≈ø≈øolved, yeelding to the teeth, tender, the which is not hard of concoction, and nourisheth much.

Crab fish, which have no tailes, and Lob≈øters, Lob≈øters. and crawfish which have tailes, and are frequent in our Countries, ≈øeeme to have no great difference in their nature, all of them are hard of concoction, and are not well concocted, unle≈ø≈øe by a ≈øtrong ≈øtomach, yet if they are well concocted they nourish much and beget good juice.

div.head: CHAP. IV. Of drinke.
div.p:
DRinke whereby the moi≈øt ≈øub≈øtance is re≈øtored which is dayly con≈øumed, and the naturall thir≈øt allayed, The benefi of drink. the
fat, and thick moi≈øture, carried through the narrow pa≈ø≈øages, and the meat in the ≈øtomach is mingled, concocted, and powred forth, and an inflamation of that fat, which is de≈øtinated by nature to nourish our bodies, is prohibited; there are divers kinds, The kinds. Water, Wine, ≈øtrong Beere, and water mingled with Hony, and certaine liquors made with Apples, Peares, and ≈øuch like.

There is great variety of Waters, Waters. all which are cold, and moi≈øt, but the be≈øt is that which is found to be pure and fincere, by the ≈øight, ta≈øte, and ≈ømell, and offers the ≈øavour of nothing to the ta≈øte, Differences of Waters. neither odour to the ≈ømell, which ≈øoone growes hot, and ≈øuddenly grows cold, which is light, and wherein flesh, and fruit are ≈øoon boyled: ≈øome is Fountaine water other is River, ≈øome is Raine water, other lake, or Pond water, ≈øome Marish, other Snow water.

The Fountaine is the be≈øt which hath the≈øe notes of good water, Fountain. that which ≈øpreds towards the Ea≈øt, and runs towards the ri≈øing of the Sun, and thrickles through ≈øand, and gravell, that carries no mud with it, that is hotter in Winter, and colder in Summer.

River water for the mo≈øt part is Fountaine water, River. and ari≈øeth from many Fountains flowing together, and therefore is of a mixt nature, and receives al≈øo a mixt nature from the earth through which it flowes, and ≈øomtimes al≈øo, they are mingled with Snow melted in the Mountaines, and great Showres of water collected together, yet its crudity is corrected by the beames of the Sun, whil≈øt it runs through many parts of the Earth; before the u≈øe of it, it should ≈øtand, and ≈øetle, in water-tubs, that what≈øoever it carries with it that is impure may ≈øettle in the bottome.

Rain water which falls in the Summer time with thunder is the thinne≈øt, Raine. and lighte≈øt, but ≈øince many Vapours are lift up by the heate, and mingled with the Showres, the≈øe waters are not very pure, whence they are obnoxious to putrifaction.

Well waters, Well waters. ≈øince they are not rai≈øed above the Earth, and are lifted up on high, only by the benefit of Art, they are thick and heavy, whence they continue long in the bowels and offend them.

Lakes and marish waters are the wor≈øt, Lake waters. they ea≈øily become purred, they are thick, and crude, and often times, malignant, and Pe≈øtilent, from whence the ≈øtomack is offended by them, the bowels ob≈øtructed, and humours corrupted and
often times putred, and malignant feavers and Pe≈øtilentiall do thence ari≈øe,
Waters of Snow, and Ice, are condemned, Of Snow and Ice. for they are thick and hurt the ≈øtomach, and ≈øtirr up greivous di≈øea≈øes of the joynts, nerves, and bowels.

But the malignancy of waters are corrected, by boyling, Boyling of waters. whereby not only the crudity, and frigidity is amended, but al≈øo, the terrene, and vitious parts are ≈øeparated, which afterwards when the heate vanisheth, ≈øettles in the bottome.

Wine hath a heating, Wine. and drying power which even the Spirit which is drawn out of it teacheth, yet becau≈øe it ea≈øily nourisheth, and increa≈øeth moi≈øture, and blood, fit to nourish the body, tis ≈øaid to be moi≈øt, namely Wine is a medicinall aliment, hot, and dry, ≈øome in the fir≈øt, ≈øome in the ≈øecond, and ≈øome in the third degree; for this rea≈øon, the u≈øe of it is forbidden boyes, and by rea≈øon of this drying faculty many u≈øe to mixe water therewith, yet there is not a little difference in heating, and drying, not only according to age, but al≈øo according to the nature of the Wine it ≈øelfe, for ≈øome is very little ≈øuffering, becau≈øe in mixture it will indure but little water, but other Wine is called winy Wine, becau≈øe it may indure more water to be mixt with it.

But Wines differ according to ta≈øte, ≈ømell, colour, Differences of Wines Savour. and manner of ≈øub≈øi≈øtance: as for what belongs to the ta≈øte, ≈øweet Wines properly ≈øo called, nourish be≈øt, and are not only mo≈øt gratefull to the palate, but to the bowells, but becau≈øe they are thicker, they ea≈øily produce ob≈øtructions in the Liver, and Spleen, inflame the Hipocondries, and are ea≈øily turned into choler, they are profitable for the Lungs, Chops, and Throate, nor do they ≈øo hurt the head, nor offend the nerves.

Au≈øtere or har≈øh wines have the weaker heat, tarry longer in the belly, nor doe they ea≈øily pa≈ø≈øe through the veines, and penetrate through the pa≈ø≈øages of the urine, whence they are good for a loo≈øene≈ø≈øe of the belly, but hurtfull in di≈øea≈øes of the bre≈øt and Lungs, for they detaine ≈øpittle; the be≈øt wines are the middle ≈øort which are neither very ≈øweet, nor ≈øowre.

A fragrant ≈ømell is a token of the be≈øt Wine, Smell. becau≈øe it can increa≈øe Spirits, re≈øtore decayed ≈øtrength, and recreate, and ≈øuddenly refre≈øh tho≈øe that are langui≈øhing, even by its ≈ømell, and can exhilerate the mind, and ≈øtrengthen the
whole body and all its faculties, and principally tis good for old men, only that it fills the head, and hurts the nerves, but Wines that have no ≈ømell are ba≈øe, and neither received ≈øo greedily by the ≈øtomach, nor are they ≈øo ea≈øily concocted, nor do they afford matter, nor ≈øo fit aliment to engender Spirits, nor do they add ≈øo much ≈øtrength to the heart, nor do they ≈øo much refre≈øh the body, but tho≈øe which have a ≈øtrange ≈ømell, whence≈øoever contracted, are all nought.

White or pale Wines heate le≈ø≈øe, Colour. then full and yellow Wines, and are weaker, e≈øpecially if be≈øides their whitene≈ø≈øe they are of a thin ≈øub≈øtance, all black wines are of thicker ≈øub≈øtance, and for the mo≈øt part ≈øweete and nouri≈øh very much, yet they beget thick blood, and not ≈øo laudable, they cau≈øe ob≈øtructions, and continue long in the bowels, and fill the head with many Vapours; between the white, and red, there are middle colours, yellow, reddi≈øh yellow, a pale red, and perfect red; a pale red are necre≈øt to the white, and if the ≈øub≈øtance be thin, are the be≈øt, ≈øuch as are Rheni≈øh Wines, the mo≈øt apt to ≈øtrengthen the heart, and to renew ≈øtrength; Greek Wines al≈øo ≈øtrengthen the heart, and are beneficiall to to tho≈øe that are troubled with cholick paines, and with the flatus of the ≈øtomach; red Wines for the mo≈øt part have not ≈øo great a force of heating, they generate good blood, and do not load the head, but if they are of a thicker ≈øub≈øtance, they are not ≈øo good for the Liver, and Spleen, by rea≈øon of the ob≈øtructions, which they occa≈øion; between the white, and red, is a Wine of a mixt colour, which al≈øo doth not heat ≈øo much, nor offend the head.

As for the manner of ≈øub≈øi≈øtence, The manner of ≈øub≈øi≈øtance. tenuity is in the fir≈øt place in that which is watry, hence that which is of a pale red, and yellow; cra≈ø≈øitude is in that which is black, red, ≈øweet and ≈øowre, and thin wines ea≈øily penetrate, and ≈øoon refre≈øh the ≈øtrength, they open pa≈ø≈øages, move ≈øweates and urine, yet they nouri≈øh more ≈øparingly, but the thick nouri≈øh more, and are longer detained in the parts, and heat and dry them more, and often times bring forth ob≈øtructions.

Wines al≈øo differ according to age, Differences of Wines according to age. new Wine is thick and flatuous, begets the cholick, impeads excretion of urine, yet it loo≈øens the belly, and unle≈ø≈øe it doth ≈øo, tis the more hurtfull, new Wine, and that which it as ≈øweet, as Wine new pre≈øt, is not ea≈øily di≈øtributed into the body, but old Wine does work too much upon the nerves, and offend the head.

That which is middle aged is more commodious for all u≈øes, in which thing neverthele≈ø≈øe there is a great difference according to the nature of the Wine, for ≈øome will indure age, others ≈øooner loo≈øe their ≈øtrength, and con≈øume away, and loo≈øe all their Spirits.

In places towards the Septrentrionall, Strong drinke. wherein there is not ≈øo great ≈øtore of Wine, ≈øtrong Beere, or Ale, is the familiar drinke, and indeed profitable enough, as experience ≈øhewes.

But the ≈øtrong drinke is prepared, ≈øome of Wheate, Its differences. ≈øome of Barly, others of them both, in Polonia it is made of Oates, and pre≈øerved with Hops, the manner of preparing is very different every where, the waters al≈øo differ, wherewith they are boyled, they are kept al≈øo in ≈øome places in pitched Ve≈ø≈øels, in others not pitched.

Strong drinke made of Wheate nouri≈øheth more then that of Barley, and al≈øo heats and moi≈øtens more, Drinkes made with Wheate. e≈øpecially ≈øeeing the ≈øtrong drink made of Wheate hath le≈ø≈øe Hops, then that which is made of Barly, but it generates more vi≈øcous juice, it cau≈øeth ob≈øtructions, it provokes urine, With Barly but it loo≈øens the belly.

Barly Beere, becau≈øe of the Barly, heateth le≈ø≈øe, but becau≈øe more Hops for the mo≈øt part are put into it, acquires no ≈ømall force of heating, it nouri≈øheth le≈ø≈øe, Mixt. and yeelds a thinner juice, but is more diuretick, that which is mixt of Wheate and Barly is of a middle nature.
That drink which is made of Corne, no way dried but by the heate of the Sun, hath more excrementicious humours, and often times brings forth ob≈øtructions.

All new drink is more unwhole≈øome, e≈øpecially, if it be troubled, for it ob≈øtructs the pa≈ø≈øages, and breeds the ≈øtone, but that which is more clean≈øed is whole≈øomer, but principally, ≈øtrong drinkes have their faculties, from various waters of ≈øeverall natures.

Hony and water mingled, Hydromell. for the mo≈øt part heate and dry more then Wine, e≈øpecially if Aromatick things are added, but it ea≈øily turnes into choler, by rea≈øon of the Hony and therefore is not ≈øo good a drink for cholerick per≈øons.

div.head: CHAP. V. Of the pa≈ø≈øions of the mind, and of the exerci≈øe and re≈øt of the body.
div.p: THE perturbations of the mind, Tranquility of mind. have great power in the pre≈øervation of health, for an Euthumie, or well ≈øetled mind, and ≈øuch as is at quiet doth much conduce to the pre≈øervation of health. Joy.

Next to that moderate joy is fitre≈øt to pre≈øerve the health of body, and a naturall con≈øtitution, becau≈øe it recreates the heart, ≈øpirits, and the whole body, but if it be overmuch, it di≈ø≈øipates, Exerci≈øe of body. and diffu≈øeth the Spirits.
