As to the time, Time. to eate often and much is neither commodious for the body nor mind, yet tis better to eate a little often, then much at once, but it is mo≈øt whole≈øome that a man of middle age, well tempered, and that hath government of him ≈øelfe, doe eate twice aday; ≈øo that he takes onely ≈øo much meate, as may not oppre≈ø≈øe the ≈øtomake; in other things ≈øome thing is to bee granted to Age temperatemperament,
kind of life, cu≈øtome and ≈øuch, like but the time betwixt dinner and ≈øupper ought to bee ≈øhorter then that which is betwixt ≈øupper and dinner againe.

But whether ≈øupper or dinner ought to be larger, Whether ≈øupper or dinner ought t ‚Ä¢ be large≈øt. is ≈øeverally under≈øtood among≈øt Phy≈øitians: that we may briefly conclude the matter, if any dine more ≈øparingly, and frugally, which the Ancients for the mo≈øt part did, the ≈øupper ought to be the larger, but if we ob≈øerve our cu≈øtome and manners, ≈øince men about noon day dine more plentifully, and cannot ≈øufficiently concoct their meat in that ≈øhort time, which is betwixr dinner and ≈øupper; tis altogether nece≈ø≈øary that they ≈øhould ≈øup more ≈øparingly, ≈øince tis not convenient to be twice filled with meat the ≈øame day, for then they ≈øhall have a trouble≈øome night, and in the morning perceive crudities, and principally this to be ob≈øerved by old men, becau≈øe experience te≈øtifieth, that all old men are offended with large ≈øuppers.

As for the order of meats, tis of ≈øome concernment, Order. whether wee take this or that meat in the fir≈øt or ≈øecond place; namely, tho≈øe are to be taken in the fir≈øt place, which mollifie the Paunch, and make it ≈ølippery, and tho≈øe which are not of ≈øo good juice, are ea≈øily concocted, and de≈øcend out of the Stomack, and are ea≈øily corrupted; to the≈øe are to bee added tho≈øe things which may ≈øtop the belly, they are not ≈øo ca≈øily concocted, and which de≈øcend ≈ølower, and are of better juice.

As for drink, quantit ‚Ä¢ y of drink. of the qualities and differences thereof wee have ≈øpoken before; as to the quantity, as a little of Wine, ≈øtrong Beere, and if their be any other kinds of drinkes like to the≈øe, the u≈øe of them moi≈øtens the body, cheri≈øheth the ≈øpirits, corroborates the ≈øtrength, helps concoction and di≈øtribution of meats, provokes Urine, heates the habit of the body, and is a remedy again≈øt the coldne≈ø≈øe, and dryne≈ø≈øe of old age, it cau≈øeth ≈øleep, corrects the acrimony of choler, exhilerates the mind, and makes mens manners plea≈øing; ≈øo the immoderate u≈øe thereof, and drunkenne≈ø≈øe is the Plague it ≈øelfe of health, and of a man, for by immoderate drinking, the native heat is con≈øumed, crude and perver≈øe humors are accumulated, the mind is troubled, and a kind of madne≈ø≈øe is begotten

The mo≈øt convenient time of drinking is betwixt meales Time fit to drink.
for ≈øo it conduceth much to the concoction of meate, and the right di≈øtribution of the ≈øame, but if you drink upon an empty ≈øtomack, the head and the Nerves are extended; if after meat, the concoction is thereby hindred; if the meat doe not ca≈øily de≈øcend, the concoction being perfected, tis profitable to drinke ≈øomething; drink al≈øo is to be avoided going to re≈øt, but e≈øpecially after exerci≈øes and Bathes; ≈øudden drinking of cold drink is unwhole≈øome; tis more commodious al≈øo to divide the drinke then to drinke it together, lea≈øt it cau≈øe a floating in the ≈øtomack.
The pa≈ø≈øions of the mind, Pa≈ø≈øions of the mind. all of them that are vehement are to be avoided, and on the contrary, moderate joy is to be cheri≈øhed.

Motions of the body all of them, Exerci≈øe of body. doe not agree with all, yet for all ≈øound men, deambulation may ≈øuffice, and frication and ≈øuch like exerci≈øes; otherwi≈øe to thinner bodies more moderate, to ≈øtronger greater exerci≈øes are more convenient, yet regard is here to be had of cu≈øtome, according to that of Hippocrates, 2. Apho. 49. tho≈øe which were accu≈øtomed to dayly labours, although they are weake and old, ea≈øier endure exerci≈øes then tho≈øe that are unaccu≈øtomed thereunto, although they are ≈øtrong and yong; regard al≈øo is to be had of the time of the yeare, for in ≈øummer, le≈ø≈øer and ≈øhorter exerci≈øes, in Winter greater and ≈øtronger are to be appointed; ≈øo long al≈øo onely the body is to be exerci≈øed, untill a fre≈øh colour appeare in the body, and the body begin in ≈øome mea≈øure to ≈øwell, and ≈øweat to flow out: exerci≈øe and motion is to be u≈øed when the concoction is performed in the ≈øtomack and liver, and as Hippocrates, 6. Epid. Sect. 4. Apho. the la≈øt labour ought to goe before meate, wherefore the mo≈øt convenient time for exerci≈øe is the morning, when the Stomack is empty, and the excrements of the Paunch and Bladder are fir≈øt ≈øent out, the ≈øame time is mo≈øt fit for ≈øtudy; regard is al≈øo to bee had of the place where exerci≈øes are, for exerci≈øe under the Sun heates the body very much, powers out humors, and are very obnoxious to tho≈øe who≈øe heads are weake or full of humors, but all exerci≈øes that are in the ≈øhade are ≈øafer.

Re≈øt is no le≈ø≈øe nece≈ø≈øary then motion, for this is the remedy of wearine≈ø≈øe, and repaires decayed ≈øtrength, and therefore exerci≈øe and re≈øt take their interchangeable turnes. Sleeping and waking.

The time al≈øo is to be appointed for ≈øleeping and waking, the mo≈øt fit time for ≈øleep is the night, appointed for man by God him≈øelfe, but we ought not to ≈øleep pre≈øently after meat, but an houre or two after ≈øupper, otherwi≈øe the head will be filled with many vapours; diurnall ≈øleep likewi≈øe fils the head with vapours, but if any one hath contracted a ≈øence of weari≈øomene≈ø≈øe, or hath pa≈øt an unquiet night without ≈øleep, tis lawfull to cheri≈øh ≈øleep ≈øo long in the day time, and e≈øpecially for old men, who ≈øeldome ≈øleep the whole night, but wee are to ≈øleep ≈øo long untill the meate be concocted in the Stomack and Liver, and the ≈øpirits that are taken away are re≈øtored, which ≈øpace is not equally in all, le≈ø≈øe then ≈øix houres ≈øcarce ≈øufficeth, but beyond 9. houres ≈øleepe is ≈øcarce to be extended, for the mo≈øt part the ≈øpace of ≈øeven houres is ≈øufficient.

But tho≈øe which are ≈øtudious principally offend in their ≈øleep, if they wake long after ≈øupper, Sleep for tho≈øe that are ≈øtudious. and ≈øleep after the ri≈øing of the Sun, for they do not onely pervert the order of nature, but al≈øo much hinder the concoction, whil≈øt they impeade the in≈øtauration of ≈øpirits, which were wa≈øted with diurnall labours, and watchings, and call them from the Stomack, and fill the head with vapours.

But we ought to lie downe with our legs and armes a little bent, our head ≈øomething elevated, on either ≈øide, Manner of lying. ≈øince lying ≈øupine hurts much, and fir≈øt to lie on the right ≈øide, that the concoction of the Stomack may bee helped by the Liver, not under the canopy of Heaven, nor the Beames of the Moone, and the windowes are to bee ≈øhut, and the nocturnall aire to be kept out, the bed-chamber ought to be without any ≈ømell, the bed ≈øhould bee ≈øoft, and fitted to drive away the frigidity of the Aire, when you plea≈øe, the Head al≈øo is not to be wrapt with too many cloathes.

Watchings after ≈øleep ≈øhould bee moderate, Watchings. for too much con≈øumes the native heate, and di≈ø≈øipates Spirits, dries the body, brings forth crudities, dulls the ≈øen≈øes, and of
‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ nds all the actions.

There is no ≈ømall profit al≈øo of Bathes, Bathes. for the pre≈øervation of health, as is ≈øaid before, part the fir≈øt chap. the ≈øeventh, yet the right u≈øe of them is to be appointed, neither are we to go into a Bath before the meate be concocted in the ≈øtomach, lea≈øt crud humours ≈øhould be carried into all the parts of the body. In a Bath we mu≈øt ab≈øtaine from all meat and drink, and we are to go out before we are weary, and to defend the whole body from cold, nor mu≈øt we eate nor drink before the heate of the bath be expired.

Lotions of the head open the pores of the skin and di≈øcu≈ø≈øe Vapours, Lotions of the head. yet they are not to be u≈øed when either a Catarrh, or paine of the head offendeth, but are to be u≈øed in the morning, or an houre before Supper, and after the wa≈øhing of the head it ≈øhould be throughly dryed with warme linnen cloathes. La≈øtly the wa≈øhing of the feet is not profitable, to hinder their ≈øweating, but to avert humours which would flow from the head thither.

La≈øtly we mu≈øt endeavour that pre≈øently after ≈øleep, Ex ‚Ä¢ rements. the dregs of the paunch may be ca≈øt out, if the paunch an≈øwers not to de≈øire, tis to be moi≈øtned with Rai≈øins of the Sun, the broath of a Cock, a decoction of the ≈øtaulkes of Burrage, Mallowes, Beares breech, or ≈øix or ≈øeven Pruins, boyled in the broath where Senna hath been infu≈øed, to be taken for the fir≈øt cour≈øe, or a little before meate, the excrements of the third concoction are to be expelled by dayly exerci≈øe, the head is to be combed in the morning, the mouth to be wa≈øhed with water, the eares, no≈øe, and palate to be clean≈øed, the eyes and the whole face, are to be wa≈øhed in cold water, and the body, e≈øpecially the Armes, and the Legs are to be rubbed.

And if ≈øo any error be committed in the u≈øe of the≈øe things, which may ea≈øily happen, afterwards it is to be mended the next day by its contrary, and an inequality being introduced the contrary cau≈øe is taken away.

div.head: CHAP. V. Of the dyet of old men.
div.p:
THat part of Phy≈øick which rules, Diet for old men. or governs the age of old men is called, Geronomick, but becau≈øe in old age the body every day is more and more dryed, and the native heate is con≈øumed, we are to endeavour that dryne≈ø≈øe may be
prevented, and the native heate ≈øo much as may be pre≈øerved.

Hotter and moi≈øter Aire therefore is agreeable to this age, Aire. and unle≈ø≈øe it be ≈øuch of it ≈øelfe, tis to be corrected by art, e≈øpecially in Autumne and Winter, which Aire is cheifly offen≈øive to old men.

The Aliment it ≈øelfe al≈øo ought to be hot and moi≈øt, Aliment. of good juice, and ea≈øie of concoction, but thick meates, hard, glutinous, and which fill the head, grow ≈øowre in the ≈øtomach, and are ea≈øily corrupted, are to be avoided, and if hurt be contracted by the u≈øe of ≈øuch things, tis to be corrected, by the u≈øe of Diatrion, Pipereon, Diacalaminth, and ≈øuch like.

Of the u≈øuall quantity al≈øo every day ≈øomething is to be abated, for as Hippocrates writes, 1. Apho. 10. there is little heate in old men, and therefore they need little nouri≈øhment, ≈øith thence their heat is extingui≈øhed with much; and therefore meate is to be given ≈øparingly, but often, and indeed very conveniently thrice aday, viz. break-fa≈øt, dinner, and ≈øupper.

The be≈øt drink for old men is Wine, Drink. from whence Wine is called old mens milk, yet tis not to be taken in too great plenty, and it ought to be of a hotter nature, and other things good and generous, middle aged, but thick Wines which cau≈øe ob≈øtructions, and have an a≈øtringent faculty or hinder urines, are not convenient for old men, wine mingled with hony is good for old men al≈øo.
Old men ≈øhould u≈øe moderate exerci≈øes before meate, Exerci≈øe. yet ≈øo that no la≈ø≈øitude may thence en≈øue, but principally moderate frication is commodious for them, e≈øpecially in the morning.

Old men ≈øhould ≈øleepe longer, Sleepe. and if they are troubled with waking, that remedied with the u≈øe of ≈øweet Almonds, Lettice boyled with Sugar, and dill being taken the la≈øt cour≈øe, and with Somniferous lotions of the feet and hands.
Fir≈øt of all let them avoid vehement perturbations of the mind, Perturbations of the mind. Excre. ments. and let them rather refre≈øh their minds and bodyes with hone≈øt plea≈øures.

La≈øtly let old men be carefull that they void their excrements well, and therefore, if the body be co≈øtive, the belly is to be moi≈øtned with convenient meates or with hony of Ro≈øes ≈øolutive, but ≈øtronger, and more Phyficall things are not to be given to old men.

div.head: CHAP. VI. Of the Dyet of ≈øuch as are out of temper and of neuters.
div.p: AS for what belongs to the Dyet of bodyes, Bodies that are neuters how manyfold. that are neutrals, there art two kinds of bodies deviating from perfect health, for ≈øome are more remote from a ≈øickly con≈øtitution, others are neerer to it, and the≈øe are twofold as before is ≈øpoken lib. the fir≈øt Chap. the third, neuters falling away, which governing part of the Method of the defence of health is called Prophylactick; in neuters tending to health and waxing ≈øtrong, the governing part of the Method of re≈øtoration of health is called Analyptick.

But tho≈øe former neuters which are as yet far from difea≈øed, yet decline from the be≈øt health, whether from their birth, or whether they have contracted ≈øuch a habit from cu≈øtome and dyet, it is hard to change, neither can it be done ≈øuddenly, but by degrees, and with long diligence; but if lea≈øure doth not permit, tis neither commodious, nor po≈ø≈øible, for as Galen 2. of the defence of health Chap. the third tho≈øe who are bu≈øied in civill affaires, and di≈øtracted with many bu≈øine≈ø≈øes tis ≈øafer for ≈øuch a one not to indeavour to change his temperament.

Such bodyes therefore, Dyet of untemperate men. if either lea≈øure will not permit, and their minds are not bent to reduce them into a better ≈øtate, they ought to be pre≈øerved ≈øo by their likes, but if you intend to reduce them to a better condition, you mu≈øt u≈øe contraries by degrees; yet a hot and moi≈øt di≈øtemper, ≈øince that tis more agreeable to our nature, is by no meanes to be changed, becau≈øe it introduceth no di≈øea≈øe, but bodyes which are become too dry, are alwayes to be moi≈øtned as much as may be, during the whole terme of life.

Hot bodyes therefore ≈øhould avoid hot Aire, Of ≈øuch as are hot. hot and ≈øharpe meates, their drink ought to be more plentifull, but ≈ømaler, and ≈øtrong drink rather then wine, their exerci≈øe ought to be moderate, the u≈øe of bathes, of fre≈øh waters warme, frequent; they mu≈øt ≈øhun anger, too tedious meditations, and their ≈øleepe ought to be longer.

If dryne≈ø≈øe be joyned to the heate, let them avoid the u≈øe of hot and drying things, and therefore let them beware
of a hot and dry con≈øtitution of Aire, and vehement exerci≈øes, if humidity be joyned and that be moderate, fince that temperament is mo≈øt agreeable to man, and conduceth to the prolongation of life, tis to be pre≈øerved as much as may be, and only to be fore-warned that no more of the heat and humours may be added, and cau≈øe di≈øea≈øes, and ≈øtir up putrifaction, wherefore let the≈øe avoid Aire that is too hot and moi≈øt, let meat be given which hath attenuating force, and let them endeavour that it may be well concocted, let their exerci≈øes be ≈øuch, as may di≈øcu≈ø≈øe excrements, yet not dry the ≈øolid parts; let all other things be moderate, and principally let them endeavour, that the excrements of the belly and the urine may freely pa≈ø≈øe from them.
Tho≈øe which are cold are to be nouri≈øhed with hot meates, let them u≈øe exerci≈øes, which may ≈øtir up heate, O≈øcold. let them evacuate timely the pituitous excrements.

Dry con≈øtitutions ≈øhould u≈øe moi≈øt meates, Of dry. and moi≈øtning drink, and bathes of fre≈øh water, but the mo≈øt unhappy con≈øtitution is cold and dry, which repre≈øents old age from the beginning, and ha≈øtens to it and therefore ≈øuch are to u≈øe heating and moi≈øtning things, and to be nouri≈øhed with hot and moi≈øt food, their exerci≈øes ≈øhould be moderate, ≈øuch as only ≈øtir up the naturall heate, their ≈øleepe longer and the u≈øe of bathes of fre≈øh water frequent; Venery is very hurtfull: cold and moi≈øt, if the con≈øtitution of the body be ≈øo, Moi≈øt. the frigidity is to be corrected, and the humidity pre≈øerved, to which purpo≈øe moderate exerci≈øe conduceth, and excrements if they are timely and duly evacuated.

Neuters declining; which now incline to ≈øickne≈ø≈øe, Dyet of neuters declining. di≈øea≈øes are imminent to them, e≈øpecially for two rea≈øons, Plethory, and Cacochymie, both of them therefore are to be taken away; if the falling away from health be but little, it may be done with re≈øt and ab≈øtinence; but if it be greater, opening of a veine, and purging is to be u≈øed, which is ≈øpoken of in the following book, for this Prophylactick part is placed in the end of a cure.

Only we here admoni≈øh two things, fir≈øt that the Spring-time is be≈øt for pre≈øervation; as Hippocrates 6. Apho. 47. teacheth, he ≈øayes, to tho≈øe that the breathing of a veine or purging are profitable, to them the opening of a veine, and a purgation is to be commanded,
in the Spring; it is al≈øo profitable, to purge black and Melancholy humours, before Autumne.

Moreover the u≈øe of aloes doth much conduce to the pre≈øervation of health,
∆≤≈øe of the aloes. ≈øince it gently purgeth the excrements which ≈øtick in the fir≈øt pa≈ø≈øages, which are oftentimes the cau≈øes of many di≈øea≈øes, it re≈øi≈øts putrifaction and corruption, and ≈øeldome reacheth the Liver, but becau≈øe aloes, if it comes to the Liver offends it, it is not to be u≈øed too often, and in too great plenty, lea≈øt it ≈øhould penetrate to the Liver, but it purgeth onely the fir≈øt pa≈ø≈øages, which is performed profitably, if it be taken in a ≈ømall quantity, a little before Supper.

La≈øtly, Dyet of neuters growing better. for what belongs to the dyet of tho≈øe newters that are inclinable to health, two things in the fir≈øt place are to be ob≈øerued in their dyet, fir≈øt that they fall not againe into the di≈øea≈øe; ≈øecondly that they may ≈øuddenly recover their former health: fir≈øt when, as it is 2. Apho. 12. tho≈øe things which are left in di≈øea≈øes after a cri≈øis are wont to cau≈øe relap≈øes, if ought of the peccant matter be yet remaining, that is to be taken away by degrees, and by helping, and the principall parts are to be ≈øtrengthned, but if nothing of the vitious matter be pre≈øent, the body is carefully to be refre≈øhed with moi≈øt aliment, and that which is ea≈øie to be concocted, namely the yolkes of eggs, broathes with Bread, Chickens, Hens, Capons, Fi≈øh; la≈øtly Goates fle≈øh, Mutton, Veale; ≈øleepe helps concoction, unctions ≈øtrengthen the ≈øtomach, before meate are appointed frications al≈øo, moderate walking, Baths of fre≈øh warme wa ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ r, la≈øtly ≈øtrengthening things are to be u≈øed, and ≈øuch as may re≈øi≈øt the reliques of the cau≈øes of imbecility, and of ≈øickly di≈øpo≈øition, but tho≈øe things which may call back the di≈øtemper, which trouble ≈øick, the≈øe are to be avoided.

div.head: THE FIFTH BOOK,
PART 1. Of the Materialls for Cure.
SECT. I. Of Medicines.
CHAP. I. What a Medicine is.
div.p: THere remains the la≈øt part of Phy≈øick which is the Therapeuticall, which re≈øtores men that are fallen into di≈øea≈øes to their former health, and expells tho≈øe di≈øea≈øes from mens bodyes which torment them, but that the Phy≈øitian may obtaine this end, it is nece≈ø≈øary that he be in≈øtructed in two things, fir≈øt a Method whereby he may find tho≈øe things that are helpfull by Indications, ≈øecondly In≈øtruments or Materialls for cure, whereby he may performe that which he found out by Indications.
The matter fit for cure is properly reduced to three heads, In≈øtruments of Phy≈øick. dyet, manuall operation, and making up of Medicines.

Fir≈øt you are to be admoni≈øhed that you are to di≈øtingui≈øh cures, from the materialls u≈øed in curing, for cure is that whereby in≈øtruction is given from the Indicant to performe or act ≈øomething, and is alwayes one, as to heate or make hot, but the Matter of helpe is that whereby that is performed by the Phy≈øitian which the Indicant commands,
which may be manifold, as whil≈øt you are to heat, it may be done with Pepper, Ginger, Wormewood. &c.

But ≈øince that of Dieteticall matter is ≈øpoken ≈øufficiently in the former book, it remaines that wee ≈øpeake of Medicines, Medicine what is it. and Manual operation, and fir≈øt as for Medicines, by amedicine wee under≈øtand every thing that is a different thing from nature, which may alter our bodies and reduce them to a naturall ≈øtate from a preternaturall. In which re≈øpect it differs from aliment and Poy≈øon, for Aliment, as it is aliment, is onely that which increa≈øeth the ≈øub≈øtance, or it renewes and increa≈øeth our bodies; a Medicince alters, but doth not repaire, but if any thing can together nouri≈øh and alter our bodies, tis alimentall Medicine, or medicinall aliment; but poy≈øons neither nouri≈øh, nor alter our bodies, but are de≈øtroyers of our bodies, and have power to corrupt them.

div.head: CHAP. II. Of the faculties of Medicines in generall.
div.p: MEdicines are two-fold, Medicines how manyfold. Simple Compound ≈øome are ≈øimple, other compound; a ≈øimple is that which is ≈øuch by nature onely, and hath nothing mixt with it by art; compound are when more naturall things are mingled by art into the forme of one medicine.

Simple Medicines are taken from Plants, Simple how many fold. Plants. Animalls, Mineralls; and Plants are either taken whole or their parts, Roots, Woods, Piths, Barkes, Leaves, and Branches, Flowers, Seeds, Fruits, Juices, Gumms, Ro≈øins, Oiles, and Liquors, as Wine.

Animals al≈øo are u≈øed whole, Living Creatures. or their parts, as Harts-Horn, Marrow, Fle≈øh, or tho≈øe things that are generated in them, as Milke, Eggs, or their workes, as Hony, Wax, or their excrements as Gall, Urine.

Under Mineralls are comprehended not onely tho≈øe things which are properly called Mineralls, Mineralls. Vitriall, Antimony, Sulphure, and Mettalls, and the excrements, but al≈øo divers kinds of earths, as Uermillion, Iri≈øh Slat, Bole-Arminack, as al≈øo all Stones and Gemms, al≈øo divers kinds of Salts, and concreted juices in the earth, of which Naptha is one, al≈øo bathing-waters, in which ranke Manna may be put, if there be no other place fit for it.

The faculties are various, of ≈øo many different things, The difference of Medicines Actuall. and from hence the divi≈øions of Medicines are various, for fir≈øt, ≈øome Medicines are ≈øaid to bee ≈øuch in action, others in power to be ≈øuch; things as are ≈øaid to be ≈øuch in action, which in them containe that which they are ≈øaid to be, the act being as it were pre≈øent, and ab≈øolved, and ≈øo the operation is in a readine≈ø≈øe, and can affect our bodies at the fir≈øt touch, with that quality wherewith they are endued: ≈øo Water, and Ice, are cold in action, becau≈øe after what manner ≈øoever they are applyed to a body, they can pre≈øently coole the ≈øame; but tho≈øe things are ≈øuch in potentia, Potentiall. who≈øe force is not perceived at the fir≈øt touch, but lyeth hid and as it were a≈øleep, nor doth it di≈øcover it ≈øelfe by action, untill it be ≈øome way changed by our heat and be burnt, and reduced into action, ≈øo Pepper, and Wine, although to the touch they are cold, yet neverthele≈ø≈øe they heate.

div.head: CHAP. V. Of extenuating, and preparing of humours.
div.p: OVt of this forme of humours are ≈øought digerent, Of clean≈øing and preparing. dige≈øtive, or preparing things; ≈øo called, all which, ≈øince they hinder nature in acting, take away and change the qualities, which re≈øi≈øt the action of native heat, namely they coole too much tho≈øe things that are hot, and heate too much tho≈øe things that are two cold; they moi≈øten dry things, and dry up moi≈øt things, they attenuate what is thick, and incra≈ø≈øate what is thin.

Namely yellow choler is to bee corrected with cooling, Cholers. moi≈øtning and thickning things, Phleagme is to be prepared with heating, drying and attenuating things; melancholy humors are to bee corrected with things moderately heating, moi≈øtning and attenuating; black Choler is to be prepared with things that are very moi≈øtning & attenuating.

div.head: CHAP XI. Of Medicines purging through the Paunch.
div.p: IN the fir≈øt ranck of Medicines, Purging. namly of tho≈øe things which con≈øi≈øt in the ablation of any thing, and are fir≈øt called Purgers, but although all Medicines in generall which free any parts of the body from excrements may be called, purging medicines, yet u≈øe hath brought it to pa≈ø≈øe that they are only called purging medicines in particular which lead or drive out excrements through the paunch or by Vomit; tho≈øe which move by the belly and are wont to be known by the common name of Evacuators, are twofold; ≈øome of them are ≈øuch as only purge the belly and the fir≈øt pa≈ø≈øages, others there are which reach beyond the fir≈øt Region of the body and emit peccant humours from the more remote parts, which are more properly called purging medicines.

But the purging medicines are mo≈øt properly ≈øo called which ≈øend forth ≈øome particular humour out of the body, Things purging. from ≈øome particular part, but by what power they performe, that is much controverted by Phy≈øitians, but it ≈øeemes probable, that purging medicines, whither taken in at the mouth, or by Cli≈øter, or externally applyed to the Navell or belly, or held in the hands or applyed to the Buttocks are re≈øolved and deduced into action by the heate of our bodyes, and that the mo≈øt ≈øubtill ≈øpirits, or vapours of them ≈øo re≈øolved are di≈øper≈øed through ve≈ø≈øels into the whole body, and by a hidden force and propriety, move the humours which have affinity with them, and trouble, ≈øtir up, and as it were ferment them, and do ≈øo bring it to pa≈ø≈øe, that tho≈øe humors, which before were mixed with the blood, and cau≈øed no di≈øturbance of nature, being now ≈øtirred up and ≈øeperated from them, and being by them≈øelves, ≈øtimulate nature and irritate it to expul≈øion, which being irritated by the helpe of the expul≈øive faculty, expells both the purging medicine, and the vitious humor ≈øo ≈øeperated by the power thereof, together from the body.

But ≈øome of them are more mild which mollify the belley, More mild. yet be≈øides this, by a propriety of ≈øub≈øtance, regard a peculiar humour, and exerci≈øe their ≈øtrength beyond the fir≈øt wayes, to the Liver and Spleen, yet cannot evacuate from the whole, and the mo≈øt remote parts, ≈øome are ≈øtronger, which evacuate beyond the liver and ≈øpleen, al≈øo greater ve≈ø≈øells, but the ≈øtronge≈øt purges are tho≈øe which evacuate humours out of the whole body, Stronger. and from the mo≈øt remote parts, and from the ≈ømalle≈øt veines; there are divers purging medicines, yet the difference of them is drawn, from the number of humours, which they attract by a ≈øpecifique force.

div.p:
THe convenient placing of a part that is bound con≈øi≈øts in this, that it may have that po≈øition, which may pre≈øerve its naturall figure, and may be without paine, and may be convenient for the cure of a di≈øea≈øe. A member ≈øhall be ≈øo
placed if all its parts, bones, mu≈øcles, nerves, veines, and arteries, may enjoy that po≈øition whereby they neither are di≈øtended, nor pre≈ø≈øed; if the member be ≈øet or placed ≈øoftly, and equally; if the orifice in a hallow ulcer, or wound, tend downeward as much as may be, that the quitture may be purged out; la≈øtly if moderation be ob≈øerved in ordering of the binding ≈øo that it be neither too ≈øtraight nor too loo≈øe.

But collocation is made either by putting in, or by ≈øu≈øpending; a member is fitly re≈øtored, when tis underpropt with certaine ≈øtayes, with feathers, wooll, or ≈øoft rags, that it may be quiet and leaning or re≈øting on ≈øomewhat, it ≈øhould lye allwayes even, and ≈øoft, lea≈øt it either ≈øhould be ≈øhaken by motion, or extended by rea≈øon of flux, or lea≈øt the ≈øanies and thin matter ≈øhould be retained in it: the member is ≈øu≈øpended, either when the ≈øick keepes his bed, or newly begins to walke, and e≈øpecially the hand, and the arme are to be kept in a Swath, which Cel≈øus calls, Mitellam.

div.head: CHAP III. Of Coaptation of broken bones.
div.p: Synthe≈øis, which joynes together ≈øeperated parts, is either of bones, Setting how manyfold. or of fle≈øhy and ≈øoft parts, ≈øetting together bones is either a fitting tho≈øe that are broken, or a re≈øtoring tho≈øe which were out of joynt.

The putting together of broken bones, is performed by two operations, Of broken bones. whereof the one is called Cata≈øta≈øis, Antita≈øis, or exten≈øion; the other is called Diortho≈øis conformation, or tis called repo≈øition of the bones, into their owne places; exten≈øion is either equall, or unequall, equall is that wherein the member is equally extended from either ≈øide of the broken bone, but that is ≈øaid to be unequall, when the member is more extended on one ≈øide; that ≈øide ought to be more extended, wherein the broken bone is contained but no man can rightly performe tho≈øe operations, Exten≈øion. unle≈ø≈øe he knoweth the nature, and differences of bones and fractures, for when a mu≈øcle is drawn back to its head, and ≈øo carries with it that part of the member which is joyned to it, fir≈øt there is need of extending, which the Greekes call Antita≈øis, which ought to be done, as neere as may be, with little or no paine, and that is performed by one worke, or more, and that either with the hands only, or raynes as it
were ≈øwathings, or in≈øtruments, according as the bone is more or le≈ø≈øe broken.

Diortho≈øis, or conformation, Strengthning. is a re≈øtitution of a broken bone into its place, and a right fitting of the extremities of the broken bone, which is performed if after the member be ≈øo much extended, that in putting it back the bones cannot touch one another, the Chyrurgeon is to take hold of the member on both ≈øides, with both his hands, and that which is ≈ølid into the right part he ≈øhould thru≈øt into the left, and the contrary, and what ever hangs out of the bones, he ≈øhould put back into their owne cavities, untill the extremities of the bone are rightly united, and thru≈øt back, into their places, and the member hath recovered its naturall figure. The cure of a fracture with a wound.

But if the extremities of the broken bones, breake through the skin, that they hang out, ≈øome convenient in≈øtrument of Iron, like a barr, is to be u≈øed, to force the broken bones into their place, but if any particle of a bone ≈øo hang out, that it cannot ea≈øily be put into its place, it is to be cut off with a ≈øharp paire of ci≈ø≈øars, or to be filed off with a file, that it may be ≈øhorter, neither let it any more hinder the repo≈øition: in ≈øuch a fracture which is joyned with a wound, if any thing ≈øtick betwixt the broken bones, which may impede their glutination, whither particles of a bone, or any thing what≈øoever, it is to be taken away without violence; when the bones are rightly placed, the exten≈øion is to be remitted by degrees, and with convenient binding and placing of the member, and ≈øo to be performed, that the bones united and rightly framed may remaine ≈øo.

Yet before ≈øwathing-bands are put about a broken member ≈øome medicines u≈øed to be applyed, to hinder the Flux of humours and inflamation, and to farther the generation of brawny fle≈øh, of which, read the In≈øtitutions.

The deligation is to be performed, Manner of ≈øwathing or deligation. neither too ≈øtraight nor too loo≈øe, with two ≈øwathing-bands, whereof the fir≈øt is to begin above the fracture, and to be bound about it, twice or thrice upwards; the other, being longer by halfe, is to be rolled about the contrary way, and is to be put on fir≈øt upon the fracture, and beginning from thence to be rolled about ≈øomething downeward and againe is to be carried above the fracture, and la≈øtly towards
the ≈øuperior ≈øound part, but in fractures of great bones, that the deligation may be the more ≈øtable, and the bones firmely put into their places, may remaine ≈øo, Bol≈øters or cro≈ø≈øe folded cloathes, and ≈øplentors, and Plates, are al≈øo to be u≈øed, moreover the member is rightly to be placed, gently, equally, and inclining upwards, ≈øo that the part may obtaine its naturall po≈øition, to which purpo≈øe, both a hollow Pipe, and Cane, or Plate, or ≈øuch like, are ≈øometimes to be applyed, the deligation being well performed, is to be loo≈øned the third day, the fracture to be clean≈øed, and bound up againe, and this is to be continued untill hard fle≈øh be grown, and the fracture healed, but if a fracture be joyned with a wound, after the exten≈øion is abated, and there is convenient conformation of the broken bones, the lips of the wound are to be drawne together, and being drawn, to be kept together, yet ≈øo that the ≈øwath-bands be not too ≈øtraight bound, which ought to be flacker, and to be extended on both ≈øides, beyond the lips of the wound, lea≈øt paine ≈øhould be ≈øtirred up, but in the following deligations, a hole, or vent, may be cut above the wound, both through the Plai≈øters, and ≈øwathing bands, that it may be perfectly cured.

div.head: CHAP IV. Of re≈øtoring of bones that are out of joynt.
div.p: Synthe≈øis which puts bones ≈ølid out of their places into them again, calle this Arthrembla, this is performed three wayes, either with the hands of the Chyrurgeon which is convenient in tender bodyes, and when the hurt is newly done, or with certaine common in≈øtruments, as by the helpe of raynes, ≈øwathing-bands, Laqueorum, ≈øcalarum, ≈øedilium, forium bifidarum, and it is convenient for children, Women, and tho≈øe who≈øe mu≈øcles are grown ≈øtronger, and luxations have been longer, or by in≈øtruments, certaine Engines, peculiar for that purpo≈øe, is performed, and are u≈øed for ≈øtrong bodyes, and old luxations, and altogether on tho≈øe, which cannot be re≈øtored by the two former wayes, of ≈øuch Engines, you may ≈øee Hippocrates, of joynts and fractures, and Oriba≈øius of Engines intititled, de machinis.

But after what manner ≈øoever, re≈øtitution of a boneout of joynt is performed, foure operations are nece≈ø≈øary to doe, it
fir≈øt Exten≈øion, Repo≈øition, Deligation, and Confirmation, What things are required for the ≈øetting of bones. and Collocation, of the members ≈øo replaced.
Exten≈øion, is made, either by the hands of the Chyrurgeon, or his Servants, or by raynes, bindings and ≈øwathings, or In≈øtruments, and Engines, as is ≈øaid.

Exten≈øion being made, the bone which is ≈ølid out of its place is to be put into it againe, which worke the Greekes call, Moclia, and Mocleu≈øes, Repo≈øition. namely a compul≈øion of a bone that is out of joynt and extended into its owne place, which being ≈ølid from or out of the end, in the ≈øame way which the joynt ≈ølid, it ought to be put back to that place out of which it ≈ølid, whereof there are ≈øo many wayes as there are joynts.

The joynt being re≈øtored, the intention is to be remitted and the member afterwards, ≈øo to be ≈øtrengthned that the joynt cannot againe goe out of its place, Deligation. which for the mo≈øt part is performed in the ≈øame manner as in fractures.
La≈øtly the member is to be placed gently, and equally, and to be kept unmoved till the fourth or ≈øeventh day. Collocation.

div.head: CHAP. V. Of the putting together of the ≈øoft and fle≈øhy parts.
div.p: THe fle≈øhy and ≈øoft parts, disjoyned, Setting of ≈øoft parts. preternaturally are joyned together, either without any divi≈øion of them, or by ≈øolution of their continuity, that putting together, which is performed without any divi≈øion of parts is various, and of different parts, and fir≈øt of all ≈øometimes certaine parts being ≈ølid out of their places, come to be put into their naturall place againe, ≈øuch are the guts, and paunch, which ≈øometimes by the wounds of the paunch come out, ≈øometimes the Rim of the belly being loo≈øned, or broken, falls into the groine, and cods, or breake out at the navell, hitherto belongs the wombe, and gut Rectum, which ≈øometimes al≈øo fall out of their places, and therefore all the≈øe are to be put into their places againe, but how the re≈øtoring of each ≈øingular part ought to be performed, is ≈øpoken in our In≈øtitutions, and 3 d. Book of praxis.

Moreover, Wounds, how ≈øet. for what belongs to the manner of joyning together, wounded parts, without divi≈øion, the lips of the wounds, ≈øince they are di≈øjoyned, are to be brought and joyned together, and when they are brought, being joyned are to be kept together, which may be done too wayes without ≈øolution of continuity, either
by ≈øwathing, or gluing, or a ≈øuture with the Glue, and indeed as for ≈øwathing that is convenient being made for Wounds according to the length of the member, Swathing. and not very deep, and when we hope by fa≈øciation only, the lips may be joyned. A future is not ra≈øhly to be appointed, and indeed if the wound be long, narrow, and ≈øtraight, ≈øwathing is better, that is, deligation of three fingers breadth is enough. The manner of fa≈øciation may be ≈øeen in the In≈øtitutions.

But when in tran≈øver≈øe and long wounds, A ≈øuture by glue. ≈øa≈øciation alone is not ≈øufficient to draw and continue the lips of the wound together, there is need of a ≈øuture; but when in wounds of the face prickings cau≈øe deformities, and in other long and great wounds before the glutination of the wound the ≈øutures are broke; render bodies al≈øo cannot indure a ≈øeam which is made with a needle, a certain lutination or ≈øuture is invented by glue, by which without any divi≈øion of the wounded part, or ≈øtitching with a needle, the lips of the wound are drawn together. Provi≈øion to perform this may be ≈øeen in the In≈øtitutions.

But that conjunction of wounded parts which is made by ≈øolution of continuity is performed with a ≈øuture and pipes to the ≈øuture, A ≈øuture by a needle. three In≈øtruments are to be u≈øed, the Needle mu≈øt be triangular and thred ≈øtrong, lea≈øt it ≈øhould be broken, not too hard, but ≈øoftned with Wax, equall, or even, the Pipe ought to be Gold mixt with Copper, or Silver, with a hole in the end that the Needle may pa≈ø≈øe through the hole, and the Pipe holding it, and being put to i ‚Ä¢ , it may ≈øtay the lips of the wound, lea≈øt whil≈øt the needle is put to it it ≈øhould be ≈øtirred, neither ≈øhould it be lengthned to the protraction of the thred and needle: the manner of the ≈øuture is two-fold, the one is that which is performed in the ≈øame manner as Skinners or Furriers u≈øe to ≈øow their skins, being fitted for wounded guts; the other is thus, in the middle of the wound, with a Needle drawing a double thred, the lips of the wound are tied, and a knot being made, the thred a little above the knot, is to be cut off: Moreover in the middle ≈øpace on both ≈øides another hole is to be pricked with a double thred, and a knot being made in the like manner, tis to be cut off, and that is to be continued till the lips of the wound be rightly ≈øowne together, and brought to mutuall contract. Fibulae.

There is mention al≈øo among≈øt the ancients of a Pipe,
but what it was for the mo≈øt part is unknown at this day, ≈øince it is incredible that tho≈øe iron hooks ≈øhould be fixed to the skin, ≈øince that would have cau≈øed intollerable pain, the opinion of Gabriel Fallopius is more probable, who teacheth that pipe to be that ≈øuture newly de≈øcribed, which is called Interci≈øa, and at this day is mo≈øt frequent, which is drawn with a needle drawing a double thred through both the lips of the wound, and above the wound, with three involutions, both the ends of the thred are tied together and knit into a knot. But the word Fibula ≈øignifies every In≈øtrument that joyneth things together. And thus much of the Chyrurgicall operation which is of putting or joyning together.

div.head: CHAP. VI. Of correcting of Bones that are repre≈øt or ≈øet awry.
div.p: THe other Chyrurgicall operation is Diortho≈øis, or the putting right, a correcting of bones put awry, or writhen; The Skull if it be depre≈øt, which often happens in Children, is to be reduced into its naturall condition and place, either with Cupping-gla≈ø≈øes, the haire being ≈øhaved with a great flame put to them, and the mouth and no≈øtrils being ≈øhut, the Patient by expiration, together with a violent ≈øtriving, by putting Cucurbita Cornea, out of which the mouth and no≈øtrills of the ≈øick being ≈øhut, a ≈øtrong man may ≈øuck up aire, or with ≈øome Plai≈øter ≈øticking very fa≈øt to the skin, which is to be applied, and when it cleaves very fa≈øt then to twich it up, or with an elevating Augur, or trepan, or by performation and elevation of the Skull.

The bones of the no≈øe being broken or brui≈øed, Of the no≈øe are to be drawn back by the finger, or a Specillum put into the no≈øtrill, and without are to be directed and put into frame by the hand, and afterwards a tent is to be put into the hollow of the no≈øe or no≈øtrill.

A member being contracted fir≈øt it is to be ≈øoftned, Directing of contracted members. afterwards either gently to be bowed, or with an In≈øtrument fit for that purpo≈øe it is tenderly and by degrees to be drawn in, or ≈øtretched out.

The Legs or Armes in Infants being awry, Direction of crooked Legs or Armes. the be≈øt way of directing them is, that they may be reduced by handling and directing them gently with the hands and by degrees, and with ≈øwathings drawing them the contrary way to that which they are in, and by rolling the ≈øwath-band by little and little they may be reduced into their naturall and due figure, but if the ≈øwathing be not ≈øtrong enough, and that the child de≈øire to goe, little bootes like bagging ≈øhooes in that manner as Paraeus hath de≈øcribed them in his twentyeth book of Chyrurgery, Chap. the eleventh, are to be fitted to his Legs; and thus much of the ≈øecond operation of Chyrurgery.

div.head: CHAP. VII. Of disjunction in generall, and of di≈ø≈øection of ≈øoft parts.
div.p: THe third operation of Chyrurgery is disjunction, The kindes of divi≈øion. which devides tho≈øe parts of the body which are joyned and continued together, of the fir≈øt of the≈øe there are two kindes, Section, and U≈øtion; Section, ≈øome is of ≈øoft ≈øome of hard parts; and of ≈øoft parts according as it is made by cutting or pricking, in particular it is called, Tome, or cutting, or Paracente≈øis, pricking; of the bones and hard parts there is perforation or boaring with a wimble, ≈øhaving, filing, ≈øawing; la≈øtly U≈øtion is common both to hard and ≈øoft parts, all which operations are now to be explayned in their ≈øeverall kindes.

In cutting ≈øoft parts, Opening of a veine. fir≈øt comes the opening of a veine, which is appointed for emi≈ø≈øion of blood out of the body, in divers parts of the body, the provi≈øion and convenient preparations for that purpo≈øe may be ≈øeen in the in≈øtitutions.

Moreover ≈øince that ≈øometimes the matter in tumours ≈øhould be changed into quitture, Opening of impo≈øthumes. nor doth an impo≈øthumation, allwayes breake of its owne accord, and it is to be doubted lea≈øt the purulent matter retained ≈øhould offend the neighbouring parts, and bring rottenne≈ø≈øe to the bones, ≈øometimes al≈øo there is venemous matter, and affects the way to the internall parts, or an impo≈øthumation or Ulcer neere a principle part, or joynts, may ≈øtop the fundament, oftentimes an Ulcer or impo≈øthume full of matteris to be opened with an In≈øtrument, or by which opening ought to be ≈øo performed
as that the adjacent veines, arteries and nerves may not be offended; the Sanies either is included in a bladder, or el≈øe hath no bladder; if the quitture be not included in a bladder, let that part be wounded that the tumour may come to its height, and the skin is very thin, yet as neere as may be doe it in a declining part; the In≈øtruments fit for cutting are, variety of Inci≈øion knifes, according to the variety of figures, and nece≈ø≈øity of their u≈øe, the bigne≈ø≈øe of the cut is to an≈øwer to the quantity and the quality of the matter to be emitted, an inci≈øion being made, and the matter in ≈øome part evacuated, lea≈øt the wound before the whole matter be let out ≈øhould clo≈øe up againe, tents are to be put in, nay if neede be, the wound mu≈øt be dilated, and the part ≈øo bound up and placed, that the quitture may conveniently flow forth, but if the purulent matter be inclo≈øed in a bag, the tumour according to its longitude if it be le≈ø≈øe or cut athwart like, the letter X; if it be greater and the whole bagg with the matter in it, tis to be taken out and nothing of it to be left behind.

Thirdly Fi≈øtulaes al≈øo are often to be cut, The cutting of a fi≈øtula. which is done with a fit In≈øtrument, which therefore the Greeks call Syringotomon that is a Pipe cutter, the manner of cutting may be ≈øeen in the In≈øtitutions.

Fourthly parts al≈øo are ≈øometimes to be ≈øeparated which are joyned together from ones birth, after ones birth, Seperation of parts that are joyned together preternaturally. whereunto belongs the cutting of the tongue when it is tyed, of eares when they are ≈øhut, of the fundament when it is clo≈øed, the opening of the private part of a female, the freeing of the prepucium when tis ≈øtraightned, a ≈øeperation of it from the glans, the opening of the top of the yard, or glans when tis clo≈øed, ≈øeparation of fingers growing together, the opening of the eye lids when they grow together, all which may be performed by cutting by a skilfull Chyrurgeon, and how it ≈øhall be performed, ≈øhall be explained in the In≈øtitutions.

Fifthly hitherto belongs ≈øcarrification, Scarification. which is performed with an inci≈øion knife, or launce, and ≈øo that the skin may be opened only with gentle cuttings, or to wound it deeper, and that the more ready evacuation of blood may follow, cupping gla≈ø≈øes for the mo≈øt part with a burning flame are to be applyed, which may attract the humours more potently, yet ≈øometimes ≈øcarrification is appointed without cupping gla≈ø≈øes, ≈øuch as that of Mallets which was in u≈øe among≈øt
the Ancients, and the ≈øcarrification, in u≈øe with the Aegyptians this day.

Sixtly, Cutting of ve≈ø≈øells. Angeiologia ≈øo called in particular, which is a cutting of the ve≈ø≈øells in the forehead, in the Megrim, and an inveterate Opthalmy, and when there is a perpetuall weeping of the eyes, whereby a ve≈ø≈øell, freed from the neighboring parts, is tyed with a threed on both ≈øides, and afterwards in the middle betwixt the two threeds it is to be cut tran≈øver≈øe according as the manner of operations is delivered in the In≈øtitutions.

To the cutting of ve≈ø≈øells belong the cutting of the varices,
Cutting of the varices. which was done by the Ancients, almo≈øt in the ≈øame manner as the cutting of the other ve≈ø≈øells la≈øtly propounded, as you may ≈øee out of Cel≈øus the 18. Book Chap. the 13. Paulus Aegineta the 6. Book the 82. Chap. Hier. Fabricius hath another manner of Chyrurgicall operation, Tit. of Chyrurgery of the ve≈ø≈øells called varices, namely ≈øuch a one, the In≈øtrument Volcella (which is to pluck up haire by the Roote) bowed or lifted up fir≈øt with a hooke, he prick; the varices in many places, afterwards he puts to it a binding medicine repre≈øenting the figure of a candle, according to length of it, and upon this he puts the barke of a hollow reed or Cane,

To Angeiologie al≈øo may be referred that cutting of an Aneuri≈øme,
Cutting of an Ancuri≈øme. out of Paulus Aegineta, 6. Book, 37. Chap. and 64. Chap. which may there be ≈øeen, which neverthele≈ø≈øe is ≈øcarce to be attempted unle≈ø≈øe the Aneuri≈øme be very ≈ømall, and in an ignoble part, not having any great ve≈ø≈øells, ≈øince without great danger it cannot be performed.

Seaventhly, Paracente≈øis. to Seperation or Section, belongs Paracente≈øis by which word every pricking in generall was denoted by the Ancients, and tis performed in divers parts, and that either with a needle or with the point of a knife, this operation is famous and Ancient, in the paunch, to evacuate water of tho≈øe that have drop≈øies, which retaines the name of the generall name, the manner and rea≈øon of performing whereof in the In≈øtitutions and in the 3. Booke of Practi≈øe part the 6 th. ≈øec. the 2 d. Chap. 3. is delivered; in water of the head the ≈øame pricking is ≈øometimes u≈øed in the skin of the head, and in the cods filled with water.
Hereunto belongs the cure of a Cataract by pricking which is ≈øo to be performed as Cel≈øus al≈øo de≈øcribes in his 7. Couching of a Cataract. Book and 7. Chap.

As al≈øo the cutting of the wind-pipe, Laryngotome. which is called Laryngotome, which when it is nece≈ø≈øary is to be performed with a launce, (the other parts being removed, under the Larynx betwixt the third and fourth ring of the Wind-pipe, the manner of operation is propounded in the In≈øtitutions.

As al≈øo the cutting of the bre≈øt, in an Empyema, An inci≈øion of the bre≈øt. or an Ulcer or impo≈øthume, in the cavity of the bre≈øt, which is performed on one ≈øide of the bre≈øt, betwixt the fift, and ≈øixt rib, and how it al≈øo is to be performed is explained in the In≈øtitutions.

Moreover a Seton, Applying of a Seton. or u≈øing of a Seton Needle by which operation the neck is prickt, and the wound kept open, that peccant humours may be evacuated by it, of which operation you may al≈øo read in the In≈øtitutions.

To prickings, we have annexed leaches, Leaches. or the application of leaches, which being cho≈øen, prepared, and clean≈øed, are applyed with a rag, or a reed; by their biting they open the veines and draw out blood, and indeed from the ≈øubcutaneous parts only, and capillary veines, if they are applyed only to the skin, but if they are applyed to any great ve≈ø≈øell, they draw blood from the innermo≈øt parts of the whole body, and therefore they are applyed according as there is need of this or that evacuation, and are applyed to children when we dare not u≈øe the launce to open veines. To the veines of their armes when they are affected with any greivous di≈øea≈øe that requires evacuacion of blood.

div.head: CHAP VIII. Of Section of Bones.
div.p: BUt that cutting which is performed in hard parts or bones is fourefold, according to the various manner of ≈øeperation, and variety of in≈øtruments, namely ≈øhaving, filing perforation, and ≈øawing.

Fir≈øt ≈øhaving is a plaining and a making ≈ømooth of the inequality of bones with an inci≈øion knife ≈øhaving them, Shaving. or a detraction and taking away of the filth clinging fa≈øt to the bones, and it is performed with files, in magnitude and figure, according to the ≈øeverall natures of di≈øea≈øes and of bones; either ≈øtraight, ≈øuch as are hammers which they u≈øe in driving, or bent in the end ≈øuch as they u≈øe in drawing, ≈øometimes they u≈øe both a file, and a Hammer wrapt in a clout.
Secondly filing, Filing. or wearing away of bones with a file, it u≈øefull in the teeth when they hang out contrary to nature.

The third is perforation whereby we cut the part out of the middle of a bone, Perforating. either with a Trepan or with a file, or together with a Trepan and a file; the perforation which is made by a Trepan, the Greekes call, Trupe≈øis, a wimble they call Trupanon, Kinds of Trepans or Wimbles. and Trupane; but a Trepan is either ≈øtraight and ≈øharpe, and in a hollowed circle, which is called a wimble in particular, or it is hollow which is called, Modiclus; Trepan is like to common wimbles which Carpenters u≈øe, and tis twofold, the one is that which an≈øwers plainly to the wimbles of Carpenters; the other, which neere the point at ≈øuch a di≈øtance as the thickne≈ø≈øe of the skull is of, hath a knot without, or a circle fitted, which whil≈øt the Trepan is within the skull, hinders it that it cannot goe deeper then is fit, which kind of Trepan, becau≈øe it cannot goe deeper, the Greekes call Trupanon, or Abapti≈øton; Modiolus the Greeks call, Cointhion, and Coinichis, and Prion Caractos, tis a hollow In≈øtrument of Iron, round and long like a Pillar, at the bottome of the mouth like a ≈øaw, or full of teeth, and ≈øtraight Trepans, which are called Periteria, are oppo≈øed to it, which are turned about with a handle, which if it have a naile (or pin) in the middle tis called male, and if it have not is called female, but the perforation or boaring is performed principally when the skull is broke, or when ≈øome matter, or blood is contained within the skull, the manner of which operation may be ≈øeen in the In≈øtitutions, ≈øometimes al≈øo in rotten bones when the rottenne≈ø≈øe goes deep.

La≈øtly by ≈øawing, Sawing, or cutting with a ≈øaw, bones are divided, when any dead part, the fle≈øh being fir≈øt cut away with a knife to the bone, and the bone is laid open, or when ≈øome broken bone hangs our, and cannot be put back into it place, or when any chinke is to be filled up, or when the table of the skull is to be taken away.

div.head: CHAP. IX. Of Burning.
div.p: THe la≈øt kind of ≈øeperation remaines, Burning. which is burning, which is to be u≈øed when di≈øea≈øes cannot be taken away by medicines, nor cutting; burning is performed two wayes, Burning twofold. either by tho≈øe things which actually have in them fire, and a fiery quality as Iron, or other fiery In≈øtruments made of Gold, Silver, Bra≈ø≈øe, which are called actuall Cauteries, or with burning medicines, which are called potentiall Cauteries.

There are ≈øome differences of actuall Cauteries, e≈øpecially, An actuall Cautery. in re≈øpect of matter and figure, and differing al≈øo ≈øome other wayes; as for matter, Metallick In≈øtruments prepared of Iron, Bra≈ø≈øe, Silver, Gold, are in u≈øe this day, Iron burnes potently, Bra≈ø≈øe and Gold not ≈øo violently, the figures of Cauteries are various, which are de≈øcribed every where, ≈øometimes they are fiered more, ≈øometimes le≈ø≈øe, ≈øometimes impre≈ø≈øed deeper, ≈øometimes ≈øuperficially only, the manner of burning is to be ≈øeen in the In≈øtitutions,

Another manner of burning is that which is performed by potentiall Cauteries, Potentiall. what Cau≈øtick medicines are, and E≈øcaroticks, is ≈øpoken above, part the 1. ≈øect the 1. Chap the 10 th. and in what manner Cauteries are to be prepared ≈øhall be ≈øhewne in the end of this Book.

Fontanells, I≈ø≈øues. and I≈ø≈øues are made by actuall and potentiall Cauteries, namely little Ulcers, prepared to evacuate, draw back, and drive humours through them, but in what parts, and how the≈øe Fontanells are to be made ≈øhall be ≈øhewn in the In≈øtitutions.

To this third operation may be referred that, Cupping gla≈øses. whereby ≈øomething is drawn in the body, or out of the body, by cupping gla≈ø≈øes, but a cupping gla≈øs is a ve≈ø≈øell with a belly which is fa≈øtned to the body to draw, all who≈øe ≈øtrength of acting comes by rea≈øon of vacuity, but what the differences of them are, the manner of applying of them, and their u≈øe, ≈øhall be ≈øhewn in the In≈øtitutions: and thus much of the third Chyrurgicall operation.

div.head: CHAP. X. Of drawing of things out of the body which were ≈øent into the body from without
div.p: THe fourth Chyrurgicall operation is, How many wayes things may be drawn out of the body. Drawing out of things thru≈øt into the body. A Dart how many wayes it may be drawne out. Exaire≈øis, or extraction of hurtfull and unprofitable things out of the body; but things which are to be taken away, are either ≈øent from without into the body, or begotten in the body.

Fir≈øt for what belongs to the extraction of things ≈øent from without into the body, they are twofold; fir≈øt all tho≈øe things which are ≈øent to wound the body, as darts of all ≈øorts, and Bullets ≈øhot out of Guns; Moreover certaine externall things which come into the Chops and Throate, Eares, No≈øtrills, and Eyes, and ≈øtick in them,

But Darts are taken out two wayes, either by extraction, or impul≈øion, that is, either that way which they came in, or that way which it aimed to goe out at; tis drawne out by the part which it came in at, either without any launcing, or with launcing; for if the dart pierced not deep, if it hath not pa≈ø≈øed through great ve≈ø≈øells, or nervous parts, and and meetes with a bone, veines, arteries, or nerves, out of the region whither it tended, and if there be no feare of any great tearing, it may be drawn back that way, which it entered into the body, and that without cutting; but if there be danger, and that it be to be feared lea≈øt that the body ≈øhould be lacerated, if the dart ≈øhould be drawn out the ≈øame way that it went in at, the wound is to be dilated either by cutting, or without launcing, namely with that In≈øtrument, which Ce ‚Ä¢ ≈øus in his 7. Booke and 15. Chap. calls Hyp≈øiloeides, or Swans, or ‚Ä¢ torkes beake, or other dilating In≈øtruments whereby the Dart may the ca≈øier be drawn back. Tis drawn out by the hand, if it may be, when it is apparent, and is fa≈øtned only in fle≈øh, or with a Volcella, when it ≈øticks ≈øo deep that it cannot be taken hold of by the hands, or other In≈øtruments which the Greekes, Boloulca, that is certaine In≈øtruments to pull out Darts, of which kind are long Tongs, Tongs with teeth, ≈øtraight, a little bent inward, but the outmo≈øt part broad and round, to which the latter Chyrurgeons have given ≈øeverall names from their figure, and call them Crowes, Storkes, Ducks, Gee≈øe bill, the figures whereof are extant, in Amb. Parey in the 10 th. Booke 18 th. Chap. but
if the point of the Dart, hath pierced into the member more then halfe through, and the place by which the dart is to be drawn through, be more, then it hath hitherto pa≈ø≈øed, and neither bone, Nerve, Veines, nor Arteries hinder it, tis more convenient, to drive the Dart thither whither it tended; di≈ø≈øection being made in that part, and to draw it out by making of a new wound; but yet if the Dart be too broad tis not expedient to draw it out through another part; lea≈øt that we add to that great wound, another greate one.

The rea≈øon of drawing out Musket bullets in many things is agreeable to the extraction of Darts, The way of taking out of Musket bullets. for three things are required to extraction, the fir≈øt that the way may be dilated with an In≈øtrument; ≈øecondly that the bullet be taken hold of; the In≈øtrument takes the bullet, either as a paire of Tongs, or the point of the In≈øtrument enters into the bullet, incompa≈ø≈øeth it with its cavity, or it takes hold with the end that is toothed like a faw; thirdly a bullet being taken hold of with an In≈øtrument, is drawne out by the hand of a Chyrurgeon with the In≈øtrument, of which more in the In≈øtitutions.

Moreover ≈øometimes thing shappen externally to the Chops, Things that ≈øtick in the Chops. Throate, Eares, and happen into the No≈øtrills, and Eyes, and u≈øe to ≈øtick in them, each of which require ≈øeverall wayes of drawing forth; if a little fi≈øh bone, or the back bone of a fi≈øh ≈øtick in the Throate, and that it be in ≈øight when the mouth is opened, tis to be taken out with a Volcella, and that either ≈øtraight, or a little bowed towards the end, and convenient to take out the bones from the Threate, but if it ≈øhould de≈øcend deeper into the Throate, or having u≈øed a Speculum of the mouth to open it wide, if it doth not appeare, a vomit is to be ≈øtirred up with oyle of ≈øweet Almonds, or of Olives, or with a quill, or putting downe ones finger.

A Worme ≈øticking in the Eares, A worme in the eares how to be taken out. fir≈øt of all it is to be drawn out a live, and that it may be the better performed, and the worme may the ea≈øier be taken, it is to be enticed outward, by injecting ≈øweete things into the Eares, and applying of them outwardly, but if it cannot be enticed, or drawn out alive, it is to be killed with tho≈øe things that are bitter, and by a peculiar propriety and force, are de≈øtructive to wormes, but being killed, tis drawn out by powring in water or wine and Oyle luke warme, and putting in of tents made of Cotton, wet with Hony, Turpentine, or ≈øome glutinous gum,
wherewith twi≈øting it up and down in the Eare, the worme is drawn forth, the ≈øick leaning on that ≈øide the Eare is affected

Other things which may be put, or ≈ølid into the eare are either hard, or liquid; if the things are hard, warme Oyle is to be powred in that they may be di≈ø≈øolved, if it be po≈ø≈øible, or certainly the pa≈ø≈øages of the Eare may become ≈ølippery; but if the thing which falls in be of that nature, that it will ≈øwell with moi≈øtning, as Pea≈øe, Beanes, &c. all moi≈øt things are to be avoided, afterwards ≈øneezing is to be provoaked, the No≈øtrills, and the mouth being ≈øhut, that the ≈øpirits may be forced to goe out through the Eares, and ≈øo that together to be thru≈øt out which was ≈ølid into the Eares, but if the thing cannot be extruded in this manner, tis to be drawn out with a convenient In≈øtrument, yet very warily, lea≈øt either that which is to be taken forth ≈øhould be thru≈øt deeper, or the membrane called the drumme of the Eare ≈øhould be broken.

If that which is to be taken out be liquid, the affected ≈øhould hop upon his foote on the contrary ≈øide, bending his head downeward on the afflicted ≈øide, that the moi≈øture may come forth, which if it doth not come to pa≈ø≈øe, ≈øneezing is to be occa≈øioned, or a little dry ≈øponge is to be put into the Eare, ≈øo that the extremity of the Channell which goes into the Eare be fir≈øt ≈øtopt and fortifyed with Cotton, that whil≈øt the ≈øpirit is drawn, there be no roome granted for the letting in of Aire in any wayes.
If any thing come into the No≈øtrills ≈øticks in them, there is another way of drawing of it out, then that of drawing out tho≈øe things that ≈øtick in the Eares.

If ≈øand or du≈øt ≈øtick in the Eyes, the ≈øtone found in the maw of a Swallow, Crabs Eyes, Pearles, if they are ca≈øt into the Eyes, clean≈øe them, but if any greater thing be fixed in the Eye, tis to be drawn out with a fine linnen cloath, wet in pure fountaine water, or with a ≈øponge tyed to a ≈øoft quill, but if it be greater, tis to be taken out with a little Volcella, or unle≈ø≈øe extraction in this manner doth ≈øucceed, Anodunes, or medicines taking away paine, being applyed and other convenient medicines, the bu≈øine≈ø≈øe is to be committed to nature.

div.head: CHAP. XI. Of drawing out of things generated in the body according to nature, but retained in the body beyond the limits of nature.
div.p: AFter the≈øe, among≈øt tho≈øe things which are to be drawn out of the body, ≈øomethings are found which indeed are generated in the body according to nature, yet are detayned there contrary to nature, and hitherto belongs fir≈øt of all, extraction, or exci≈øion of a living or dead child out of the body, moreover the drawing out of Urine detained preternaturally.

Fir≈øt of all, Of taking out a lived child. if the young can neither be brought out by the helpe of the mother, nor by any other, there is no other helpe remaines then cutting, whereby the living child is taken out, and tho≈øe which are brought forth on this manner, are called Cae≈øares, the young is cut out when the mother is living or dead, Of a dead. but of this Ce≈øarean bringing forth, you may ≈øee a peculiar Book of Francis Rou≈ø≈øet, but as for the extraction of a dead child by what meanes that may be rightly performed Cel≈øus teacheth in his 7. Booke. 29. Chap. 23. Aetius Tetrach Book 4. Ser. 4. Chap. and Hieron Fabricius ab Aqua P. of Chyrurgicall operations, Amb. Parey de≈øcribes fit In≈øtruments for this operation in his 23 d. Book Chap. 26. Job. Andr. a Cruce.

Next to the≈øe is the drawing out of a Mole and the ≈øame rea≈øon for the mo≈øt part is in drawing out them as in the extraction of a dead child.
Extraction of a Mola

La≈øtly hitherto belongs the drawing out of Urine by Chyrurgicall operation,
Drawing out urine with a Cathera. but that operation is performed by Silver, or brazen Pipes, which they call Catheters, which that they may be fitted for every body greater or le≈ø≈øe, three of them are to be prepared for men, and too for women in a readine≈ø≈øe, the manner of operation is in the In≈øtitutions.

div.head: CHAP. XII. Of taking away the corrupt parts of the body.
div.p: SOmetimes the parts of the body are ≈øo corrupted that there is no hope of curing of them, Cutting of dead fle≈øh. which as being unprofitable and hurtfull, and ≈øuch as may infect the parts next to them, and pollute them, are to be taken away; whatever therefore is corrupted, is to be cut off, but the manner of cutting offis various according to the variety of the parts that are hurt, and the place where they are, and nature of the di≈øea≈øe it ≈øelfe, and therefore the righte≈øt manner of taking away ≈øuch from the body is known by particular operations, yet oftentimes in fi≈øtula's and other malignant Ulcers, cutting alone is not ≈øufficient as being that which cannot take away the ≈ømalle≈øt fibrillaes and particles, but after cutting there is need of an actuall or potentiall Cauterie that the remainders may be taken away, nay ≈øometimes without cutting, by Cauteries only things ≈øo corrupted are taken away.

Hereunto belongs the Amputation of parts corrupted with a Cancer, Amputation of a cancer. Of a Vvula, yard, wombe. Of bones. al≈øo a cutting off of the Uvula, corrupted either by inflamation or by Morbus Gallicus, the cutting off al≈øo of the putred, or corrupted yard, as al≈øo of the corrupted wombe.

Corrupted bones are taken away by filing, ≈øhaving with an inci≈øion knife, or with a wimble, of which it is ≈øpoken before, as al≈øo with divers kinds of Tongs, whereby the corrupted bones of the fingers, and broken bones hanging out may be taken away.

Hitherto belongs the plucking out of teeth, Teeth. which is performed, the Teeth being fir≈øt loo≈øned from the gums, and is done with ≈øeverall In≈øtruments, who≈øe names are taken from the figure, and ≈øimilitude for the mo≈øt part, which they have with the beakes of living Creatures, which Hieron Fabricius, reckons up, the figures of them are extant in Amb. Parey. the 16 th. Book Chap. the 17 th. and Joh. Andr. a Cruce.

La≈øtly it ≈øometimes happens that in mans body certaine parts are corrupted with mortification & they ≈øo dy that ther is no hope of recovery of life, Amputation of Limbs. when there is one indication
that which is corrupted is to be cut off, lea≈øt the ≈øound al≈øo ≈øhould be affected, which operation the Greekes call Acroteria≈ømos, or a tearing off the dead ‚Ä¢ le≈øh, but in what place and when that Amputation is to be made cannot be delivered in a compendium, ≈øee the In≈øtitutions.

div.head: CHAP. XIII. Of freeing and taking away things generated in the body contrary to nature.
div.p: THe la≈øt kind remains of taking away things out of the body, Things preternaturall begotten in the body how many-fold. namely tho≈øe which are generated in the body contrary to nature, but there is no little difference among≈øt tho≈øe things, for ≈øome of them are borne together with the parts of our body and are adhere tenaciou≈øly, as Warts, Warts great above and ≈ømall below, ≈øwellings and inflammations in the fundament, the top of the yard, the way to the wombe, callous fle≈øh, Cornes, Knots, the Kings Evill, excre≈øcencies of fle≈øh in the No≈øtrills, and Polypus, ≈øwelling in the Chops, ≈ømall tumours in the Urinary pa≈ø≈øage, Excre≈øcencies on the eye lids, fle≈øhy ruptures, or el≈øe they are contained in ≈øome part of the body, as water in an aqueous rupture in the paunch, ≈øtones or gravell in the reines, bladder or yard.

The cutting of warts is performed either by binding, Warts. cuttings, or burning; Warts hanging downe are taken away either with a ≈øilken threed, or Hor≈øe haire, or they are to be tyed with ≈øome other ≈øtrong threed every day harder and harder untill they come off; cutting is performed with an inci≈øion knife, like a Mirtle leave, or with a launce; burning is performed with an hot Iron, or with green wood that is burnt; but how ≈øeverally the tumour called Thymus in the fundament, glans or prepuce, are to be taken away is ≈øhewn in the In≈øtitutions, and in the 3 d. Book of practice.

Sometimes a little tumour ari≈øeth in the Urinary pa≈ø≈øage from an Ulcer, Caruncles extirpated out the ∆≤rinary pa≈ø≈øages. and is ≈øo increa≈øed ≈øometimes that it ≈øtops the urine, this is to be taken away by the helpe of a Chyrurgeon, and fit medicines, but lea≈øt that other parts ≈øhould be eroded, medicines are to be ejected through a ≈øilver Pipe, to the tumour, or el≈øe it is to be incorporated and mixt with the top and head of a wax Candle, and thru≈øt into the place affected, or a little Cane with Lint and white wax put into it, and bedaubed with a fit medicine, being hollow that the
urine may pa≈ø≈øe through it. This is to be put into the urinary pa≈ø≈øages.

Polypus if it admits of cure,
Taking away a Polypus. it is to be cut off with a ≈øharpe Iron In≈øtrument made after the manner of a Spatula, being put into the No≈øtrills, of which operation ≈øee the In≈øtitutions, and the fir≈øt Book of Practice.

Fle≈øhy excre≈øcencies in the Chops called, Epuli a naile in the eye.
Epuli, as al≈øo Encanthis, or excre≈øcencies in the greater corner of the Eye, and the naile of the Eye, unle≈ø≈øe they can be taken away with medicines, are to be cut off, as al≈øo peices of fle≈øh here and there growing in the skin of the body,
Excre≈øcencies of fle≈øh. Fungi. Nodi &c. and excre≈øcencies which repre≈øent a kind of ≈øoft fle≈øh, which are like the rootes of Mu≈øhroms, and grow like them, and therefore are called Mu≈øheroms, knots al≈øo, Kings evill, Kernells, ≈øwellings in the Throate, and ≈øwellings in the fle≈øh, or fle≈øhy ruptures if they cannot be eradicated by Medicines, mu≈øt be taken away by cutting.
A watry rupture, A watry rupture. or water collected into the cods cannot alwayes be taken away by di≈øcu≈ø≈øing medicines, the cods are to be opened, and the water to be let out through the wound.

La≈øtly the ≈øtone of the bladder, Stone of the bladder. ≈øince it is ≈øeldome dimini≈øhed by medicines, the bladder being cut, tis to be taken out, and ≈øometimes a ≈øtone ≈øticking in the urinary pa≈ø≈øage is to be drawn out, but in what manner tho≈øe cuttings, and operations all of them ought to be per≈øormed, is ≈øpoken in the In≈øtitutions, and may there be ≈øeen, nor can the wayes of tho≈øe operations be reduced into a compendium, but all things which are there ≈øpoken in the operations are diligently to be ob≈øerved, and thus much of the fourth Chyrurgicall operation.

div.head: CHAP XIIII. Of the re≈øtitution of parts that are lo≈øt, or of the Chyrurgery of imperfect parts.
div.p:
THere remains the la≈øt Chyrurgicall operation, Chyrurgery of ≈øuch as are maimed. which is required in the cure of ≈øuch as are imperfect and maimed, namely when the extremities of the No≈øe or Eares or Lips are ≈øhortned, and the≈øe parts maimed, but although parts that are lo≈øt are counterfeited by In≈øtruments fained made and painted, out of ≈øeverall matter repre≈øenting the
≈øimilitude of the part lo≈øt, yet this is only a counterfeite and palliating cure, but when it cannot be re≈øtored by a new generation of the deficient part, tis to be re≈øtored by the fle≈øh of another member being brought and united to it, yet that operation is not to be tryed on every body, but fir≈øt it is to be ob≈øerved what kind of body it is which is to be cured, for in old men or in a body which hath an ill habit, wherein wounds are difficult to be cured, this way of cure is not to be ea≈øily attempted. Ca≈øper Taliacotius in his Book of maimed Chyrurgery, by in≈øerting, accuratly and largely de≈øcribes the manner of this operation, the ≈øum of this operation is this; he makes his transferring, or bringing into the No≈øe, and Lips, from the Shoulder; but to cure unperfect Eares he takes away from the Region behind the Eares, namely he appoints a convenient cutting in tho≈øe parts, and the maimed parts being fir≈øt clean≈øed, he commits and joynes the skin of that part which is cut off with the maimed part, and that they may be kept joyned together untill they grow together, he binds them with ≈øwathing bands. And indeed he puts that part of the No≈øe or Lips which is maimed, into the wound made in the Shoulder, with the head tyed to the Arme, as it were to a prop, that it is, immoveable, and fixt ≈øo that it can be moved no way. And in this manner when it hath ≈øtuck ≈øo long, untill the fle≈øh of both parts be united and growes together, he cutteth off againe from the No≈øe or Lip, the traduct, or that which was brought from another place and is here g ‚Ä¢ own, then he makes conveniently, and frames that fle≈øh ≈øo cut off from the Arme into a forme of a No≈øe or Lip.

div.head: THE FIFTH BOOK, PART. II. Of the Method of healing.
SECT. I. Of ≈øhewing how to pre≈øerve health.
CHAP I. Of the Method of healing and of indications in generall.
div.p: BUt it is not ≈øufficient to know the In≈øtruments for the recovery of health, and tho≈øe things which are profitable for the curing of a di≈øea≈øe, but tis nece≈ø≈øary to under≈øtand how and in what manner every thing is to be u≈øed, or to know the Method of healing, and re≈øtoring of lo≈øt health, the next thing therefore is that we may ≈øhew the Method of healing.

Capivaccius defines the Method of healing to be an art wherein by indications remedies are found out that the lo≈øt health of man may be re≈øtored, The Method of healing. for the Method of healing (as al≈øo all Phy≈øick) is a certaine principall effective had bit u≈øing indications as In≈øtruments to find out remedies for the cure of di≈øea≈øes.

For the end of the Method of healing is twofold. The internall, or proximate, namely invention of fit helps and
remedies in every di≈øea≈øe, or rather an invention of indications, that ≈øhew what will cure. The externall is a re≈øtitution of the lo≈øt health, or which is the ≈øame, an extirpation of a di≈øea≈øe.

But an indication which the Greeks call Endixis is ≈øometimes taken in generall for every ≈øhewing or demon≈øtration, Indication what. yet properly and in particular, and as it pertaines to the Method of healing, it ≈øignifyes the ≈øhewing of remedies, and tis a perception of what is healthfull in the Indicant, known by cau≈øes, or which is the ≈øame, tis a perception, and comprehen≈øion of that which is helping, or indicated, with an apprehen≈øion of what indicates without experience or any forceable argument from the cau≈øe to effect.

But although Indication be the fir≈øt In≈øtrument of Dogmatick Phy≈øick whereby tis di≈øcernd from other Sects, yet that doth not plainely reject experience, and any forceable arguments, but when di≈øea≈øes and the morbi≈øique cau≈øes of nature are not ≈øufficiently known, it flyes to experience and example as to a forceable Argument.
Experience is the remembrance and ob≈øervation which oftentimes is ≈øeen to come to pa≈ø≈øe in the ≈øame manner. Experience what.

An Analogi≈øme, Analogi≈øme. or forceable Argument to per≈øwad is an apprehen≈øion of what is helpefull from the like, but that ≈øimilitude is either among≈øt the affects or remedies, or among≈øt the members.

As for the Indication, that is really a certaine Enthymema, by the force whereof that is found out which is done, for the con≈øequence is ≈øo manife≈øt that no man can deny it, and indeed by the force of tho≈øe propo≈øitions which are the foundations of Method, and like Axiomes, and principalls in the Method of healing, and they are the≈øe.
Every thing which jndicates ≈øhews the con≈øervation of its ≈øelfe, or the taking of it away.
That which is according to nature is to be pre≈øerved, and that which is contrary to nature is to be taken away.

div.head: CHAP. XIV. Of evacuation by ≈øweate.
div.p:
LA≈øtly vitious humours al≈øo may be expelled by ≈øweate, Sweate whence it evacuates. for although ≈øweate evacuate in the fir≈øt place from the circumference, and habit of the body, yet it may evacuate humours al≈øo from the re≈øt of the body, and indeed fir≈øt out of the greater veines and Arteries, and afterwards out of all other parts, namely from whence humours may be driven to the veines, and from thence to the ≈øuperficies of the body, for they are not conveniently thru≈øt out from the cavities of the ≈øtomach, guts, wombe, and ≈øuch like, to the extremities of the body, and there are other wayes by which they are far more ea≈øily evacuated, What humours are evacuated by ≈øweate. but the watry humour is evacuated by ≈øweate, which al≈øo may be evacuated by Urine, and ≈øo may every thin humour and cholerick, as

But medicines provoking ≈øweate are e≈øpecially to be exhibited with profit in pe≈øtilentiall di≈øea≈øes and in all malignant matter, by which the malignant matter, In what di≈øea≈øes. the pe≈øtilent and venemous matter to the great benefit to the ≈øick is driven from the internall parts, and tho≈øe that are next the heart to the extremities of the body, and is evacuated by ≈øweate. But Sudori≈øiques, which are given in ≈øuch di≈øea≈øes, ought to be of the number of tho≈øe that re≈øi≈øt poy≈øon, that they may together infringe and debilitate the venome. div.p: AS for particular Evacuations, Particular evacuation of the braine. Errhines. if any vitious humours are collected in the braine, it may be evacuated two wayes, by the No≈øe, and the Palate.

The ≈øtomach is evacuated by vomit or by the paunch, Things purging ≈øtymach, Liver, Reines, Wombe. the guts with gli≈øters, and medicines purging the belly; the cavities of the liver, through the belly; the gibbous parts, by urine; the reines, and urinary pa≈ø≈øages, by urine, the wombe by the cources.
