div.head: CHAP. XVI. Of the abating abundance of blood with Leaches, Cupping-gla≈ø≈øes, Scarrifications &c.
div.p: THe other fault among≈øt morbifique cau≈øes is quantity and the common Indication which is taken from hence that that which aboundeth may be deminui≈øhed, What ≈øhews the fault concerning quantity. What offends in quantity. and that which is diminui≈øhed, may be increa≈øed, but ≈øince nothing can be ≈øaid to abound, unle≈ø≈øe that at other times it be naturally pre≈øent; but in the body blood only and ≈øuch excrements are contained which proceed from nature; blood and naturall excrements in this ≈øecond manner may be the cau≈øes of di≈øea≈øes, as al≈øo milke and ≈øeed, and moreover the ≈øpirits and ≈øolid parts of the body, all which if they are deficient in quantity, ought to be increa≈øed, but if they exceed are to be deminui≈øhed; naturall excrements are ≈øeldome de≈øicient in quantity, but they often exceed; but ≈øince the ≈øame rea≈øon is of evacuating naturall excrements, which there is of the humours, in their kind preternaturall, here only we will ≈øpeak of taking away of blood when it abounds.

Therefore if Plethory, be pre≈øent and the blood abound, Plethory what it ≈øhews. the blood is to be diminui≈øhed, and that which aboundeth to be taken away, and too great plenty of blood indicates diminution of the ≈øame.

But concerning the manner how we abate the blood, The manner of abating blood. ≈øome performe it more ≈øtrongly, others more weakly; frications, Sweates, Bathes, Exerci≈øe, Fa≈øtings performe it more weakely; Leaches, opening of the Hemethodes, provocation of cour≈øes, Cupping-gla≈øles, and Scarrifications performe it more ≈øtrongly; but the mo≈øt generous, and powerfull remedie here, is opening of a veine.
Frications, ≈øweates, Bathes, and Exerci≈øes, they diminui≈øh the blood one way, becau≈øe they ≈øtir up the heate in the body, which di≈ø≈øolves and di≈ø≈øipates the ≈øub≈øtance of our bodyes.

But fa≈øting doth not evacuate by its ≈øelfe, Fa≈øting. but by rea≈øon that it takes away humours, and diminui≈øheth the body, becau≈øe it puts nothing in the ≈øtead of that which is con≈øumed by heate, and denyes nece≈ø≈øary aliment to the body; but becau≈øe fa≈øting evacuates the whole body equally, tis then requi≈øite when the humour abounding
doth abound not in one part but in the whole body; yet ≈øhorter fa≈øting fir≈øt evacuates humours out of the ≈øtomach and about the ≈øtomach; but becau≈øe fa≈øting evacuates by degrees it is not profitable, nor ≈øufficient for an indication, when plenitude is ≈øuddenly to be abated. Leaches by opening the mouths of veines, Leaches. and ≈øucking blood, evacuate blood by them≈øelves, and ≈øen≈øibly, yet by little, and little, in which re≈øpect they may diminui≈øh the plenitude of the whole body and helpe di≈øea≈øes of many parts to which they are applyed, and evacuate, ≈øometimes a greater, ≈øometimes a le≈ø≈øer quantity of blood, as they are applyed to a greater, or le≈ø≈øer veine, in the application therefore of them, you are to ob≈øerve, whether they are placed for the evacuation of the whole body, or for a di≈øea≈øe of ≈øome private part, for if they are applyed for the evacuation of the whole, they are to be put to the great and prominent veines, in the Legs and Armes or Hemerhodes, yet in women that are with child, they mu≈øt be applyed only to the Armes; but in regard of peculiar di≈øea≈øes they are to be applyed to divers parts, as this or that part is affected.

The Hemerhodes if they u≈øe to flow at other times, Hemerhodes. the opening of them may be in≈øtead of breathing a veine, but otherwi≈øe the Phy≈øitian in opening of them ≈øhall labour with little profit, unle≈ø≈øe happily they are opened by leaches putting to them; but ≈øince the Hemerhodes are twofold, externall and internall, the externall are opened to abate a Plethory, as al≈øo for di≈øea≈øes of the Reines, Wombe, Back, Hips, and other di≈øea≈øes ari≈øing from the hollow veine with profit; as in di≈øea≈øes which proceed from the Hypocondries, the Liver, Spleen, Me≈øentery, the internall may be conveniently opened; but the externall are opened with frications, the leaves of a Fig, cour≈øe rags, Leaches applyed, the juice of an Onion, the juice of Century, or Sow-bread, the Gall of a Hog, or Bullock, or with rags wet in the≈øe, but the internall with ≈øuppo≈øiters and ≈øharpe Gli≈øters.

Cuppings, which Scarrification al≈øo, Cupping with ≈øcarri≈øying. but by die, evacuating blood by them≈øelves, and ≈øen≈øibly, but by degrees; for which rea≈øon they are ≈øomething applyed for good rea≈øons, ≈øometimes in≈øtead of opening a veine; if they are applyed with good rea≈øon, they are indicated from no great fault of the blood. But when they are u≈øed in≈øtead of Phlebotomie they are applyed for ≈øome great fault in the blood, which indeed requires the breathing of a veine, which notwith≈øtanding weak ≈øtrength will not endure; but Cupping-gla≈ø≈øes properly evacuate cutaneous blood, yet becau≈øe ≈øome of the blood which comes out of the skin is powred into the capillary veines from the great veines, in this re≈øpect al≈øo they are ≈øaid to evacuate the whole body: but if that evacuation be more ≈øparing it doth not reach the whole. And when Cupping-gla≈ø≈øes evacuate by drawing, the u≈øe of them is mo≈øt profitable if any revul≈øion be required at the ≈øame time: as for the place of applycation, if they are applyed in re≈øpect of the whole, they ≈øhould be put to the inferior parts; if in re≈øpect of any part, then to that part which requires this remedie; yet in tho≈øe that are pregnant, they are not to be exhibited to the inferior parts but rather to the Armes.

La≈øtly ≈øimple ≈øcarification al≈øo without cupping, Scarrification. may evacuate blood; which truly is u≈øed ≈øometimes in≈øtead of opening a veine; and tis appointed in the Legs e≈øpecially, by which meanes it may not only evacuate but al≈øo re-vell from the head, and ≈øuperior parts, yet ≈øometimes in the Arme and back al≈øo, but in its proper u≈øe tis exhibited, when there is a purpo≈øe to evacuate only out of ≈øome one part, but e≈øpecially when we would evacuate ≈øome acrid, malignant, and venemous matter, lea≈øt being retained, it ≈øhould ca≈øt the ≈øick into danger, which is u≈øed al≈øo in a Gangrene, and by the ancients in a callous Ulcer.

div.head: CHAP XVII. Of opening a veine.
div.p: BUt the mo≈øt efficacious remedie for evacuation of blood is the breathing of a veine, which neverthele≈ø≈øe hath other u≈øes, What indicates a breathing of a veine. whereof we will here ≈øpeake together, for tis a que≈øtion of great moment when the breathing of a veine, or evacuation of blood by opening of a veine is to be appointed, where fir≈øt this is to be noted, that the opening o ‚Ä¢ a veine is not ≈øome one Indicate, but the matter of remedie which is profitable in many Indicates.

There are two generall benefits in the opening of a veine, The u≈øe of opening a veine. to evacuate, blood, and by accident, whil≈øt it draws away the blood, the vehicle of heate, to coole; againe in evacuating it performes two things, for it both takes blood out of the body, and allwayes the cource, and violence of humours in the veines; fir≈øt the way it both takes away the ill blood, and only diminui≈øheth it offending in quantity, but the latter way it can revell, and draw back and derive the blood flowne into a part, and the blood which is flowne in whil≈øt it is yet moveable, can draw it to the parts neere thereunto; ≈øo that the opening of a veine may wholy performe five things, namely to evacuate corrupt blood, to diminui≈øh blood, to revell, derive, and refrigerate.

For fir≈øt the vitious and putrifying blood may be evacuated by opening of a veine, Putred blood evacuated by the opening of a veine. as that which is contained in veines, and they being opened it flowes out, and indeed tis mo≈øt profitably appointed in beginning of di≈øea≈øes, ≈øince nature for the mo≈øt part in feavers u≈øe to drive no ≈ømall portion of the peccant matter to the extreames, and tho≈øe greater veines under the skin.
Secondly, breathing a veine is an excellent remedie to dimini≈øh the blood. The cutting of a vtine devinui≈øheth blood and revels.

Thirdly, the opening of a veine is u≈øed for revul≈øion, for a veine being opened, the violence of the blood is turned and drawne back to the contrary part, and therefore tis a very efficacious remedie to ≈øtop flowings of humours, contained in the veines.

Fourthly, the opening of a veine may derive the blood, which newly flowed into the part, It derives. and is not yet ≈øetled there, but as yet fluid; a veine being opened nigh at hand it may, I ≈øay drive the blood to a neighbouring part.

Fifthly, Cooles. opening of a veine cooles by accident, but if di≈øtemper
only be pre≈øent, which may be corrected by other remedies, and no other fault of the blood be joyned with it which requires breathing of a veine al≈øo, cooling medicines are ordered to be u≈øed; but if the blood be ≈øo exceeding hot that it requires ≈øudden refrigeration, which other medicines perchance cannot performe, or ≈øome other fault of the blood be joyned, which by the ≈øame means, opening of a veine may helpe, for this cau≈øe al≈øo you may open a veine.

From whence it is manife≈øt, For which Indicants cutting of a veine ≈øerves. that the breathing fo a veine may be profitable, whil≈øt the blood either putrifyes, and is corrupted, or offends in quantity, or flowes to any part, with violence, or oppre≈ø≈øeth a part, or burnes vehemently.

Yet it is not allwayes nece≈ø≈øary to open a veine when the≈øe ‚Ä¢ inconveniences are pre≈øent, ≈øince we can take them away by other meanes, but then only breathing a veine is conveni
‚Ä¢ ent, when there is a great corruption of the blood, and it requires ≈øudden relea≈øing, as being that which is the be≈øt and mo≈øt efficacious remedy among≈øt the evacuations of blood, then pre≈øently blood may be evacuated.

In ≈øhort, The adequate Indicant of cutting a veine. the Indicant to which by mediation of the Indicate, as being the matter of helpe, opening of a veine agrees, it is a vehement fault of the flowing blood, which is corrupted either in its ≈øub≈øtance, or it offends in quantity, or ru≈øheth into ≈øome part, or oppre≈ø≈øeth ≈øome part, or growes exceeding hot; yet be≈øides the≈øe principle faults, the blood al≈øo ≈øometimes, as a cau≈øe without which it cannot, and as adjuvant, it may offend; and then al≈øo it requires opening of a veine.

Yet we may not allwayes open a veine when the≈øe Indicants are pre≈øent, Things permitting opening a veine. for ≈øince the opening of a veine evacuates blood together, and al≈øo exhau≈øteth ≈øomewhat of the ≈øpirits, and ≈øo debilitates the ≈øtrength, if the ≈øtrength be great, it permits opening of a veine, if it be weake it prohibits it, and regard is to be had here not only of the pre≈øent, but of the future ≈øtrength, for when the ≈øtrength is weake, either oppre≈ø≈øed with ≈øtore of humours, or loo≈øed, in the latter imbecility only breathing of a veine is prohibited, but in the former it is profitable.

All other things which are ≈øaid to permit, or prohibit the breathing of a veine, be≈øides ≈øtrength, they doe it only in this re≈øpect, namely as they are the tokens or ≈øignes of ≈øtrength, or debility of nature, as Age, which flouri≈øhing admits of opening a veine, Child-hood and old Age prohibit
the ≈øame, Se ‚Ä¢ . the Sex, as to women with child, e≈øpecially in the la≈øt monthes, the opening of a veine is prohibited; unle≈ø≈øe ≈øome di≈øea≈øe inforce it and there be ≈øtore of blood, property of nature, cu≈øtome, habit of body, cour≈øe of life, con≈øtitution of Aire, ≈øome Symptomes, as large evacuations, watchings and ≈øuch like, which di≈ø≈øipate the ≈øpirits, and ≈øub≈øtance of our bodyes, and loo≈øen our ≈øtrength, unle≈ø≈øe they are taken away by opening of a veine. How much blood to be evacuated.

div.head: CHAP. XVIII. Of Revul≈øion.

An ≈øo, How many waies the motion of humors may be hindered although there is one Indicant, namely a fault of the humours in motion, ≈øo there is one Indicate, namely, remedy hindring motion, and averting the humour from the part to which it flowes, yet the manners of performing the≈øe are various, namely foure, Revul≈øion, Derivation, Interception, and repul≈øion.

div.head: CHAP III. Of the cure of di≈øea≈øes of Conformation.

But tis a generall Indication which ≈øupplyes the fault of the figure, a changing of the part of the viticus figure to the contrary, until it acquires the figure which naturally it ought to have, but this is performed two wayes, by fa≈øhioning, and alligation or binding; How corrected. by fa≈øhioning that mending of the figure is to be taken, which by drawing and pro≈ø≈øing with the hands, by little and little and often, is perfected; by binding, that correction is under≈øtood which is performed by ≈øwathings, and Ferrules, or Canes, namely by which part of the vitious figure by ≈øwathings is drawne contrarywife, and retained by ≈øplintors, lea≈øt it ≈øhould bend back againe towards its erroneous figure.

The ≈øecond ≈øort of di≈øea≈øes of Conformation are in the hollow places, which two generall indications doe helpe, The cure of di≈øea≈øes in the channell or pa≈øsages. namely to open that which contrary to nature is ≈øhut, and to ≈øhut that, which contrary to nature is opened.

But among≈øt di≈øea≈øes in defect the mo≈øt common is ob≈øtruction of pa≈ø≈øages, Of ob≈øtruction. who≈øe common Indication is, apertion of ob≈øtruction But ≈øith thence the cau≈øes of ob≈øtruction may be various, particular indications are taken from them, and tho≈øe being taken away, the ob≈øtructions are al≈øo opened: Therefore that ob≈øtruction which is made by thick and vi≈øcid humours, requires attenuating, clean≈øing, and cutting medicines; among≈øt which, ≈øometimes the weaker, ≈øometimes the ≈øtronger are u≈øed, according to the nature of the humour it ≈øelf, and the condition of the place wherein it re≈øides: But if ob≈øtruction be made by many humours, and they contrary to nature in their whole kind, the cure thereof con≈øi≈øts altogether in evacuation. But if the humour be not contrary to nature in its whole kind, but onely offends in quantity, the Indication is Apokeno≈øis, i. e. That which abounds is to be abated, according to its abundancy: But although all the ob≈øtructing cau≈øes ≈øhould be evacuated, yet they differ as well in other things, as al≈øo e≈øpecially in this, that each of them require their peculiar and convenient places: Tho≈øe which ob≈øtruct the Brea≈øt and Lungs, are to be ejected by cough, nor can they ea≈øily be evacuated any other way: But tho≈øe which are contained in the Liver, or in Veines, or in Arteries, or in the Reines, are ca≈øt out by Urine, the belly, or vomit.

The other kinds of ≈øtraightne≈øs, Coale≈øcen≈øe when the cau≈øes are taken away, they are likewi≈øe taken away, things growing together, or Coale≈øcents, ≈øince it comes to pa≈øs by the growing together of parts and ≈øides of a pa≈ø≈øage Indicate a Medicine breaking and taking away that Siccatrizing again.
Con≈øtipation Indicates the cau≈øe to be taken away, Pre≈ø≈øing & clo≈øing. Compre≈ø≈øion. which make that ≈øtraightne≈øs.

Compre≈ø≈øion ≈øince it proceeds from externall cau≈øes, re≈øting upon the pa≈ø≈øages, the Indication is common, namely, to take away that cau≈øe of pre≈ø≈øing together, and ≈øhutting the pa≈ø≈øage, but the ≈øpeciall Indications are various, according to the variety of cau≈øes, and the whole cure con≈øi≈øts in the ablation of tho≈øe cau≈øes which ≈øhall be ≈øhewn in their owne place.

La≈øtly, Sub≈øidence, if it be cau≈øed by too much humidity, the part is to be dryed: If the part be wrung hard, and as it were contracted, with drying things, and too many A≈øtringents, and cold, the contraries, namely, Relaxing and moi≈øtning things are to be exhibited.

On the other ≈øide, if the pa≈ø≈øages, Cure of the opening of Ve≈ø≈øels. and ve≈ø≈øels which ought to be ≈øhut are opened, and humours flow out from thence, the common Indication is, that the opened ve≈ø≈øell is to be ≈øhut, which may be performed in the externall parts, with convenient Medicines applyed, and bound: But if the opening be in the inward parts, the manner of performing that is various, according to the variety of cau≈øes: If it be an Ana≈øtome≈øis, or opening of the mouth of a ve≈ø≈øell, the orifice of the opened ve≈ø≈øell is to be hardned and bound. If by a Diapede≈øis, thickning and incra≈ø≈øating Medicines are required: If by a Rupture, the broken ve≈ø≈øell is to be united, and ≈øhut: If from Ero≈øion, Sarcotticks fir≈øt, afterwards con≈øolidating medicines are required.

Thirdly, If the part which naturally ought to be ≈ømooth, Cure of di≈øea≈øes of the ≈øuperficies. ≈øhould become rough, tis to be made ≈ømooth againe, which is performed in the Wind-pipe and Tongue: If that which is evacuated be filled up, or that which is extant be taken away; That is performed in ≈øoft parts by Medicines which moi≈øten, and have a clammy nature: But this with ab≈øtergent Medicines; But in bones whether they are eroded, Of roughne≈øs. or have any ≈øuperfluity annexed to them, the roughne≈øs is conveniently taken away by ≈øhaving.

Smoothne≈øs contrary to nature, Of ≈ømoothne≈øs. requires a contrary way of cure, and the naturall roughne≈øs is to be brought againe, by ab≈øtergent Medicines, and indeed ≈øuch as throughly clean≈øe, namely, ≈øuch as can free the glutinous humours, tenaciou≈øly cleaving to the out-≈øides of the parts, and re≈øtore the naturall roughne≈øs to the part.

div.head: CHAP. IV. Of the cure of Di≈øea≈øes of number.
div.p:
DI≈øea≈øes in Number, ≈øince they are two-fold, in exce≈øs, and in defect, either of them require their Indication, Di≈øea≈øes of number what they indicate. and that which is wanting, and naturally ought to be pre≈øent is to be re≈øtored: But that which abounds is to be taken away and removed; but ≈øince that which is wanting onely can be a naturall thing, tis the part of Nature onely to make
up and regenerate that which is wanting, but the Phy≈øitian is only the ≈øervant of nature in the≈øe things whil≈øt he defends the ≈øtrength of nature, Admini≈øters fit matter, and removes impediments, but this generall indication is varied according to the variety of parts, and cannot allwayes be reduced into action: for it proceeds in one manner in the generation of fle≈øh, in another of a bone, in another of a nerve, and other parts, of which in the ≈øolution of unity.

Moreover ≈øince ≈øome parts are ≈øimple, others compound, if compound are lo≈øt, neither the ≈øame in particular, nor any thing like unto them, can ea≈øily come in their ≈øtead; in which the third ≈øcope is to find out a certaine comeline≈ø≈øe, or to make ≈øomething, which may ≈øome wayes doe the office of a lo≈øt part, yet later Phy≈øitians have invented a way of curing imperfect parts, whereof above, part 2 d. Sect. 1. Chap. 16.

On the contrary exce≈ø≈øe requires its removall, but ≈øince tho≈øe things are various which ought to be taken away, each of them de≈øerves its peculiar cure, according to the ≈øub≈øtance, dignity, ≈øituation of the parts, and differing al≈øo in other re≈øpects, for we allwayes beware of this, that other parts may not be hurt, or at lea≈øt to doe our endeavour that they may receive very little hurt, and that there may come no greater lo≈ø≈øe to the body by the taking away, then that was which came by the thing abounding.

But the In≈øtruments wherewith a Phy≈øitian may appoint the ablation of things which abound contrary to nature, are three, Iron, Fire, and medicines; by Iron all acute In≈øtruments of every kind which are fit for the cutting of ‚Ä¢ ≈øuperfluities, are under≈øtood: by fire, actuall eauteries are under≈øtood, whil≈øt that which abounds is burnt with Iron, Silver, or fired Gold. Medicines for this purpo≈øe mo≈øt convenient, are tho≈øe which are called potentiall cauteries, Cathareticks, namely, Septicks and E≈øcaroticks, all which are mentioned before.

div.head: CHAP. V. Of curing di≈øea≈øes of magnitude.
div.p:
WHen either the whole body, Magnitude increa≈øed what it ≈øhews. or any member thereof is increa≈øed contrary to nature, ≈øo that the naturall
actions are thereby hindred, the Indication is that the magnitude increa≈øed may be dimini≈øhed: and indeed ≈øince the ≈øub≈øtance of the part is not ≈øound, when tis increa≈øed in magnitude, as in wounds, and ulcers, the ≈øame medicines are to be exhibited as to tho≈øe abounding in number; but if either the whole body or any part be equally increa≈øed, and it too much increa≈øeth through the whole, you may not u≈øe Iron, or Fire, nor corra≈øive medicines, but there are two ≈øpeciall aimes, namely, to draw away the too greate plenty of aliment from the parts, and to con≈øume it, or take it away by Digerents, and di≈øcutients, wherefore fa≈øting and ≈øpare dyet, are then convenient; and ≈øuch u≈øe of the non-naturalls as may attenuate and di≈øcu≈ø≈øe, and medicines of the ≈øame nature.

Tumours al≈øo have their peculiar aimes which that generall Indication ≈øatisfieth, Cure of Tumours. which commands us to dimini≈øh that which is increa≈øed contrary to nature; of which in its owne place.

The magnitude dimini≈øhed on the other ≈øide indicates its increa≈øe, but this is performed by new nouri≈øhing, Bigne≈ø≈øe dimini≈øhed what it ≈øhewes: or re≈øtoring, and by generation, by renutrition; that which is wanting is re≈øtored by good and plentifull aliment, and the part acquires a greater, and naturall bigne≈ø≈øe, but generation is then nece≈ø≈øary when any thing is lo≈øt of the ≈øub≈øtance of the part: for there that is re≈øtored by the re-generation of fle≈øh which was lo≈øt, and the cavity of the ulcer filled up.

div.head: CHAP VI. Of curing di≈øea≈øes in ≈øcituation and connexion.
div.p: MOreover Organick di≈øea≈øes, Di≈øea≈øes in po≈øition and connexion without they ≈øhew. ≈øince there are di≈øea≈øes in po≈øition, and connexion, that which hath lo≈øt its naturall place, Indicates its repo≈øition into its naturall place, but that, which is not joyned to tho≈øe which it ought, Indicates its conjunction with them; the fir≈øt indication performed, and bones out of joynt are cured by bending and forceing them from the oppo≈øite part to that from whence they were removed; which by what meanes it may be performed is ≈øhewne before part 1. Sect. 2. Chap. 4. ≈øo other parts are to be reduced into their owne places.

But if the parts which according to nature ought to be ≈øeparated, are joyned together, and grow together contrary to nature, they are to be freed and ≈øeparated: But that ≈øeparation is made either by Chirurgery, and the help of an Inci≈øion Knife, and Iron, or with a ≈øilken ≈øtring, or with a Hor≈øe hair, or with cau≈øtick Medicines and Septicks.

But the other kind, Di≈øea≈øes in connexion. when the part is not joyned with tho≈øe with which it ought, Indicates that, that which containes ≈øhould be rendred more firme and ≈øolid: And therefore tho≈øe parts ought to be ≈øtrengthned and contained.

div.head: CHAP. VII. Of the cure of Solution of Continuity.
div.p:
THe fir≈øt,
∆≤nity di≈ø≈øolved, what it ≈øhewes. What to be done by the Phy≈øitian. and mo≈øt u≈øuall Indication of Solution of Unity, is uniting, or unity di≈ø≈øolved Indicates that the parts that are ≈øeparated ≈øhould be united; which thing although it be the work of nature, yet the Phy≈øitian is the Servant of nature in this matter: For the≈øe are the principall duties of the Phy≈øitian here. Fir≈øt, he is to be carefull that nothing fall into the part affected, which may impede conglutination.
Secondly, That the extreams, or lips in the di≈ø≈øolved unity are rightly joyned againe, and are mutually applyed to each other.
Thirdly, That the extreames ≈øo joyned may be kept together.
Fourthly, That the Temperament of the part it ≈øelf may be pre≈øerved, and the help of nature is nece≈ø≈øarily required in agglutination.
Fifthy, That the Symptomes which may en≈øue be prevented and corrected.

But the≈øe aimes are not alwaies performed in all parts alike: The cure of wounds. For in wounds, every extraneous thing is to be taken away out of the Wound, then the lips of the Wound are to be joyned together, and it is to be endeavoured that they may be kept united: As before part 1. Sect. 2. cap. 5. is ≈øpoken, the parts being joyned, the re≈øt of the work is to be committed to nature, tis the parr of the Phy≈øitian onely to endeavour that the blood which comes out offends neither in quantity, nor quality, and to u≈øe Medicines that generate fle≈øh, of
which Galen 3. of his Method of healing, cap. 3. And la≈øtly, to citatrize the wound: yet if certaine Symptomes which may hinder the cure, do follow, as Hemerodes, paine, convul≈øions, they are to be re≈øi≈øted, and principally care is to be taken that no inflamation en≈øue.

In the cure of Fractures, Of Fraciures. the Phy≈øitian propounds to him≈øelf two aimes. Fir≈øt, that the broken bones may be rightly joyned together againe, and that the naturall Po≈øition and Figure may be re≈øtored to them: The other that being joyned they may be kept together and retained, and grow in their naturall figure: But in what manner that may be performed, is ≈øpoken before, p. 1. S. 2. c. 3.

But the generation of hard fle≈øh and skin, Generation of hard fle≈øh. whereby the bones and skin may be conglutinated and grow together is the work of nature: But the Phy≈øitian ought to help nature, which he doth if he beware lea≈øt any inflamation or ≈øuch like accident which may hurt the ≈øub≈øtance and temperature of the member, ≈øhould follow, and the aliment is to be ≈øo di≈øpo≈øed through drying Medicines, that it may the ≈øooner be changed into callous, or hard fle≈øh, of which tis ≈øpoken before.

div.head: CHAP. VIII. Of the cure of oppre≈ø≈øing and urging Symptomes.
div.p:
THe third ≈øort of preternaturall things remaines, Symptomes urging, & how many. namely, Symptomes. Symptomes as they are preternatural Indicate in generall the ablation of them≈øelves: But that Indication for the mo≈øt part is unprofitable: For ≈øince they depend on di≈øea≈øes, and their cau≈øes, tho≈øe being taken away, the≈øe al≈øo are taken away: But becau≈øe it cannot alwaies be expected, or waited, untill the cau≈øe, or the di≈øea≈øe be taken away, ≈øomethings nece≈ø≈øary Indicate, vvhich require a peculiar cure different both from the cure of a di≈øea≈øe and of the cau≈øe, and that they require to be done ≈øpeedily: Such Symptomes are tho≈øe which are ≈øaid to urge or en≈øorce: All tho≈øe things provoke which threaten ≈øuch danger and mi≈øchief, that the ablation of the di≈øea≈øe, or of the cau≈øe on which it depends cannot be expected, but if it ≈øhould be expected, it would threaten the hazard of life, or ≈øome great hurt; But then the ablation of the di≈øea≈øe is not to be expected
when either it is uncurable, and the Symptomes belongs to an action hurt, that is nece≈ølary, not ab≈øolutely for life, but for amendment, or if it be cureable, the cure whereof is ≈øo tedious, that before it can be perfected, danger and hazard of life will be like to happen, by rea≈øon of the Symptome; tho≈øe Symptomes are commonly accounted but few, principally paine, watchings, and immoderate Evacuations, yet there are ≈øome others.

Paine indicates a medicine taking away or mittigating paine, Cure of paine. but ≈øince paine is either a ≈øad ≈øen≈øation, or el≈øe is not made without a ≈øad perception by ≈øen≈øe, and two things are nece≈ø≈øary to ≈øen≈øation, perception of a thing Tangeable, or ≈øen≈øe in the part which it meetes with, and advertency of the mind, if one of the≈øe be wanting neither ≈øen≈øe nor paine is, and therefore tho≈øe things which take away, and hinder one of the≈øe, are contrary to the paine: and as for what belongs to the ≈øen≈øe in the part, we may re≈øi≈øt paine two wayes, either by oppo≈øing a contrary object to the ≈øad ≈øen≈øation, or by taking away the ≈øen≈øe; ≈øithhence therefore a ≈øweet and plea≈øant ≈øen≈øation is contrary to a ≈øad, that the ≈øad ≈øen≈øation may be taken away, that is to be offered to it, which is endued with a mild and gentle heate, and brings forth a plea≈øant, Anodines. and ≈øweete ≈øen≈øation when touched, which are Anodines (or medicines mittigating paine) properly ≈øo called, as a bath of fre≈øh water, common Oyle, the far of Animalls, Mu≈øcillages, and other things endued with a temperate and plea≈øing heate, of which above P. 1. S. 1. Chap. 7.
Moreover Narcotticks mittigate paine, Stupefactives. or Stupifactives, which ≈øtupifie the Spirits, and together provoke ≈øleepe, and ≈øo doe it, that the Dolorifique ≈øubject is not perceived.
Secondly, Intentivene≈øs of mind is hindred if it be averted to other objects.

Over much watching indicates a medicine cau≈øing ≈øleepe, Cure of over much watching. ≈øleepe may be occa≈øioned foure wayes; fir≈øt if all things may be removed which may excite any ≈øen≈øe to operate. Secondly, if the mind be drawne away from the agitation of the externall ≈øen≈øes, and the animall ≈øpirits are plea≈øantly invited, from motion to re≈øt. Thirdly, if tho≈øe things are exhibited, which allay hot, dry, and ≈øharpe vapours, and ≈øend plea≈øant fancies into the braine, whereby it is moi≈øtned, and as it were ≈øtupifyed. Fourthly, if tho≈øe things are exhibited which by a peculiar faculty make the animall
Spirits drowzie, and unapt, or dull, which ≈øpecially are called, Hypnoticks, and Narcoticks.
Thir≈øt ≈øince it is the de≈øire of cold and moi≈øt, Cure of Thir≈øt. and is made through the defect of cold and moi≈øt, it Indicates cold and moi≈øt, as its contrary.
Too great a flux of the belly, as it is ≈øuch, Of the flux of the belly. Flux of blood. is ≈øtopt by a≈øtringent things.

Blood ≈ølowing Indicates a remedie that ≈øtenches blood; but it is ≈øtopt two wayes, either by prohibiting, that the blood cannot returne to the place, out of which it came, or if the ve≈ø≈øells ≈øuffer it not to flow, which will be done, if they are ≈øhut, or clo≈øed, and ≈øometimes, one of them only ≈øufficeth, and ≈øometimes, when there is a great flux of blood both are nece≈ø≈øary. That the blood may not flow back to the place out of which it came, is to be brought to pa≈ø≈øe if it be not drawn back by it, if it be repelled, if it be drawn to another place, t ‚Ä¢ s not drawn back if the cau≈øes, by rea≈øon of which tis drawn back be taken away, as heat, pain, trouble≈øome thir≈øt: tis repelled by the u≈øe of the Refrigeratives, and a≈øtringents, tis drawne into another part by Revelling, or Deriving, but that the blood may not flow back, is prohibited when the end is ≈øhut, which is done, when the way is ob≈øtructed, and ≈øtopped; through which it flowed.

We cure a ≈øwooning by refre≈øhing the Spirits, Fainting or ≈øwooning. although it cannot be done pre≈øently by removing the cau≈øe, for this purpo≈øe the mo≈øt f ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ things, are pure Aire, excellent and O doriferous Wine, and ≈øpirits di≈øtilled of it.

But not only actions hurt, but other Symptomes al≈øo ≈øometimes trouble, if the Arme pits ≈øtink and ≈ømell ranke, that inconveniency is remided by the u≈øe of ≈øweet things, if the breath ≈øtinks, that imperfection is hid by the chewing of ≈øweet ≈ømelling things.

div.head: THE FIFTH BOOK, PART II. SECT. III. Of the vitall Indication.
CHAP. I. What doth Indicate Dyet in tho≈øe that are ≈øick.
div.p: SIth hence, it is ≈øpoken by what means things preternaturall are to be taken away, now it remains that we ≈øpeake, how that which remains in a ≈øick man, according to nature may be kept, or pre≈øerved: but tho≈øe things which are according to nature commonly come under the name of ≈øtrength, or force, and Indication which is taken from thence, is called vitall, and Con≈øervatory, becau≈øe it pre≈øerves tho≈øe things which are hitherto in the ≈øick, according to nature, and tho≈øe things which can pre≈øerve the ≈øtrength of our body by them≈øelves, and are according to nature, are called vitall and Pre≈øervatory Indicates.

But ≈øince as above in the 4. Booke, part 2. Chap. 1. it is ≈øaid there are three vitall, or Pre≈øervatory Indicants, health, the cau≈øe of health, and ≈øound actions, as we are to endeavour, that in a ≈øound condition all the≈øe may be pre≈øerved, ≈øo it is to be aimed that as much as it is po≈ø≈øible they may be
kept in ≈øuch as are ≈øick, and this is to pre≈øerve ≈øtrength; namely to pre≈øerve the native heat, in the whole, and in all the parts, and the right u≈øe and ob≈øervation of things called non-naturalls.

Namely the ≈øtrength ≈øhews the Aliment, The ≈øtrength what it ≈øhews. in this re≈øpect becau≈øe 'tis placed in ≈øpirituous, ≈øolid, and fle≈øhy parts, having a ju≈øt quantity, and doth u≈øe them as an In≈øtrument; and the vitall Indication is bu≈øied only about keeping the ≈øub≈øtance of the ≈øpirituous, ≈øolld and fle≈øhy parts.

But although the ≈øtrength only Indicate Aliment, Things prohibiting. yet it may be prohibited from others, for oftentimes the giving of meate increa≈øeth the morbifique con≈øtitution, and al≈øo to regard this, that 'tis not to Indicate Aliment, but to prohibit it, for when meate is given nature is called away from concoction, and evacuation of morbifique matter, and therefore when the powers Indicate their pre≈øervation, which is performed by exhibiting nouri≈øhment in that quantity which the ≈øub≈øtance to be pre≈øerved wanteth, but the morbifique cau≈øe indicates its Evacuation, and therefore commands nature to be at lea≈øure for it ≈øelfe alone, and ≈øo prohibits Aliment, whereby nature would be called away, and hindred from its worke, you mu≈øt be carefull, what urgeth more.

In breife: ≈øtrength only Indicates Aliment; the morbifique cau≈øe permits, or probibits; the re≈øt, as age, cu≈øtome, Time of the year, the ≈øtate of Heaven, and ≈øuch like are the ≈øignes of firme ≈øtrength, or of weakne≈ø≈øe, or ≈øuch as may ≈øhew the force, and greatne≈ø≈øe of the morbifique cau≈øe.

div.head: CHAP. II. What things belongs to Dyet.
div.p:
ALthough Dyet con≈øi≈øts principally of meate and drink, Things prohibiting to Dyet. yet other things al≈øo called non-naturalls, as Aire, ≈øleep and watchings, exerci≈øe and re≈øt, and accidents of the mind, belong thereunto: but among≈øt the≈øe there are ≈øome things out of which primarily, and by them≈øelves Aliment is generated; ≈øuch is Aire, meate and drink, but others, are accounted among≈øt the matter of food, in this re≈øpect, not becau≈øe really out of tho≈øe as the matter, Aliment of the body is generated, but as they are the cau≈øes of Aliment by
accident, and helpe that tho≈øe things which are the true materialls of Aliments, may be more commodiou≈øly turned into Aliment: ≈øuch are ≈øleep, and watchings, exerci≈øes, and re≈øt, Repletion and Inanition, and pa≈ø≈øions of the mind, of which is ≈øpoken above in the 4. Book.

div.head: CHAP III. How many ≈øorts there are of Dyet, and which agrees to which di≈øea≈øes.
div.p: BUt Dyet is threefold, Dyet threefold, Thick. Indifferent. div.head: CHAP. II. Of the kinds of heate.
div.p: AS for what belongs to operations, The degrees of heate. and performances, ≈øince all Apothecaries what≈øoever have need of heat and fire, as being the mo≈øt common and u≈øefull In≈øtrument, fir≈øt let us treat of heare.

But in heate in the fir≈øt place, the degrees thereof are to be con≈øidered and the manners, of adding of fire; the degrees of heate in generall and ab≈øolutly are accounted foure; The Fir≈øt is that which appears plea≈øing and milde or gentle; the Second is that which is quicker and allmo≈øt not to be endured by the hand; the Third de≈øtroyes, the Fourth is the highe≈øt: but every of the≈øe degrees have a great latitude, and therefore not unde≈øervedly every degree may be divided againe into its degrees, in rightly ≈øhewing wherof much di≈øcretion is required, but for the mo≈øt part tis better to erre in defect, then in exce≈ø≈øe, for if any thing be once corrupted by the violence of the fire, it cannot be re≈øtored to its ≈øelfe againe, and oftentimes gla≈ø≈øes are corrupted, and other dangers are accumulated, but if there be any error in defect, by continnance and increafing the degree of heate, it may be recompenced, although the time of operation be prolonged.

But the degrees of heate may be made up divers wayes, How they may be varied. and depend on divers cau≈øes, the cheife whereof we will propound. For fir≈øt fire may be u≈øed divers wayes and manners, for ≈øometimes the matter with a fit ve≈ø≈øell, or without a ve≈ø≈øell, naked and open, is put to the fire, which again is done ≈øeverall wayes, for either it is circular, which in plaine incompa≈ø≈øeth the ve≈ø≈øells and is removed from a di≈øtant place by degrees neerer to the ve≈ø≈øell, untill at length, 'tis heaped up over the ve≈ø≈øell, or el≈øe the ve≈ø≈øells are put in a fit furnace or the fire is made above the ve≈ø≈øel Reverberatory, or ≈øtriking back when the flame is repercu≈ø≈øed by the cover, or doore of the furnace, it ≈øtrikes as it were the matter, and ≈øo it flyes round every way.

At other times the matter with its ve≈ø≈øell is not expo≈øed to the open fire, A dry Bath. but is ≈øetagain≈øt another body intervening, and that divers wayes; for fir≈øt, if a pot to put ≈øand or ≈øuch
like matter into, put on a ve≈ø≈øell ≈øtanding on a Trivet containing the matter to be prepared, be empty, tis mo≈øt conveniently called a dry Balneum or a dry Stupha, but if the ve≈ø≈øell be not empty, a various heate according to the variety of matter which is put in it, may be afforded, and may be called by ≈øeverall names; if it be filled with water and the ve≈ø≈øell together with the matter to be di≈øtilled, be ≈øet into the water; it is ≈øimply called Balneum Maris or Mariae; Balneum Maris. a Bath al≈øo may be prepared not only of water but of the ≈øaw-du≈øt of ≈øawed wood or Hay filling the ve≈ø≈øell and then moi≈øtning it, and ≈øo cover it with a gla≈ø≈øe, but if the ve≈ø≈øell with the matter to be elaborated be not ≈øet in water, but be ≈øo placed, that it may receive only the vapour of the heated water, it is called Balneum Vaporo≈øum, afterwards let the pot be filled with the du≈øt of Bricks, with Sand, Sawdu≈øt, the filings of Iron and ≈øuch like.

Secondly, the moderation or governing of the heate, depends on the ≈øtore of fuell, the quantity whereof in the kindled coales, the Arti≈øt can at plea≈øure abate or increa≈øe, or make it how he plea≈øe, and that either by the plenty or want of coales, or by the more free eventilation of Aire, and the ≈øhutting out interception of the ≈øame; for a greater quantity of coales make a greater and ≈øtronger heate, if they can by the fuming of the Aire, and by opening of breathing holes, be kindled, all which may be better ≈øhewne then de≈øcribed.

Thirdly, for the variation of the fire, the di≈øhes commonly called Cappellae do make it according to their various di≈øtance from the fier; for if they are moved neerer to the fier it is increa≈øed, but if further off, the heate is remitted.

div.p:

Heterogenialls, of pure from impure, of Profitable, from unprofitable, ≈øuch are fifting, wa≈øhing, infu≈øing, boyleing, ≈øtraining, fumeing, Clarifying, Filtring, Dige≈øtion, Expre≈ø≈øion, Di≈øtillation, Sublimation, Ex≈øiccation, Evaporation, Exhalation and Coagulation.

div.head: CHAP. V. Of the third manner of Operations.
div.p:
THe third forme comprehends tho≈øe operations which are appointed them, The third forme of operations. for alteration, immutation, and perfection of a thing, and aime at this, that a thing may be reduced to a better ≈øtate and more noble degree. But although ≈øome do reckon more ≈øuch operations, and perhaps there are more, yet in this place all of them are properly called by the name of Dige≈øtion, Dige≈øtion. and as it is di≈øtingui≈øhed from the two higher kinds of dige≈øtion, whereby a new quality of a thing newly elaborated, is introduced, ≈øo that if the thing containes any thing that is hurtfull, it puts away that, or if any thing is wanting to it, it begets that; and if there are any others to be here repeated, they ought to be accounted for certaine wayes of Dige≈øtion;
In≈øtitution Chap. 15. and 16. Circnlation. For all of them for the mo≈øt part, in the ≈øame manner by a gentle externall heat, exciting the internall force of a thing are performed, which here is the primary agent.

Hitherto belongs conditing, Conditing. pre≈øerving, and confecting; fruits, flowers, roots, are condited or pickled with Honey, Sugar, Vinegar, Salt, not onely that they may be pre≈øerved the longer, but that they may be the more plea≈øant to the ta≈øte.

div.head: THE FIFTH BOOK, PART III. SECT. III. Of the Formes of Medicines.
CHAP. I. The Divi≈øion of Medicines.
div.p: AFter we have fini≈øhed the operations nece≈ø≈øary for an Apothecary: The Divi≈øion of Medicines. It remaynes that we now come to the preperations them≈øelves of Medicines, which are perfected by tho≈øe operations. The differences of Medicines, are taken either from the ≈øub≈øtance or from the parts to which they are applyed. Medicines being con≈øidered the former of the≈øe wayes are, ≈øome full of Vapours, others Corpulent; Corpulent are either fluid, or having a con≈øi≈øtance, Fluid are various, as di≈øtilled waters, Spirits, Liquid tinctures, Vineger, Medicinal wine, Hydromel or Hony and Water, clarifies Juyces, Oyles, Emul≈øions, Decoctions, Infu≈øions, Julebs, Syrrups, Baths, Cly≈øtets, &c. Again tho≈øe that have a con≈øi≈øtance, ≈øome of them are actually moy≈øt, others dry; Of the former ≈øort are Con≈øerves, Electuaries, Eclegmas, Juices, Extracts, Boles, Mu≈øcillages, Fat Lineaments, Bal≈øomes, Unguents, Catapla≈ømes: Tho≈øe that are actually dry, are either continuous, and the parts cohaere together, or el≈øe they are di≈øcontinued. Of the former kind are, Pills, Troches, Rotule ‚Ä¢ , Mor≈øels, Plai≈øters, Cerates, Suppo≈øiters, Gla≈ø≈øes, Regulus, and certain things ≈øublimed: Of the latter ≈øort are, ≈øeveral Species and Powders, Meal or brann, Flowers, & things praecipitated.

But in re≈øpect of the parts to which they are applyed, ≈øome are called internal, Internal. others external. The internal are tho≈øe which are taken into the body that common and u≈øual way as we take in meat and drink, all the re≈øt whether they are applyed to the body, or ≈øpread over the body, or any other way applyed to the bodie ‚Ä¢ , or if they are ca≈øt into the body any other way, External. as, at the fundament, ears, no≈øtrils, wombe, we call them externals.

The formes of Internal Medicines are various; The difference of internal Medicines. for ≈øome are fluid, others not fluid, and the≈øe are either ≈øoft and liquid, or altogether dry, The fluid are, Decoctions, Infu≈øions, Medicinal VVines, Honey and VVater mixt and boiled together, wine mingled with honey, vineger, and honey, and barleywater, Juices, di≈øtilled waters, Spirits, tinctures, and Liquid extracts, Oils, Sirups, Julips, Emul≈øions; Soft and not fluid are, Extracts, Con≈øerves, Pre≈øerves, Medicinal Juices thickned, Electuaries, Eclegmaes, or Medicines to be licked or ≈øupt, Boles, Not fluid, and plainly dry are, powders, Sweet meats, Salts; Saffron-flowers, Precipitates, Comfits, little round Cakes, Mor≈øels, or little ≈ønips, march-paines, And tho≈øe which belong to the≈øe, as Troches, and Pills.

But externals are either ≈øent into certain parts of the bodie, Of Exterternal. or they are only applyed, or exhibited to the ≈øuperficies of the bodie, or they are only hung about, as Ammulets, and Periapticke medicines, or medicines to hang about ones bodie; Suppo≈øiters and Cly≈øters are injected, and ca≈øt into the body; Cly≈øters, and pe≈ø≈øaries, are al≈øo injected into the womb, al≈øo certain Liquours are injected into the yard and bladder; into the mouth are put gargari≈ømes, to wa≈øh the mouth, or throat with, Apophlegmati≈ømes to draw away Phlegme, Dentifrices to rub and clean≈øe the Teeth, To the no≈øe Erhines, Sneezing-wort; Odours, Suffumigations, peculiar injections into the Ears, Collyries, or medicines, applyed to the eyes. To the out≈øide of the bodie only are exhibited, and applyed, oiles, bal≈øomes, ointments, linements, cerots, plai≈øters, Catapla≈ømes, Dropa≈øes, or ointments to take away hair, Sinapi≈ømes, Phaenigmaes, or medicines cau≈øing the bodie to break out in bli≈øters, or Pu≈øtules, Epithems, or medicines ≈øome what ≈øofter then plai≈øters to be applied to the bodie, fomentations, or any thing applied plai≈øter-waies to a≈øwage pain, little baggs, powders, embrocations, wa≈øhings of the extream parts, baths, wa≈øhbals, ≈øearing irons or cauteties.
Externally waters, and Collyries, ointments, fomentations, unguents, catapla≈ømes, are convenient for the eyes.

Into the ears di≈øtilled waters, Juices, decoctions, oiles, and other liquours are infu≈øed and dropt, and other Medicines in the form of evaporation, and fumes are ≈øent into the ears, al≈øo liniments, ointments, fomentations, epithemes, Catapla≈ømes are applied.

For the teeth are convenient, lotions for the mouth, To the Teeth. liniments, ≈ømall pills to be put into hollow Teeth, unctions for the Jawes, powders for rubbing the Teeth, and al≈øo troches, and pen≈øills made in the form of ≈øuppo≈øiters are convenient for the Teeth, and being dryed, and hardned, the Teeth are rubbed therewith.
Medicines applied to the mouth, and Chopps are lotions, For the mouth and Chopps. For the Brea≈øt. and gargari≈øines, ointments made of hony, of ≈øyrups and juices, lohocks.

Mo≈øt internal things are good for the Brea≈øt, but e≈øpecially, lohocks, troches, and litle rolles, ≈øuch as they u≈øe to hold under their tongues, the thicker ≈øort of ≈øyrups, vapours, and fumes drawn in with aier, externally, the ≈øamemedicines may be applied in the form of oiles, ointments, unguents, catapla≈ømes, plai≈øters and cerots, little baggs, fomentations, and epithemes.
Medicines are applied to the Heart, To the Heart. for the mo≈øt part after the ≈øame manner, and moreover fumes, or ≈øteames, which are profitable for the recreating and refre≈øhing of the ≈øpirits.

Internal Medicines may be conveyed to the Stomack in all formes, To the Stomack. but principally tho≈øe which are taken in at the mouth, but externally, in the form of oils, unctions, fomentations, liniments, unguents, catapla≈ømes, plai≈øters, epithemes, baggs.

Moreover, To the Liver. all internall things may penetrate to the Liver. But externall in the forme of Ointments, Fomentations, Linements, Catapla≈ømes, Unguents, Plai≈øters, little bags, Epithems, are applyed.

In the ≈øame manner Unctions are exhibited to the Spleen, To the Spleen Reiues and Bladder. and Bladder; Bathes al≈øo, and Tubs of waters to fit in, are u≈øefull for the Reins, Bladder and ≈øpermatick Ve≈ø≈øells; and Cly≈øters injected are good for di≈øea≈øes of the Reines.
All the ≈øame things are convenient for the wombe, and moreover injections into the wombe, Pe≈ø≈øaries, Errhines or medicines to put into the no≈øe, fumes, and Evaporations, Lotions of the feet.
And all the≈øe ≈øorts of medicines ≈øhall now be explained in their order, as far forth as this compendium will admit of.

div.head: CHAP. II. Of Decoctions.
div.p: DEcoctions which the Greeks call Apozemes, are potulent medicines prepared by the boyling of plants and of their parts, Decoctions what. How many fold. are potulent medicines prepared by the boyling of plants and of their parts, ≈øeldome of Animalls; all Decoctions may conveniently be reduced into two formes; namely into Decoctions altering, and purging; under Decoctions altering, we will comprehend all tho≈øe that have any other verrue be≈øides purging, and do alter the body, whether they are given in regard of them≈øelves only, or for ≈øome following purge; which Decoctions are then called Preparatives, Dige≈øtives, or Apperatives, that is opening things.
But the matter to be decocted is taken out of the rank of Vegetables, The matter of them. wherein are variety of parts of plants or herbs, ≈øeldome of living Creatures.

But as for the quantity of the materialls to be decocted, Quantity. if a weight be to be a≈ø≈øigned generally to what ever is to be boyled, it begins from an ounce or two ounces for the mo≈øt part, and a≈øcends ≈øometimes to halfe a pound, nay ≈øometimes to a pound, a pound and halfe, and two pound, but as for the do≈øe of the ≈øeveral kinds Decoctions are prepared.
Of the Roots and Barks ‚Ñ•2. ‚Ñ•3. and ‚Ñ•4.
Of Leaves, 3.4.5. or 6. handfulls.
Of ≈øeeds 3.4.5.6. drachms
Of Fruires, in number 1.2.3. couples or paires 5.6.
Of flowers, pugills 4. or 5.

Halfe an ounce, five drachms or ≈øix drachms an≈øwers to a little handfull, two drachms or three to a pugill, but it is not nece≈ø≈øary to mixe all tho≈øe together in every decoction, and to heape up a mixture of them all, but when a few will performe the intentions, tis in vaine to put in many, yet if the decoction be provided to be given at many ≈øeverall times, ≈øuch a quantity of materialls ought to be taken, as that the decoction made of them may be powerfull to performe the aime of the Phy≈øitian.

But in the ≈øeething, Preparation of the matter. Or of boyling. the preparation of the things to be boyled, and the manner of ≈øeething, is to be ob≈øerved, for fir≈øt if the materialls are too thick or hard, they are fir≈øt to be cut or gently brui≈øed, or fyled or beaten in a mortar.
In the manner of ≈øeething, order is to be ob≈øerved in putting in the things to be decocted the fire and in≈øtruments and Liquor which is decocted; and time al≈øo is to be ob≈øerved.

Order of boyling is to be ob≈øerved, that all the things may not be put in together, but the Roots, Barkes, Woods, which are the more ≈øollid things, and without ≈ømell, ≈øhould be put in fir≈øt, then the Leaves, and ≈øeeds, la≈øt of all flowers, and Aromatick things, and all tho≈øe things which ≈ømell ≈øtrongly, and tho≈øe things which may di≈øper≈øe their ≈øtrength by much boyling; but this cannot be ob≈øerved except the ve≈ø≈øell be opened, but if the decoction be made in a thing that is covered, it matters not much to put in all the things altogether, and if any of them are more difficult to be ≈øeethed, tho≈øe ≈øhould fir≈øt of all be brui≈øed by them≈øelves.
The fire ≈øhould be cleare and equall, but very gentle, ≈øince the vertue is ea≈øily called forth, but ≈øtronger when there is need of much boyleing.

But decoctions are made by the Apothecaries commonly when the ve≈ø≈øell is open and the fire al≈øo, but tis more convenient, lea≈øt the ≈øtrength of the medicines ≈øhould vani≈øh in boyling, to make a decoction in a Biploma, as they call it or a double ve≈ø≈øell, the ve≈ø≈øell being ≈øhut, or if a decoction be made the fire being open, tis convenient to ≈øet on it a clo≈øe Alembick, or if it hath a beake, o ‚Ä¢ ≈ønout, to fit it with a receiver to take the liquor, and to mixe it with the ≈øtrained decoction.

The Liquor in which the things are boyled ought to be ≈øuch as may performe the intentions of the Phy≈øiti ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ , Liquor for the De coction. as water of the Fountaine, di≈øtilled water, Barly-water, Chaly-beate, Water, Whey, water mixt with Honey called Hydromell, ≈øometimes Wine is taken, ≈øeldome ≈øtrong Beere is u≈øed, ≈øometimes ≈øome Vineger is put in, that the vi≈øcid and tough humours may more powerfully be cut thereby, and the medicine may penetrate the more; ≈øometimes Roots alone, before the decoction is made, are brayed in Vineger. Di≈øtilled waters al≈øo are often u≈øed for decoctions with no great profit but with great charge, unle≈ø≈øe the decoction be made in a clo≈øe ve≈ø≈øell, ≈øince ≈øo long boyling takes away all their ≈øtrength.

The quantity of the Liquor ought to be ≈øuch as may ≈øatisfie for the decoction, The quantity of Liquor. and ought to cover the medicines three or foure fingers breadth; which for the mo≈øt part is left to the di≈øcretion of the Apothecarie. But if the proportion be appointed by the Phy≈øitian, the Liquor is for the mo≈øt part foure-fold, ≈øix-fold, eight-fold, in proportion to the medicines, according as the Herbs are dry, or full of juice, thick, or thin, and may imbibe more or le≈ø≈øe of the Liquor, and they ought to ≈øeeth a little, or long.
Sometimes before boyling, the medicines are ≈øomewhat cut, or brui≈øed, and ≈øometimes they ≈øtand a while (after decoction) before they are ≈øtrained.

But they are boyled to the con≈øumption of halfe or of a third part, or of a fourth part only of Liquor, or till but a third part remaines, according as the medicines and the ≈øcope of the Phy≈øitian requires: for tho≈øe who≈øe vertue ea≈øily vani≈øh and are in a thin, and ≈øeperable ≈øub≈øtance are to be boyled the le≈ø≈øe time: but tho≈øe who≈øe ≈øub≈øtances are thicker, the ≈øtrength cannot be drawn forth without longer boyling, the decoction is ≈øtrained with, or without ≈øqueazing, according as there is need of the thinner parts only, or thicker, and ≈øuch as lye deeper.

A decoction is prepared either for one do≈øe or more; for one, three, four, or five ounces may ≈øuffice, if for more, the decoction ≈øhould be made that the remainder may be a Pint, or a Pint and an half, and afterwards of things making it plea≈øant, for one Do≈øe an Ounce, or an Ounce and an half may be added, yet more than a Pint, or a Pint and an half of a decoction, at one time, is ≈øeldom made, (except the decoction of Guiacum and ≈øuch like) ≈øince that if more
≈øhould be prepared, it would ea≈øily be ≈øpoiled before it would be taken by the ≈øick; Unto three four or five ounces of the decoction ≈øtrained are added, of Sugar, which often is ‚Ä¢ u≈øed or Honey, ≈øix drachms, or an ounce, or of ≈øome convenient Syrup in every do≈øe an ounce, or an ounce and halfe: Sometimes the juices that are mo≈øt convenient of Herbs, or Fruits, and often other Liquors, as Aqua vitae, Spirit of Vitrioyle, Copper, Salt-peter, ≈øome drops thereof are added, and indeed only one of the≈øe is added ≈øometimes to an Apozeme, but of lenitives more, as more Syrups, or juices & Syrups, or of juice and Sugar, when juices are adminii≈øtred, for the mo≈øt part; Sugar or Syrup is mixed with them, and ≈øometimes plea≈øant things; that they may be the better mingled, a gentle ebullition is appointed at a weak fire; if it be convenient, the white of an egg may be added, that the Sugar and Honey, and decoction al≈øo may be clarifyed; or if that clarification doth not ≈øuffice, the decoction is to be put into the Balneum Mariae, till the thick dregs ≈øettle in the bottome, and they by ≈øetling in the bottome, and powring off of the cleare Liquor are ≈øeperated, and that is to be repeated ≈øometimes if it be needfull; ≈øometimes the decoction is to be made plea≈øant either for the acquiring of a good ta≈øte, or ≈ømell, or ≈øome other vertue, namely the Aromaticks a little before the end of boyling being reduced into into powder, or Aromatick ≈øpecies fitted for the di≈øea≈øe, halfe a drachm, or a drachm thereof in each pint, is to be hung in a thin skin, or bladder in the decoction, and are often pre≈ø≈øed out, or el≈øe a little after, the decoction is removed from the fire, the decoction being as yet hot, they may be cut, or brui≈øed more gro≈ø≈øely, and ≈øo injected, and after they have ≈øtood together ≈øome time in a ve≈ø≈øell well covered, it is ≈øtrained againe. Muske al≈øo, and Ambergreaze, if it be convenient, may be al≈øo given to the do≈øe of a graine of each; or a drachm or two of Cinamon water may be added. If Wine or Vinegar be nece≈ø≈øary, tis more convenient to add them after the boyling, or a little before they have done boyling.

Hereunto belong re≈øtorative Broathes as they call them, Re≈øtorative broaths. which are made of Hens, or Capons, to which Veale, or Goates fle≈øh may be added, and there are of three ≈øorts; the fir≈øt they call a compleat, Jus Con≈øum matum. or a perfect bro ‚Ä¢ th, becau≈øe 'tis mo≈øt ab≈øolute, and fitte≈øt to nouri≈øh: it is prepared as ordinary broathes are, only that they boyle longer, and indeed ≈øo long untill the ≈øixth, eighth, or ≈øometimes the tenth part only remaines; Gelatina. the ≈øecond is called Gelatina, which is made if the≈øe meates are boyled in a double ve≈ø≈øell without powring off the water, and the juice is pre≈ø≈øed out from thence, from which after it is cooled, the fat ≈øwimming on the top is to be ≈øcummed off: Contu≈øum. the third is called Contu≈øum which is prepared when the meates fir≈øt ≈øodden or ro≈øted, afterwards are beaten in a morter, ≈øo long untill they may melt when broath is put to them, and afterwards are ≈øtrained.

div.head: Purging Decoctions.
div.p: PUrging decoctions differ not from other decoctions, The manner of prepuring purging of decoctions. unle≈ø≈øe in re≈øpect of materialls; namely that ≈øimple purging medicines are mingled in purging decoctions, the manner of preparing is the ≈øame: for purging medicines convenient for the evacuation of the humours are taken, and that for one and more do≈øes, yet becau≈øe in ≈øeething their ≈øtrength will decay, or wa≈øte they ought to be taken in a greater do≈øe, then in the ≈øub≈øtance, the ≈øtronge≈øt for the mo≈øt part double, but of the milder purgers, four-fold. div.head: CHAP III. Of Infu≈øions and other purging Potions.
div.p: INfu≈øions are next unto decoctions, Infu≈øions. and differ only from decoctions ≈øimply ≈øo called, in that they are wont to be prepared only by boyling without macerating them before hand: but the≈øe are when the medicines are broken, or beaten before, and put into a convenient Liquor for ≈øome certain time that they may leave their vertue in it The m ‚Ä¢ nner of preparing.

They are prepared of medicines of all ≈øorts, but mo≈øt commonly of Purgers, which ≈øhould be given in ≈øomewhat a greater weight, then in the ≈øub≈øtance, namely halfe ≈øo much in the ≈øub≈øtance, and double in the Infu≈øion, with their correcters and directers being ca≈øt in al≈øo in a due quantity, (≈øometimes in a nodule or little bagg of fine linnen, ≈øhut) in a Liquor convenient for the purpo≈øe of the Phy≈øitian: the Chymi≈øts at this day, that the extract
may be made the ea≈øier, put to the men≈øtruum or prepared matter ≈øome drops or ≈øpirit of Salt of Vitrioll, or Oyle of Vitrioll is added, which is made by draining, which they call per deliquium.

The quantity of the Liquor ought to be ≈øuch as may cover tho≈øe things that are macerated, and may be ≈øomething higer then they, being infu≈øed in this manner, fix, twelve, or twenty foure hours in a warme ve≈ø≈øell ≈øtopt or ≈øhut, they being beaten or cut in peices ≈øhould ≈øo long lye in it untill the Liquor hath extracted all their ≈øtrength, which may be known by the ta≈øte and ≈ømell. But if, which often happens, there be urgent occa≈øion, the medicines cannot be macerated for want of time, that defect may be ≈øupplyed by gentle boyling of them, afterwards that which is ≈øtrained with or without ≈øqueazing is appointed for u≈øe, and indeed without ≈øqueazing or pre≈ø≈øing that which is ≈øtrained is more clean≈øing and plea≈øing to the ta≈øte, but weaker: but with expre≈ø≈øion tis more troubled and thicker, but more efficacious.
You may add to the infu≈øion things that ≈øweeten it or other purging things as tis ≈øaid before of decoctions.

Sometimes Decoctions, and Infu≈øions are given together; namely a Decoction is prepared in the ≈øame manner as is ≈øaid before. In a ≈øufficient quantity of that decection are infu≈øed purgers with their correcters, and the re≈øt of the things are afterwards mixt as in other infu≈øions.

Another way al≈øo a Potion is made of in≈øu≈øion and decoction mixt, or an infu≈øion with a decoction, namely the decoction is prepared by its ≈øelfe, and the in≈øu≈øion by it ≈øelfe, both of them according to the method formerly de≈øcribed, and the≈øe two Liquors are afterward mingled together.

To the≈øe purging decoctions, A purging Potion. The menner. and infu≈øions, by rea≈øon of their fimilitude we add a purging Potion peculiarly ≈øo called by ≈øome, which is prepared in this manner, fir≈øt a ≈øufficient quantity is taken of any ≈øort of Liquor, decoction, di≈øtilled water, Whey, water and Honey mixt, Broath, Wine, Juleps of Violets, ≈øufficient for a draught, namely two 3. or 4. ounces, in the Liquor a ≈øufficient quantity of Ca≈ø≈øia, Manna, or a ≈øufficient quantity of any one purging electuary, or more, is to be di≈ø≈øolved for one do≈øe; ≈øometimes of ≈øome Syrup half an ounce, or 6. drachms, or ≈øome of the Aromatick powders are added, and the≈øe potions are taken as the re≈øt, which we have ≈øpoken of heretofore, hot in the morning fa≈øting.

2. Secondly, as tis ≈øpoken of pu ‚Ä¢ ging things, ≈øo here al≈øo ≈øtraining, and Clarifying may be appointed, but then the electuaries are to be taken in a greater quantity, then if they are given without ≈øtraining.
