Thirdly, purging Potions may be prepared of purging extracts, but ≈øeeing that extracts are wont to be given in a ≈ømaller do≈øe, they require le≈ø≈øe quantity of Liquor, and th ‚Ä¢ rfore are more gratefull to the affected: ≈øometimes two or three ounces of other Liquors are taken in≈øtead of Muskadine, and the extract is di≈ø≈øolved in them, and if there be danger of being too hot, ≈øome Sorrell, or Lemons, or ≈øome other convenient things may be added.

4. La≈øtly, purging Potions are prepared of powders as well ≈øimples, as of compound purging medicines, as al≈øo with purging Roles, but the do≈øe of ≈øuch powders, ought not to be much more then a drachm, otherwi≈øe the Potion will be too thick, and ungratefull: and ≈øometimes ≈øome powder is mingled with di≈ø≈øolved electuaries.
In the ≈øame manner al≈øo, Potions and infu≈øions for vomits. Infu≈øions and Potions for vomits, ≈øweates, and medicines provoking of Urine may be prepared.

div.head: CHAP. IV. Of Medicinal Wines, drinks of honey and Water ≈øodden together, of Wine mingled with Honey, of Oxymel, of Medicinal Vinegar, Decoction or Barley-water, al≈øo of Clarified Juices.
div.p: OUT of tho≈øe things which have bin hitherto ≈øpoken of Infu≈øions and Decoctions, Medicinall wines. it will ea≈øily appear how medicinal wines are prepared, and they are either altering, ‚Ä¢ r purging and altering together.

They are prepared, either of Mu≈øt; or of Wine that is re
‚Ä¢ ined, tho≈øe that are prepared of Mu≈øt, have a more plea
‚Ä¢ ant ta≈øte, and they are thus done; The dry Medicines are ‚Ä¢ ut into little woodden Caskes; when the Mu≈øt is ≈øome
‚Ä¢ hat abated, and the Wine clean≈øed, and made clear, it ≈øhould ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ e drawn out into another Ve≈ø≈øel, and kept for your u≈øe.

In the ≈øame manner Phy≈øical drink may be prepared, Ph ‚Ä¢ ≈øica ‚Ä¢ l ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ nkes. of
Wormwood, Harts tongue, Bittony, Sage, Ro≈øemary, and other herbs, and al≈øo of purging things: but for the mo≈øt part, the herbs are fir≈øt brui≈øed in the drink, after tis brewed, being as yet warm, and afterwards in due ≈øea≈øon things to make it work, being put in, they are ≈øuffered to cool.

Of Wines ≈øo clean≈øed, Medicinal Wines are prepared; Dry medicines are clean≈øed, cut, and broken, and are put into a gla≈ø≈øe, or earthen Ve≈ø≈øel, ≈øometimes into a Nodule, or little Bagge of fine linnen, or thin linnen ≈øewed up; a ≈øufficient quantity of good white Wine is powred in, ≈øo they ≈øtand in infu≈øion, in a Ve≈ø≈øel that is ≈øhut, afterwards ≈øtrained, unle≈ø≈øe they are inclo≈øed in a little Bagge.

But this proportion for the mo≈øt part is ob≈øerved, that to a pound of medicines, there is taken of Mu≈øt, or Wine eight Pints, twelve, nay, to twenty five, nay thirty, or thirty ≈øix, ≈øo that an ounce may an≈øwer to the proportion of two or three Pints.

Medicinall Wines al≈øo that alter, are prepared if di≈øtilled Oyles are added to them being fir≈øt mixt with Sugar, or Spirits, or tinctures, ≈øpirit of Wine drawne out of ≈øimple medicines, or moi≈øt extracts.

Sometimes medicinall Wines are ≈øweetned with Sugar or Honey, Claretum. and are called Clare ‚Ä¢ s, and Hippocratick Wine, they are profitable in cold durable di≈øea≈øes, they a ‚Ä¢ e made in this manner: Aromatick things or roots al≈øo and ≈øeeds gratefull to the ≈ømell and ta≈øte, principally are gro≈øely beaten, or cut, and ≈øuch as have great efficacy, are infu≈øed in ≈øweet Wine, ≈øo they are to ≈øtand ≈øometime in the Infu≈øion, in a warme place for ≈øome hours, or let them ≈øimper in Balmum Mariae, for halfe an houre, e≈øpecially if you may accelerate the worke, or to prepare Wine mingled with Honey; afterwards there is added a ≈øufficient quantity of Sugar to make it plea≈øant to the ta≈øte, ≈øo that to two, three or ≈øoure parts of Wine, one part of Sugar may be taken, and oftentimes Wine is drained through Hippocrates ≈øleeve, that it may become cleare, ≈øome of the di≈øtilled waters that are convenient, may be mixt with the Wine.

Some infu≈øe the Aromaticks in ≈øpirit of wine, about eight or ten parts whereof is u≈øed to one part of the Aromaticks, and when the ≈øpirit of wine hath drawne out the tincture, they ≈øeperate it by declination, and ≈øtraining or filtring, and keepe it for their u≈øe, but when tis convenient to make Hippocraticall wine, they power ≈øome drachms, and withal ‚Ä¢
an ounce or two ounces, to one mea≈øure of Wine, a ≈øufficient quantity of Sugar to ≈øweeten it.

But ≈øuch Wines and Clarets, may be prepared not only to alter, but al≈øo to purge, with the ≈øame do≈øe for the more choice ≈øort of per≈øons, namely with purgers, principally the Leaves of Sena, Mecoacam, Agrick, Turbith, with their „Äà‚óä„Äâ recters are put into a ≈øufficient quantity of Rheni≈øh Wine, and being heated in water luke-warme in a gla≈ø≈øe afterwards mu≈øt ≈øtand in a warme place, ≈øix hours in Infu≈øion, afterwards add of Julep of Violets, or Ro≈øes hal≈øe an ounce, or let them be ≈øweetned with halfe an ounce of white Sugar and be ≈øtrained, and filtred through a browne paper, let three ounces of that which is ≈øtrained be perfumed with two drops of Oyle of Cinamon; Manna al≈øo may be taken in≈øtead of Sugar.

If the Wine be ≈øweerned with Honey in≈øtead of Sugar, Wine mingled with Honey. tis called Oinomell. Mul≈øum, or wine mingled with Honey, is prepared of one part of Honey, and two or three parts of Wine mixt and boyled together: and Aromaticks of every ≈øort may be added, and it may be prepared at the time of gathering of Grapes, namely if one part of Honey be taken and two of Mu≈øt: of water if it be convenient three parts or five parts in quantity, and let them heate together.

Hydromell, and Mul≈øum, and Melicratum, Hydromell. Mul≈øum. Melieratum. are names of medicinall Potions of the ≈øame nature, namely made of water, and Honey, and ≈øometimes of other things boyled therewith, or if there be any difference among≈øt tho≈øe, 'tis only in comeline≈ø≈øe, for Melicratum is made ≈øuddenly for pre≈øent u≈øe of a mixture of Honey and water; but Hydromell is prepared to keep longer, and is neater made; of Mul≈øum ≈øome is more clean≈øeing, others purer, ≈øo that there is a ≈øeverall proportion of Honey to the water, according to the various ≈øcope of the Phy≈øitian, and temperature of him that takes it. To prepare it eight, ten or twelve times the quantity of Fountaine water is to be taken: but this is made of one part of Honey and five or ≈øix of water, boyled till the fourth or fifth part be con≈øumed.
Among≈øt the kindes of Mul≈øum, which can keepe, Meade. the mo≈øt noted at this day, is that drinke which is called Meade, and the be≈øt indeed is prepared in Li ‚Ä¢ uania.

But Hydromell is prepared not only of water and Honey but al≈øo of ≈øeverall Aromaticks, Herbs and Rootes, as
Clary, Hy≈øop, Bettony, and others, both kindes are made, that which is for pre≈øent u≈øe, and that which is more durable, and will keepe longer, it is prepared for pre≈øent u≈øe, if in a pint of the water of Plates, a drachm, or at mo≈øt two drachms are boyled, the 10th. or 12th. part of the be≈øt ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ ney be added, to every pint of the decoction. Hydromell is made after the u≈øuall manner: But ≈øometimes Hydromell is compounded, when the ≈øimple Hydromell is ≈øented with the≈øe only, although no other thing be boyled in it.
Be≈øides the compound Hydromell which doth alter, a purging Hydromell is al≈øo prepared, which is nothing el≈øe but a purging decoction made with ≈øimple Hydromell.

The next to Mul≈øum, Oxymell. is Oxymell, which differs from it, only by the mixture of Vinegar, a drinke very u≈øuall among≈øt the Ancients; but the old Phy≈øitians did not make Oxymell alike, but ≈øeverally and added Vinegar according to the nature of a di≈øea≈øe and of the di≈øea≈øed and other circum≈øtances, and they gave it not only mingled with other medicines, but alone to quench thir≈øt, and other purpo≈øes to drinke, but that which is mo≈øt clean≈øing, and may al≈øo be u≈øed in feavers was made of twelve parts of water two of Honey and one of Vinegar; they were gently boyled and ≈øcummed, and the fire not being fierce, and by the addition of the white of an egg were clarified, and afterwards ≈øtrained through a woollen cloath, till it become cleare and pure.
There are prepared by the Phy≈øitians other kindes of Oxymells compounded of more medicines; ≈øuch is the Oxymell Helleborated of Ge≈øner or rather of Iulian.

To this head we referr the water, Barly water. or decoction of Barly which is made of whole Barley boyled in the water till it comes to a Pti≈øan, and ≈øome is ≈øimple when nothing is boyled be≈øides Barley; another is compound when certaine other things al≈øo are added to the Barley, namely Rai≈øons, Licori≈øh, Anni-≈øeed, Fennell-≈øeed, Cinamon, Sugar: of Licori≈ø ‚Ä¢ is added, from two drachms to half an ounce or ≈øix drachms, Rai≈øons from an ounce to two ounces of ≈øuch as are ≈øtoned, halfe or a whole drachm, Cinamon to one drachm, or 2. drachms, for a pint and halfe or z, pints of Liquor.

Sometimes a ≈øowre medicine is prepared, Medicinall Vinegar. as with Squills, Ro≈øes, the rindes of Scordium, the Flowres of Elder and many others, and not only of one, but more ≈øimples by infu≈øion and materation of them in the ≈øame manner, as in medicinall wines.

Moreover to this Head we may refer clarified juices, Clarified juices. which being pre≈ø≈øed out of new gathered Plants are purified, either by the white of an Egg, or by ≈øtraining, often repeated, principally by filtring, or by ≈øeparation.

div.head: CHAP. V. Of di≈øtilled Waters and Spirits.
div.p: THo≈øe things which are prepared by di≈øtillation are called di≈øtilled things, which are of divers kindes, Things di≈øtilled. yet all of them may be reduced to two formes, for either the things di≈øtilled are in the forme of waters, or Oyles; Water. tho≈øe that are of the ≈øame con≈øi≈øtence with water are again two-fold, for either they come neere the nature of water, and are plainly called waters, or el≈øe they are ≈øpirituous, Spirits. and are called Spirits, yet the≈øe names are often confounded, for oftentimes that which is ≈øpirituous is called a water.

1. Fir≈øt di≈øtilled waters are prepared of divers things: Manner of di≈øtilled waters. of herbs and Flowers, all for the mo≈øt part are di≈øtilled by a≈øcent; and principally of fragrant flowers, and other thinner and colder things, who≈øe force ea≈øily vani≈øheth, for the mo≈øt part, waters good enough are di≈øtilled in a crooked gla≈ø≈øe, by the Balneum Mariae.

2. Others brui≈øe the flowers, and herbs that are to be di≈øtilled, and pre≈ø≈øe the juice out of them, and out of that juice by di≈øtillation through an Alembick they draw out water into the Balneum Mariae.

Some cut in ≈ømall peices the Plants to be di≈øtilled, or brui≈øe them, and being brui≈øed they they fill the Gourd having a narrow mouth all mo≈øt full, and the patelli the gla≈ø≈øes being put on with the powder of the gla≈ø≈øe of Copper and borax Hermeticall, they ≈øhut and afterwards they put the gla≈ø≈øe ful of water into a Cauldron, and boyle it ≈øix or ≈øeven hours, afterwards they put the gla≈ø≈øe when tis taken out of the water, into a warme place to clean≈øe it, untill the drops cea≈øe to ≈øtick to the ≈øides of the gl ‚Ä¢ ≈ø≈øe, and the dige≈øtion be ab≈øolute: they di≈øtill the matter dige≈øted in Balneo Roris, they ≈øeperate the Oyle from the water they power out the water with the reliques againe and repeate the di≈øtillation.

4. But the hotter, and Aromatick Herbs, and tho≈øe who≈øe ≈øtrength doe not ≈øo ea≈øily vani≈øh and lyes deeper, are not ≈øo conveniently di≈øtilled by Balneum Mariae, but in ve≈øica, but in this di≈øtillation by a ve≈ø≈øell of water, ≈øome diver≈øity al≈øo is ob≈øerved, for ≈øome brui≈øe the herbs, or cut them into ≈ømal peices, and fill the fourth part of the Ve≈øica be≈øides for them, then they poure of the pure water that three parts of the Ve≈øica may be filled therewith, and one quarter for the mo≈øt part remaines empty, and a Refrigeratory ve≈ø≈øell, being applyed and the worme al≈øo (if you de≈øire meerely a ≈øpirituous water) or with an Alembick with a Refrigitory, and their conjunctions or joynts ≈øhut, and a convenient fire being kindled and placed under the Ve≈øica they di≈øtill water gently and by drops.

5. Others having powred in hot water into a ve≈ø≈øell clo≈øe ≈øhut, fir≈øt they brui≈øe the herbs, twenty foure hours for the mo≈øt part, they think it mo≈øt profitable if the herbs are not only macerated in warme water a day and night ≈øpace, but being brui≈øed, or beaten, they ≈øhould ≈øtand in dige≈øtion, and putrifaction in Hor≈øe dung, or Balneo Roris, or Mariae, for ten or fourteen dayes, afterwards they ≈øhould be di≈øtilled. That water which fir≈øt drops out is the be≈øt: but that which comes out la≈øt is like water it ≈øelfe; di≈øtilled water, if it be convenient, may be poured off, with new herbs to be dige≈øted, and di≈øtilled againe.

6. But ≈øince that water and ≈øpirit a≈øcend together, they mu≈øt be ≈øeperated, which is mo≈øt conveniently done by the Balneum, namely all the water is to be powred into a crooked gla≈ø≈øe or Violl, and by a gentle heat only the ≈øpirituous part is to be di≈øtilled, by which di≈øtillation if the heat be rightly governed, the ≈øeparation happily may be made at once, yet if it ≈øhall not ≈øo happen the fir≈øt time, the di≈øtillation is to be repeated, and that rectification which was fir≈øt made by a Gourd, afterwards rectification is appointed by a Phyoll. Examples may be ≈øeene in the In≈øtitutions.

div.head: CHAP. VI. Of Oyles.
div.p:
FOr the mo≈øt part it comes to pa≈ø≈øe that with the water in di≈øtillation of hot herbs, Oyles. and Aromatick ≈øeeds, Oyle
comes forth together, which is to be ≈øeperated from the water; but this is performed fir≈øt by a kind of tunnell which they call a Separater or Tritorium, afterwards through a filter or a cour≈øe woollen cloath, thirdly through browne paper: the Precepts of which operations are to be ≈øought out of the In≈øtitutions.
Yet certaine Oyles are di≈øtilled al≈øo without waters; ≈øo Oyles are drawn by di≈øtillation from Amber, Ma≈øtick, Frankin≈øen≈øe; Of which in the In≈øtitutions.

div.head: CHAP VII Of Syrups and Juleps.
div.p: SYrups, and Seraps, The name of Syrups. derive their names from the Arabicks, and therefore are not to be written with a ‚Ä¢ y, which the Arabicks want, and 'tis drawne from the roote Schareba, which ≈øignifies to ≈øup, and therefore it ≈øignifies a Liquor to be Supt; Syrups therefore are fluid medicines prepared of a convenient Liquor, whether it be boyled, or infu≈øed, or a juice made up with Sugar or Honey, and boyled for the mo≈øt part to the con≈øi≈øtence of Honey: Syrups are invented both for delight to the ta≈øte, and for durability, that convenient medicines may be in a readine≈ø≈øe at any time of the yeare.

Some of them are ≈øimple, Differences. which are made of one ≈øimple medicine only, and with Sugar, or Honey; compound which are prepared of more; both kindes are appointed for ≈øeverall u≈øes, of them are ≈øome altering and ≈øtrengthning, others purging, and the liquour is taken from decoctions, infu≈øions, clarified juices and Vinegar.

This is the manner of preparing, Manner of preparing Syrups. Fir≈øt the decoctions art taken; to the Decoctions are added Sugar or Honey, according as the u≈øe and ≈øcope of the Medicine requires; namely, two pounds of Sugar or Honey to a pound, or a pound and halfe of the decoction, as it is de≈øired to be thicker or thinner, and ought to be kept more or le≈ø≈øe time: Then afterwards it is to be clarified by adding of the white of an Egge, that the decoction by a gentle Fire may ≈øeeth to the con≈øi≈øtence of a Syrup: If Honey be added, it ought to bee boyled le≈ø≈øe, becau≈øe being cooled it ea≈øily becomes thick. Syrups al≈øo, like an concoctions, may be made with Aromaticks, or Aromaticke Powders.
2. Seconldy, they are prepared of clarifyed Juices, to which is added half the quantity of Sugar, and boiled to the con≈øi≈øtence of a Syrup.

3. The≈øe Syrups are better if fre≈øh flowers are infu≈øed 24. hours in the expre≈ø≈øed juice in Bal. Mariae, and are again expre≈ø≈øed, and that repeated as often as it is fit. Then the juice is to be clarified by dige≈øtion, and half the quantity of Sugar to be mixt with it.

4. Others boil the juice till half be con≈øumed, then they ≈øtrain it, and ≈øuffer the decoction to ≈øtand and ≈øettle, that the juice may be the purer, the which when Sugar is added, they ≈øettle to the con≈øi≈øtence of the Syrup.

5. Sometimes the juice pre≈ø≈øed out is poured into hot clarifyed Sugar, and expo≈øed to the heat of the Sun, to con≈øume its aqueous humidity. But, if the heat of the Sun be not ≈øufficient, it may be performed by gentle boiling.
6. Syrups are al≈øo made of Infu≈øions, Sugar being added in the ≈øame manner as of Decoctions.
7. And ≈øometimes other things are infu≈øed in juices, and afterwards when 'tis ≈øtrained, Sugar is put to it, and the Syrup is made according to art.
8. Syrups may be made of extracts al≈øo, if a little Sugar be added to the extract being thickned by ab≈øtraction of the Men≈øtruum.

9. Syrups may al≈øo be made of ≈øoft Electuaries, if the Electuary be di≈ø≈øolved in ≈øix times or eight times the quantiny of warm liquour, and ≈øtrained, and half ≈øo much Sugar added thereto, by a gentle heat without boiling, the liquour ≈øhould evaporate to the con≈øumption of the third part.
10. Al≈øo Syrup is prepared of Sugar and Vineger onely, namely four pound of Sugar, and two of Vineger, and according to ≈øome five Pints of water, and 'tis called Syrup of Vineger ≈øimple.

11. Moreover, Syrrups are made much more artificially, e≈øpecially of hot and dry Plants, if onely ≈øo much water is poured off as that ≈øo much of the liquour may be left after ≈øtraining without concoction, as otherwi≈øe u≈øeth to be left after concoction is made, and the matter infu≈øed on this manner in a Gla≈øs or other convenient ve≈ø≈øel, ≈øuch as Fire-ve≈ø≈øels,
or earthen ve≈ø≈øels, who≈øe orifices may be fitted with a cover made for it, that is round and channelled, which ≈øhould be put into the Balneum, three or four days to dige≈øt, and afterwards ≈øhould be ≈øtrained, and that which is ≈øtrained ≈øhould again be put alone in Balneo, or becau≈øe of ≈øtraightne≈øs of time, it ≈øhould be clarifyed with the white of an Egg, what ever is feculent in it. Afterwards Sugar ≈øhould be taken and clarifyed, and boiled to ≈øuch a con≈øi≈øtence, as is ob≈øerved in the Confection of Penides, and it ≈øhould be mingled with the clarifyed infu≈øion.

The neare≈øt to this is Oxymel, Oxymel. which is to be had in the Shops, which is prepared of one part of Water, one of Vineger, and two parts of Honey, whereof divers compo≈øitions may be made al≈øo.

Syrups are ≈øeldom given alone in Di≈øea≈øes of the Brea≈øt and Stomack; The manner of admini≈øtration. but oftentimes are mixt with double the quantity of di≈øtilled waters, or decoctions; and an Ounce or an Ounce and an half of Syrups may be drank with two or three Ounces of Water or Decoction at one time.

To Syrups and Juleps belong Ro≈øated water, A Potion of Ro≈øes and water. which is a Potion compounded of Ro≈øes, and Water, and Honey or Sugar: Oribacius put into ≈øixty Pints of warm water, ten pound of Ro≈øe-leafs, he ≈øhut the Ve≈ø≈øel till they were perfectly boiled, afterwards the Ro≈øes being taken out, he infu≈øed of boiled and clarifyed Honey thirty pound, and put it into a Cellar. Actuarius took ten Pints of water, and five pound of Sugar and boiled them together to a convenient thickne≈øs, afterwards he infu≈øed a pound of the juice of Ro≈øes.

The like≈øt to Syrups are Juleps and Zulaps, Juleps. as they are called, from the Arabick word Sialaba, which is to heal or make ≈øound, without doubt it is derived from thence, ≈øo that indeed Phy≈øicians often times take them for the ≈øame Medicine, and Potions that are mixt of Water and Syrups called Juleps, but the name of Juleb is often extended farther now than with the Arabians, who invented this Medicine to be made; for the name of Juleb was ab≈øolutely given by them, when Sugar onely is di≈ø≈øolved in Ro≈øe-water, and boiled, as Julep of Ro≈øes is, otherwi≈øe called Alexander's Julep.

But a Julep, if there be any difference betwixt it and a Syrup, is a Medicine clearer than a Syrup, and therefore more delicate and gratefull, and it is made of di≈øtilled waters, clarified Juices and Sugar.

They are made with, The manner of preparing of Juleps. and without boiling; without boiling on this manner, Common or di≈øtilled water is taken, or a decoction of Barley, to the which ≈øome Juice al≈øo of Citrons, Limmons, Pomegranates, Quinces, or Vineger may be added, and white and clarified Sugar is poured in, or in≈øtead thereof common Juleps of Ro≈øes and Violets, which being boiled to the co≈øi≈øtence of a Syrup, are kept for u≈øe, and are diligently mixt together, and if there be need, are drained through Hippocrates's ≈øleeve. But the proportion of Sugar, or u≈øual Juleps, which is ob≈øerved to the waters and juices is various, as the pre≈øent occa≈øion requires it. For the mo≈øt part the Palate of the ≈øick is their guide, and ≈øometimes the proportion of water and Juices to Syrups and Sugar is threefold, ≈øometimes fourfold, ≈øixfold, eightfold, or twelvefold. Sometimes Juleps are made with Aromatick Powders, or convenient little Tabulets are di≈ø≈øolved in them. 'Tis mo≈øt convenient al≈øo in ≈øome Di≈øea≈øes to add Spirit of Vitriol.

2. Moreover, Juleps are prepared of Con≈øerves and medicinal Juices, if di≈øtilled waters that are proper, or a Decoction of Barley be poured into them in a ≈øufficient quantity, and are ≈øtirred with a Pe≈øtle in a Morter, or are mingled together over a gentle fire, and ≈øtrained.

3. But tho≈øe Juleps which are ≈øaid to be prepared with decoction, are nothing el≈øe but the pure and finer decoctions of Syrups, and the ≈øame manner of preparing of them which is of decoctions and Syrups, onely that they are removed from the fire before they receive a thicker con≈øi≈øtence.

div.head: CHAP. VIII. Of Emul≈øions and other Mixtures, bringing or cau≈øing milk, and of ≈øtrengthning things.
div.p:
AN Emul≈øion is ≈øo called, Emul≈øion. becau≈øe it is like Milk, and is prepared as it were by milking; for 'tis a potulent Medicine prepared of the pith and ≈øtrength of ≈øeeds and certain
fruits, e≈øpecially of ≈øweet Almonds (Which Emul≈øion in particular by ≈øome is called Amgydalatum) by the affu≈øion of convenient waters, or of ≈øome other liquour, and by pounding and pre≈ø≈øing of them, to which the Pulpe of a Capon or Pullet may al≈øo be added, if you have a de≈øire to nouri≈øh.

They are prepared for ≈øeverall purpo≈øes or u≈øes, The u≈øe. according to the variety of the matter, namely, to quench thir≈øt, to cau≈øe ≈øleep, to provoke ≈øweats, and other things; and ≈øometimes externally in ≈øtead of Epythems, and may be exhibited for the heat of the braine, and to mitigate paine, and cau≈øe ≈øleep.

They are prepared in this manner, Manner of preparing. Sweet Almonds are blanched, ≈øo are the foure great cold Seeds, and other things, the Kernels al≈øo are beaten in a ≈øtone or marble Morter, pouring in by degrees ≈øome fountaine water, or of Ro≈øes and other convenient di≈øtilled waters, or clarifyed with a convenient decoction that is plea≈øant to the ta≈øte: The proportion of the liquour is uncertaine, ≈øometimes more, ≈øometimes le≈ø≈øe, according to the ≈øtrength of the ≈øeeds and fruits, and according as the Emul≈øion is required to be thicker or thinner: But at the lea≈øt a threefold, oftentimes a ≈øix-fold, eight-fold, ten-fold, &c. quantity of the liquour is required; being beaten they are ≈øtrained, and if convenient, Syrups or Julips that are proper, as of Violets or Ro≈øes are added: The Emul≈øion being made ≈øometimes it is to be ≈øweetned with Sugar, or Rowles of Diamarg. frig. manus Chri≈øti perlati, or the Juleps lately mentioned: Sometimes there may be added ≈øome Cinamon water, if the di≈øea≈øe will ≈øuffer it; and ≈øometimes con≈øerves, Comfits, and liquid Electuaries may be added, from halfe a drachm to a drachm, two drachms or more.
Pearles al≈øo, Corall, Harts horne burnt, and other powders and Spices, may be added to Emul≈øions.

Sometimes potulent Medicines may be made of Pearles onely, Corall, Harts horne, and ≈øuch like, with convenient waters, which al≈øo by rea≈øon of the colour of Milke, which they have, are called Emul≈øions, and are very frequent, with moderne Phy≈øitians.

Oftentimes Juices al≈øo that are drawne out by expre≈ø≈øion, as of Pomegranates, Lemmons, or other liquours al≈øo are mixt with tho≈øe waters (yet ≈øo that the di≈øtilled waters for the mo≈øt part exceed the re≈øt in quantity) ≈øometimes,
but ≈øeldome, ≈øome convenient Syrup. But becau≈øe Phy≈øitians for the mo≈øt part de≈øire a white colour in this water, for the mo≈øt part they omit all tho≈øe things that may di≈øcolour it.

div.head: CHAP. IX. Of Tinctures, and Extracts, and liquid di≈ø≈øolutions.
div.p: AN Extract is nothing el≈øe but the pure e≈ø≈øence of a thing ≈øeparated from its gro≈ø≈øer body by a fit men≈øtruum (whence they are al≈øo called E≈ø≈øences by many) which whil≈øt it is as yet in a more liquid ≈øub≈øtance, An Extract. and joyned with the men≈øtruum, it hath al≈øo the colour of the thing, and therefore is called a Tincture; alth ough ≈øometimes they are called Tinctures al≈øo, when the e≈øsence of a thing is now ≈øeparated from its men≈øtruum which extracted it.

E≈ø≈øences or Tinctures that are liquid, E≈ø≈øences. are prepared either of green Plants, or of Juices: when they are prepared of green things, the Hearbs are brui≈øed, and a little ≈øpirit of Wine is put in for the pre≈øervation of them, and the juice is pre≈ø≈øed out, which being clean≈øed is called an E≈ø≈øence.

Tho≈øe that are properly called Extracts are prepared of dryed Plants, from whence if the whole men≈øtruum be not ≈øeparated it is called a Tincture, or liquid extract: But men≈øtruums, that is, Liquours exhibited for the drawing out of the e≈ø≈øence of a thing are various, according to the diver≈øity of the matter, and u≈øe; they of ≈øpirit of Wine, di≈øtilled Waters, Whey, Vinegar, and ≈øuch like, are exhibited.

In choo≈øing a men≈øtruam, fir≈øt you are to con≈øider whether you de≈øire a liquid tincture, or an extract, or a thicker or gro≈ø≈øer body: For if a liquid tincture be de≈øired, a men≈øtruum is to be taken, which is of the ≈øame kind and faculty: But if the men≈øtruum ought to be ≈øeparated, it is no matter, although it be of another kinde then the Tincture is of.

But ≈øince it is required in a men≈øtruum that by the ≈øubtility of its ≈øub≈øtance it may penetrate the matter, and by its familiarity intice out the purer parts, and without ≈øpoyling and corrupting of the Extract it ≈øelfe, may againe be ≈øeparated
from it: Spirit of Wine may ea≈øily be e≈øteemed the be≈øt among≈øt them, and take the fir≈øt place; but May-dew, di≈øtilled Vineger, Spirit of Salt, of Turpentine, &c. are u≈øed al≈øo according as ≈øome pre≈øent occa≈øion may require.

If compound Extracts are prepared, The manner of preparing Extracts. and the ≈øimples be of divers natures, each of them ≈øeverally, or tho≈øe which are neare≈øt one to the other, are drawn off by their Men≈øtruum, and afterwards the Extracts are mingled.

The way of preparing Extracts is plain of it ≈øelf, namely, the Men≈øtruum is poured into the matter, that is beaten and poudred, which ≈øometimes by the help of an external heat, when the e≈ø≈øence of a thing is drawn out, and the Men≈øtruum coloured enough, 'tis poured out, and another is put in, and that ≈øo often repeated, till all the ≈øtrength and virtue is extracted; afterwards the Men≈øtruum is ≈øeparated by heat, which if it be not ≈øeparated whole, 'tis called a Tincture or liquid Extract; but if almo≈øt whole, and of the con≈øi≈øtence of Honey, 'tis called a ≈øimple extract; examples may be ≈øeen in the In≈øtitutions.
Nor are ≈øuch Extracts as well liquid as thicker prepared ≈øimply alone, but al≈øo compounded: to the≈øe belong E ‚Ä¢ ixir, of propriety, purging Extracts, and univer≈øal purgers, Laudanum opiated.
To Extracts belong tho≈øe Ro≈øins al≈øo which are prepared of Scammony, Mechoacam, Jalep, and ≈øuch like, containing in them a kinde of gummy ≈øub≈øtance.
Of Tinctures, of Gemms, Coralls, Metalls, as of Bal≈øum of Venus, may be ≈øeen in the In≈øtitutions.

div.head: CHAP. X. Of Con≈øerves, Pre≈øerves, and medicinal Juices.
div.p:
THe name of Con≈øerve is given principally to Flowers, The manner of making Con≈øerves. and ≈øometimes to Herbs, and certain ≈øoft and tender Roots, which being made up with Sugar are kept many years: they are prepared in this manner, the Flowers or Herbs newly picked or clean≈øed, and (if they abound with too much humidity) fir≈øt a little dried in the ≈øhade, let them be mingled and brayed in a ≈øtone-morter, with a woodden Pe≈øtle, with twice or thrice the quantity of Sugar, and afterwards
the mixture is to be put up in a Gla≈øs or gla≈øed ve≈ø≈øel. If the Plants are moi≈øter, 'tis profitable to heat the Con≈øerves when they are made, by a gentle Fire.

2. Others take a Gla≈øs, and cover the bottom of it with Sugar, then they put in the Flowers to be condited, the depth of three Fingers breadth, and then they put in Sugar again, and in this manner heap upon a heap, and the Gla≈øs clo≈øe ≈øhut they expo≈øe it to the Sun ≈øome certain weeks.

3. Sometimes the Roots are boiled untill they can be pounded, or without boiling, are wa≈øhed and clean≈øed, and are beaten very ≈ømall, to them ≈øo pounded, or to the Decoction ≈øtrained through a Hair-≈øieve, the Sugar is added as it u≈øe to be for Syrups.

The name of Condite although it may be taken for a compound medicine al≈øo, Things condited. as well as for a ≈øimple Plant mixt onely with Honey or Sugar, ≈øo that Con≈øerves al≈øo may be comprehended under the notion of Condites, yet in particular the name of Condite here, is given onely to medicines which are not pounded, but whole for the mo≈øt part, Pre≈øerved with Sugar or Honey, both that they may be kept longer, and rendred more gratefull to the ta≈øte.

Fruits in the fir≈øt place are pre≈øerved, Manner of Pre≈øe ving Roots, Barks, Stalks, and ≈øome Flowers, as of Citrons or Lemmons, and Oranges: this is the Preparation, the ≈øofter Fruits, as Cherries, Black-berries, Barberies, Apritocks, Peaches, Pears, Mo≈øhcattellina, and the like, which are ≈øoft, being put into Sugar or Honey, that is hot, they are boiled, untill the humidity of the Fruits „Äà‚óä„Äâ con≈øumed and the Sugar or Honey receive their former con≈øi≈øtence; or if there be danger le≈øt being boiled they ≈øhould decay and lo≈øe their colour, the Sugar onely being hot, they are poured out, and when the Sugar hath drawn their aqueous humidity, the Sugar alone is again to be boiled, till that aqueous moi≈øture is con≈øumed, and afterwards to be poured out again to the Fruits, to be pre≈øerved: but tho≈øe which are more ≈øolid ≈øhould fir≈øt be brui≈øed in Water, or boiled, untill the bitterne≈øs and ungratefull ta≈øte be drawn out, and they become ≈øofter; yet you mu≈øt ob≈øerve that while≈øt we do ≈øtrive to plea≈øe the Pala ‚Ä¢ e, we mu≈øt not lo≈øe the ≈øtrength of the Pre≈øerve by too much maccration or boiling; afterwards we di≈ø≈øolve and clarifie the Sugar, either in fair water, or in the water where the Medicine is macerated, unle≈øs it hath an ill ta≈øte, we pour out the clarified Sugar upon the Fruits or Roots, and
then we ≈øeethe them again, untill the aqueous humidity which remains be con≈øumed.

La≈øtly, being ≈øo prepared, they are kept in a Gla≈øs or carthen Ve≈ø≈øel covered with a round woodden Cover, and clean ≈øtones being put upon the Lid, the Lid is depre≈øt ≈øo as that it covers the Liquour.

Next to the≈øe are thickned juices, Thickned juiees. and ≈øuch as are fit for medicinal u≈øes, which the Arabicks call Rob: They are prepared for the mo≈øt part of the juices of Fruits, ≈øometimes of Flowers al≈øo, that they may be u≈øefull in the Winter, when we want fre≈øh Herbs and Fruits; and in this manner they are prepared, the juice being drawn out is boiled over a gentle Fire to the con≈øumption of half, or the third part, then while≈øt as it is yet hot, the thicke≈øt is ≈øtrained: that which is ≈øtrained is permitted to be clarified by ≈øettling in the bottome, or it is clarified with the white of an Egg; that which is clear is boiled again, untill it acquire its due con≈øi≈øtence. But becau≈øe the juices of them≈øelves will not ea≈øily keep, unle≈øs they are boiled to a thicker con≈øi≈øtence and all the watrine≈øs be taken away, for the mo≈øt part le≈øs than half ≈øo much of Sugar or Honey, or a little quantity of one of them is added.

Tho≈øe pure≈øt, cleare≈øt, fine≈øt juices, Gelatinae. like icicles in fro≈øty weather, as they call them, being poured out u≈øe to be kept, which commonly are called Gelatinae, or frozen juices, and they are prepared principally of juices that are made without expre≈ø≈øion, the purer and more delicate juice of Quinces, Apples, Pears, Goosberries, (or Currans.)
That compo≈øition called Diacydonium, Diacydonium. which u≈øe to be prepared for the mo≈øt part in the form of a ≈øolid Pa≈øte, unle≈øs you would rather refer it to the Electuaries.
And Purgers may be mingled with tho≈øe Juices, and of them plea≈øant Medicines are made for infants and more delicate Per≈øons.

div.head: CHAP. XI. Of Electuaries.
div.p:
THe name of an Electuary, although it be ≈øeverally u≈øed by ≈øeveral, An Electuary what. yet we think that it is to be attributed to Medicines, which are reduced with Honey, or Syrup, or plain
≈øugar, or ≈øome other convenient thing, being u≈øed to a thicker con≈øi≈øtence then a ≈øyrrup, and not ‚Ä¢ o fluid, yet ≈øomewhat moi≈øt, this word is derived, or rather corrupted from the word in Greek Elleickton, or Elleickton, by which name they call a Medicine which may be taken as it were by licking, by ≈øome they are improperly called Opiats, Whence ≈øo called Opiats. not becau≈øe they have Opium in them, but becau≈øe they are of the like con≈øi≈øtence, with tho≈øe Medecines of the Ancients which had Opium in them, ≈øuch as Treakle, and from hence they are called Opiats.

Electuaries may be for ≈øeverall u≈øes, according to the nature of the ≈øimples whereof they are compounded, for ≈øome are to alter, and ≈øtrengthen, others again≈øt poy≈øons, which becau≈øe for the mo≈øt part they have opium in them, they are called Opiats, as Treakle, Mithridate, Aurea Alexandrina, others are fit to purge, which are called Catharticks. Difference of Electuaries.
Electuaries are twofold, the preparation of the former is thus,

Aromaticks, and other ≈øimples being beaten into a fine powder. In the fir≈øt place clarified honey is put into it, or ≈øugar, or ≈øome convenient waters, or ≈øyrups, or proper decoctions of proper ≈øimples in faire water, or a ≈øufficient quantity of another liquor, or infu≈øions, or juyces pre≈øt out of other Medecines ≈øtrained and boyled with clarifyed ≈øugar, or honey, to the con≈øi≈øtence of a ≈øyrup, or of many of the≈øe together, while≈øt they are as yet warme by the fire. A third part is ≈øprinkled in by little and little, which may conveniently be done through a Sieve, and is to be ≈øtirred about with a woodden Pe≈øtle in a Morter, and ≈øhould be exactly mingled and kept in a convenient Ve≈ø≈øell.

The other manner is thus, Con≈øerves they are convenient for your pre≈øent purpo≈øe, to which are added powders, and Aromatick Species, Troches, Con≈øerves al≈øo, and medicionall juyces, or Robs mu≈øt be exactly mixt together in a Morter, with a ≈øufficient quantity of di≈ø≈øolved ≈øugar, or a convenient ≈øyrup, or honey: But the proportion betwixt the Con≈øerves and Powders, and Species are not ≈øo exact, as ≈øome do determine, but ≈øeverall times they may be three fold, foure fold, ≈øix fold, eight fold, twelve fold: For a ≈øufficient quantity of a convenient ≈øyrup being poured in, what≈øoever the proportion be betwixt it and the Powders, they may be all reduced ea≈øily into the con≈øi≈øtence of an Electuary, which is al≈øo to be held of Con≈øerves. Sometimes al≈øo ≈øpirit of
Ro≈øes, of Salt, of Vitrioll, di≈øtilled waters compounded, or of di≈øtilled Oyles, ≈øome drops are to be put in. And the≈øe kinds of Electuaries were called by ≈øome Condites, as is ≈øaid before, tis ≈øo called by ≈øome from the mixture. Mixture. Purging Electuaries for the mo≈øt part are ≈øo made.

There is another manner like to this: Fruits, ≈øeeds, or roots are put in, or are boiled in wine or water, to the f ‚Ä¢ rm of a Poultice. Afterwards they are ≈øtrained through a haire Sieve, ≈øugar, or clarified honey is added, or Syrups, or Manna, and if it be needfull are boiled to the con≈øi≈øtence of honey, ≈øometimes the Species, and Powders al≈øo. Spirits al≈øo of Vitrioll, and Salt, and di≈øtilled Oyles.
Of Ray≈øins and Pruants that are laxative, you may ≈øee the In≈øtitutions.

div.head: CHAP. XII. Of Eclegmaes, and Lohochs.
div.p: EClegmaes, or Eclectaes, from the Greek word Eclei ‚Ä¢ o, Eclegma. that is to take up with ones tongue, or lick of, the Arabicks called Lohoch, or Linctns, Lohoch. and things that are to be licked, as they are commonly called, are like unto Electuaries, nor do they differ from Electuaries, only in that they are of a moi≈øter con≈øi≈øtence, and as it were the middle betwixt Syrups and Electuaries, and are appointed peculiarly for divers di≈øea≈øes of the Brea≈øt and Lungs.

Species and Powders, Con≈øerves, thickned juices, Honey, Manner of preparing. Sugar, Extracts, Mu≈øcellages, Syrups, Juleps, Oxymell, di≈øtilled Oyles, the manner of preparing is the ≈øame al≈øo with that of Electuaries. The Powders are taken, which are mo≈øt convenient, Gums of Arabick, Tragacanth, Juice of Liquori≈øh, Rice, and all things are incorporated in a ≈øufficient quantity of honey, or Syrups, or Juleps, or Mu≈øcellages, or Juices, or In≈øu≈øions, or of ≈øome decoction for this purpo≈øe, prepared of roots, herbes, ≈øeeds, fruits, But principally of Mu≈øcellages, and vi≈øoid things being ≈øtrained and expre≈ø≈øed and boiled with honey, or ≈øugar, to the con≈øi≈øtence of a ≈øyrup, or any one, or more of the≈øe, and all of them are to be wrought ≈øo long in a Morter with a woodden Pe≈øtle, untill they are exactly mingled, and come to be of the con≈øi≈øtence of honey, or rather the middle betwixt Honey and Electuaries.
Eclegmaes may be prepared without the addition of Powders, and Species, if a juice, or Mu≈øcellage be boiled with honey, or ≈øugar, to the con≈øi≈øtence of an Eclegma.
3. Eclegmaes al≈øo may be made according to that manner which is explained la≈øt of all among≈øt the Electuaries, ≈øo that if it ought to be licked, the con≈øi≈øtence ought to be the moi≈øter.

4. And ≈øuch things are often admini≈øtred alone to be ≈øupt up by the ≈øick, or el≈øe they are prepared of them other things being mixt, a new Eclegma is made for the pre≈øent occa≈øion; for you may take as much as you plea≈øe of the u≈øuall Eclegma; Con≈øerves al≈øo are added, and convenient Powders, Sugar, and an Eclegma may be reduced into the forme of a Syrup, with a ≈øufficient quantity of Syrup, or Juleps or clarified Honey, or Sugar di≈ø≈øolved; To which ≈øometimes ≈øome drops of di≈øtilled Oyles are added.

Hereunto belong medicines which by ≈øome are called Saponea, Saponea. from the ≈øimilitude of white Soape not yet made hard, by others tis called Linctus, from a Liniment made of Almonds. Sweete Almonds are taken being blanched, and are pounded; to tho≈øe that are pounded, clarified Sugar, or Penedies, or Sugar-Candy is added; being fir≈øt di≈ø≈øolved in a convenient Liquor, they are boyled to the con≈øi≈øtence of Honey; a little before they have done boyling a pound of Rice is added, to wit, unto two ounces of Sugar, an ounce of Rice, and another of Almonds, and a ≈øufficient quantity of Ro≈øe water, and a little before it be ended ≈øome Ginger al≈øo, or Aromatick may be added. Others draw a milke out of Almonds with Ro≈øe water, or ≈øome other convenient Liquor, with ≈øome portion of milke; Sugar is di≈ø≈øolved, the Rice is ra≈øt in afterwards, and the other part al≈øo of the mul≈øion being poured in they are ≈øtirred with a gentle fire.

The compo≈øition which is called Leucophagum, Leucophagum. is ≈øo named from its colour, and therefore may be referred to this, or the precedent head; tis prepared of ≈øwee ‚Ä¢ Almonds macerated in Ro≈øe water, and the fle≈øh of a Capon, or Patridge boyled with it, being very much wrought in a Marble Morter, and ≈øtrained through a haire ≈øeive, with a little of the beaten blanched Almonds, and Sugar, boyled to a due con≈øi≈øtence, to which according to the ≈øeverall aimes of the Phy≈øitians, Aromaticks, Corralls, and other things may be added.

div.head: CHAP XIII. Of Boles.
div.p: A Bolus hath that name becau≈øe it is a gobbet of Phy≈øick in a round figure, A Bole. allmo≈øt as much as ones mouth will hold, whence it is calied Buccilla; but the name of Bolus agrees not only to purging, but altering Phy≈øick.

Boles to cau≈øe vomiting, Vomiting boles. and they are prepared after th ‚Ä¢ ≈øame manner, and are made of ≈øome Emettick powder, ≈øim ple, or compound, to which ≈øometimes is added ≈øome of the things that alter or correct, ≈øome certaine grains, or ≈øome Emittick extract, with a con≈øerve or ≈øome confection of the like con≈øi≈øtence, and with ≈øyrups.

div.head: CHAP. XIV. Of Powders, and Trageis, or Comfits.
div.p: BUt as for the formes of dry Medecines, Powders, and Trageis. Powders, are the plaine≈øt way of compounding among≈øt them, commonly called Trageas, without doubt corruptly derived from the word Tragema, which con≈øi≈øts of one, or more Medecines compounded, if the ta≈øt be ungratefull, an equall part of ≈øugar, or half ≈øo much ≈øugar is to be added.

But Powders are either thin, and ≈øubtile, which if they confi≈øt of pure Aromaticks, and Sugar, they are wont to be called generally Tragemats, or Trageae, or el≈øe more thick, and not ≈øo ≈øubtile; nay ≈øometimes Aromaticks are not pulveri≈øed, but onely cut a≈øunder, and ≈øeeds hardned with ≈øugar, or candied, called Comfits, are added to them, and Species that are cut, are al≈øo called gro≈ø≈øe Trageaes.

div.head: CHAP. XV. Of Salts.
div.p: ALl things almo≈øt containe two kinds of Salts, Salt two≈øold. the one volatile, which endures not the fire and heat, but flies away and is di≈øper≈øed, and vani≈øheth by burning, the other is fixed, which endures the fire, and is left in the a≈øhes.

div.head: CHAP. XXI. Of Trochees.

div.head: CHAP. XXII. Of Pills.
div.p: PIlls are ≈øo called from their ≈øimilitude to little Balls by the Latins, and from the ≈øolid form, Pills. the Greeks call them Catapo≈øia from Catapineine, that is, Drinking or ≈øwallowing down: Pills are Medicines made into the form of a Globe or Ball, principally for this end, that they may be ≈øwallowed whole, and the un≈øavorine≈øs of the Medicine may the le≈øs be perceived by the ta≈øte.

8. There is another manner al≈øo of making Pills, The Simples whether Altering or Purging are macerated for two days in Wine or ≈øome other Liquour, or el≈øe they are boiled, in it, or a certain juice is taken out of convenient things

div.head: CHAP. XXIII. Of Suppo≈øiters.
div.p: EXternal Medicines are twofold, External Medicines. ≈øome are injected and put into certain parts, others are applied onely to the Superficies of the body; of the former kinde are Suppo≈øiters, and Cly≈øters, both tho≈øe which are injected into the Paunch, as tho≈øe which are injected into the Womb; and Pe≈ø≈øaries, Injections, which are made into the Yard and Bladder, Gargari≈øms which are in Mouth and Chops, Aphophlegmati≈øms, Dentifrices, Errhines, Sternutatories, Odoraments, and Fumes; Injections into the Ears, Collyries, which we ≈øhall ≈øpeak of in the fir≈øt place.
