div.head: CHAP. XXIV. Of Cly≈øters.
div.p: CLy≈øters which the Greeks call Cly≈øter, Cly≈øter. Cly≈ømos, Cly≈øma, and Encly≈øma, is ≈øo called from purging or clean≈øing, although it ≈øignifies every ≈øort of Medicine in general, which pours in that which is liquid into any part, yet in particular, as al≈øo Enema from injecting, for the mo≈øt part is taken onely for a Medicine which is injected by the Fundament into the Guts.

A Cly≈øter is injected for ≈øeveral ends, Differences of Cly≈øters. whence there ari≈øeth various differences of Cly≈øters; for ≈øome loo≈øen the belly, and of the≈øe ≈øome do it by Emolliating, which are made of Emollients, propo≈øed before, p. 1. S. 1. c. 6.

Others purge, to which purging Medicines are added. Some clean≈øe, namely, tho≈øe which are compounded of Barley, the herb Mercury, Pellitory, Wormwood, Agrimony, Century the le≈øs, Pea≈øe, Par≈ønibs, Lupines, Flour, Honey with Ro≈øes, Hiera. Some are compo≈øed for the di≈øcu≈ø≈øing and breaking of winde, and are made of tho≈øe Medicines that expell winde, above mentioned, pag. 1. ≈øect. 1. cap. 15.

Some binde and are prepared of A≈øtringents, propo≈øed in the ≈øame, cap. 6. Some glutinate, and are prepared of glutinating things, ≈øpoken of in the ≈øame part and ≈øect. cap 9. Sometimes Cly≈øters are made of Anodyns, or Medicines that mitigate pain, for pains of the Guts and Reins.

But Cly≈øters are compounded in this manner, there are taken of Roots and Rindes an ounce or two, of Leafs three, four or five handfuls, of Seeds three, four or five Drachms: of Flowers ≈øome Pugils, of Fruits, Pears ten, that is, twenty; to which if a purging Cly≈øter ought to be made, Purgers are added, Agrick, Colloquintida, Seeds of Carthamons, (all which lea≈øt they ≈øhould ≈øtickto the Guts, and offend them, are tied in a Linnen-cloath) the Leafs of Senna; but there is no need of ≈øuch variety always, but oftentimes a few ≈øimples ≈øuffice. All the ≈øimple Medicines are boiled in a ≈øufficient quantity of water; of the Decoction take three, four to fifteen Ounces, according to the age, for infants three Ounces, hence tho≈øe that are a little riper four, five or ≈øix may ≈øuffice; for one that is come to ripene≈øs of years, for the
mo≈øt part they take a Pint, ≈øometimes al≈øo fifteen Ounces; yet ≈øometimes, namely, when we would retain the Cly≈øter long, and le≈øt the too great quantity ≈øhould oppre≈øs the other parts, onely eight or ten Ounces is taken in the Stone. In the Decoction ≈øtrained tho≈øe things which agree to our pre≈øent purpo≈øe, we di≈ø≈øolve, as Oyls from an Ounce to two or three. When we onely are to emolliate, we put in Oyls onely or Butter, but indeed in greater quantity: tho≈øe which have a purging faculty are then wholly to be omitted, le≈øt by rea≈øon of the hard ordure ≈øticking in the Guts, nature ≈øhould be ≈øtimulated in vain, and humours being drawn greater evils do en≈øue. On the contrary, when you are to purge, to repell, and a ≈øharp Cly≈øter is required, the Oyls whereby the force of ≈øharp and purging things is re≈øi≈øted, are to be omitted, and purging Electuaries are to be added for the mo≈øt part double the weight, which at other times they u≈øe to be taken in at the mouth, or Pills are to be di≈ø≈øolved, Salt al≈øo is to be added from a Scruple to a Drachm; al≈øo Ab≈øtergents, as Honey of Ro≈øes, or Sugar, in weight an Ounce or an Ounce and half; all of them being mixt, and moderately heated by a convenient and known in≈øtrument, they are to be injected into the Paunch an hour or two before meat.

Tho≈øe who are unwilling to have it done by others may give a Cly≈øter, as they call it, to them≈øelves by in≈øtruments de≈øcribed in many places, the mo≈øt convenient whereof Guil. Fabricius propounds in his Chyrurgical Operations, Cent. 1. Ob≈ø. 78.

div.head: CHAP. XXV. Of Injections into the Wombe, and of Pe≈ø≈øaries
div.p: TO Cly≈øters which are inje&ed into the Guts, Injections into the Wombe. we may well joyne tho≈øe which are ca≈øt into the Womb, and are therefore called Uterine Cly≈øters; The In≈øtrument, or Squirt, by which the liquor is ca≈øt into the Womb, is called by the Greeks, Metrencytes, but the Medecines which are injected they call Metrencyta.

A due quantity is taken of ≈øimples agreeable to every ones di≈øea≈øe, Way of preparing. tis boiled, and three or foure ounces of the decoction, or in≈øtead thereof di≈øtilled water is taken, and two or three ounces of Oyle are added, and powders, to the quantity of three drachms; and of tho≈øe mixt together, three ounces are injected into the Womb.
For the ≈øame cau≈øes, P ‚Ä¢ ≈ø≈øaries. for the mo≈øt part, for which Cly≈øters as they call them, are injected into the Womb, Pe≈ø≈øes, and Pe≈ø≈øaries, barbarou≈øly called Na≈øcalia, are put in.

1. The manner of preparing. There are many waies of preparing Pe≈ø≈øaries, the fir≈øt is cotten, or wooll that is ≈øhore and well carded, and are mixt with a juice, or ≈øome liquor, either alone, or with ≈øome convenient powders mixt, twi≈øted, or wreathed, about the bigni≈ø≈øe and length of a finger, tis wet in it, and applied to the generative parts of women, the quantity of Medecines that are pounded for the mo≈øt part is an ounce.

2. Moreover Medecines that are pounded are taken in convenient liquors, as with oyl, fat, wax, Galbanum, Storax, honey, and are made up and mingled into a ma≈ø≈øe, and fa≈øhioned in the figure of a Pe≈ø≈øary, to which a thred is tied, which al≈øo may be covered with fine linnen, or a thin peece of ≈øilk.
3. Sometimes green herbs, and ≈øuch as are full of juice, are a little brui≈øed, and tied about with a thred, and bound in the form of a Pe≈ø≈øary.
4. There is a time al≈øo when Powders onely being taken in fine wooll, or cotten, being made round, are put into a thin bagg made of a fine ragg.

Na≈øcalies, Na≈øca≈øia. as they are barbarou≈øly called, are compounded of the ≈øame Medecines, which are taken with cotton,
or ≈øoft wooll, and applied to the externall orifice of the womb, e≈øpecially in Virgins, to whom you may not give Pe≈ø≈øaries.

div.head: CHAP. XVI. Of tho≈øe things which are injected into the Yard, and Bladder.
div.p: INjections into the Bladder, Injection into the Bladder. are liquid Medecines which are injected into it through the urinary pa≈ø≈øage; in the u≈øe whereof, the whole art con≈øi≈øts in injecting, for ≈øometimes tis ≈øufficient to ca≈øt in this Cly≈øter by a Squirt, ≈øometimes a Catheter which opens the way, as it were, and tis nece≈ø≈øary to precede.

It happens al≈øo ≈øometimes that there is need of injection into the Yard, namely, when it is either hurt by the ≈øtone, Into the Yard. or troubled with paine, or the pa≈ø≈øage within is ulcerated; tis prepared of tho≈øe things which are agreeable to the ≈øcope of the Phy≈øitian.

But not onely fluid Medecines are injected, but Unguents are ca≈øt in in this manner: Take a wax Candle, to which ≈øome Turpentine may be added, of that thickne≈ø≈øe and length which may an≈øwer to this pa≈ø≈øage and chanell, this Candle is bedaubed with an Oyntment, and is thru≈øt in, but you mu≈øt be carefull that the candle may be ≈øo prepared, and ≈øtick ≈øo long, that it may not melt with the heat of the yard; you may boyle al≈øo ≈øome convenient Plai≈øter, and put the wax candle, or a little In≈øtrument made of lead, into it.

div.head: CHAP. XXVII. Of wa≈øhings of the mouth, and Gargari≈ømes
div.p: COllutions of the mouth with the Greeks, Diacly≈ømata, Mouth-waters. they are fluid Medecines, which are contained in the mouth, and without ≈øwallowing, by the help of the tongue are agitated up and down, being principally appointed for paines of the teeth, and di≈øea≈øes of the Gumms.

Next unto the≈øe are Gargari≈ømes, to wit liquid Medicines, Gargari≈ømes. by which the Chaps are wa≈øhed without ≈øwallowing, namely, while≈øt the humour contained in the mouth, flowes towards the top of the Wind-pipe by its gravity, the head leaning backward, the breath breakking out is repelled, and is agitated by a reciprocall motion.

Gargari≈ømes are admini≈øtred for divers purpo≈øes, U≈øe of gargari≈ømes. ≈øome to repell, others to re≈øolve, and di≈øcu≈ø≈øe, others to ripen, others to ab≈øterge, or wipe oft, others to con≈øolidate: But of all medicines for what purpo≈øe ≈øoever they are intended, tho≈øe are to be cho≈øen which are not ungratefull to the ≈ømell or ta≈øte, nor have any venemous and malignant qualitie, ≈øince it may ea≈øily come to pa≈ø≈øe, that any thing may be ≈øwallowed contrary to the will.

Some are prepared with di≈øtilled waters, Manner of preparing. others with decoctions, wherein Juices, or Syrups are di≈ø≈øolved, under a three-fold, foure-fold, or ≈øix-fold quantitie, ≈øo that to a pinte of di≈øtilled waters, or of a decoction, two, three, or foure ounces are taken, to which ≈øometimes ≈øome of the Aromaclck Species are added, and being mixt all are exhibited together luke-warme.

div.head: CHAP. XXVIII. Of Medicines that draw away Phlegme.
div.p: APophlegmati≈ømes, Apophlegmati≈ømes. are Medicines al≈øo, which are held in the mouth, and draw out Phlegme from the head, and neighbouring-parts, from whence they have their name, for the mo≈øt part they are called Diama≈ø≈øemataes or Ma≈øticatories.
But they are not all made alike, Manner of preparing. for fir≈øt Apophlegmati≈øms are u≈øed in the forme of Gargari≈øms, which how they are made is newly ≈øhewn.
Moreover, Medicines may be made by bearing, and with a convenient liquor, reduced into the forme of an Electuarie, wherewith the Palate ≈øhould be annointed. Ma≈øticatories.

The third are called Ma≈øticatories, which are retained and ma≈øticated longer in the mouth, partly by their heat, they di≈ø≈øolve Phlegme, draw it out, and intice it
forth, partly by the ≈øtrength wherewith they are endued, of ≈øtimulating the expul≈øive facultie of the braine, they irritate it, to eject what ever troubles it, which againe may be done three waies.
For fir≈øt ≈øimple Medicines, either whole, The way of making. or a little cut onely are detained and chewed in the mouth.
Secondly, The ≈øame medicines pounded, and with a ≈øufficient quantitie of Honey, or Wax, which is taken, are made into Troches, like Lupine ≈øeeds, or Hazel-nuts, being in weight a ≈øcruple.
Thirdly, The ≈øame medcines ≈øtamped, being put in a linnen cloath, which may be brui≈øed and chewed with the Teeth.

div.head: CHAP. XXIX. Of Medicines to rub, and clean≈øe the Teeth.
div.p: DEntifrices, which the Greeks call Odontrimmata, Dentifrices and Smegmata Odonton, are principally prepared to whiten, clean≈øe, and ≈øtrengthen the teeth, The way of making. and fa≈øten the Gumms when they are loo≈øe; But there is not one ≈øort of them onely, for fir≈øt they may be wa≈øhed with convenient liquors, or rubbed with cotton, or a linnen ragg, wet in a convenient liquor.
2. Moreover the forme of an Oyntment may be u≈øed, if the powders are taken in honey, ≈øimple Oxymell, with Squills, honey of Ro≈øes, or ≈øyrup of Ro≈øes.
3. The Teeth may be rubbed with powders.
4. Troches, or Penfills may be made in the forme of ≈øuppo≈øiters, which being dried and hardned, the Teeth may be rubbed.
5. After Dentifrices, tis convenient that the mouth he wa≈øhed, principally with Wine wherein Orice roots, or ≈øome other convenient thing is fir≈øt macerated.

div.head: CHAP. XXX. Of Medicines put into the No≈øe, and to provoke ≈øneezing.
div.p: ERrhines, Errhines. as the name ≈øhews, are medicines which are put into the no≈øtrills, which is done for ≈øeverall ends; either for calling out Excrements from the braine, and to provoke ≈øneezing, tho≈øe that performe which in particular, are called Ptarmica, Ptarmica. or ≈øuch as cau≈øe ≈øneezing; or to open the ob≈øtructions of the pa≈ø≈øages, or to heale an Ulcer, or ≈øtench blood; whence the matter of Errhines, is not allwayes the ≈øame but various according to the various intentions, which is ≈øhewne before in the faculties of medicines.

They are prepared al≈øo in ≈øeverall formes; Way to make them. for ≈øome are moi≈øt, and Liquid, others hard and dry; againe, the Liquid are twofold, either they are powred into the no≈øtrills, or the no≈øtrills are anointed with them only expre≈ø≈øed juices are powred into the no≈øtrills, and are drawne in by and clarified them.

2. Or di≈øtilled waters are added to the clarified juices, Wine, Oyle, Honey, ≈øomewhat le≈ø≈øe then double, or ≈øomewhat le≈ø≈øe then foure times the weight, according as thicker, or more fluid Errhines are required, or convenient powders may be added, about a drachm in weight.
3. Or decoctions are prepared which are mixt with ≈øomewhat le≈ø≈øe then double, or ≈øomewhat le≈ø≈øe then foure times ≈øo much Honey, and are put into the no≈øtrills.
But tho≈øe things wherewith the no≈øtrills are anointed, are mo≈øt conveniently made of Oyles and Powders, to which belongs Bal≈øoms, which the No≈øtrills are anointed with.
Be≈øides the≈øe, to the moi≈øt there ≈øeemes to belong, tho≈øe things which are put into the No≈øtrills in the forme of a tent.

But dry Errhines are made fir≈øt of convenient Rootes, Dry Errhiaes. or Staulkes, as of Beetes, Flowre-deluce, Sow-bread, which are fa≈øhioned in the forme of a Pyramid, and afterwards macerated in the water of ≈øweet Marjerom, or ≈øome other
a fit water, or Oyle, a thred being fir≈øt tyed about them, they ‚Ä¢ re put in.

2. Moreover dry Errhines are made when ≈øimple medicines are reduced into a thin powder, and a graine or two or two of them is blowne into the No≈øtrils, and ≈øo they u≈øe to call Errhines in particular Ptarmaca, or Sternutatories.

3. Thirdly, Errhines and Sneezings may be made of the ≈øame powders, if with a linnen or woollen cloath, or a Linnen bagg, that is round, they are wrapt up in it, and either with juice, or convenient di≈øtilled waters; for example of Marjerom, the Sternutatorie powder be dipt in it or ≈øprinkled with it, and put into the No≈øtrills.

4. Fourthly, medicines for the no≈øe being reduced into a powder, are taken in a Mu≈øcellage, or Gumm, or Turpentine, or Oyle and wax, and diligently mixt, are made up into Pe≈ø≈øaries, in the forme of a Pyramid, as it were in that bigne≈ø≈øe that they may be put into the No≈øe, to the end whereof a thred is tyed, that it may be drawne out at plea≈øure.

div.head: CHAP. XXXI. Of ≈øweet Smells, Perfumes, and Odoriferous, Bal≈øomes.
div.p: SWeet Smells al≈øo are taken in at the No≈øtrills, Things cau≈øing ≈øweete Odours. Simples Odori≈øerous. but principally they are exhibited for altering of the braine, and recreation of the Spirits and are exhibited for the re≈øi≈øting of filthy and Pe≈øtilentiall ≈ømells.

The materialls of the≈øe things are all ≈øuch as breath a ≈øweete Odour out of them≈øelves, as Muske, Amber, Civit, Benzoin, liquid Storax and Ladanum, wood of Aloes, Ro≈øe-mary, Lavender, Marjerom, Spike, wild Ba≈øill, Stechados of Arabia, Mace, Cloves, Cinamon, Frankin≈øen≈øe, Myrrb, graines of Juniper, Gallia Mo≈øchata, Camphir, and tho≈øe things which are given cold, as Ro≈øes, Violets, Flowers, Kindes of Odor ferous things. of Nimphea, ≈øantalls.

But they are exhibited ≈øeverall wayes, and ≈øeverall kinde of ≈øweet ≈ømells, are made of tho≈øe ≈øimples, for fir≈øt they u≈øe to be reduced into powders, and are kept either in a Box, or woodden ve≈ø≈øell, and as often as nece≈ø≈øary, are put to the No≈øtrills, or el≈øe are included in a little bagg, or nodule of ≈øilke.

2. Secondly, the ≈øame reduced into powder are taken with Ladanum, Wax, Liquid Storax, to which ≈øome Turpentine may be added al≈øo, and made into one ma≈ø≈øe in a hot Morter, by powring in of Ro≈øe-watar, of which little balls are made commonly called Pomander:

3. Thirdly Unguents and Linements, u≈øe to be made of ≈øweete things, Bal≈øomes. which they call Bal≈øomes at this day, they are prepared of di≈øtilled Oyles, to which is added Amber, Muske, Civit, Indian Bal≈øom, whereof the whole force of them depends, which are mixed with a certaine body which affords a convenient con≈øi≈øtence, in≈øtead whereof although ≈øome take other things, yet extract of Plantine is conveniently taken, or Oyle drawne out of Nutmegs, by which all the ≈ømell for the mo≈øt part, colour, and ta≈øte is extracted by the Spirit of Wine, or which is mo≈øt convenient, an extract and Oyle of Nutmegs, together to this mixture a colour agreeable to the Bal≈øom, ≈øhall be made of a juice or tincture of the medicines.

4. Fourthly, perfumed waters u≈øe to be prepared, wherewith the Garments u≈øe to be ≈øprinkled, or the no≈øe, hands, and other perts of the body u≈øe to be wet, the ≈øame waters being put in a convenient ve≈ø≈øell upon the coales, are di≈ø≈øolved into an Odoriferous Vapour.
5. Fifthly, wa≈øh-balls are al≈øo prepared, or ≈øweet balls to wa≈øh the hands, and feete, of which hereafter Chap. 42.

6. Fumes. Moreover, ≈øweet Vapours, or fumes, belong to Odoriferous ≈ømells the Greeks Thymiamata, which although they are taken for the ≈øweetne≈ø≈øe and plea≈øantne≈ø≈øe of ≈ømell, or for ≈øtrengthning the braine, yet they may be appointed for other ends al≈øo, namely to ≈øtop di≈øtillations, for drying ulcers of the lungs, when they are ≈øtuffed with thick matter, peculiar ≈øuffumigations, al≈øo are prepared for the wombe, and to provoke and ≈øtop cour≈øes, the falling down, and ≈øuffocation of the mother, & the coming out of the Fundament.
1. How prepared. But ≈øuffumigations are prepared, fir≈øt of ≈øweet medicines, that are cut, or powred, being throwne upon live coales, or hot a≈øhes.
2. Moreover, the ≈øame powders are made into Cakes or Trochees, with a convenient Liquor, and with a Gumme or Ro≈øin.
3 Thirdly, the coales of Lime or Teile-tree or of Willow being mixt, Pyramids and Candles as it were are made of the ≈øame matter, which is kindled, when there is u≈øe for, them.

div.head: CHAP. XXXII. Of tho≈øe things which are put into the Eares.
div.p: THo≈øe things which are put into the Eares to a≈ø≈øwage their pains, for inflammations, Ulcers, Singings, Things to be injected into the Eares. Hummings, and other infirmities, are exhibited, either in a Liquid forme, and fir≈øt dropt into the Eares.

1. Secondly, a hot Vapour of Decoctions, or convenient Liquors are injected into the Eares, (which they commonly call Embotum) or ≈øimples that are convenient are included in a bagg, and boyled, and put into the Eares.
3. Thirdly, they are exhibited in the forme of a Linement.
4. Fourthly, ≈øimple medicines may be reduced into powder, and blowne into the Eares, or ≈øent in, in the manner of a fume, or Vapour.

div.head: CHAP. XXXIII. Of Liquid medicines for the eyes.
div.p: COllytion, and Collurion, as much as to ≈øay Collurion, Collyrium. that is Colobon ten Ouran, or Colobee Oara, it is ≈øo called becau≈øe it is like muti≈øarae caudae, in which forme although various medicines appointed for various u≈øes, were heretofore prepared: yet at this day by the name Collyries, are under≈øtood only externall medicines proper for the Eyes.

But medicines which are exhibited to the Eyes, and in generall have borrowed their name from tho≈øe dry ones, Way of preparing. are named Collyries, and are commonly divided into dry and moi≈øt, dry ones are made when medicines pounded very ≈ømall, are made fine in a Morter, and with a ≈øufficient quantity of Whites of Eggs, or of ≈øome Mu≈øcellage, are made into the forme of a Pyramid, or Trochees, and are dryed in the ≈øhade
when there is need of them, they are beaten againe, in a marble, or Stone Morter, ≈øome convenient Liquor being powred in, and the Liquor, afterwards, which is then prepared, is dropt into the eyes.

2. Moi≈øt Collyries are twofold, for either they are dropt into the Eyes, in the forme of a Liquor, which is made of juices, di≈øtilled waters, Decoctions, or many of the≈øe mixt, powders being added, and e≈øpcially of tho≈øe medicines which will di≈ø≈øolve in a moi≈øt body.
3. Or they are made in the forme of an unguent.
4. La≈øtly, convenient medicines al≈øo, are boyled in water, and the warme Vapour exhaling out of the pot, which is covered with a linnen cloath, is received into the eyes.

div.head: CHAP. XXXIV. Of Oyles and Bal≈øomes.
div.p: BUt as for what belongs to Medicines which are exhibited to the ≈øuperficies of the body, Oyles. the fir≈øt among≈øt them are Oyles; whereof ≈øome are naturall, as Petroleum and common Oyle, which is made of ripe Olives, and Omphacine, which is drawne of unripe Olives; others are artificiall, which are made three manner of wayes.

1. How to prepare them. For fir≈øt; Unctuous juice is expre≈ø≈øed, after which manner Oyle of ≈øweet Almonds, Pi≈øtack-nuts, Nuts, ≈øeed of Flax, Gourds, Cucumbers, Henbane, Hempe, and Oyle of Poppy is prepared; by expre≈ø≈øion al≈øo, Oyle of Yolkes of Eggs is made,

2. Secondly, Oyles are prepared by Infu≈øion many wayes, for ≈øometimes ≈øimple medicines are boyled with Fountaine or di≈øtilled water, and Wine, or other convenient Liquor, in common Oyle, to the con≈øumption of the moi≈øture, or juice; ≈øometimes the ≈øame ≈øimples by a gentle heate are macerated in the Sun, yet it ≈øeemes more convenient if dryed Plants are ≈øteeped in Oyle, in Balneo Mariae, twenty foure hours, afterwards the Oyle is expre≈ø≈øed, and clarified by re≈øidence.
Thirdly, Oyles are prepared by di≈øtillation al≈øo, as is ≈øaid before, among≈øt which ≈øome at this day are called Bal≈øomes; examples whereof are to be had in the In≈øtitutions.

div.head: CHAP. XXXV. Of Linements and Oyntments.
div.p: A Linement, or Litus, with the Greeks Cri≈øma, A Linement. and Syncry≈øma, and that which takes away weari≈øomne≈ø≈øe, is called Acopon, that is, freed from labour, tis a liquid Medecine, externally applied, thicker in con≈øi≈øtence then oyle, but more liquid then an unguent, or of a middle con≈øi≈øtence betwixt an oyle, and an unguent.

It con≈øi≈øts of oyles, butter, wax, fat, tallow, marrow, gums, juices, mu≈øcellages; for the mo≈øt part they have no wax, or if any be u≈øed, they take onely a drachm of wax to an ounce of oyle, to the≈øe ≈øometimes, flowers, powders, and ro≈øins are mixt.

They are prepared in this manner, The oyles, fats, How prepared. or other things here named, are taken: to the≈øe powders are added, Juices, and ≈øuch like, of that proportion for the mo≈øt part, that to an ounce of oyl, three drachms of fat, or two drachms, and one drachm of powders is taken, or that proportion is ob≈øerved, as may make the con≈øi≈øtence onely a little thicker then oyle; and all are mingled either without fire and boiling, or are di≈ø≈øolved at the fire as Gums, and Fats, or al≈øo by ≈øome ebullition, namely, to the con≈øumption of the Juices, or Vinegar, if any ≈øuch thing be mingled with it.

Unguents which the Greeks call Myra, and Alleimata,
∆≤nguents. from whence Miropolae and Alyptae were the names that the Ancients fir≈øt called them by, which for plea≈øantne≈ø≈øe were made of odoriferous things, and were di≈øtingui≈øhed from oyles not in thickne≈ø≈øe, but in plea≈øantne≈ø≈øe of ≈ømell. But tho≈øe things which are at this day called Unguents, are Emmota, ≈øo called by the Greeks, and are made of the ≈øame things whereof Linements are; But are ≈øomewhat thicker then Linements, and tho≈øe things which thicken, are taken in a greater quntity in an Unguent, then in a Linement, but as for the liquid and oyly things a le≈ø≈øe quantity is ob≈øerved in compounding them, this is the proportion for the mo≈øt part; that to an ounce of oyles a drachm of powder, two
drachms of wax may be taken, or a ≈øufficient quantity, namely in tho≈øe things where Unguents are made of oyles, powders, or mettals, or plants, and wax.
But they are prepared either with fire, How prepard. or without fire, without fire they are prepared in this manner;
1. The powders being beaten, and ≈øifted, are taken, which are ≈øprinkled in the oyle, and a ≈øufficient quantity of wax being added, are reduced into the forme of an Unguent.
2. Or u≈øual Unguents are taken, and for the mo≈øt part foure fold, or eight fold, the quantity of powders, and ≈øpecies are mixt with ≈øome convenient oyle.
3. Or fat, or marrow are taken alone, or with oyle in equall weight, double, or halfe ≈øo much again, a few powders being added with a ≈øufficient quantity of wax, an Unguent is made,
4. With fire al≈øo, they are made many waies, for either the grea≈øe, oyles, or gumms are melted, that the powders may the ea≈øier be mingled.

5. Or herbes, roots, ≈øeeds, are macerated, ≈øometime in water, wine, juices, oyle, afterwards they are boiled almo≈øt to the con≈øumption of the liquor: to the decoction when tis ≈øtrained, the other things are added, and with ≈øome grea≈øe and a ≈øufficient quantity of wax, or a gumm, an Unguent is made.

6. Or they are prepared without oyle, with grea≈øe, namely, herbes, flowers, or fre≈øh roots, are brui≈øed with grea≈øe, and wrought in a Morter, untill the herbes have imbibed the grea≈øe, and then they are melted by the fire, and pre≈ø≈øed out.

div.head: CHAP. XXXVI. Of Cerots, and Emplai≈øters.
div.p: THe name of a Cerat, or Cerot, the Ancients u≈øed for a ≈øoft medicine, namely for that which con≈øi≈øting of oyle and wax is anointed.

But at this day tis taken for a medicine, like unto a plai≈øter, yet is not ≈øo hard as a plai≈øter in con≈øi≈øtence, and tis ≈øo called from Cera, that is wax, becau≈øe the greater part of it is wax: And tis compounded at this day of powders, oyles,
Gums, Pitch, Turpentine and Wax, and ≈øometimes Lard, Marrow, and Mu≈øcellages are added.

But the proportion of the things that are mixt is various, neither can it ea≈øily be defined and comprehended by Rules, and the quantity of Wax to be mixed is left for the mo≈øt part to the di≈øcretion of the Apothecary, who a≈øcends by degrees, according to progre≈øs from a le≈ø≈øer quantity to a greater; yet for the mo≈øt part the analogy of mixture u≈øeth to be de≈øired, ≈øo that when they con≈øi≈øt of Oyl, Wax, and Ro≈øin, one part of Oyl is taken, half ≈øo much of Ro≈øin, of Wax the third part: But when Pouders are added, the proportion of Oyles to Pouders is eight-fold, to Wax, two three, four or ≈øix-fold; and to Ro≈øin, that it may ≈øtick the fa≈øter, they u≈øe to add twelvefold; a Cerot becomes the harder three ways, namely, by defect of Oyl and Grea≈øe, by boiling, and ≈øtore of Pitch, Wax, or Pouders.

1. They are made in this manner, How made. If the Cerot ought to be made of Pouders only, Oyl and Wax; the Oyl and Wax ≈øhould be di≈ø≈øolved together at the fire, and the Pouders put in by degrees, and exactly mingled.
2. If Lard, Gums, or other things to be melted by the fire are taken, they ≈øhould be melted with the wax.

3. If Gums are to be di≈ø≈øolved in Vineger or Wine; fir≈øt they mu≈øt be di≈ø≈øolved in Oyl, and mingled with Wax, that the Vineger or Wine may be con≈øumed with boiling, afterwards the Pouders may ≈øprinkled in.
4. If you are to add Roots, Fruits, or Seeds, the≈øe are fir≈øt to be boiled, and the Decoction to be boiled again with Oyl to the con≈øumption of the moi≈øture.
La≈øtly, the things melted and pounded are to be added, and all to be mixt together, and to be kept for u≈øe.

But when you may pre≈øcribe fre≈øh things for pre≈øent u≈øe, three Ounces and an a half may ≈øuffice for a great Cerot, for an indifferent one two Ounces, for a little one, one Ounce, & three or four Drachms of Pouders are ≈øufficient for an indifferent Plai≈øter: and ≈øuch Cerots u≈øe to be put with an Aromatick Pouder ≈øprinkled on them into a piece of Leather, or to be covered with fine Linnen; the quantity and figure, if it may be, ≈øhould an≈øwer and be conformable to the parts to which they ought to be applied.

Plai≈øters, Plai≈øters. from Emplattein, that is, from fa≈øhioning, and ≈øoft anointing is derived, becau≈øe they may be extended, and ≈øpred on a Linnen cloath, or peice of Leather; they are medicines ≈øomewhat harder and more ≈øollid then Cerots, and are compounded of the ≈øame things whereof Cerots are, only that metalls, and mineralls, and for the mo≈øt part, Litharge are added, which makes them of a more ≈øollid con≈øi≈øtence.

For the mo≈øt part this is the manner of compounding them; How compounded. the wax for the mo≈øt part is melted in Oyle, if the Litharge be in readine≈ø≈øe, that al≈øo ≈øhould be boyled in Oyle. If Juices of herbs, or decoctions, Mu≈øceilages, Vinegar, Wine or any other Liquor be to be mixt, then that al≈øo is to be mixed with the re≈øt, and being mixt, are to be boyled ≈øo long, untill the aqueous humidity be con≈øumed; afterwards the Ro≈øins, fat, thickned and concreate juices, and Gumms, are to be put in ≈øometimes, di≈ø≈øolved fir≈øt, and ≈øtrained, with Wine, Vinegar, and Oyle; la≈øtly Turpentine is to be mixt, and all to be boyled to a due con≈øi≈øtence, which when tis done, and taken from the fire, the powders mu≈øt be put in by little and little, and continually ≈øtird about, that they may be brought into one ma≈ø≈øe, with the re≈øt, of which being cooled, but before it growes hard, are to be fa≈øhioned, in the ≈øimilitude of a Pyramid, or a long Rolle, or Rollers, and be kept for u≈øe, of the which when tis nece≈ø≈øary, a part may be cut off, and if need be ≈øoftned ≈øomewhat with convenient Oyle, ≈øpred on Linnen, and applyed to the skin.

The proportion of mixture, can ≈øcarce be defined exactly, and ≈øtrictly, and if any error be committed, it may ea≈øily be corrected by boyling or mingling of more dry, or liquid things; but this proportion for the mo≈øt part is ob≈øerved, that to an ounce of dry things, there is taken of Oyle, Fat, or Honey, three Ounces, of Wax a pound, of Ro≈øin eight Ounces: But if boyled, and pounded Herbs are added, a little handfull, requires an Ounce, or an Ounce and halfe of Oyle, or Grea≈øe, ≈øo that the proportion of Wax to Ro≈øin is ≈øix-≈øold, to Oyle foure-fold, to Powders double: but if the quantity of Ro≈øin be greater, there needs the le≈ø≈øe Wax.

Sometimes before the Emplai≈øtick ma≈ø≈øe be cooled a Linnen Empla≈øtick Web.
cloath that is worne out by age is dipt in, and when tis bedaubed with the ≈øub≈øtance of the Plai≈øter, tis taken out, extended, cooled, and kept for u≈øe; which kind of Plai≈øters, they called Empla≈øtick Webbs of cloath, and Sparadrapum, and applyed them for clean≈øing of Ulcers, Glutinating, Cicatrizing, and other u≈øes.

And the≈øe are properly called Plai≈øters, yet ≈øome things are referred to Plai≈øters al≈øo, which are prepared without Wax, Pitch, and tho≈øe Glutinous things, and without fire, and are compounded with Honey, Mu≈øcellages, and a certain thick juice, or Barme, or only with a little Wax, melted with Oyle; of which kind is the Plai≈øter of Bay-berries and de Gru≈øta panis, and ≈øuch like, which are as it were in the middle, betwixt Plai≈øters, and Catapla≈ømes.

div.head: CHAP. XXXVII. Of Catapla≈ømes.
div.p: CAtapla≈ømes, which the Ancients called Pulta≈øes, A Catapla≈øme. are Topicall medicines ≈øoft, and having the con≈øi≈øtence of Pulta≈øes, and are prepared to a≈ø≈øwage paine, repell, mollify, di≈øcu≈ø≈øe, to ripen, and other ends.
1. They are either prepared without fire and boyling, How made. or with fire and boyling, from whence the one is called crude, the other boyled.
Without fire, greene Plants are pounded, and reduced into a Poultice, or dry, reduced into Powder, are mingled with a ≈øufficient quantity, namely double, or trebble, of Oyle, or a convenient Liquor.

2. They are made with fire, and boyling, if the plants being beaten, and pounded, are boyled in a ≈øufficient quantity of water, till they are ≈øoft; afterwards ≈øtrained through a ≈øeive, which neverthele≈ø≈øe, if they are well boyled, and brui≈øed is not allwayes nece≈ø≈øary, to the≈øe are added Mu≈øcellages, Flowre, and a ≈øufficient quantity of Fat, and Oyle, and are all boyled againe to the con≈øi≈øtence of a Poultice, ≈øometimes plants al≈øo are immediatly boyled in Oyle.
The Catapla≈ømes being prepared, and put on a piece of linnen are applied hot to the part.

div.head: CHAP. XXXVIII. Of Medicines to take away Haire, Salves made of Mu≈øtard, Medicines cau≈øing Wheales, or Pu≈øties in the body, and Ve≈øicatories, or Medicines that cau≈øe Bli≈øters.
div.p: A Dropax, or any thing to take away haire, a Synapi≈øme, or a Salve made of Mu≈øtard, a Phaenigne, a Medicine to cau≈øe Wheales, or Pu≈øtles, differ not from the forme of a Catapla≈øme, yet for ≈øome certaine peculiar effects which they produce, Authors have been plea≈øed to ≈øeparate them from other Cerots, Plai≈øters, and Catapla≈ømes.

Dropax in Greek, A Dropax. with the Latines Picatio, is a Medicine compo≈øed in the forme of a Plai≈øter, or Catapla≈øme, powerfully ≈øticking to the skin, which heretofore was exhibited to extenuate and relax the Member, to heat and draw more ≈øtore of blood, as is ≈øpoken before, part 2. Sect. 2. Cap. 5. or to dry moi≈øter bodies; It is two-fold, the one ≈øimple, Its differences. which con≈øi≈øts of Pitch and Oyle melted together, the other compound, which be≈øides Pitch and Oyle, hath in it, Pepper, Ca≈øtor, Pellitory, Bittony, Galbanum, Brim≈øtone, Nitre, or the a≈øhes of Vine-twiggs, and other things which are needfull; out of all which a Plai≈øter is made with Oyle and Pitch, which is put in a peice of Leather, or linnen cloath, and applied to the member, being hot, the haire ≈øhaved before hand, and the part well rubbed, and before tis quite cold, is twitched off againe, and put to the fire againe, and applied to the part againe, and that is ≈øo often repeated, untill the part growes red, and is ≈øomewhat ≈øwelled.

Synapi≈ømes are Catapla≈ømes, A Synapi≈øme. or Plai≈øters, principally con≈øi≈øting of Mu≈øtard-≈øeed, from whence they have their names, or other things are compounded, which are of the ≈øame nature with mu≈øtard-≈øeed, and they are two-fold, the
one more mild and gentle, which the Greeks call Phoinigmon, becau≈øe it makes the skin look red, and is to draw out the matter which lies ≈øo deep hid in the body, to its ≈øuperficies. A Ve≈øicatory. The other is ≈øtronger which al≈øo rai≈øeth bli≈øters in the part to which it is applied, which they properly call Ve≈øi catories.

The Ancients made Synapi≈ømes of Mu≈øtard ≈øeed, How to prepare Synapi≈ømes. or ≈øheere-gra≈ø≈øe, dry Figgs were macerated in warme water, the next day after Mu≈øtard-≈øeed pounded was mixt with that pulpe, and if a ≈øtronger Synapi≈øme were required, they would mingle two parts of Mu≈øtard with one of Figgs, but if weaker, one part of Mu≈øtard-≈øeed, and two parts of Figgs,: If indifferent equall parts, being mixed they were applied to the part affected,, and left there ≈øo long, till the skin run down with moi≈øture, and looked red.

Other Medicines al≈øo, both making red, How to make Ve≈øicatories. and cau≈øing Bli≈øters, are mentioned before, part the fir≈øt, Sect. the fir≈øt, Cap. 10. and are mingled with honey, Oxymell with Squills, Vinegar with Squills, Melle Anarcardino, Spirit of Wine, Turpentine, Soap, the crum of bread, and G ‚Ä¢ mme, with ≈øharp things and Plai≈øters, and Catapla≈ømes are made of them, whether to cau≈øe the part to look red, and burn onely, or to rai≈øe bli≈øters. The principall thing to rai≈øe bli≈øters is a medicine compounded of Cantharides, and Leaven. When a bli≈øter is rai≈øed by a medicine, and is broken, tis not forthwith to be dried, but to be permitted to run, that the humour which we de≈øire to evacuate, revell, or derive, may flow out, and therefore ≈øome fat unguent, or a Figg, or the leaves of Coleworts, are to ‚Ä¢ e put to it.

div.head: CHAP XXXIX. Of Epithems (which are ≈øomewhat moi≈øter then Plai≈øters) Medicines made of Vinegar and Ro≈øes, and of Medicines applied to the Temples, to ≈øtop fluxes of Rehume from falling to the eyes.
div.p:
ALlthough all medicines which are externally adplied to the body may be called Epithems, Epithems yet by cu≈øtome tho≈øe onely are called ≈øo at this day which con≈øi≈øt of di≈øtilled waters, decoctions, or juices mingled with ≈øpecies and powders, and are externally applied, principally to the region of the
Liver, Spleen, Heart, Stomach, fore-head, and joynts.

As for the matter whereof they are made, tis various according to their ≈øeverall intentions: of di≈øtilled waters, Juices, Decoctions, Oyles, either alone, or mixt, Epithemes are applyed for the mittigation of heate, re≈øi≈øting of humours, that flow, ≈øtrengthning the parts, and Liquors, or Powders that are appropriated to any part what≈øoever, are to be applyed.

Epithemes are prepared two wayes, How prepared. fir≈øt of liquid things only, di≈øtilled waters or juices are taken convenient for the di≈øea≈øe and proper for the part, to which ≈øometimes, ≈øome Vinegar, or Wine for penetration ≈øake is added: afterwards Species or Powders, beaten very fine a drachm and a halfe or two drachms, to a Pint, and ≈øometimes more Powder is taken: the matter of the Epitheme is pre≈øcribed according to the magnitude of the part, from three Ounces to a pint, the mixture in the fir≈øt place hath a linnen or wollen cloath Cotten, or Spunge dipt in it, and ≈øtird about, when tis to be u≈øed lea≈øt the Powder ≈øhould ≈øettle in the bottome, and for the mo≈øt part tis applyed warme, and as often as tis taken off, tis dipt into it againe, and applyed.
Sometimes certaine Powders are put in, but they are fir≈øt macerated in fountaine water.

To Epithemes belong Oxyrhodes, Epithemes for the fore-head. as they are called, which are Epithemes peculiar to the fore-head, prepared of Oyle of Ro≈øes, and Vinegar, to coole, and repell; The Ancients, tooke of Oyle of Ro≈øes three parts, and of Vinegar one part, and ≈øtird them well together, wherein they dipt a peice of leather, or skin and applyed it to the forehead; At this day al≈øo other Oyles, as of Violets, Myrtles, Nimphaea, or water Lillies, and ≈øometimes di≈øtilled waters, and Powders are added Santalls, and other things.

To the≈øe are referred anacollemata, Anacollemata. which are wont to be applyed for di≈øea≈øes of the Eyes, and Hemorhodes of the no≈øe, principally to the fore-head, ≈øo called for this rea≈øon, whether they con≈øi≈øt of medicines that fill up, glutinate, and have an a≈øtringent quality, becau≈øe they ≈øtop the violence of humours that flow into them, or becau≈øe by their clammine≈ø≈øe, they adhere, and as it were ≈øtick like glue to the part to which they are applyed.
And they are prepared of Volatile or fine Flowre, How prepared. Bolearmoniack, Dragons-blood, Acacia, ma≈øtick, Manna, Frankincen≈øe, and ≈øuch like, mixt with the white of an Egg.

2. Yet they are often prepared without the white of an Egge, to mittigate the paine of the head, or cau≈øe ≈øleepe which are applyed, either with a Leather, or a skin dipt therein, or inclo≈øed in a little bagg, and they are more properly called Epithemes, or Frontells.

div.head: CHAP. XL. Of Medicines applyed Plai≈øter-wayes to mittigate paine, and of little Bags.
div.p: LIke unto Epithemes, are Fomentaes, ≈øo called, Fomentations. becau≈øe they doe by their heate, as it were cheri≈øh the parts of the body to which they are applyed, and they are exhibited either to heate the parts, or to clean≈øe, and di≈øcu≈ø≈øe, or to mittigate paine, or ≈øoften that which is hard. Differences of Fomentations. Moi≈øt.

1. And they are two-≈øold, moi≈øt, and dry; the moi≈øt are made either of hot water, Oyle, Milke, or wine, or decoctions of Plants, made with warer, wine, Vinegar, Milke, whither a ≈øpunge, or linnen cloath, an≈øwerable, to the magnitude of the part affected, is dipt whil≈øt it is hot, and applyed to the part, and when they begin to be luke-warme, or to coole, they are changed for hot, or the ≈øame are heat againe in the Liquor.

2. Sometimes, ≈øimples, included in Linnen baggs, are boyled in water, wine, or Milke, and are applyed hot to the part affected, for which purpo≈øe, tis convenient to prepare two Baggs, that when the one is cooled, the other may be applyed.
3. Sometimes, a Hoggs Bladder, or an Oxe his Bladder, is halfe filled with the Liquor of the decoction and applyed hot to the part affected.

4. Fomentations, are made al≈øo, of living Creatures di≈ø≈øected, and as yet warme, e≈øpecially Pidgeons, as al≈øo of the parts of living Creatures newly ≈ølaine, whil≈øt they are hot, as the Lungs, Paunch, o ‚Ä¢ Oyles made of the ≈øame.

5. Sometimes the ≈øteam onely of Waters, of Wine or Vineger boiled, is ≈øtirred up by the fire onely, or by ca≈øting in of ≈øtones or Irons burning into the Liquour, or ≈øome of the Liquour poured on them is applied to the part; the vapour is taken by a Pipe or Tunnel with a wide orifice, or it is put about the part with ≈øome covering, whereby the ≈øteam being detained and included, it may act the ≈øtronger on the part affected.

But dry Fomentations are made with Bags, Dry. the Bags are compounded of Herbs, Flowers, Barks, Roots, Seeds, Aromaticks, Gums, which are agreeable to the pre≈øent intention, being cut and pounded proportionable to the figure and magnitude of the part affected, are put into a Bag, and applied to the part, for a cordial Bag an Ounce, or an Ounce and half may ≈øuffice, for the ≈øtomack a greater quantity is required.

The Bag is prepared either of Linnen or Silk, and being pricked through with a Needle is applied dry to the part, and ≈øometimes it is wet in Wine or Vineger, and put on a hot ≈øtone or brick heated by the fire, it is applied to the part affected and makes it warm.

div.head: CHAP. XLI. Of Embrocations, Lotions, and Bathes.
div.p: THe like≈øt to Fomentations are Embrocations, or Waterings, Lotions, and Bathes, all which ≈øignifie rather a certain manner of u≈øing, than any Compo≈øition and Forme of Medicine, and they contain for the mo≈øt part the ≈øame matter with moi≈øt Fomentations.

Embrochee, Embrocations. is a certain di≈øtillation or dropping down of a moi≈øt humour from above like Rain: the dropping which is made on any part is performed, either by pouring water out of a ve≈ø≈øel, with a long ≈ønout, or by dropping out of a Laver.

Tis applied principally to three parts; Fir≈øt, upon the Coronall Suture, in di≈øtempers of the braine, and the moi≈øture runs no further, then the Sagittall ≈øuture. Secondly, from the beginning of the ≈øpinall marrow, in di≈øea≈øes of the Nerves and the moi≈øture is terminated at the end of the ≈øpine. Thirdly,
to heat or dry the ≈øtomach, and the matter is ≈øuffered to run over all the belly: if the guts al≈øo are weak, a Cerat with Santals is to be applied to the liver, if there be feare of inflaming it, the matter to be ≈øo di≈øtilled is common water, water of Bathes, decoctions, milk, oyle, according as the part affected requires it.

Some Lotions are exhibited to certain parts which are called particular Lotions, Lotions. others to the inferiour parts of the body onely, which are commonly calted Ince≈ø≈øus, and Semicuoium, i. e. a Ve≈ø≈øell that you may ≈øit upright in, others are fit for the whole body, which are called Bathes.
Peculiar Lotions principally u≈øe to be admini≈øtred to the head, hands, and feet, and are prepared as Fomentations of hearbs, or faire water, or boiled in a lee, Wine, or Oyle.

Ince≈ø≈øus, which the Greeks call Encathi≈øma, Ince≈ø≈øus. is a bath for the belly, and inferiour parts wherein the di≈øea≈øed mu≈øt ≈øit up to the Navell, and ≈øuch bathing Ve≈ø≈øels ≈øerve for ≈øeverall u≈øes, ≈øometimes to mittigate paine, ≈øometimes to ≈øoften and di≈øcu≈ø≈øe wind, ≈øometimes they are u≈øed to provoke cour≈øes.
A Bath is a wa≈øhing of the whole body, A Bath. and is admini≈øtred either for clean≈øing and taking away the faults of the skin, or to relax the parts; or for ≈øome di≈øtemper of the whole.

Some bathes are naturall, others are made by Art. The Differences. Among≈øt the naturall bathes the plaine≈øt is that of Fountainewater, which hath a power of heating and moi≈øtning, and therefore is convenient for ≈øuch as are Hectick. Nature al≈øo affords bathes, for the imitation of bathes artificiall, and of naturall Bathes, the Phy≈øitian may prepare many things to ≈øupply the want of them.

div.head: CHAP. XLII. Of Soapes.
div.p: SOap al≈øo, Sapones. or Wa≈øh-balls are u≈øed to certaine parts of the body, which are prepared in this manner;

There is taken of Venice Soap made ≈ømooth, How mad ‚Ä¢
or of ≈øome other good and white Soap as much as is ≈øufficient, to which is added ≈øix or eight times ≈øo much Powder, and all of them are mingled in a ≈øufficient quantity of a water that is proper,
and reduced into one ma≈ø≈øe, from whence round Balls are made in the forme of an Apple.
They are exhibited principally to clean≈øe the body, or ≈øome parts thereof, and to give a plea≈øant ≈øent to it.

div.head: CHAP. XLIII. Of Cauteries.
div.p: LA≈øtly, Cauteries. That we may ≈øpeak ≈øomething al≈øo of Potentiall Cauteries, their preparation is manifold, and there is no man, but here will ≈øomewhat boa≈øt: But the mo≈øt profitable which will make an E≈øcarre ≈øoone≈øt without paine, and other Symptomes, is that which is thus prepared;

Take the Lee, whereof black Soap is made and put it into a Frying-pan, till it become almo≈øt as hard as a ≈øtone, and when it growes cold cut it into the forme of great Dice, and let it be kept in a gla≈ø≈øe clo≈øe ≈øhut, lea≈øt it ≈øhould melt, and it is commonly called the Corra≈øive ≈øtone; the u≈øe whereof is very frequent at this day; to quicken Ulcers, by the which humours may be diverted from the more noble parts, to the ignoble, and therefore they are called I≈ø≈øues, or Fontanells.

div.head: Book I. Of Fevers in General, and of an Ephemera, and of a Synocha with Putrefaction.
CHAP. I. Of the Nature of a Fever.
div.p: THat which is called by the Latines a Fever, The name. of a Fever by the Greeks (from fire) is called the fiery di≈øtemper; Hippocrates plainly calls it fire, if it be very vehement, as being by the con≈øent of all men a hot di≈øtemper; For although ≈øome Germans call it Daskalte, yet that appellation belongs not to every Fever, neither doth it expre≈øs the nature of a Fever, but only ≈øignifieth Cold, An intermitting Fever may be ≈øo called.

A Fever is a hot di≈øtemper of the whole body, ati≈øing from heat, kindled contrary to nature in the heart, Its definition and nature. and by the mediation of the Blood and Spirits, conveyed through the veins and arteries to all the parts, and hindring natural actions, unle≈øs it be prevented.

And indeed a hot di≈øtemper only con≈øtitutes a Fever; Drine≈øs is no part of the E≈ø≈øence of a Fever. for although all fevouri≈øh heat tend to drine≈øs, yet that drine≈øs is not ≈øickne≈øs in all Fevers, neither is the body by fevouri≈øh heat rendred unfit to perform its natural actions, it is ≈øo by drine≈øs in every Fever that the natural actions are hindred; but although the fevouri≈øh heat always tend to drine≈øs, yet oftentimes the di≈øpo≈øition of the body wherein that heat acteth, and moi≈øture therewithal, hinders the production of a di≈øea≈øe by drine≈øs.

The adequate Subject of a Fever is the whole body, The Subject. or certainly mo≈øt of its parts, but the principal is the heart, as being that wherein that heat is fir≈øt kindled, and from thence communicated to all the other parts of the body, unle≈øs it be hindred; nor can a Fever be generated, unle≈øs the heart fir≈øt become hot. Indeed the whole body is the Subject of a Fever in regard of the ≈øimiliar parts, and as it is indued with actual heat, which is as it were kindled by the innate and influent heat; For this heat when it is changed and converted into a fiery heat from a temperate and moderate, a Fever is ≈øtirred up.

The immediate cau≈øe of a Fever is heat kindled in the heart contrary to nature, The proximate cau≈øe. and diffu≈øed over all the body; For as the heart while≈øt it is well and according to nature, is the fountain of natural heat, and di≈øper≈øeth the ≈øame over all the body, ≈øo if it grow hot contrary to nature, it di≈øtributes that unnatural heat over all the parts. For although a Fever may be kindled by the inflamation of other parts likewi≈øe, yet that happens not unle≈øs that heat be fir≈øt ≈øent to the heart, and afterwards from thence to all the parts of the body, whence it comes to pa≈øs that in every Fever the Pul≈øe is changed. Neverthele≈øs every kind of heat in the heart is not ≈øufficient to
cau≈øe a Fever, but ≈øuch a kind of heat it ought to be, as can cau≈øe ≈øuch a hot di≈øea≈øe as can hinder the performance of natural actions.

Whence 'tis manife≈øt that a Fever is one thing, A Fever and feveri≈øh heat differ. and a feavouri≈øh heat another thing. A Fever properly is that hot di≈øtemper which happens in the living parts of a body, and renders them unable to act; but the fevouri≈øh heat is al≈øo in the humors and ≈øpirits, and ≈øtirrs up that hot di≈øtemper of the body, which con≈øtitutes the e≈ø≈øence of a Fever.

div.head: CHAP: II. Of the cau≈øes of Fevers in general.
div.p: ALthough there is but one only cau≈øe of a hot di≈øtemper of the whole body, which con≈øtitutes the e≈ø≈øence of a Fever, namely, preter-natural heat kindled in the heart, and thence di≈øtributed over all the body, yet the cau≈øes from whence that heat in the heart ari≈øeth, are ≈øeveral, as Galen of the cau≈øes of di≈øea≈øes, cap. 2. and in the fir≈øt book of differences of di≈øea≈øes, cap. 3. recites five, Motion, Putrefaction, Contact of ≈øome hot thing, Cloa≈øure of the pores of the skin, or a Retention of a hot ≈øtream; and la≈øtly Mixture with ≈øome hot thing: And of the≈øe cau≈øes, ≈øome by them≈øelves, and ≈øome by accident ≈øtir up heat.

Fir≈øt from Motion, Motion. ≈øithence the Spirits and humours of our bodies are hot, from the confluence of them into any part, according to the various motion of the body and mind, heat is increa≈øed, which if it be greater, and be either kindled in the heart, or communicated to the heart, a Fever en≈øueth.

Secondly, Putrefaction excites heat. Putrefaction. For ≈øince all things that do putrifie become hotter, and out of putred bodies are exalted many hot vapours, thence heat is conveyed to the heart by the veins and arteries, and from thence a Fever rai≈øed.
Thirdly, contact of a hot thing exciteth a Fever: Contact of a hot thing. As if the body wax hot by the Sun, Fire, Bath, or Medicine, and that heat be ≈øent to the heart a Fever followeth.

Fourthly, if the pores of the skin are clo≈øed, and a hot ≈øtream and hallituous excrements, Retention of a hot ≈øteam. which in concoction are generated in the body, and u≈øe to be ≈øent out through the pores of the skin, be penn'd in, heat is thereby kindled, and a Fever bred.

La≈øtly, when hot things are mingled with humours and ≈øpirits, as meat, drink, hot Medicines, all tho≈øe communicate
that heat which they contained in them≈øelves to the Spirits and humours, which if they penetrate the heart, and from thence be di≈øtributed to the other parts of the body, a Fever is thereby kindled.

And indeed the fourth of the≈øe cau≈øes, or the retention of the hot effluvium, is ≈øufficient alone without the re≈øt to cau≈øe a Fever: But the other cau≈øes without this can hardly do it. For although from Motion, Putrefaction, Contact, and Mixture with a hot thing, hot vapours are ≈øtirred up in the body; yet if the body freely ventilate, and that ≈øo much be daily evaporated and emitted of tho≈øe vapours as are generated, a Fever is not ea≈øily occa≈øioned, but when tho≈øe vapours are detained, a Fever is ≈øoon kindled.

But although the≈øe cau≈øes if they be powerful, Di≈øpo≈øition of a body to a Fever. may rai≈øe a Fever in any body what≈øoever, yet in bodies inclinable an ordinary power in the cau≈øes may ≈øuffice to beget a Fever. Now they are mo≈øt inclinable to Fevers which abound with much heat, ≈øalt and ≈øharp humours: For which rea≈øon Youths are more apt to Fevers, of which you may read, Galen 8 Of the Method of healing, cap. 8. where the whole order of Inclinations to Fevers are ≈øet down. 1. Hot and dry. 2 hot and moi≈øt. 3. hot only. 4. dry only. 5. temperate. 6. cold and dry. 7. cold only. 8. moi≈øt only. 9. cold and moi≈øt. Yet to another kind of Fevers other bodies are more inclinable.

div.head: CHAP. III. Of the Symptomes of a Fever in general.
div.p:
WHereas in a Fever the temper of a body is changed, Symptomes of Fevers. and rendred hotter, hence certain Symptomes of Fevers mu≈øt nece≈ø≈øarily en≈øue: And fir≈øt of all it is hence manife≈øt, that tho≈øe actions are e≈øpecially hindred, which ≈øhould be performed by the ≈øimilar parts as they are ≈øuch, and by the benefit of the temper of each ≈øuch part, no organick part concurring. Such action ≈øince it is Nutrition, and tho≈øe that are ≈øub≈øervient thereunto, they are e≈øpecially hurt in Fevers. Yet becau≈øe the In≈øtruments by which other actions are performed, con≈øi≈øts of ≈øimilar parts, that imperfection is derived to the hinderance of them, as of vital and animal actions. Indeed the vital actions are principally hurt in a Fever, becau≈øe the fevouri≈øh heat is fir≈øt kindled in the heart. Whence in all Fevers the Pul≈øe becomes more frequent and ≈øwifter; for ≈øince the motion of Pul≈øes in all Fevers may be increa≈øed,
fir≈øt, a thick Pul≈øe, as being mo≈øt facile of all; but if that frequency ≈øatisfies not the nece≈ø≈øity, celerity happens, which if that be not ≈øufficient, then magnitude follows: So that the ≈øtrength be not debilitated: The animal actions al≈øo are often hurt. As for other Symptomes, preter-natural heat is ob≈øerved to offend internally or externally. Al≈øo the excrements and qualities of a body are variou≈øly changed by rea≈øon of the hinderances of concoctions.

div.head: CHAP. IV. Of the differences of Fevers in general.
div.p: THe differences of Fevers are taken from their e≈ø≈øence, Differences. or from their accidents. Hippocrat 6. Epid. comment. text. 29. propounds the differences taken from the heat it ≈øelf of the Fever, that ≈øome Fevers are biring, namely, ≈øuch as ≈øtrike the hand of them that touch them, and by rea≈øon of that ≈øharp vapour, which is ≈øtirr'd up by putted matter, it doth as it were prick the hand; but a mild one is ≈øuch as hath trouble≈øome heat, but not ≈øo violent. Moreover the heat o ‚Ä¢ ≈øome Fevers at the fir≈øt touch is not ≈øharp, and nipping, but if the hand be continued longer, afterwards it betrayes it≈øelf. On the contrary others are quick at fir≈øt to the touch, but if the hand continue longer, it is overcome by the hand, and a little abated.

But tho≈øe are the mo≈øt proper differences which are taken from inherence in the Subject, and the cau≈øe of inhering, which Fevers are divided into Ephemeraes, putred and hectick, the true≈øt foundation of which divi≈øion is, that one Fever is in habitude, the other in habit, for although the fevouri≈øh heat in every Fever po≈ø≈øe≈øs the ≈øimilar parts of the body; yet ≈øome are ≈øo inherent in the body, that they require no cau≈øe to cheri≈øh them, and although they are not fed by the kindling of humours and Spirits, neverthele≈øs they will continue, which ≈øort are called Hecticks. Another hot di≈øtemper is ≈øo inherent in the ≈øimilar parts of the body, that unle≈øs it be cheri≈øhed by the kindling of humours and Spirits it can no more ≈øub≈øi≈øt, which Fever is called a Fever in habitude, which in re≈øpect of the cau≈øe is twofold, an Ephemera, to which al≈øo a Synocha without putrefaction is referred; and a putrid.

There is another thing worth the noting, that one Fever is Primary, another Symptomatical, Primary is that which follows no former di≈øea≈øe, but depends on its proper cau≈øe: Secondary
or Symptomatical is that which ari≈øeth from the inflamation of any member. See Galen. 4. Aphor. 7.

But of Symptomatical this is to be noted, that tho≈øe which by the ancients were accounted Symptomatical, were indeed primary many of them, and inflamations of the parts, of the Membrane that covers the ribbs, of the lungs or chopps, rather happened to tho≈øe parts, then the Fever to take it's ri≈øe from them: Feavers accompanied. div.p: THere remains another kind of Fever, An Ephemera of many days. called Ephemera, to which that appellation doth not belong, becau≈øe it is extended more dayes: Yet it can be referr'd to no other ≈øort of Fever then this more conveniently; therefore although Ephemera ≈øhould ≈øignifie the e≈ø≈øence of the Fever, Ephemera is ≈øo called though with the addition of more dayes.

Of either of which kinds of Fevers there are again many differences; For either the putrefaction is kindled in the common ve≈ø≈øels, and not in private pa≈ø≈øages, whence ari≈øe continued Fovers, called Primary: Or the putredity comes by the inflammation of ≈øome peculiar part, and from thence putred vapours are continually communicated to the heart, which Fevers are called Symptomatical.

Primary continued again are two-fold, for ≈øome have no augmentation,
nor remi≈ø≈øion, which they call Fevers containing, or fiery Synochaes.
Others are continued, yet there is ≈øome increa≈øe of heat, and ≈øometimes remi≈øne≈øs, which are called Synochaes, and by the general name of continual Fevers.

The continual for the time of their increa≈øe and decrea≈øe of heat, ≈øome are called tertian, others quotidian, others quartan, according as the heat is exa≈øperated, dayly, each other day, or the fourth day likewi≈øe.

Intermitting al≈øo according to the time of their invading, ≈øome are called, tertian, others quotidian, others quartan. Nay it is ob≈øerved that there are Fevers that have a longer di≈øtance between the Paroxi≈ømes.

div.head: CHAP. III. Of the ≈øignes of putred Fovers in general.
div.p: APutred Fever is known. The Diagnosticks. 1. From it's heat, which is more gnawing and acrid, then of any other Fever, and that in the increa≈øe and ≈øtate. For in the beginning of fits, the heat doth not at the fir≈øt touch of the Pul≈øe di≈øcover it's acrimony, but if the hand be continued longer it may be perceived, which proceeds from fuliginous vapours which exhale out of putred humours. 2. Becau≈øe it begins without any manife≈øt cau≈øe. Which indeed is a proper ≈øign, but not an in≈øeparable one, for as often as any Fever is kindled without any manife≈øt cau≈øe, you may well determine it to be a putred Fever: Yet ≈øometimes humours are ≈øo di≈øpo≈øed to putrefaction, that upon any light occa≈øion they'l become putred. 3. Urines in putred Fevers either are crude or el≈øe at lea≈øt afford but ob≈øcure notes of concoction, unle≈øs an Ephemeral be degenerated into a putred Fever, otherwi≈øe there is no putred Fever wherein the Urine in the beginning doth not appear crude or ob≈øcurely concocted. 4. The pul≈øe is more changed then in other Fevers. 5. Putred Fevers begin with a cold ≈øhaking. Which is a proper, but not an in≈øeparable ≈øign. 'Tis a proper ≈øign becau≈øe neither Diaries nor Hecticks do ever begin with cold ≈øhaking; yet it is not in≈øeperable, becau≈øe all putred Fevers do not begin with a cold fit, as a putred Synocha. 6. It is the property of putred Fevers to return by fits and Paroxi≈ømes; and no other Fever hath fits. Yet this is not an in≈øeperable ≈øign, becau≈øe it doth not agree with all putred Fevers. 7. La≈øtly, if any ≈øign be pre≈øent which is proper to any ≈øort of putred Fevers, 'tis a ≈øign it may admit of the general appellation of a putred Fever.

Concerning the event of putred Fevers in general not much can be ≈øpoken, The Progno≈øtick. ≈øince there is great variety and difference of putred Fevers, and the event various: Only this, that the event is be≈øt to be known by comparing the magnitude of the di≈øea≈øe with the ≈øtrength of the Patient; For if the patient be very ≈øtrong, there is much hope of a good end of it, if the party be weak, there is great danger.

div.head: CHAP. IV. Of the cure of putred Fevers in general.
div.p: NOw ≈øeeing a putred Fever is cheri≈øhed by the cau≈øe containing, Indications in putred Fevers. Indications in putred Fevers are taken ≈øome from the Fever it ≈øelf, others from the cau≈øe thereof. Nor indeed ought vital indications to be neglected. Fir≈øt, a Fever as it is a Fever, indicates cooling things; Moreover as that heat of the whole depends on a hot putred vapour, as on the cau≈øe containing, the removal of that is al≈øo indicated; but becau≈øe putred vapours depend on putred matter, they cannot be removed, unle≈øs the matter putrified be taken away; putrefaction cannot be taken away except its cau≈øe be removed, as we ≈øaid before. Fir≈øt, all evident cau≈øes which are pre≈øent are to be removed; the antecedent cau≈øes and what≈øoever is in the body, either of ≈øuperfluous blood or peccant humours, they are to be prepared. and if occa≈øion require, to be evacuated, ≈øtreightne≈øs of pa≈ø≈øages if it be external or interal in the bowels, they are to be opened and free ventilation and re≈øpiration for the humours is to be procured, Putrefaction is to be re≈øi≈øted, and the putred humours are to be cooled and dryed; the generation of peccant humours, by ablation of their cau≈øe is to be prevented. Yet neverthele≈øs ≈øeeing that the≈øe indications are often contrary, and that tho≈øe medicines which are admini≈øtred for the cau≈øe, may make the Fever wor≈øe, and the contrary. We mu≈øt be careful how to perform the≈øe intentions. And for the mo≈øt part, ≈øince the Fever comes la≈øt, the cau≈øe is to be taken away fir≈øt, ≈øince the cau≈øe hath more power then the di≈øea≈øe, and the cau≈øe of a putred Fever being taken away, the Fever of nece≈ø≈øity cea≈øeth.

Yet if the greatne≈øs of the Fever inforce, 'tis nece≈ø≈øary to have regard of the Fever fir≈øt; and afterwards to the taking away of the cau≈øe; or certainly if we may fir≈øt go to the taking away of the cau≈øe, we ≈øhould be very careful that by tho≈øe things by which we take away the cau≈øe, we increa≈øe not the Fever. But tho≈øe
things are never to be u≈øed for the cure of the Fever, which increa≈øeth its cau≈øe, fince that for the mo≈øt pare that is of greate≈øt force.

div.head: CHAP. V. Of breathing of a vein.
div.p:
NOw for the cure to be performed by the≈øe intentions, Letting blood. and fir≈øt concerning Phlebotomy. Galen 11. meth. medendi. cap. 15. gives this rule. It is mo≈øt whole≈øome he ≈øayes in all Fevers to open a vein, not only in continued, but al≈øo in all others which the putrifying humour ≈øtirreth up, Whether, when, and why to be done in a putred Fever. e≈øpecially when neither age nor want of ≈øtrength prohibites it. And he addeth this rea≈øon; For nature which rules our bodies being enlighthed, and unburthened of that by which as with a pack it was oppre≈ø≈øed, what remains, it will overcome without difficulty, and therefore not being forgetful of its proper office, will both concoct what can be concocted, and ca≈øt out what may be emitted. Yet this precept of Galen is to be rightly under≈øtood and explained. For although there are many occa≈øions for opening a vein, and Authors cannot agree about the rea≈øon why Galen commands Phlebotomy in putred Fevers: Yet 'tis clear he did it, that by evacuation of the blood, nature might be enlightened and freed from the greate≈øt part of her burthen, for when blood abounds, the opening of a vein, and purging of Cacochymy are the be≈øt remedies; furthermore when it is a plethorick body, without doubt we ≈øhould open a vein. In ≈øome mea≈øure the breathing of a vein, doth take away the cacochymy contained in the veins, and mixed with the blood, ≈øince the vein being opened, the vitious humours go out with the blood, e≈øpecially becau≈øe purgation which can take away foul humours out of the veins, is not ≈øo ≈øafe as the breathing of a vein to be appointed at the beginning of a Fever. For although Phlebotomy cannot take away all the ill humours out of the veins, yet nature is le≈ø≈øned ≈øome part of her burthen, and therefore can concoct and ma≈øter the remainder the more ea≈øily, for it may be that the plenty of blood, which before the ≈øickne≈øs was no trouble to the party, now being ≈øick and weakened with a Fever, may become burthen≈øom unto him. And although ≈øome good blood be emitted therewith, yet that hurts not the ≈øick, but rather helps, as is ≈øaid: As we al≈øo ≈øee by critical Hemorrhodes, that nature ≈øends out no ≈ømall quantity of good blood together. Yet nature for the mo≈øt part u≈øeth to
drive no ≈ømall part of peccant humours to the extream and ≈øubcutaneous parts; thence and in the fir≈øt place mo≈øt commonly the wor≈øt blood comes fir≈øt out. Whence it is manife≈øt e≈øpecially in continual Fevers, in tho≈øe who abound with blood, or have peccant humours mixt with their blood, that bleeding is proper, and that at the beginning, that nature may be unladed of part of her burthen, but if vitious humours are not intermingled with the blood in the greater veins, the breathing of a vein for evacuation thereof is not to be u≈øed.
Cooling and fanning the blood is performed by lerting blood: but they are only to be done when bleeding will not cool it alone. Rules allowing Phlebotomy.

We are not only to ob≈øerve whether bleeding be needful, but al≈øo whether the party be ≈øtrong enough to ≈øuffer it, when the ≈øtrength of the vital faculty is principally to be required, ≈øo that the ≈øtrength do not langui≈øh by too great ≈øtore of blood ≈øuffocating the Spirits, Age, Habit of body, and condition of the ambient air ≈øhew the ≈øtrength.

But how much blood is to be taken away, The quantity that may be taken. fir≈øt by the plenty of blood, then by comparing the ≈øtrength of the Patient with the greatne≈øs of the di≈øea≈øe, will be manife≈øt; for greater quantity requires larger emi≈ø≈øion, le≈ø≈øer, le≈øs; robu≈øtious bodies require larger breathings of veins, weaker require le≈øs. The ≈øtrength varies according to temperament, habit of body, age, ≈øex, ≈øea≈øon of the year, the condition of the Heavens, and the Region, as al≈øo in regard of certain Symptomes, which u≈øe to be accompanied with Fevers, as of watchings, pain, and ≈øuch like.

As for the time for letting blood, The time. 'tis to be done when 'tis indicated, and no way prohibited; which is in the beginning, and by how much the more the di≈øea≈øe ha≈øtens to increa≈øe, ≈øo much the ≈øooner blood is to be taken away, The place. but if the concoctions are more dull and ≈ølow, Pulebotomy may be deferr'd longer.

Veins that are opened for evacuation are be≈øt in the middle of the arm; yet if the ≈øick be weak, and that al≈øo revul≈øion is to be made from the head, the veins in the foot are to be opened to the greate≈øt benefit of the ≈øick.

div.head: CHAP. VI. Of Purging.
div.p:
BUt becau≈øe all putred Fevers have their original from foul humours: Purgation Now we are to con≈øider by what means they may
be evacuated, but ≈øeeing tho≈øe things which evacuate them are twofold, Lenitives and Purges, properly ≈øo called: Lenitives are ≈øafely to be admini≈øtred in the beginning of all putred Fevers, becau≈øe there are ≈øcarce any bodies wherein the ≈øtomack, guts, and Me≈øaraick veins contain not ≈øome of the peccant humours.

The≈øe evacuations are to be cau≈øed by Cly≈øters, Cly≈øters. called loo≈øening medicines, and by vomit. The Cly≈øters are made of Mallows, Mar≈øh-mallows, Violets, Pellitory, Beares-breech, Mercury, common Oil, or mixt with Violets, brown Sugar, Ca≈ø≈øia, Lenitives. Elect Lenitive, Diacatholicon Hiera, and ≈øuch like.

Or tho≈øe lenitive medicines may be given which are at this day in u≈øe: Syrrup of Ro≈øes ≈øolutive, of Violets ≈øolutive, Honey of Ro≈øes ≈øolutive, Tamarinds, Ca≈ø≈øia, Manna, the lenitive Electuary ≈øimple, Cream of Tartar.
You mu≈øt u≈øe ≈øuch medicines at the times of remi≈øne≈øs and intermittings, when the Fever lea≈øt offendeth, whether it be carly in the morning or in the evening.

Sometimes al≈øo in the beginning of Fevers you may admini≈øter a vomit; when great ≈øtore of matter is contained in the ≈øtomack and adjacent parts, whereof no concoction can be expected, the which u≈øeth to corrupt and putrifie in the body, and oftentimes that is ea≈øily vomited out, which with great difficulty is purged out. Vomits.

The Vomits are ≈øet down in the fifth Book of the In≈øtitutions part. 1. Sect. 1. cap. 12. Some give at this day the roots of A≈øarabecca, from half a drachm to a drachm. The Chymi≈øts u≈øe white Vitriol, Salt of Vitriol, Medicines prepared of Antimony; which do not open only the fir≈øt pa≈ø≈øages, but ≈øtir the whole body: The≈øe are to be u≈øed with much caution, and as Hippoc. Purging medicines. 1 Aphor. 24. Not without skilful advice.

Concerning Purgers at what time they are to be u≈øed, there is great controver≈øie; for although vitious humours at any time during the de≈øea≈øe, ≈øhew that they ought to be taken away; Yet they ought not to be evacuated at any time, but in≈øtead of an Oracle, Galen admoni≈øheth four of pre≈øervation of health, c. 5. the Aphori≈øme of Hippocrates is to be had in e≈øteem, 22. Sect. 1. Such as are concocted and ripe, ought to be purged and removed, not crude; neither in the beginnings, unle≈øs the matter trouble much, which ≈øeldom cometh to pa≈øs. But although ≈øome interpret this Aphori≈øm otherwi≈øe, yet if it be diligently con≈øidered, 'twill be manife≈øt, that Hippocrates meant to ≈øpeak only of putred Fevers, and of no other di≈øea≈øe, and by crude humours intends tho≈øe that by rea≈øon of their putre≈øection in putred Fevers
ought not to be purged, being unfit; by concocted he intends ≈øuch as are fitting to be purged: The words crudity and concoction, being tran≈ø≈øated from their proper ≈øignification of crudity and concoction to excrementitious humours.

Although there are certain other preparations of humours for purgation both in Fevers and out of Fevers: Concoction of humors. Yet the name of concoction belongs not to them, and we mu≈øt di≈øtingui≈øh betwixt concoction and preparation of humours. Concoction, whereof Hippocrates ≈øpeaketh, is a reducing of the putred humours into a better condition, and le≈øs obnoxious to the body, and a ≈øeparation of them from good blood, that they may the more profitably be evacuated out of the body; hence concoction belongs only to humours, which are contained in the Veins, and mixed with the blood, but tho≈øe that are in other places, and not mixed with the blood, may be purged at any time. For the≈øe humours unle≈øs they are reduced to a certain mediocrity as they are capable of, and are ≈øeperated from laudable blood, the Phy≈øician in vain, and with much detriment to the ≈øick, endeavours to expell them by purging. For neither will the humours follow the foregoing medicine, neither hath the Phy≈øician nature for his a≈ø≈øi≈øtant, ≈øince the matter is only ≈øtirr'd and troubled, and various Symptomes ari≈øe; either the ≈øtrength is weakned by the vio ‚Ä¢ ence of a ≈øtrong medicine, or the native heat is con≈øumed and weakened.

Yet flatulent humours may be purged without concoction; Flatulent humours. For although the≈øe are not as yet concocted, yet becau≈øe there is not only danger le≈øt they ≈øhould fall upon ≈øome principal part, but al≈øo becau≈øe being thin, and already in motion, they ea≈øily follow their leading medicine; and the Phy≈øician hath nature to a≈ø≈øi≈øt him, which alone ≈øometimes expells ≈øuch humours at the beginning, to the great advantage of the ≈øick. But by flatulent humours here, we are not to under≈øtand only tho≈øe which hitherto are moved to no determinate part, but al≈øo tho≈øe which although they ru≈øh into ≈øome part yet they are ≈øtill moveable, and ≈øo di≈øpo≈øed, that they'l ea≈øily remove into another part, and according to their manner, are hitherto wandring, but have not any fixed ≈øeat any where.

Concoction, whereof we here ≈øpeak, is the work of nature only, which when 'tis ≈øtrong, gives what perfection they are capable of receiving, even to the vitious humours, as may be ≈øeen in the generation of quitture; and this concoction is made only in putred Fevers‚ñ™ For while≈øt the humours ferment in the veins, like new wine, and the good and bad are mixt together,
and cannot ea≈øily be ≈øeperated: They are called crude, but when the humours are appea≈øed and cooled, and the good may ea≈øily be ≈øeperated from the evil, they are ≈øaid to be concocted.

div.head: CHAP. VII. Of Concoction and Seperation of humours.
div.p: ALthough the concoction of humours be the work of nature only. Yet a Phy≈øician may help her by his medicines, which may either cheri≈øh and ≈øtrengthen the native heat, or take away impediments which may hinder nature in concocting, Dige≈øtive medicines. and reduce the exce≈øs of qualities to mediocrity. And medicines of the latter of the≈øe two kinds are called Dige≈øtives and Concoctives, namely, ≈øuch as cool the hot humours, heat the cold, moi≈øten the dry, attenuate the thick, incra≈ø≈øate the thin, and if there are any other exce≈ø≈øes of qualities, reduceth them to mediocrity.

So Cholerick humours becau≈øe they are hot to be allayed; Concocters of cholerick humours. and tempered with cold medicines, and their tenuity if too much, to be reduced to mediocrity, and its power of inflaming to be prohibited. The≈øe perform this, Chichory, Endive, Sowthi≈øtle, Garden-Endive, Sorrell, Burrage, Buglo≈øs, Violets, Barley; the greater and le≈ø≈øer cooleing ≈øeeds, the juice of Lemmon Pomegranates, Goo≈øe-berries, Vinegar, Spirit of the ≈øalt of Vitriol, and medicines prepared of the≈øe.

Phlegmatick humours becau≈øe they are thick and dull, Phlegmatick. require attenuating, and cutting medicines; ≈øuch are the opening roots, Hy≈øop, Bittony, Agrimony, Venus-hair, Vinegar, al≈øo Spirit of Vitriol.
In a Melancholly humour, Melancholy. attenuating medicines are al≈øo u≈øeful, but ≈øuch as moi≈øten withal: Such as are Burrage, Buglo≈øs, Polypody, Caeterach or Spleen-wort, and ≈øuch like.

But becau≈øe in all the≈øe Fevers, Re≈øi≈øting of putrefaction. corruption of humors is pre≈øent, tho≈øe things which re≈øi≈øt putrefaction are al≈øo nece≈ø≈øary, ≈øuch are Vinegar, Juice of Lemmon, Citron, Pomegranates, Sorrel, Spirit of Salt of Vitriol.

And tho≈øe things which are ≈øpoken about concoction and crudity of humours, principally take place in continued and acute Fevers, which is manife≈øt from Hippocrates, who 1. A≈øh. 24. adjoynes, In acute di≈øea≈øes ≈øeldom, and about the beginnings, purging is to be u≈øed, and that with diligent premeditation, and 2 Aphor. 29. In the beginning of di≈øea≈øes if ought
be to he moved, move it; but when it flouri≈øhes 'tis be≈øt to be quiet, namely, if the matter ≈øwell big in acute di≈øea≈øes, pre≈øently at the beginning 'tis to be evacuated, but if not, a concoction is to be expected, which nature alone performing, very often u≈øeth to expell vitious humours, which if it be not done, the Phy≈øician u≈øeth to do it: The ≈øame crudity and concoction is required in intermitting Fevers, for ≈øince their cau≈øes are ≈øcituated in the Me≈øaraick veins, and the Me≈øaraick veins contain and elaborate blood of their own accord, if peccant humours be any where mingled with that blood, and begin to putrefie, crudity is ≈øaid to be pre≈øent: But when tho≈øe humours are ≈øo conquer'd by nature, that they may ea≈øily be ≈øeperated, concoction is performed.

Although in intermitting Fevers in every fit ≈øome of the peccant matter be evacuated, yet notwith≈øtanding the humour, which is the fuel of ≈øuch Fevers, is not fir≈øt taken away before the concoction be performed, and the bad are ≈øeperated from the good: That which in quartanes u≈øeth to be long in doing; For although each Paroxi≈øm ≈øome may be expelled, yet as Galen. 2. of the difference of Fevers. cap. the la≈øt teacheth, ≈øuperfluities in the part wherein the fewel feeding the Fever is contained being left behind, cau≈øe new fits, and purgation is appointed in vain before the humour be concocted and rendred fit to be purged, whereof ≈øhall be ≈øpoken among≈øt the intermitting Fevers. Preparing of humers.

But be≈øides this concoction and preparation of humours, there is yet need of other things, which when the humours are concocted, are to be exhibited: For con≈øidering purgation that it may be happily u≈øed, the pa≈ø≈øages ought to be open and the humours fluid, if the pa≈ø≈øages are ob≈øtructed, and thick ≈øluggi≈øh humours be pre≈øent, the wayes through which the humours ought to pa≈øs are to be opened, and the humours to be cut and taken away,

div.head: CHAP. VIII. Of Sudorificks and Diureticks.
div.p:
BUt becau≈øe nature for the mo≈øt part expells the concocted matter by ≈øweats, Cau≈øing ≈øweat. ≈øo that almo≈øt no Fever without them cea≈øeth and is well cured. By Urine al≈øo ≈øometimes part of the fevouri≈øh matter is evacuated, Urine provoked. and therefore Diureticks after other evacuations are to be appointed, and the mo≈øt temperate among≈øt them are to be cho≈øen, which together attenuate the humours, and free the pa≈ø≈øages from ob≈øtructions, as Maiden-hair, Sparagus, Agrimony, &c.
