div.head: CHAP. IX. Of Diet in putred Fevers.
div.p: LA≈øtly concerning dyet, Dyet. and fir≈øt, of meat and drink, not only regarding the u≈øe of them, for the comfort and refre≈øhment of our ≈øtrength, but in re≈øpect of what is to be permitted, and what prohibited; for when nature is mo≈øt bu≈øied in concoction and evacuation of matter, ≈øhe ought not to be called from that work to the concoction of meat, hence Hippo. 1. Aphor. 8. When the violence of the di≈øea≈øe is great, dyet is to be u≈øed mo≈øt ≈øparingly, and ibid. Aphor. 11. In the Paroxi≈øm it ≈øelf, food is to be taken away; for it affords mi≈øchief: and when by circuit the Fever returns in the fits we ought to ab≈øtain.

In the admini≈øtration of dyet in Fevers, we are to ob≈øerve, form, Form of Diet. quantity, quality, and time. The form of dyet is threefold, thick, indifferent, and thin. Which of the≈øe are mo≈øt proper for every one, is to be collected by comparing the ≈øtrength of the ≈øick with the morbifique cau≈øe; neither ought we to give more meat then the ≈øtrength can concoct: and we ought to con≈øider whether the ≈øtrength do more require food, or the di≈øea≈øe forbid it, or the contrary: for by how much the bu≈øier nature is in oppugning the morbifique cau≈øe, by ≈øo much the le≈øs thre ought to be burthened with food: She is by ≈øo much the more bu≈øied in oppo≈øing the di≈øea≈øe, by how much the paroxi≈øm is neerer at hand, hence Hippocrates 1. Aphor. 8. When the di≈øea≈øe is in it's vigour, then 'tis nece≈ø≈øary to u≈øe the thinne≈øt
food, and 1. Aph. 7. When the di≈øea≈øe is peracute, there are extream labourings; and at height, the thinne≈øt nutriment is to be taken. But when 'tis not at height, and that we may u≈øe more nouri≈øhing things, by ≈øo much is to varied from the thinne≈øt of all, by how much the di≈øea≈øe is remitted and abated, and ibid. 10. Tho≈øe who expect the vigour forthwith to come, ought pre≈øently to take a little nouri≈øhment. They who expect it afterwards much, and ≈øhould both in the vigour of it, and a little before it, ab≈øtain. But before-hand the ≈øick ≈øhould be more plentifully nouri≈øhed, that he might be the better able to endure the di≈øea≈øe. But how dyet is to be moderated according to the ≈øtrength, Hippocrates teacheth, 1 Aphor. 9. We ought to conjecture by the ≈øick, whether he can hold out to the vigour of the di≈øea≈øe by the pre≈øcribed dyet or not, or whether he will fir≈øt faint, and being in≈øufficient with ≈øuch food, ≈øhould dye before the di≈øea≈øe depart and be overcome. And 1. Aphor. 13. Old men that are not decrepid ea≈øily endure to fa≈øt, according to the≈øe, middle aged men, young men le≈øs, children lea≈øt of all; and among≈øt them e≈øpecially ≈øuch as are endued with the choice≈øt and mo≈øt acute wits: Cu≈øtom al≈øo and cour≈øe of life is to be con≈øidered in pre≈øcribing of dyet.

The quantity of meat al≈øo is to be con≈øidered by comparing of the di≈øea≈øe with the ≈øtrength of the ≈øick: Quantity. For ≈øince that we mu≈øt never give more food then can be concocted at the time when nature is mo≈øt bu≈øied in oppo≈øing the morbifique cau≈øe, the lea≈øt quantity of food is to be taken, which is in the height thereof.

Concerning the quality of meat, Quality. ≈øince it is to be con≈øidered either as it is meat, or as it is medicinal meat, in the former re≈øpect tho≈øe meats are to be cho≈øen that are of ea≈øie≈øt concoction, full of good juyce, facile to be di≈øtributed, and which hath the lea≈øt excrements: But if it be con≈øidered as Medicinal, Fir≈øt, it ought to be contrary to the Fever, and therefore it ≈øhould be cold and moi≈øt, 1. Aphor. 16. moreover it ≈øhould be repugnant to the cau≈øes, and all exce≈øs of qualities in them.

The time for food is mo≈øt proper when 'tis indicated, Time. when the body requires nouri≈øhment, which is when the former meat is concocted, and no ≈øign is pre≈øent, which may prohibit the taking of it, to wit, no combate betwixt nature and the di≈øea≈øe; therefore during the fits, we ought to ab≈øtain. 1. Aphor. 11. unle≈øs the ≈øtrength be much decayed and ≈øpent.

Care al≈øo is to be taken what drink is fitte≈øt in Fevers, for although it be ea≈øier concocted then meat, Drink. and by it's cooling it
mitigates the heat, and the drine≈øs is hindred: Yet we are to be careful that nature be not burthened with it, and the concoction of matter hindred by it, and therefore in intermitting Fevers during the Paroxi≈øm, we ≈øhould ab≈øtain from drink as neer as we can: But in continued Fevers, when heat, thir≈øt, and debility of ≈øtrength do require, you may give more drink; but ≈øithence drink is to be con≈øidered, not as drink only, but as medicinal, hence it comes to pa≈øs, that at certain times, certain drinks are to be cho≈øen. Drink con≈øidered as drink, ought to be given according to the rules for meat: But as it is con≈øidered as altering, by how much the dry heat is more inten≈øe, by ≈øo much the more, hotter drinks are to be avoided, and the colder to be cho≈øen. Yet regard is to be taken of the cau≈øe, and oftentimes there will be need of attenuating and ab≈øterging drinks, and not of cooling only; and the matter being deeper fa≈øtened in the part, admits not cooling drink. The drinking of cold water is only u≈øeful in acute Fevers, 'tis never proper in intermittent. Fair water is often altered with barley, which is called a decoction, and barley-water. In≈øtead of drink, Juleps are al≈øo exhibited, water mixed with Honey, Oxymel, Emul≈øions, Whey, ≈øtrong beer, wine. But ≈øeeing certain drinks for certain Fevers are mo≈øt convenient, we may more properly handle them ≈øeverally among≈øt the different kinds of Fevers, of which ≈øorts are peculiar for ≈øuch a particular Fever then in general to treat thereof.

The air in all Fevers ought to be pure, cold rather then hot, yet ≈øo temper'd, Air. that the drawing in thereof may rather allay the fevouri≈øh heat, then meeting with a naked body, cau≈øe it to ≈øhut its own pores, which hinders the di≈øcu≈ø≈øion of vapours and ≈øweats, and therefore the ≈øick is to be covered with outward garments, but ≈øuch as are light, that ≈øo the heat may be drawn to the outmo≈øt parts of the body.

Sleep ought to be moderate. Re≈øt in putred Fevers is mo≈øt advantagious: Sleep, rest. Excrements, pa≈ø≈øions of the mind. Excrements ought not to be retained beyond mea≈øure, but to be ejected in due time. The pa≈ø≈øions of the mind ought to be at peace, and ≈øadne≈øs, and anger are to be avoided.

div.head: CHAP. X. Of the differences of putred Fevers.
div.p: HItherto we have ≈øpoken of putred Fevers in general, The differences of putred Fevers. it remains that now we ≈øpeak of them particularly. Fir≈øt their differences are a little more cleerly to be explained. And they are taken chiefly from the matter putrifying, and the place of putrefaction.

As for the matter, Feversari≈øe either from choller, or phlegm, From the matter. blood or melancholly: To which not without rea≈øon is added a ≈øerous humour, e≈øpecially that Ichor, which is very evil, ea≈øily obnoxious to putrefaction, A ≈øerous humour. and cau≈øeth the blood and other humours to putrefie more ea≈øily. Whence ≈øome are of opinion that Ephemeral Fevers, which commonly are ≈øaid to ari≈øe from Spirits kindled, do all proceed from the ebullition of the ≈øerous part of the venous or arterious blood: And much more a Synocha without putrefaction; although the vital Spirits being heat may fir≈øt allure the heat to the ≈øerous humour. The ≈øame ≈øhew that all Synochaes or Fevers containing, as they are called, which have no periods, as well putred as not putred, do ari≈øe from the ≈øame aqueous and ≈øerous humour, whether putrefying or not putrefying; whereof the Tract of Fevers may be ≈øeen.

Tho≈øe Fevers which proceed from blood do all keep a certain continuity and equality; and are neither exa≈øperated daily, From blood. Phlegm. Choller. nor each other day, nor the fourth day, but tho≈øe which do ari≈øe from Phlegmatick, chollerick, or melancholy humours, all have their periods, whether they are continued or intermittent.

The matter whereof putred vapours are bred in Fevers, From the place. is either contained within the ve≈ø≈øels or without. The ve≈ø≈øels which carry the perfect blood, as the vena cava, and the arteries, or the more imperfect, as the Me≈øeraick veins. within the ve≈ø≈øels. While≈øt blood putrifies in the vena cava, there ari≈øe continued Fevers, whereof ≈øome are called Synochaes, or containing Fevers, others continued in≈øtead of a genus and periodick continued. If excrementitious humours putrefie in the Me≈øaraicks, intermittent Fevers are ≈øtirred up, but if imperfect blood putrifie in the Me≈øaraick
veins, continued Fevers are rai≈øed, but calm ones.

Putrifying matter without the ve≈ølels, Without the ve≈ø≈øels. ≈øending putred vapours to the veins and arteries, kindles continued Fevers. Such are fir≈øt Symptomatical, which proceed from inflammations of certain parts. Moreover calmer Fevers, which proceed from the ≈øtubborne≈øs of the guts and their ob≈øtructions. Thirdly, tho≈øe that are cau≈øed by an Ulcer, Fi≈øtula, and all putrefaction. Fourthly, from corrupt milk, as in Infants, from blood putrefying without the ve≈ø≈øels, al≈øo the matter of Catarrhs, whence they are called Catarrhal Fevers.

La≈øtly, there are Fevers called Comitatae, or Companions, which are occa≈øioned from matter putrefying in the veins, Fevers accompanied. part whereof when nature either expells out of the body, which happens in a Diarrhaea, Dy≈øentery, and a Catarrh, or protrudeth into ≈øome part, which happens in the Meazles, Small Pox, Stragling pains, Quin≈øey, Peripneumonie, Phren≈øie, Eri≈øipelas, oftentimes. Another di≈øea≈øe then accompanies the Fever.

div.head: CHAP. XI. Of a continued putred primary Fever, and fir≈øt of a Synocha in particular.
div.p: NOw concerning putred Fevers in particular, A primary continued Fever. and fir≈øt we will handle a primary continued Fever: A primary continued Fever is that which comes not to apurexie before it be plainly taken away; and hath its ri≈øe from putred humours contained in the greater branches of the vena cava and arterie. For ≈øince that thence putred vapours are continually ≈øent to the heart, a continued heat is al≈øo cau≈øed, thence until it fully be cured there is no ab≈øence of fire, neither doth it return by intervalls, with tremblings and ≈øhaking fits.

Primary continued Fevers are two-fold, Some without any remi≈ø≈øion or exacerbation of the heat, continue from the beginning to the end: But there are others, wherein the heat before the Fever be throughly cured, doth never totally depart, yet at certain periods is increa≈øed. The former are called fiery Synochaes, and Fevers containing; the other are called Synoches, or continued, in≈øtead of a genus.

The Fever Synocha putred, A Puered Synocha. is a Fever, which without any ≈ølacking or increa≈øing afflicteth from the beginning to the end, ari≈øing from putrefaction of the blood in the greater branches of
the vena cava. Although continued Fevers may ari≈øe out of ve≈ø≈øels of determinate parts, yet ≈øuch are Symptomatical: And if they are true Synochaes, which have their original from the default of any part, as from the womb offending: Yet that part only affords an occa≈øion, the polluted, putredity being communicated, that the blood in the greater ve≈ø≈øels might corrupt. But there are Fevers ri≈øen from determinate parts, for the mo≈øt part continued Periodicks.

So ≈øometimes peccant matter in the fir≈øt pa≈ø≈øages collected in the fir≈øt concoction, which u≈øeth to go to ≈øome of the humours, which at certain Periods are moved, and hath not as yet received its limits for motion, it u≈øeth then to corrupt the humours, and communicate putrefaction to the vena cava, which Fevers for the mo≈øt part are malignant.

A putred Synocha hath its original for the mo≈øt part from tran≈øpiration hindred, and want of ventilation of the blood, The cau≈øe. and hot fuliginous retentions, by rea≈øon of ob≈øtruction of veins, as well in the skin, as al≈øo in the internal parts. And the blood appointed to nouri≈øh the body putrifies in the≈øe Synochaes, and putrefying, continually ≈øends hot vapours to the heart. For when preter-natural heat is ≈øo kindled in the veins, that nature can no longer rule it, it becomes putred and is corrupted. Nor is there any need that the putred blood ≈øhould be turned into another humour pre≈øently. For blood of its own nature is apt to putrefaction, and in inflamations we ≈øee it changed to quitture, not into choller; though nothing hinder it in the veins but that it might: And e≈øpecially the Ichor or thin wateri≈øh part of the blood is apt to turn to putrefaction, and by rea≈øon of the Ichor the blood in the fir≈øt place is corrupted, which happens, when the vapours which ought to tran≈øpire, are retained in the veins. Yet the whole blood doth not putrifie, but ≈øome parts thereof, which ≈øo long as they are not ≈øeperated from the good blood, crudity is ≈øaid to be pre≈øent, which afterwards by concoction are ≈øeperated from the good blood, which being done, Nature appoints evacuation, by which the blood returns to its former purity again.

A Synocha is three-fold, Acmastick, i. e. when it remains alwayes in the ≈øame ≈øtate, namely, Differences. when ≈øo much of the humour daily putrifies as is di≈øcu≈ø≈øed, this is called al≈øo Homotonos. Epacmastick or Anabaticos is when the heat continually increa≈øeth, and more of the matter is kindled then can be di≈øcu≈ø≈øed. Paraema≈øtick is when there is more di≈øcu≈ø≈øed then corrupted, and thence the heat alwayes decres≈øeth. Furthermore it blood which
putrifies be temperate ab≈øolute, 'tis called a ≈øanguinious Synoch a in particular: But if it be hotter, which u≈øeth to be called cholerick, the di≈øea≈øe is then called Synocha bilo≈øa.

The Fever is known fir≈øt by this, Diagno≈øtick ≈øigns. that it continues from the beginning to the end without any exa≈øperation and mutation: Moreover becau≈øe the Pul≈øe is great, vehement, ≈øwift, frequent, unequal and inordinate. And in a Synocha proceeding from temperate blood the ≈øigns of Plethory are pre≈øent: The blood to him that toucheth ≈øeems much and full of vapours, and is not ≈øo trouble≈øome and ≈øharp as in other Fevers, and other ≈øignes are pre≈øent which are ob≈øerved in a Synocha that is not putred. A putred Synocha is di≈øtingui≈øhed from a non-putred by certain ≈øigns. The heat in a putred is ≈øharper then in a non-putred. In a putred the urine is red, thick and troubled, without any ≈øediment, and crude, or a little concocted in the beginning; the Pul≈øe affords ≈øignes of putrefaction, and all the Symptomes are greater then in a Fever that is not putred.

A Synochabilo≈øa happens to tho≈øe that are troubled with cholerick blood, and the heat is ≈øharper then in a Synocha proceeding from temperate blood, thir≈øt is more trouble≈øome, the urine thinner and ≈øharper, and other ≈øignes which are u≈øual in cholerick Fevers are di≈øcerned.

This Fever is the mo≈øt ≈øimple among≈øt the putred, Prognosticks. and ea≈øie≈øt to be cured. And being pure, ≈øeldom pa≈ø≈øeth ≈øeven dayes, but the ≈øpurious is extended to the fourteenth day, and is terminated ≈øooner or later, as the ≈øignes of concoction appear ≈øooner or later. A white urine in a Synocha is evil. The lea≈øt dangerous of all is that which is called Synochos Paracma≈øticos, next to that Acma≈øticos: But that is mo≈øt dangerous which continually increa≈øeth, and is called Epacma≈øticos, which ea≈øily degenerates into a di≈øea≈øe called Cau≈øus. And by how much the fewer the evil Symptomes are, by ≈øo much the better hopes; the more they are, the more danger is ≈øhewn.

The whole cure con≈øi≈øts in taking away the cau≈øe, Indicatious. and altering the fevouri≈øh heat. Blood therefore as abounding in plenty is to be le≈ø≈øened, the pores of the skin to be opened, the cau≈øes of ob≈øtructions being taken away. The fevouri≈øh heat is to be tempered and allayed, if there be ≈øtrength, as for the mo≈øt part there is, thin diet is to be u≈øed.

Therefore a vein is forthwith to be opened in the right arm, a Cly≈øter or lenitive medicine being given fir≈øt, if occa≈øion require, and to take away as much blood as the ≈øtrength will permit. Breathing of a vein. and you may more boldly take away blood in this, then in any other ≈øort of Fever.

Blood being evacuated, Medicines. that the concoction may be made more facile, we are to u≈øe tho≈øe things which allay the heat, free from ob≈øtructions, and re≈øi≈øt putrefaction; namely, the juice of Sorrel, Lemmons, Citrons, and Syrrups and Con≈øerves prepared of them, Syrrup of Sorrel ≈øimple, Oxymel ≈øimple, Oxy≈øauharum ≈øimple, Spirit of Vitriol, and the four cold ≈øeeds with cooling waters are to be admini≈øtred.

Principally we ought to endeavour that the pores of the skin may be freed from ob≈øtruction, which for the mo≈øt part is the cau≈øe of this di≈øea≈øe, which thing Oxymel and wine mingled with honey, and the honey di≈ø≈øolved, will conveniently perform, ≈øince they are ea≈øily carried to the outmo≈øt parts of the body, and attenuate dull thick humours, and ≈øimple Oxymel re≈øi≈øts putrefaction.

Concoction being perfected, the Ancients u≈øed to drink cold water, and gave ≈øo much of it to drink, as might not only extingui≈øh the fevouri≈øh hear, but that the matter concocted might be evacuated by ≈øtool, vomit or ≈øweats. But in our countries, ≈øick people are not ≈øo accu≈øtomed to drink cold water, and many inconveniences are to be feared by the u≈øe thereof. So likewi≈øe ≈øwimming in cold water, which was u≈øual with the Ancients, doth not agree with our bodies.

The concoction being perfected, nature u≈øeth for the mo≈øt part critically to evacuate the corrupted matter, which if it be not done, it ought to be performed by the Phy≈øician with purging medicines.

Dyet in this Fever ought to be thin, Diet. becau≈øe both that blood aboundeth, and the di≈øea≈øe is ≈øhort; It ≈øhould be cooling and moi≈øtening, and al≈øo to have power of attenuating thick humours, and deterging vi≈øcid ones.

div.head: CHAP. XII. Of a Cau≈øus, or Burning Fever.
div.p:
WHereas among≈øt continued Fevers there is often mention made of a Cau≈øus, we are al≈øo here to ≈øay ≈øomething of it: But a Cau≈øus is not any difference of a Fever, but rather a mea≈øure expre≈ø≈øing the quality of fevouri≈øh heat. The word Cau≈øus is ≈øometimes taken generally, and not ≈øo properly, ≈øometimes ≈øpecialiter, and more properly: Generally for any ≈øort of Fever who≈øe heat is vehement, in particular for a Fever which hath two Pathognomonicks, great heat, extream and
unextingui≈øhable thir≈øt. A Cau≈øus properly and in ≈øpecie ≈øo called, is again twofold, legitimate and ≈øpurious: legitimate is that which hath alwayes, and that evidently, tho≈øe two ≈øignes joyned with it: an illegitimate is that wherein tho≈øe two ≈øignes are not ≈øo evident.

Whence it is manife≈øt that burning Fevers, Burning Fevers. and ≈øuch as properly and in ≈øpecie are ≈øo called, are continued Fevers, and ari≈øe from choller. And ≈øo a Cau≈øus or burning Fever properly ≈øo called, is a Fever continued, Bilions, and indeed either Synocha bilo≈øa, which we have newly handled, or a continued tertian, whereof we are to ≈øpeak next.

The Pathognomonick ≈øignes as we ≈øaid before, are two, vehement and burning heat, and unquenchable thir≈øt, although the ≈øick ≈øhall drink; Diagno≈øticks. and the more legitimate the Cau≈øus is, by ≈øo much the≈øe ≈øignes are greater, yet the thir≈øt is ≈øometimes re≈øi≈øted if a little cough happen, which may draw humors from the neighbouring parts.

Concurrent ≈øignes there are many, as a dry tongue, rough, black, watching, giddine≈øs of the brain, difficulty of breathing, thick and great, and the ≈øick continually blow, opening their mouth, that the hot ≈øpirits may the ea≈øier exhale.

The≈øe Fevers if they are pure, Progno≈øticks. never continue long. For nature cannot long endure ≈øuch burning and vehement heat; and the Symptomes which accompany it with their vehemency. And for the mo≈øt part they are terminated the ≈øeventh day, ≈øometimes the ninth, eleventh, fourteenth: but the ≈øpurious are protracted longer, and all of them are dangerous according to Hippocrates 4. Aphor. 43. Fevers of what kind ≈øoever that have no intermi≈ø≈øion by the third day, are the ≈øtronger, and fuller of danger. Yet ≈øome are more dangerous then others, according to the violence of the heat, and of the Symptomes, and force of the ≈øtrength, and by how much the greater digre≈ø≈øion is made from the natural ≈øtate, by ≈øo much the more dangerous is the Fever. Hence if an old man be troubled with a burning Fever, which ≈øeldom happens, 'tis deadly, as Galen hath it, 1. Aphor. 14. They lye down in no le≈øs danger who are exeedingly burnt in cold air: Who if they have not great ≈øtrength, neither the ≈øignes of concoction appear, it can not be that they ≈øhould e≈øcape, as the ≈øame Galen 11. Met. med. cap. 9. writeth. To whom if vehement Symptomes happen, by ≈øo much the more dangerous the di≈øea≈øe ≈øhall be, whether they are Pathognomonick or ≈øupervenient, yet if by the other ≈øignes, it be manife≈øt to be a burning Fever, and that thir≈øt be wanting, this al≈øo is dangerous, for
it ≈øhews the ≈øick either to be in a Delirium, or that the de≈øiring faculty of the ≈øtomack faileth.
Black urines are al≈øo evil, as al≈øo thin, crude, and ≈øuch as have other ill tokens in them.

But it is good if the ≈øick can ea≈øily endure his ≈øickne≈øs, the Symptomes being not without vehemency, if he can ea≈øily fetch breath; if he complain of pain in no internal part, if he ≈øleep; if he find benefit by his ≈øleep; if the body be equally hot and ≈øoft, if the tongue be not too dry, if the urine be good. But if when the ≈øignes of concoction appear, and that there is much ≈øtrength, in a critical day there happen large Hemorrhodes, or bleeding at the no≈øe, without doubt the ≈øick e≈øcapeth: For it is proper if there be any other of the pure burning Fevers, that they ≈øhould be cured by bleeding. Yet ≈øometimes they are determined by Sweats, loo≈øene≈øs of the belly, vomits, and impo≈øthums. But there are many Progno≈øticks of burning Fevers in Hippocrates in Prognosticis, Porrheticus, and Choacis praenotionibus, and there are many expounded in the In≈øtitutions, lib. 3. part. 3.

But by what means burning Fevers are to be cured, appears by what hath been ≈øpoken of a Synocha bilo≈øa with putrefaction, and tho≈øe things that ≈øhall be ≈øaid of the cure of the continued Tertian ≈øhall make manife≈øt.

div.head: CHAP. XIII. Of continued Periodick Fevers in general, and of a continued Tertian.
div.p: ANother kind of continued putred Fevers which they call in particular continued, comprehends tho≈øe Fevers, Continus periodick Fevers. which indeed continually remain, and have no remi≈ø≈øion before they are plainly di≈ø≈øolved, yet at certain periods they are exa≈øperated, whence they are called continued periodick and proportionated Fevers.

But as Fevers containing have their original from the blood appointed for nouri≈øhing the body; ≈øo continued Periodicks, their cau≈øes. as al≈øo intermittints proceed from an excrementitious humour and Cacochymie. Therefore continued Periodicks agree in this with Fevers containing, that both their cau≈øes are contained in the vena cava, but with intermittents in this that both proceed from excrementitious humours. But they differ from Fevers containing, in that they proceed from alimentary blood; the≈øe from an excrementitious humour: From intermittent becau≈øe the
matter which is the cau≈øe of continued Periodicks is generated in the ≈øecond concoction, and contained in the vena cava: But that matter which is the cau≈øe of intermitting Fevers is contained in the fir≈øt concoction, or certainly in tho≈øe parts which are about the liver, which are not appointed for perfect ≈øanguification. Namely, the matter of continued Periodick Fevers is generated in the Organs of the ≈øecond concoction, if for any cau≈øe what≈øoever it be not rightly performed. For then the peccant humours generated in the ≈øecond concoction are ≈øent with the blood into the veins, which there ≈øtirreth up the≈øe continued periodick Fevers.

Which matter ≈øince it is not only confu≈øed with the blood, as in intermitting Fevers, The rea≈øon of its continuity. but from the very fir≈øt original is mixed therewith throughly. Nature al≈øo cannot expell it before concoction, and therefore the Fever from the beginning continually la≈øteth. Yet the≈øe Fevers have exa≈øperations at ≈øet times, becau≈øe that from the in≈øtruments of the ≈øecond concoction, fre≈øh matter which is the cau≈øe of the≈øe periods is afforded, and indeed for the mo≈øt part from the liver: Whence al≈øo continued Tertians are mo≈øt frequent.

The≈øe Fevers are generally known becau≈øe they never come to apurexie, Signs. yet at certain periods they are increa≈øed and remitted. Neither doth cold, trembling, nor ≈øhaking fits precede their exa≈øperation, neither doth ≈øweat follow their remi≈ø≈øion.
There are three kinds of the≈øe Fevers.

For ≈øome are exa≈øperated each other day, Differences. and proceed from Choller, and are called Tertians continued. Others every day which are cau≈øed by Phlegm, and are called continued quotidians. Others the fourth day, which ari≈øe from Melancholy, and are called Quartans continued.
Fir≈øt a tertian continued is a putred Fever, A Tertian continued. ari≈øing from blood with ill juyce and choller putrefying in the vena cava, indeed continued, but afflicting mo≈øt the third day.

The cau≈øes of this Fever are all things which can increa≈øe ≈øtore of cholerick Cacochymy in the veins, The cau≈øe. and being cumulated there of cholerick Cacochymy in the veins, and being cumulated there can introduce putrefaction; ≈øuch as are before propounded.

div.p: A Continued Quotidian vulgarly called Latica, becau≈øe it hath a certain hidden and ob≈øcure heat, A continued Quotidian. is indeed a Fever continually la≈øting, yet having every day exa≈øperations ari≈øing from indige≈øted phlegmatick humours in the vena cava.

div.head: Of the Fever Epiala.
div.p:
THe Fever called the Epiala is referred to continued putred Fevers, The Fever Epiala. which it ≈øelf is indeed continued and quotidian,

Galen in the place newly quoted, draws this Fever from acid and vitrious phlegm puttrefying; Cau≈øe. yet in his book of an unequal di≈øtemper, cap. 8. he addeth bitter choller, whence he infers that ≈øince heat and cold are perceived together in one place, it argues mixture of phlegm and choller; in another place he determines it to ari≈øe from vitreous phlegm, part whereof putrifying, exciteth heat, the other not putrifying cau≈øeth trembling and cold. div.head: CHAP. XV. Of a continued Quartane.
div.p: LA≈øtly a continued Quartane is a Fever, A continued quartan. who≈øe heat is indeed continued, yet the fourth day 'tis exa≈øperated, it proceeds from melancholy mixed with blood putrifying in the vena cava.

div.head: CHAP. XVI. Of Symptomatical Fevers.
div.p: BE≈øides the≈øe continued primary Fevers which have hitherto been explained, Symptomatical Fevers. there are yet other continued Fevers called Symptomatical and accidental, which happen upon ≈øome other di≈øea≈øe which hath gone before, and which follows as a Symptome the di≈øea≈øe, and is taken away at the cure of the di≈øea≈øe, and ≈øo the≈øe Fevers follow other di≈øea≈øes which being taken away, they cea≈øe. Whence the Ancients, al≈øo as Galen teacheth, 4. Aphor. 73. ≈øaid tho≈øe only were fevouri≈øh, which were ≈øick without an inflammation or other di≈øtemper, but tho≈øe that did febricitate by rea≈øon of an inflammation of the ≈øide, lungs or any other part, they did not call them fevouri≈øh, but Pleuretick, Peripneumoniack, Hepatick, or other ≈øuch like names.

But there is not only one ≈øort of the≈øe Fevers, Differences. yet the principal and mo≈øt u≈øual is that which follows an inflamation of ≈øome internal part neer the heart, or which hath con≈øent with the heart, when from blood powred into the inflamed part and putrifying, vapours are communicated to the heart, and heat it; which in a Pleuri≈øie, Peripneumony and Angina happens as we are commonly taught. But although it cannot be denied but that from the inflamation of the≈øe and other ≈øuch like parts Symptomatical Fevers may ari≈øe, and that the Fevers en≈øuing the inflammations in accidental wounds do prove it; yet if we diligently con≈øider it, all tho≈øe Fevers which are commonly called Symptomatical are not ≈øuch but primary.

For fir≈øt putrefaction is kindled in the vena cava, whence a continued primary Fever is ≈øtirred up; Fevers accompanied. but becau≈øe nature is burthened with the weight of tho≈øe peccant humours; ≈øhe u≈øeth to force them as much as it could out of tho≈øe greater ve≈ø≈øels, and from a publique and Kingly ≈øeat as it were into le≈ø≈øer veins and ≈ømaller parts of the body, the blood with tho≈øe vitious humours being diffu≈øed into tho≈øe le≈ø≈øer parts cau≈øeth inflammation. And it is manife≈øt by this, becau≈øe a Fever for the mo≈øt part precedes inflammation it doth not follow it, and oftentimes the matter pa≈ø≈øeth from one part to another, whence changes of di≈øea≈øes are made. Hence the≈øe Fevers are properly called by Platerus Comitatae rather then Symptomatical, and ≈øuch Febres Gomitatae are not only tho≈øe which have an inflammation of any part accompanied with them, but al≈øo tho≈øe, to which other evils are annexed, namely a Diarrhea, a Dy≈øentery, Spots, Mea≈øles, the ≈ømall Pox, wandring pains, the Gout of the joynts, or running Gout, Catarrhs. For all the≈øe evils do ari≈øe when nature being oppre≈ø≈øed with the weight of its burthen of peccant humours, it protrudes ≈øome part of them out of the ve≈ø≈øels.

A Fever of this kind is al≈øo accompanied, which is an Ery≈øipelas, Ery≈øipelas or Ro≈øe. called by the Germans Ro≈øe; for this Fever doth not proceed from an inflammation of an external part, but this evil accompanies the Fever; for when the thinner and hotter blood burneth in the ve≈ø≈øels by what means ≈øoever, putrifies, and is corrupted, and acquires a vitious quality, which principally is cau≈øed by anger, and fear, nature being ≈øtimulated protrudes the ≈øame to ≈øome external part of the body, whence this evil invadeth with a trembling and quaking, and while≈øt the matter ≈øtriving to go outwards, cea≈øeth on the Glandules under the Arm-pits, and about the groin; ≈øome of the humour that is ≈øtirred up, ≈øticks there, and pain and ≈øwellings are there perceived, till at length it manife≈øts it ≈øelf in the leg or ≈øome other external part which may be known by the heat, pain, and ro≈øie colour.
But we do not a≈ø≈øent unto Platerus in that he ≈øays that all tho≈øe Fevers are ≈øimple and pure continued, and are without any putrefaction.

The Urines, that we may pa≈øs by other things, do manife≈øtly ≈øhew putrefaction, which hath the ≈øame tokens of crudity and concoction as in other putred Fevers, and nature ≈øometimes critically, ≈øometimes Symptomatically, expells the matter offen≈øive to it; for it doth not only expel by in≈øen≈øible tran≈øpiration, and by a moi≈øt ≈øteam, which u≈øeth to be in Ephemeraes and Synochaes which are without putrefaction.

Some of the≈øe Fevers whether they ari≈øe from an inflammation of the parts, or whether they have that as a companion, Differences of Fevers. are called Phlegmonides, which principally proceed from blood; but tho≈øe which ari≈øe from Ery≈øipelas or inflamation, are called Eru≈øipolatodes, and inflame fires. Phlegmonides. Typhodes. Lipyriae.

To the≈øe belong the Fever that leaves fire as it were behind it, which burneth ≈øo exceedingly, that all the interals are as it were burnt, but the external parts grow cold, and that during the whole cour≈øe of the di≈øea≈øe; and this Fever ari≈øeth from an Eri≈øipelas or inflamation of any internal part, but principally of the ≈øtomack, and from blood and Spirits meeting in the part inflamed.

Concerning the cure of the≈øe Fevers in general: Indications and Cure Since their cau≈øe is collected and generated in the me≈øeraick veins, there putrifies, and thence is diffu≈øed over all the body, and at length is di≈øcu≈ø≈øed by in≈øen≈øible tran≈øpiration or ≈øweats: But the cau≈øe of the recour≈øe of the Fever, as Galen teacheth, 2. de Febr. cap. the la≈øt is a twofold vitious di≈øpo≈øition in a body, the one a certain pollution or putrifaction left after the former paroxi≈øme; the other imbecility of the member or part, generating excrementitious humours; what therefore is to be done in each ≈øort of Fever, ea≈øily appears from hence.

For ≈øithence the beginning of generation and corruption of humours producing a Fever, is in the fir≈øt pa≈ø≈øages, Purging we are to endeavour to purge out that peccant humour, before it corrupts the re≈øt of the blood, and brings weakne≈øs, and a vitious di≈øpo≈øition to the parts; but we mu≈øt proceed warily in tho≈øe evacuations, ≈øince there is not the ≈øame rea≈øon of all intermitting Fevers: For when that vitious and excrementious humour, the cau≈øe of a Fever, in the me≈øeraicks is mixed with blood, crudity al≈øo, and concoction, according to their manner are nece≈ø≈øary; whereby the vitious humours may be ≈øeparated from the good, and rendred fit for evacuation: and that often happens in a ≈øhort time in Fevers full of Choler, and the cholerick humour is otherwi≈øe apt enough to motion: But in a Quartan the humour is more ≈øtubborn, and moreover according to Galen 1. ad Glau. cap. 11. no ≈øtrong medicine is ea≈øily to be admitted at the beginning.

And Sudorifiques are not at all (or altogether) to be u≈øed, Sweats unle≈øs evacuations have preceded; for if many vitious and excrementitious humours do hitherto abide in the fir≈øt ways, it may ea≈øily come to pa≈øs that by rea≈øon of hydroticks untimely exhibited, they may be detruded thence to the more noble parts, and may become the cau≈øe of various and grievous evils, and ≈øuch as may bring more danger then the Fever it ≈øelf.

As for breathing of a vein, Letting blood. 'tis not indicated from the primary cau≈øe of intermitting Fevers, which is generated in the me≈øeraick veins, where the greate≈øt part abideth: Yet becau≈øe that
≈øomtimes blood al≈øo abounds, which may ea≈øily be corrupted and polluted by the vitious humours, and ≈øo if it be too plentiful, cannot be well governed by nature when it is weakned by a Fever; and in the progre≈øs of the di≈øea≈øe, from thence ≈øome of the peccant matter pa≈ø≈øeth into the vena cava, and is mixed with the blood, it is ≈øomtimes needful to open a vein, which neverthele≈øs is not to be appointed pre≈øently in the beginning, before the evacuation of the primary pa≈ø≈øages.

If the Fever be not cured by the≈øe evacuations, we are to endeavour that the cau≈øes of the returns of fits may be taken away, and moreover two things remain to be done; namely, that that di≈øpo≈øition and weakne≈øs of the part generating vitious humours, may be taken away, which is performed by altering medicines, which together correct the fault of the humour, and di≈øcu≈øs that pollution, and tho≈øe ≈øeeds which were left out of the putrifaction of humours: and indeed that paroxi≈øms depend on that pollution, and that when it is taken away the Fever cea≈øeth, appeareth from hence, That whil≈øt that is driven by nature to the circumference of the body, out of the veins, and that Pu≈øtules are rai≈øed about the lips, no≈øe, and other parts of the face, the Fever cea≈øeth Wann der Mundt oder die Na≈øe au≈øs ≈øchiaget.

But 'tis principally taken away by Sudorifiques; yet there are al≈øo certain other medicines known both to Phy≈øitians and to the vulgar, Febrifuga. which take away feveri≈øh fits, and therefore are called Febrilia, Puretagoga, and ≈øuch as ≈øpecifically cau≈øe, and are called The flight of a Fever, or Febrifuga, which neverthele≈øs cau≈øe no ≈øweat, but without doubt ≈øome other way take away that ≈øeed, and by con≈øequence the paroxi≈øm, ≈øuch as commonly are accounted the powder of burnt ≈øhells of Cockles or Snails or of the Pearl bearing ≈øhels, or mother of pearl calcined, of River Crabs, and principally their eyes, which are ≈øo called prepared, and ≈øuch like: But how they perform this, is not explained by Authors. That I may ≈øpeak my own opinion, ≈øuch like medicines ≈øeem by a certain precipitation to take away that force of heating and ≈øtirring up a paroxi≈øm which is in the humours, to which Opiats ≈øeem to belong: yet ≈øuch like cannot be given ≈øafely, unle≈øs the vitious humours, and tho≈øe things which may afford the rea≈øon of the antecedent cau≈øe be fir≈øt taken away; for otherwi≈øe tho≈øe things which may be expell'd by nature when it is irritated in a paroxi≈øme, are left in the body, and afterwards may become the cau≈øe of a Chachexie, Drop≈øie, Jaundies, Cholick pains, and of other gri ‚Ä¢ vous evils.

Externally al≈øo are applied certain medicines to cure intermitting Fevers, of Cobwebs, oyl of Spiders, and certain ve≈øicatories, Topical Medicines. which without doubt, that which they do, is performed by drawing out, and evacuating of that Feveri≈øh corruption and pollution.

div.head: CHAP. XVIII. Of Intermitting Fevers in particular, and first of an Intermitting Tertian.
div.p: AFter we have handled intermitting Fevers in general, An intermitting Tertian. we will now go through them in particular; among≈øt them the mo≈øt frequent is a Tertian intermitting, which ari≈øeth from Choler putrifying in the me≈øeraick veins.

But there is a certain difference of the≈øe Fevers; for fir≈øt, Its difference. Choler it ≈øelf out of which the≈øe Fevers are generated, is not of the ≈øame kind; for ≈øomtimes the choler is like to that natural choler which afterwards is collected in the Galls bladder; ≈øomtimes it is preternatural green and aeruginous, ≈øuch as ≈øomtimes by tho≈øe that are Feveri≈øh, is evacuated by vomit or ≈øtool. Moreover, Choler either putrifies alone, or el≈øe hath ≈øome other humour mixt with it; Flegme or Melancholy that cau≈øeth a pure, this a ba≈øtard Tertian. They differ al≈øo in re≈øpect of duration; for if the fits are not extended beyond twelve hours, they are wont to be called pure tertians; but in ca≈øe the Fit be extended above twelve hours, they are no more called exqui≈øite and pure tertians, but either ≈øimply tertians, or ≈øpurious tertians; and when the paroxi≈øm is extended above twenty four hours, they are called exten≈øe tertians; but this is occa≈øioned either by the thinne≈øs or thickne≈øs, plenty or paucity of the humour. For by how much the Choler is thinner or le≈ø≈øer, by ≈øo much the ≈øooner 'tis di≈øcu≈ø≈øed, but by how much the thicker, or more mixed with thick humours, or the more plentiful, by ≈øo much the longer the paroxi≈øm continueth.
If the cau≈øes generating Flegme and Melancholy be annexed to tho≈øe that generate choler, ≈øpurious tertians are bred.

This Fever pre≈øently invadeth, A pure Tertian. if it be pure, with a ≈øhaking fit, as it were pricking the fle≈øh; afterwards when the cold fit cea≈øeth, pre≈øently much heat followeth, ≈øharp and biting, and in its vigour is extended equally over the body, whence the ≈øick draw their breath much, and are troubled with thir≈øt. The pul≈øes in the beginning of a fit are little, weak, ≈ølow, and thin; but the fit increa≈øing, they become vehement, ≈øwift, frequent, and in ≈øome mea≈øure hard, and void of all inequalities be≈øides Feveri≈øh. When the fit comes to the height, and the ≈øick drinks, many vapours are ≈øent through the skin, vomiting of choler followeth, which oftentimes u≈øeth to happen after the cold fit al≈øo, the belly is loo≈øened, choler is pi≈ø≈øed out, or ≈øomtimes more then the≈øe happen. Afterwards a ≈øweating out of hot vapours en≈øueth over the whole body, and the pul≈øe is ≈øwift, great, vehement, ≈øuch as theirs u≈øe to be who are over-heated by exerci≈øe. The Urine is of a light red, or deep yellow, and afterwards hath a white cloud or ≈øu≈øpen≈øion. The fit la≈øteth not above twelve hours, and the cau≈øes which generate melancholy, have either gone before, or are then pre≈øent.

A ba≈øtard tertian is known from the cau≈øes which do not generate pure choler, A ≈øpurious Tertian. but to gather Flegm or Melancholy: The heat is not ≈øo ≈øharp as in a pure tertian, but more mild, neither is it pre≈øently diffu≈øed over the whole body. Neither is this Fever di≈ø≈øolved by vomitting of yellow choler, or by ≈øweat, but certain vapours go out in the declination, and if any ≈øweats come forth, they either are not univer≈øal, or if they are univer≈øal, they cure not the Fever. The Urine is not ≈øo fiery as in a pure tertian, and the ≈øigns of concoction do not appear ≈øo ≈øoon in it. The pul≈øe in the beginning is hard, and that hardne≈øs increa≈øeth daylie, until the ≈øeventh paroxi≈øm, then by degrees it becomes ≈øofter, and the Urines al≈øo appear more concocted. The paroxi≈øm is often extended to eighteen hours and more: yet ≈øomtimes, to wit if the matter be le≈øs, and Nature ≈øtrong, it is likewi≈øe terminated in twelve hours. It endeth not in ≈øeven fits, but often endureth till it comes to fourteen, and ≈øomtimes to twenty.

But the≈øe Fevers are lea≈øt dangerous among≈øt all the putred ones 4. Progno≈øticks. Aphor. 43. and ≈øuch as are pure, do not long continue,
but at ≈øeven fits they are accounted at the height, 4. Aphor. 59. Somtimes they are terminated at the third or fourth fit; but ≈øpurious tertians, as they are more frequent, ≈øo they continue longer: for although if the matter be little, and nece≈ø≈øary medicines are timely exhibited, they ≈øomtimes cea≈øe at the fifth or ≈øeventh paroxi≈øm, yet for the mo≈øt part they ≈øcarce end at fourteen fits, and are often lengthned out to the fortieth day; ≈øomtimes they continue ≈øix moneths, and end with ≈øome di≈øea≈øe of the Liver or Spleen, or el≈øe are al≈øo ch ‚Ä¢ ri≈øhed by them.

Although Tertians for the mo≈øt part are not dangerous, yet ≈øomtimes they become pernitious. Fir≈øt, If any errour be committed by the ≈øick, or the Phy≈øitian. Secondly, If the humour which Nature endeavours to expel, ≈øhould fall upon any principal part. Thirdly, If the humour be exceeding thin, putred, or filthy. Fourthly, If a thin humour have a thick one mixed with it, and ≈øtir the ≈øame, and enflame it. Fifthly, If a thick humour poured out by heat, either fall down into ≈øome principal part, or cau≈øe a dangerous Catarrh, or A≈øthma, or the Gout, or draw the womb into con≈øent. Sixthly, If the humour acquire a malignant quality.

But in the cure of this Fever, as al≈øo in others, Indications and Cure. regard mu≈øt be had of the Fever, the cau≈øe and nature of it; the Fever indicates cooling and moi≈øtning things, the ≈øame Choler al≈øo, as being the cau≈øe requireth, which al≈øo ought to be evacuated: yet if another humour be mixed with it, altering preparing and evacuating medicines, which that humour requires, are to be mixed; and becau≈øe the abundance of the matter is in the me≈øeraick veins, the vitious humour is to be purged out of them, and if need be, prepared before it infect the good blood: afterwards al≈øo it is to be altered, and the di≈øpo≈øition of the part generating peccant humours to be corrected. La≈øtly, We mu≈øt endeavour that the pollution and putrifaction may be di≈øcu≈ø≈øed by Sudorifiques.

Fir≈øt therefore, the fir≈øt pa≈ø≈øages are to be clean≈øed, Purgers. either by Cly≈øters, or lenitive Medicines exhibited of the Syrup of Ro≈øes ≈øolutive, Manna, Ca≈ø≈øia, to which al≈øo we may add Rhubarb, Agarick, the leaves of Senna, according as the quality of the peccant humour requires. Vomits al≈øo convenient may be given, e≈øpecially if the ≈øick be troubled with pain in the heart, loathing, and a de≈øire to vomit: And ≈øince the matter con≈øi≈øts in the me≈øeraick veins, and that nature her ≈øelf at the beginning of the paroxi≈øm ≈øtrives to expel it either by vomit or ≈øtool, the Phy≈øician ought to be ob≈øervant to it, and to eject the matter, if Nature
endeavour to expel it by ≈øtool or vomit; and becau≈øe the matter for the mo≈øt part in the fir≈øt pa≈ø≈øages is either more abundant, or hath thick humours mixed therewith, there is need not only of lenitives, but tho≈øe medicines al≈øo which we lately mentioned; nay ≈øomtimes of ≈øome of the Electuary of Fleawort or Fleabane, of the juice of Ro≈øes, Ro≈øati Me≈øuae: Yet care mu≈øt be taken that we do not draw the humours out of the veins into the fir≈øt pa≈ø≈øages.

Concerning the opening of a vein, Opening a vein. although Choler re≈øiding in the me≈øeraick veins do not require it, yet if there be ≈øtore of blood, and the peccant humour out of the fir≈øt region of the body have penetrated the vena cava, which may be di≈øcerned by the thickne≈øs and redne≈øs of the Urine, and if the party be ≈øtrong, a vein may be breathed; and moreover note, that not at the fir≈øt invading, but afterwards, Phlebotomy is to be u≈øed: Yet regard of the Fever is to be had; for if it be a pure Tertian, which u≈øeth to be ≈øhorter, a vein is to be opened more timely, if it be required, becau≈øe if it be referred till after the third fit, the di≈øea≈øe comes to its height; but if it be a ba≈øtard tertian, you may defer it till after the third paroxi≈øm, namely, becau≈øe more of the morbifique matter is then mixed with the blood in the vena cava; but blood is to be taken away in le≈øs quantity in a pure Tertian; becau≈øe as in continued Fevers that is not the primary indicant, and the ≈øtrength cannot bear the taking away of a greater quantity, blood may be taken away more ≈øafely, and in greater abundance in a ≈øpurious tertian: But the opening of a vein is mo≈øt conveniently appointed during the intermi≈ø≈øion.

Afterwards tho≈øe medicines are to be exhibited which both correct the qualities of the cholerick humour exceeding, Preparatives. whereby it is trouble≈øome to nature, and al≈øo the vitious di≈øpo≈øition in the part generating excrementitious humours, and ≈øuch as are contrary to that pollution which remains after putrefaction; ≈øuch are cooling and moi≈øtning things, which together have a power of purging the fir≈øt ways, and of re≈øi≈øting putrifaction; ≈øuch are Cichory, Sowthi≈øtle, Endive, Sorrel, Barley, the four great, and four ≈ømall cold ≈øeeds, the juice of Citron or Limon, and medicines prepared out of the≈øe, Syrup of Sorrel, Aceto≈øa ≈øimplex, Oxy≈øauharum, Syrup of Cichory, Endive de acitocitate citri, with waters and decoctions of the ≈øame, to which in ≈øpurious tertians we may adde tho≈øe things which are proper for Flegme and Melancholy, the roots of Fennel, gra≈øs, a≈øparogus, a≈øarabecca, polypodie, carduus benedictus, centurie the le≈ø≈øer, wormwood, ≈øcolopendrium, betony, the ≈øpirit of vitriol and ≈øalt is profitable, cream of Tartar, Tartar vitriolated.

But among≈øt tho≈øe medicines there are ≈øome which by a certain peculiar force are ≈øaid to oppugne Tertians; Specificks among≈øt which notwith≈øtanding for the mo≈øt part manife≈øt cau≈øes may be rendred for it: ≈øuch are Sowthi≈øtle, Camomil, Century the le≈ø≈øer, Plantane, Divels bit.

Altering medicines being given, Purgers. if the Fever be more pertinacious, ≈øomtimes purging and vomiting are convenient, which for the mo≈øt part are to be admini≈øtred on the intermitting day; but if it be adverti≈øed that the matter during the paroxi≈øm doth encline towards the ≈øtomack, or tend downwards, it is lawful even when the fit is pre≈øent to admini≈øter vomits, or a gentle purge, yet ≈øo that before the beginning of the paroxi≈øm the operation may be pa≈øt, in ca≈øe a purge be given.

Among≈øt the vomits, A≈øarabecca and Broom are principally commended; among≈øt the purges, Rhubarb; to tho≈øe that are ≈øtronger, the Electuary or Fleawort or Fleabane, Elect. Ro≈øatem, Me≈øne, and of the juice of Ro≈øes may be given in ≈øpurious Tertians; Agarick or Senna may be added, in whom it is al≈øo nece≈ø≈øary to repeat preparatives and purgations.

The body being ≈øufficiently purged, Medicines cau≈øing of urine. the remainder is to be taken away by Diureticks: In a pure Tertian an Emul≈øion of the four great cold ≈øeeds is profitable, made with the whey of Goats milk, or the water of Barley, Strawberries, Cichory. In a ≈øpurious, a decoction of the roots of Gra≈øs, Sparagus, Fennel, Maidenhair, red Par≈ønips, Bindweed, flowers of Camomil and Wormwood are convenient.

But principally the Phy≈øitian ought to imitate nature, Sweats. which at the end of the paroxi≈øme u≈øeth to move ≈øweats, and ≈øhould di≈øcu≈øs the Reliques of the vitious humours by fudoriferous medicines given either before or after the paroxi≈øm; and indeed in pure Tertians, wherein nature u≈øually cau≈øes ≈øweat in the end of the fit, it often ≈øufficeth that the ≈øick drink only Barley water, or the water of Sorrel, or Carduus benedictus may be given with the Syrup of the juice of Citron or Limmon. In ≈øpurious, hotter medicines are to be u≈øed, ≈øuch as hereafter ≈øhall be mentioned among≈øt malignant Fevers, which being given ≈øome hours before the paroxi≈øm, often prevents or cures the ≈øame.

If the Fever be not cured with the≈øe remedies, Coroloratives. and that there be any ≈øigne of vi≈øcous matter, and that the Liver and Spleen are likewi≈øe affected, regard thereunto mu≈øt al≈øo be had; and ≈øince the Liver for the mo≈øt part in ba≈øtard Tertians is ob≈øtructed by thick choler, or choler mixed with thick humours, which pollutes the blood, tho≈øe things which clean≈øe the body from choler
are to be u≈øed; to which purpo≈øe Wormwood is very good to be u≈øed, which hath a force of deterging choler, and bringing away the ≈øame by ≈øtool and urine, as al≈øo hath century the le≈ø≈øer, Troches al≈øo of Wormwood, of Rhubarb, Gentian and ≈øuch like are al≈øo profitable; care al≈øo mu≈øt be taken of the Spleen and Stomack, if they are debilitated.
There are certain other medicines given ≈øomtimes, Febrifuga. which are called Febrifuga, of which 'tis ≈øpoken in the fore-going chapter.

And be≈øides the≈øe, Topical Medicines. there are yet others, which are externally applyed to the body to cure Fevers; namely, a plai≈øter of cobwebs, with unguento populio, the leaves of Shepherds pouch, nettles, crowfoot, and other ve≈øiccatories.

Concerning Diet, Diet. in a pure intermitting Tertian, the ≈øame diet u≈øeth to be kept for the mo≈øt part as in a continued Tertian, they are to ab≈øtain from honey, ≈øweet things, and all tho≈øe things which ingender choler, wine is not to be drunk before concoction: but when the notes of concoction have appeared, you may u≈øe it, ≈øo it be thin and watry; meat is to be given when the paroxi≈øm is pa≈øt, unle≈øs Syncope imminent per≈øwade the contrary, Galen 10. Meth. Med. c. 5.

In ba≈øtard Tertians two things are principally to be ob≈øerved concerning diet; fir≈øt, that the di≈øea≈øe by too plentiful a diet may not be increa≈øed. Secondly, that the ≈øtrength by too ≈ølender a diet may not be debilitated, which ≈øhould hold out mo≈øt in a long di≈øea≈øe; and therefore the magnitude of the di≈øea≈øe, and the greatne≈øs of the ≈øtrength are to be compared one with another; and in ca≈øe the ≈øtrength be greater, and the matter harder to be concocted, the thinner diet is to be u≈øed, but the larger diet, if the ≈øtrength be weak, and the matter ea≈øier to be concocted. The drink ≈øhould not only cool and moi≈øten, but al≈øo cut, and therefore it may be mixed with Hy≈øop and wilde Marjerom, and if water ≈øweetned with honey be exhibited, Vinegar being thereunto added, that Choler may be thereby corrected.

div.head: CHAP. XIX. Of a Quotidian Intermittent.
div.p: THe ≈øecond ≈øort of intermitting Fevers is that which proceeds from Flegm, A Quotidian Fever which becau≈øe it takes them every day, is called a quotidian. Fernelius writes that this is the rare≈øt of all Fevers, and that which ≈øcarce happens once among≈øt ≈øix hundred: Nay there are ≈øome who plainly deny it: and although many are affected every day, yet they are ≈øick of a double Tertian, or treble Quartan.

The cau≈øe of this Fever ≈øithence it is Flegm putrifying in the me≈øeraick veins, all tho≈øe things may be cau≈øes of this Fever, The cau≈øe which conduce to the generation of Flegm, namely, weakne≈øs of the bowels, e≈øpecially of the ≈øtomack, heat, cold and moi≈øt aliment, and too great plenty of them.

This Fever is known by the cau≈øes generating Flegm which went before, Diagno≈øtick ≈øigns. and al≈øo by the ≈øigns of Flegm abounding in the body, explained in lib. 3. of In≈øtitutions part. 2. cap. 2, This Fever chiefly comes to invade in the night, only with coldne≈øs of the extreme parts, and trembling: The heat after refrigeration ≈ølowly invades, ≈øo that ≈øomtimes heat, ≈øomtimes cold is perceived; and the heat at the fir≈øt doth not ≈øeem ≈øharp, but habituous; yet if the hand put thereunto continue ≈øome time, it appears a little ≈øharp, and when it is diffu≈øed over the whole body, it doth not burn much, ≈øo that the ≈øick do not breath extraordinarily, neither are they very thir≈øty: The face is not very red, but for the mo≈øt part yellowi≈øh, or a little puffed up; the eyes in the beginning are white, thin, and crude; afterwards when the matter is concocted, they become thick, troubled, and oftentimes al≈øo red. In the fir≈øt paroxi≈øms al≈øo they ≈øweat not, but in the progre≈øs of the di≈øea≈øe they ≈øweat a little; the Pul≈øe al≈øo is exceeding little, thin, and more then in Quartans, but equally ≈ølow; the paroxi≈øm is extended to eighteen hours, and the interval, which is ≈øix hours, is ≈øeldome pure and free; nay 'tis often extended to four and twenty hours.

But how long this Fever ≈øhall continue, Progno≈øticks. may be conjectured by the ≈øigns of concoction appearing ≈øooner or later in the Urine, and by the longitude and brevity of the paroxi≈øm; for if nature timely aim at ≈øome evacuation, it affords hopes of ≈øhortne≈øs of the di≈øea≈øe: But this Fever as being that which ari≈øeth from a pertinacious humour is long, and continueth unto forty days
three moneths or more, and is not without danger; and when the Stomack and Liver are much affected with it, the ≈øick are often ca≈øt into a Drop≈øie and Cachexy.

The cure for the mo≈øt part is the ≈øame with a Quotidian continued; The Cure for the pituitous humour is to be prepared and evacuated, to wit, the fir≈øt pa≈ø≈øages are to be opened with Cli≈øters accommodated to the pituitous humour; breathing a vein is ≈øcarce u≈øed, but a Vomit is more u≈øeful then in any other ≈øort of Fever, becau≈øe the ≈øtomack is principally affected, but 'tis to be occa≈øioned by ≈øeed of Radi≈øh, Orach, of Dill, flowers of Broom, in tho≈øe that are ≈øtrong, with Spurge, and others that are every where known.

The Flegmatick humour is to be prepared with convenient medicines; Preparers. the opening roots, Hy≈øop, wilde Marjoram, Betony, Mayden hair, Agrimony, Groundpine, Camomil, and other things convenient for Flegm, Syrup of Sorrel ≈øimple and compound, Syrup of the two and of the five Roots, Honey of Ro≈øes, Syrup Byzant, ≈øimple and compound, of Hy≈øop, Oxymel ≈øimple and compound with Squills, ≈øpirit of Salt and Vitriol.

The matter in the fir≈øt place being prepared, Purgers. it ≈øhould be evacuated with Agarick, Mechoachan, Turbith, Troches of Alhandal, Elect. Indo Diaphaenico, Diacarthamo, pills of Hieca, with Agarick, and ≈øuch like.

div.head: CHAP. XX. Of an Intermitting Quartan.
div.p: THe third ≈øort of intermitting Fevers which ari≈øeth from a Melancholy humour putrifying in the me≈øeraick veins, A Quartan. and ≈øeizeth on the fourth day al≈øo, whence it is called a Quartan.

rat. in acut. t. 38. writeth, it attenuateth melancholy humours, rai≈øeth them, and frames many vi≈øions in the mind: For Vinegar is a Leader or ≈øtirrer of Melancholy. The time is principally in Autumn, e≈øpecially if a hot Summer have preceded.

This Fever is known by its quartane circuit, Signs, and ≈øigns of melancholy abounding in the body, and it invadeth with a certain unequal di≈øturbance of the body, the which a cold ≈øhaking fit followeth, which at the fir≈øt is little, or at lea≈øtwi≈øe in≈øtead thereof there is at the fir≈øt refrigeration and horrour, in the progre≈øs of the di≈øea≈øe the cold paroxi≈øm is alwaies greater, and at length mo≈øt vehement with pain, cau≈øing the bones to knock together. The heat is kindled by degrees, neither is it burning, but ≈øomwhat milde. The pul≈øe is thin and ≈ølow, and although in the vigour of the paroxi≈øm it become ≈øwift and frequent, yet in compari≈øon of Tertians it is thin and ≈ølow. The Urines at fir≈øt are thin and white, but in the progre≈øs of time higher coloured and thicker. Sweats in the beginning are not frequent, but in the progre≈øs of the di≈øea≈øe plentiful.

This Fever continueth the longe≈øt of all other, Prognosticks. and oftentimes is not only extended to ≈øome moneths, but years; and if it be not gone by the next ≈øol≈øtice or aequinectial, after it was fir≈øt taken, it la≈øteth for the mo≈øt part till the next after, and for the mo≈øt part goes away in the Spring. Lazuli, and compounds of the≈øe Syrup of Apples, Regis Sapor, Electuary called Diacatholicon, Confection of Hameck, with the compound powder of Senna and Dia≈øenna, Tartarious pills, or pills evacuating melancholy of lapis Lazuli, Armoniack, beginning with the more milde or gentle ones.

If the Hemorrhodes can be opened, Hemorrhodes. there will be much good expected thereby; ≈øeeing that the flowing of the≈øe, pre≈øerves and frees a man from many di≈øea≈øes ari≈øing from adu≈øt and melancholy humours. The opening and preparing things before mentioned, may al≈øo cau≈øe Urine.

div.head: CHAP. XXI. Of Compound Fevers, and Semi-Tertians.
div.p: BE≈øides the≈øe ≈øimple Fevers hitherto mentioned, Fevers compounded. there are yet Compound Fevers, which is, when one Fever is complicate with another. They are divided into confu≈øed and explicite.

They are commonly called confu≈øed, Confu≈øed when two Fevers begin and end at the ≈øame time, ≈øo that they can ≈øcarcely be di≈øcerned; namely, when ≈øeveral humours confu≈øed among≈øt them≈øelves, putrifie in the ≈øame place, and each or every of them pre≈øerves its own proper nature; which neverthele≈øs how it might be done, ≈øcarce ≈øeems po≈ø≈øible: Implicite But implicite are tho≈øe that are ≈øo joyned together, as that the nature and ≈øymptomes of either of them ≈øeverally and peculiarly may be known.

That complication happens many ways; for fir≈øt, a non-putred is joyned with a putred, as a hectick with a putred; moreover a putred with a putred, and that ≈øeveral ways; for fir≈øt, continued are mixed with continued, and intermittent with intermittent; and that either of the ≈øame ≈øort, whence there are double Tertians, double and treble Quartans; or different, but that is rarer, as a Tertian intermitting with a Quotidian intermitting, and a Tertian intermitting with a Quartan intermitting, continued Tertians with intermitting, when a Tertian intermitting with continued Quotidian, or an intermitting Quotidian with a continued Tertian is mixed, which Fevers are called Semi-Tertians.
There are three ways of compo≈øition of Fevers, Three ways of compo≈øition of Fevers. and three differences of compounded Fevers; Subintrante, Coalternate, and Communicant.

Subintrante are, when the fit of the one Fever begins before the termination of the other: Coalternate, when one paroxi≈øm being-ended, by and by after a ≈øhort interval, another begins a Communicant are ≈øuch whereof the paroxi≈øme of the one doth begin forthwith after the end of the other, there being no interval.

But the≈øe Fevers are for the mo≈øt part more dangerous then others, Prognosticks. ≈øince that they more afflict the patient then ≈øimple, and a ≈øet time for their paroxi≈øms is for the mo≈øt part wanting, and e≈øpecially in ca≈øe the compound Fevers con≈øi≈øt of ≈øeveral humours, and they are more difficult to be cured, ≈øeeing tho≈øe things that are accommodated to one humour, are not fit for another.
But their cure depends on the manner of cure of their ≈øimples, Cure and to every humour and Fever that is kindled, thereby are to be exhibited their oppo≈øite remedies.
But that we may ≈øay ≈øomthing of compound Fevers, we will add ≈øomwhat concerning a double and treble Tertian and Quartian, and likewi≈øe of a Semitertian
A double Quotidian is cau≈øed by Flegme putrifying in two places, A double Quotidian. and invadeth the ≈øick twice in the ≈øpace of four and twenty hours.

A double Quartan is cau≈øed by a melancholy humour putrifying in two places; A double Quartan and tho≈øe that are troubled therewith, are one day free from a Fever, and the two next are troubled with it. But ≈øuch as are troubled with a treble Quartan, are Feveri≈øh every day; Nay, 'tis not impo≈ø≈øible but that tho≈øe that are troubled with a compound Quartan, ≈øhould be affected twice in one day.

And indeed a double Tertian is often ≈øuch from the beginning, A treble Quartan but a double or triple Quartan for the mo≈øt part from the untimely u≈øe of medicines, e≈øpecially of hot ≈øodorifiques, 'tis become ≈øuch, becau≈øe the crude matter is only ≈øtirred up, but not di≈øcu≈ø≈øed, but di≈øper≈øed over more parts.

Cure A compound Tertian and Quartan is cured as other Tertians
and Quartans are: yet this is to be taken notice of, that the meats or medicines may be u≈øed at fit times in regard of the paroxi≈øme.

As for a Semitertian which by the Greeks is called a Semitertian fire, 'tis compounded of a Tertian and a Quotidian, Semitertian. the one continued, the other intermittent, and indeed principally of an intermitting Tertian, and continued Quotidian, and hath its continuity from Flegm, its hoirour from intermitting, as commonly 'tis taught; whence the≈øe are al≈øo called horrid Fevers. But although I ≈øhould not deny that humours putrifie together in the vena cava, and the me≈øeraick veins, and that from thence there may ari≈øe complicate Fevers, which have various exacerbations and mutations in their ≈øymptomes; yet it ≈øeems not ab≈øurd to call tho≈øe Fevers al≈øo Semitertians, which by their nature are indeed intermitting Tertians, yet when 'tis joyned with an inflammation of any Intral, a ≈øymptomatical continued Fever is ≈øtirred up; for when the Feveri≈øh part of the matter is thru≈øt out with the blood into the Guts, Stomack, Liver, and parts adjacent, an inflammation is cau≈øed, and thence a continued ≈øymptomatical Fever, which being complicate with an intermitting Tertian, con≈øtitutes a Semitertian, which in re≈øpect of the intermitting Fever is horrid, in regard of the ≈øymptomatical continued. That which Phy≈øitians ob≈øervations teach us, by whom 'tis found out, by the di≈ø≈øected bodies of ≈øuch as have died in Semitertians, that there are inflammations about the hollow parts of the Liver, as al≈øo in the Stomack, Guts, Me≈øentery, Kell or Cawl, Spleen; Whence 'tis ea≈øie to give a rea≈øon of a trembling or ≈øhaking fit in this Fever; for it happens ≈øomtimes ordinately, according to the nature of the intermittent Fever; ≈øomtimes inordinately, when the inflammation ≈øeizeth on ≈øome new part, or when quitture or purulent matter is made; according to Hippocrates, 2. Aphori≈øm. 4.7. Somtimes malignity happens to be joyned with the≈øe Fevers, and then for the mo≈øt part they are popular, and there are many affected therewith.

This Fever is known, Signs: and if it be according as it is commonly de≈øcribed, compounded of a continued Quotidian, and an intermitting Tertian, by the ≈øigns of each Fever; for a continued Fever on the one humour, daylie brings a paroxi≈øm, but the other every third day, and ≈øo in one day there will be two fits, in the other but one. See Galen. 2. de diff. Febr. cap. 7. But if it proceed from an inflammation of any Intral adjoyned, ≈øigns of an inflammation are pre≈øent, and together therewith
the intermittent Fever keeps it likene≈øs; malignity, if it be pre≈øent, Progne≈øticks. is known by its ≈øigns.

div.head: The Third Book. Of a Hectick Fever.
CHAP. I. Of the Nature of a Hectick Fever.
div.p: ANd ≈øo the≈øe things of putred Fevers are handled, A Hectick Fever. and con≈øequently the fir≈øt ≈øort of Fevers, who≈øe heat according to inclination, di≈øpo≈øition, or habitude, is in the living parts of the body; It ≈øtill remains that we ≈øpeak of Hecticks, wherein the Feveri≈øh di≈øtemper becomes as it were habitual, and ≈øo po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øeth the living parts of the body, that although it be fo≈øtered by no cau≈øe, yet neverthele≈øs it can ≈øub≈øi≈øt without it.

An apt habit of body to take this Fever, is a hot and dry body, whether it be natural, or from what cau≈øe ≈øoever it proceed.

The≈øe Fevers are generated two ways; Manner of generation. for either they follow other Fevers, whether burning or la≈øting, when their heat is vehement; or being durable, it po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øeth all the parts, and con≈øumes their moi≈øture; or they ari≈øe from them≈øelves, and from evident cau≈øes, which if they are weaker or lighter, they produce Ephemeraes; if ≈øtronger, they bring forth Hecticks.

But there are certain degrees of a Hectick Fever: The fir≈øt is, Differences. when the rorid humidity is dried. The ≈øecond, when the fle≈øhy and fatty ≈øub≈øtance peri≈øheth. div.head: CHAP. II. Of the ≈øigns of a Hectick Fever.
div.p: A Hectick Fever is known by its continual heat, cau≈øing no pain, Diagno≈øtick ≈øigns. as being equal; and Hectick which indeed at the fir≈øt touch is weak, afterwards it appears ≈øharper: It is perceived more in the Arteries then the other parts: And moreover, the heat after taking food, within an hour or two is increa≈øed, and the Pul≈øe either is changed, as to greatne≈øs or ≈øwiftne≈øs, yet ≈øo, that its a≈øcending appears ≈øtrong and free, and none of tho≈øe things precede which forego the fits of putred Fevers mo≈øt commonly; and this mutation of pul≈øe and heat, endures until the aliment be di≈øtributed. The pul≈øe al≈øo in this Fever is little, Signs of differences. frequent, and moderately ≈øwift; and by how much the more the ≈øtrength receiveth this Fever, by ≈øo much the more the body is con≈øumed, and the ≈øtrength debilitated, ≈øo that the ≈øick can ≈øcarce lift up the eye-lids, and together with it in the ≈øecond place, fatne≈øs in Urine ≈øwims like cobwebs. La≈øtly, The ≈øame things which appear in an hippocratical face, as 'tis de≈øcribed by Hippocrates, are al≈øo di≈øcerned in a mara≈ømodes or Hectick, with wa≈øting.

A Hectick with a Putred, Signs of a Hectick with a Putred. and an Intermittent conjunct, is known from hence; That the fit declining, the heat neverthele≈øs, although remi≈øs, ≈øome is left thereof, and there is great langui≈øhing of the ≈øtrength, and all the other parts are more temperate, only the parts where the arteries are become hotter, and the pul≈øe lo≈øeth not its ≈øwiftne≈øs and frequency, and the ≈øick takes food, but is not ≈øtrengthned thereby. It is hard to know a Hectick in the beginning of it; Prognosticks. 'tis not ≈øo difficult to cure at the fir≈øt: but that which is neerer to wa≈øting, or a con≈øumption, is ea≈øily known, but hardly cured, and at the la≈øt it becomes plainly incurable.

div.head: CHAP. III. Of the Cure of a Hectick Fever.
div.p: LA≈øtly concerning the cure: Indications and Cure. div.head: The Fourth Book. Of the Plague, and of Pe≈øtilential and Malignant Fevers.
CHAP. I. Of the Nature of the Pestilence.
div.p: HItherto we have fini≈øhed the e≈ø≈øential differences of Fevers; it remains that we now ≈øhould ≈øpeak of the accidental. Among≈øt which, the principal and mo≈øt nece≈ø≈øary to be known, are tho≈øe that enfold the Pe≈øtilence, pe≈øtilential Fevers and malignant.

And indeed concerning the Plague, with which, What the Plague is. although not alwaies, yet mo≈øt commonly a Fever is joyned; That name is mo≈øt noted to be attributed to the mo≈øt pernitious and de≈øtructive of all others: But what the nature of that di≈øea≈øe is, among≈øt Authors is much controverted. For fir≈øt of all, ≈øithence various and ≈øeveral kinds of di≈øea≈øes and ≈øymptomes may appear in the Plague: Yet becau≈øe they are al≈øo often perceived without the plague, the nature of the plague is not to be placed in ≈øo many di≈øea≈øes and ≈øymptomes differing in ≈øpecie, but in ≈øome peculiar ≈øort: Nor doth the being epidemical or contagious, con≈øtitute the nature of the pe≈øtilence, ≈øince other di≈øea≈øes al≈øo may be univer≈øal and contagious.

But ≈øince that this is granted by all, The plague a di≈øea≈øe of the heart that the Plague ≈øpreads mo≈øt, when many are infected together with the ≈øame di≈øea≈øe, and they die, and others are infected: Hence it may ea≈øily appear, that the plague is primarily a di≈øea≈øe of that part on the which life depends chiefly, and the which being hurt, a man is in very great danger of his life, namely the heart, the fountain of life, and ≈øtore-hou≈øe of vital heat: For although the humour wherein the venome inhereth may ≈øub≈øi≈øt in divers parts (whence the ≈øame di≈øea≈øes and ≈øymptomes in every pe≈øtilence are not the ≈øame to appearance) yet in what place ≈øoever it ≈øub≈øi≈øteth, it hath
a peculiar antipathy with the heart, and thereby de≈øtroyeth a man ≈øo ≈øuddenly.

But from whence that force and quality ≈øo mi≈øchievous and inimicous to the heart, Whether the nature of the plague con≈øi≈øt in putrifaction. hath its original, and dependeth, of that there is a very great controver≈øie among≈øt Phy≈øitians; and indeed, ≈øome do conceive that the Pe≈øtilence only con≈øi≈øteth of putrifaction, and conclude, that by putrifaction the nature of the Pe≈øtilence may be con≈øumed. But becau≈øe they them≈øelves acknowledge that all putred Fevers are not pe≈øtilential, they ≈øtrive variou≈øly to determine it in putrifaction, and that they divers ways ≈øtrive to explain, but all in vain. What≈øoever therefore putrifaction is concluded to be, it ≈øufficeth not to con≈øtitute the pe≈øtilence; for there are mea≈øures and degrees of putrifaction al≈øo what≈øoever they are, ≈øince that they differ only according to magis and minus, they differ not in their kind, neither do they ≈øeparate the plague from the re≈øt of the putred Fevers. Moreover the Plague hurteth in another kind then a putred Fever doth; for it ≈øpreads it ≈øelf for the mo≈øt part in a moment, and brings forth pernicious effects, it diffu≈øeth it ≈øelf in an a≈øtoni≈øhing manner, and into what≈øoever it enters, a very little of the pe≈øtilent venome may lie hidden any where a long time, and remain whole, and afterwards be taken into the body, and on a ≈øudden produce ≈øuch grievous ≈øymptomes, and brings forth ≈øuch effects as are not in the power of the primary qualities, on which the ground of putrifaction depends: Moreover, if the plague ≈øhould proceed from putrifaction only, a Fever al≈øo would never be without the pe≈øtilence: yet ≈øince it is ob≈øerved that a Fever is without the plague, as out of Hippocrates 3. epid. comm. 4.25.55. Galen de ≈øimp. med. facult. de terra Armenia. Jac. de partib. in 1. quarti Avicen. cap. de Febre Pestilent. Alex. Benedicto, Fr. Valleriola loc. comm. lib. 3. c. 18. and out of others it is manife≈øt. La≈øtly, the way of cure is far different from that of other putred Fevers, and the pe≈øtilent poy≈øon indicates and requires alexipharmall means, which in other putred Fevers are neither indicated nor have any place.

Therefore we have determined that the plague doth con≈øi≈øt in a hidden quality, and in its nature wholly adver≈øe to the heart, and that the pe≈øtilential poy≈øon is endued with ≈øuch a quality, which by the effects of it, as we lately ≈øaid, beyond the primary qualities doth prove.
Contagion is joyned with the pe≈øtilence, and pe≈øtilential poy≈øons have always contagion joyned with them as a proper accident, becau≈øe it belongs to all plagues, but not only to the plague.

Therefore we define the pe≈øtilence to be a venomous di≈øea≈øe of the heart, from venomous matter, Definition of it. and in its whole ≈øub≈øtance peculiarly adver≈øe to the heart, and gotten by infection, and therefore is of it ≈øelf infectious, and ≈øuddenly and joyntly hurting all the actions of the heart, very acute, deadly, introducing de≈øtructive ≈øymptomes of all ≈øorts.

But what the ≈øpecifique nature of this venome is, and what its differences are in divers con≈øtitutions pe≈øtilential, no man can ea≈øily explain. To me it ≈øeems probable to be the highe≈øt degree of corruption, which indeed the humours in our bodies can po≈ø≈øibly receive; to which through many alterations, mutations, and fermentations it comes, and into which di≈øea≈øes which went before, at length degenerate: Whence it comes to pa≈øs, that when the Plague reigns, other ≈øporadick di≈øea≈øes that come not by ordinary means, and all benigne di≈øea≈øes for the mo≈øt part are ≈øilent, and tho≈øe epidemical di≈øea≈øes that reigned before cea≈øe.

div.head: CHAP. II. Of the cau≈øes of the Pestilence.
div.p: COncerning the cau≈øes of the Pe≈øtilence, A cau≈øe or this great corruption, they are twofold; ≈øome of them generating the Pe≈øtilence, others propagating the ≈øame, which are comprehended under the name of contagion. In the former rank are Ayr, Stars, cour≈øe of Diet, Poy≈øons, imagination and terror.

For fir≈øt, Ayr. Ayr ≈øomtimes contains in it the ≈øeeds of the pe≈øtilence, which when by drawing in the ayr by our breath, men draw in that therewith, and ≈øo the pe≈øtilence is ≈øtirred up in them, and that when it happens, mo≈øt grievous pe≈øtilential con≈øtitutions are occa≈øioned, and is far more pernitious then to tho≈øe to whom the contagion of the plague is only transferred. Ayr becomes pe≈øtilential, when there is in it exce≈øs of heat and moi≈øture, which di≈øpo≈øe bodies to putrifaction; ≈øuch a con≈øtitution of ayr Hippocrates de≈øcribeth 3. epid. comm. 3. yet the Plague may be bred al≈øo without ≈øuch a con≈øtitution of ayr, and that very corruption it ≈øelf is not terminated in the primary qualities; but 'tis nece≈ø≈øary that certain occult qualities, and that ≈øomwhat divine, mentioned by Hippocrates ≈øhould concur, but it takes its veneno≈øity and pe≈øtilential quality fir≈øt from heaven, whil≈øt that the ayr by a peculiar influence from the ≈øtars, whether it be ≈øo di≈øpo≈øed in the fir≈øt qualities, that it ≈øhould putrifie and be corrupted, or in an occult manner al≈øo it be ≈øo di≈øpo≈øed and affected,
that in it poy≈øonous ≈øeeds are generated, which in their whole ≈øub≈øtance are adver≈øe to man.

To which thing A≈øtrologers teach, that Saturn doth principally act his part. Moreover the Ayr may receive its pe≈øtilential ≈øeeds from the caverns of the earth, whil≈øt from thence venomous ≈øteams exhale, being generated in the ayr long pend up before; to which purpo≈øe Earthquakes much conduce, which move venomous ≈øteams in that manner, and open ways for their evaporation; ≈øo out of a che≈øt which hath been long ≈øhut, being opened, the plague cometh forth, as Julius Capitolinus hath noted in Vero: The ≈øame may happen in ≈øtanding pools and lakes, and corrupted waters in Wells. La≈øtly, Hi≈øtori ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ inform us, that the ayr hath been infected by the carca≈ø≈øes of ≈øuch as have been ≈ølain, and by the corruption of multitudes of dead locu≈øts.

Secondly, although the ≈øtars by corrupting of the ayr may be the cau≈øe of the pe≈øtilence whil≈øt they ≈øo corrupt it, as that that pe≈øtilence which is contained in it, the ≈øeeds or ≈øparks being communicated to man, they excite the plague in him: yet by it ≈øelf al≈øo, by affecting of mans very body, they may cau≈øe the plague, whil≈øt either they di≈øpo≈øe the ayr ≈øo, that whether by manife≈øt or occult qualities, 'tis rendred not fit for the pre≈øervation of mankind, but corrupteth the humours therein, ≈øo that they become of a pe≈øtilential nature; or al≈øo proximately and immediately by occult influencies, they corrupt mans body, and principally the humours and ≈øpirits contained therein; concerning which thing A≈øtrologers are to be advi≈øed with. Common Diet.

Thirdly, Pe≈øtilential venome may be generated from common Diet. That which often happens in a long dearth of provi≈øion, in Camps and Sieges, where men are compelled to make u≈øe of corrupt and unwhol≈øome meat, by rea≈øon whereof ill humours are generated; which being detained in the body, are more corrupted, and at length become pe≈øtilential; as Hi≈øtories ≈øufficiently te≈øtifie.

Fourthly Unguents and venomous powders being ≈øpread abroad may cau≈øe the plague, Poy≈øonous things. being that which by mi≈øchievous per≈øons hath been done and committed, as hi≈øtories again inform us: yet if any one would refer this kind of cau≈øe to contagion or infection, Imagination. we will not contend with him.

Fifthly, The cau≈øe is imagination, terror, and fear; and experience hath taught us, that ≈øome whil≈øt they have beheld tho≈øe that were infected with the plague, or dead of it, or ≈øeeing ≈øome go out of a hou≈øe that was then infected, by rea≈øon of too much
