div.head: CHAP. III. Of Contagion.
div.p: ANd the≈øe are the cau≈øes, by means whereof the pe≈øtilent poy≈øon may be generated in the ayr, or in mans body; yet it often comes to pa≈øs, that neither the ayr, nor evil diet, nor any of the re≈øt of the≈øe cau≈øes have ≈øtirred up the pe≈øtilence, but otherwi≈øe from el≈øewhere being brought into ≈øome place by contagion, and afterwards by contagion al≈øo it is diffu≈øed into more places. Infection. For although there are other di≈øea≈øes contagious al≈øo, yet the plague is the mo≈øt infectious of all others.

Contagion is a production of the like di≈øea≈øed or ≈øickly affect in another body, by pollution ≈øent out from a di≈øca≈øed body, but there are three things required to perfect contagion: A contagious body it ≈øelf that may infect others, a di≈øea≈øe or an affect contrary to nature, which is communicated to another, and the body which is infected.

Fir≈øt, a contagious body is that which whil≈øt 'tis ≈øick of any di≈øea≈øe, diffu≈øeth not the di≈øea≈øe it ≈øelf (for the actident goes not out of the ≈øubject) but ≈øome of the morbifique cau≈øe out of it ≈øelf, and communicates it to another, and ≈øo in this manner excites the ≈øame di≈øea≈øe in it. For that which is communicated to another from out of a contagious body, is not the di≈øea≈øe it ≈øelf, but a certain body flying out of the di≈øea≈øed body, and received into another, having power of ≈øtirring up the ≈øame in it. The Greeks call it No≈øeras apocri≈øcis, and aporroias, and mia≈ømata: The Latines, the pollutions and ≈øeeds of contagion; and ≈øince that we ≈øee that ≈øuch ≈øeeds have not only hurtful qualities in the ≈ømalle≈øt quantities, and that they ea≈øily in≈øinuate them≈øelves into the body, but al≈øo they endure a long time, and retain their ≈øtrength entire, and they are mo≈øt exactly mixed, and are ≈øome way ≈øpirituous, Infection how many ways it is ≈øpread. and 'tis nece≈ø≈øary they ≈øhould ≈øowe their ≈øtore of ≈øtrength by ≈øome occult quality.

But contagion is not ≈øcattered after one manner, for ≈øomtimes it goes out by breathing, ≈øomtimes through the pores of the skin, or in the form of vapours, or of ≈øweat and filth adhering to the skin, and is communicated to other bodies. And this ≈øeed goeth out mo≈øt plentifully from an infected body, when the poy≈øon is too ≈øtrong for nature, and overcomes it, which happens in tho≈øe that are dying.

The ≈øeeds of contagion are communicated either by immedidiate contact, or by ≈øome medium and vehicle. This vehicle is twofold; ayr, and ≈øome fewel, as they call it: Ayr, when it receives the ≈øeeds of contagion from infected bodies, it can carry them to places nigh, yea and ≈øomtimes more remote places. That hath the nature of fewel in it, which can receive the ≈øeeds of contagion, and communicate the ≈øame to another; which kind of bodies are thin and porous, as Flax, Cotton, Feathers, the hairy skins of animals, and garments made of them, feathers al≈øo of birds, and birds them≈øelves; and it is found out for a truth, that tho≈øe pe≈øtilential ≈øparks have often lain hid in the cinders or a≈øhes; and it may come to pa≈øs, that any one may carry the ≈øparks of it about him in his garments, and not be infected, and yet they being moved and ≈øhaked, may infect another.

But the ≈øeed of a contagious pe≈øtilence when 'tis received into a body, it brings in that di≈øpo≈øition with it wherewith that body from out of which it came was afflicted, and that for the mo≈øt part ≈øuddenly, yet ≈øomtimes it is found to lie hid ≈øome days in the body before it denudates it ≈øelf.

Thirdly, Concerning the body that receives the pe≈øtilent trea≈øury, although no man can promi≈øe to him≈øelf immunity from the pe≈øtilent venome, yet it is certain ≈øome are more ea≈øily, ≈øome more hardly infected. The cau≈øe whereof without all doubt con≈øi≈øteth in ≈øome peculiar occult quality of the heart, by the power whereof it hath or hath not ≈øtrength to re≈øi≈øt the venomous pe≈øtilence; yet becau≈øe the venomous quality is not tran≈øferred without a ≈øubject out of the infected body into another, it will more powerfully in≈øinuate it ≈øelf if it be received into a body proportionable and like unto that wherein it was generated: whence kin≈ømen are ≈øooner affected then others. Yet there are al≈øo other things that occa≈øion the more facile reception of the pe≈øtilence; for ≈øuch as breath ≈øtronger, and ≈øuch as have wide and open pores of their bodies, ea≈øier take in the ≈øeeds of the plague, inhering in the Ayr, or any place apt to retain it.

div.head: CHAP. IIII. Of the ≈øignes of the Plague.
div.p: MOreover concerning the ≈øigns, Diagno≈øtick ≈øigns that I may ≈øay nothing of approaching ≈øigns, de≈øiring brevity, but only by what means it may be known we will ≈øpeak. Indeed the plague when many have been infected, may ea≈øily be known; but before many have been over≈øpread thereby, there is ≈øcarce any pathognomick ≈øigne by which it can certainly be known, that one or a few being affected are ≈øick of the plague; afterwards when more are vi≈øited, it is not ≈øo difficult to be known, e≈øpecially when all ≈øporadick di≈øea≈øes for the mo≈øt part are ≈øilent: For fir≈øt, the plague ≈øeizeth on many, and the mo≈øt it kills. Secondly, 'Tis contagious, and ea≈øily given to others, and 'tis more contagious then any other di≈øea≈øe. Thirdly, by its violence it de≈øtroys the ≈øtrength, and principally the vital ≈øpirits. Whence fourthly, when little, frequent, and unequal pul≈øes are made, palpitation of the heart happens, lipothymie, ≈øyncope, and great angui≈øh and perplexity altogether. Fifthly, If the di≈øea≈øe be protracted, and the venome corrupt the humours, evils and ≈øymptomes happen of all kinds, and the whole order of the body is di≈øturbed; Fevers happen, divers wheals or pu≈øtules, buboes, carbuncles; yet if there are no pu≈øhes, bubo, or carbuncle appear, we mu≈øt not therefore conclude that the ≈øick hath not the plague; for it often happens that before they come out, and can be drived out by rea≈øon of the debility of nature, the ≈øick die with the violence of the di≈øea≈øe. There happens likewi≈øe other ≈øymptomes of all ≈øorts; for when the ≈øtrength of the body is debilitated by the vehemency of the poy≈øon, the humours and ≈øpirits are corrupted, the excrements are changed, and the urine either becomes crude, or fully corrupted, the ≈øweats are ≈øtinking and untimely, filthy, foetid, ill coloured excrements proceed from the belly, the qualities of the body are variou≈øly changed, and there is nothing at all in burning and malignant Fevers, which may not appear likewi≈øe in the pe≈øtilence: Progno≈øticks But there is no di≈øea≈øe at all to which the Aphori≈øm of Hippocrat. 19. ≈øect. 2. doth more agree: for oftentimes when the plague flatters mo≈øt, it brings unexpected death; and on the contrary, tho≈øe that have ≈øeemed de≈øperate, often recover when pa≈øt hope.

But there is the more hopes when tumors come forth ≈øuddenly in a place that is not dangerous, and after their coming forth the
≈øymptomes abate, al≈øo if the wheals are of a good colour, and with remi≈ø≈øion of ≈øymptomes; if medicines, meat and drink are not vomited up again, if ≈øweats come out with light≈øomne≈øs to the ≈øick, and other ≈øigns are di≈øcerned, which u≈øe to be pre≈øent in ≈øalutary Fevers.

But the greate≈øt danger is, when tumors come not enough out, and carbuncles draw near to the heart, or vani≈øh again; if giddine≈øs in the head, watchings, a coma, or convul≈øion fits are pre≈øent, if the ≈øick ≈øhall ≈øay every thing ≈øtinketh, if trembling of the heart, fainting of the ≈øpirits be pre≈øent, if all things are thrown up by vomiting, if the extremities of the body wax cold, if the ≈øweat be cold, if the excrements are of divers colours, black, and ≈øtinking, and if the other ill ≈øymptomes of malignant Fevers be pre≈øent.

div.head: CHAP. V. Of pre≈øervation from the Pestilence.
div.p: BUt becau≈øe 'tis ≈øafer to prevent the Plague, Pre≈øervatives. then being pre≈øent to expel it out of the body, we ≈øhould therefore be careful fir≈øt to prevent it. The way of pre≈øervation (with Gods a≈ø≈øi≈øtance, which we ought to ≈øeek by prayers) con≈øi≈øts in two things.
The fir≈øt is, That all tho≈øe cau≈øes that may occa≈øion the ≈øickne≈øs may be avoided.
Furthermore, that the force of tho≈øe cau≈øes when they cannot be avoided, may be broken, and our bodies rendred le≈øs apt to entertain them, and more able to re≈øi≈øt them.

Fir≈øt therefore if the Plague reign any where, all commerce with the infected is to be avoided, and if any one be certainly infected, he ≈øhould be ≈øeparated from the re≈øt with all his hou≈øhold-≈øtuff, indeed for many weeks, and the hou≈øe infected (as hereafter ≈øhall be ≈øhewed) clean≈øed; and in ca≈øe it be doubtful whether any one be ≈øick of it or no, 'tis better to be too cautious then carele≈øs.

But if the pe≈øtilence be now ≈øown in any place, 'tis ≈øafe≈øt to remove from thence, according to that common ver≈øe,
Mox longe tarde, cede recede redi.
Forthwith far from it go,
Returning come back ≈ølow.

The rea≈øons of which do not prove that he ≈øhould change his place, the a≈ø≈øi≈øtance of God being implored, he ≈øhould often u≈øe
medicines again≈øt poy≈øon, and fortific the body with tho≈øe things that re≈øi≈øt contagion, as al≈øo he ≈øhould endeavour that his body ≈øhould be free from all excrements, and pre≈øerved in its natural ≈øtate.

And that we may begin a posteriore, Purging. the body is not to be ra≈øhly weakned with ≈øtrong medicines; yet if any vitious humour ≈øhall be in the body, le≈øt that the force of the Alexipharmacal medicines ≈øhould be debilitated, or the venomous poy≈øon ≈øhould ea≈øily take root in the body, it is to be purged by little and little with lenitives; to which purpo≈øe the mo≈øt profitable are pills of Ruffi, ≈øo called from the authors name, and by cu≈øtome called Pe≈øtilential pills; out of which al≈øo is made the Elixir proprietatis, oyl of Vitriol being thereunto added: Syrup of Ro≈øes ≈øolutive is al≈øo profitable, and Rhubarb, Agarick, and medicines compounded with them, which are every where extant. If blood abound, it may be abated by opening of a vein.

The Diet ought to be ≈øuch, Diet. whereby vitious humours may not be cumulated; and with meats and drinks mo≈øt principally things good again≈øt poy≈øon ≈øhould be mixed; and al≈øo, if as it may ea≈øily happen, any of the vitious humours be cumulated, let them be purged by the ≈øaid medicines.
And fora≈ømuch as Fontanels take away excrementitious humours by little and little, and hence take away the provi≈øion for the plague, they al≈øo in pe≈øtilential times are profitable.

Mediocrity al≈øo is to be kept in exerci≈øe and re≈øt, ≈øleeping and waking, and the pa≈ø≈øions of the mind, and principally as much as 'tis po≈ø≈øible, intentive thoughts of the plague, and fear of the ≈øame is to be ≈øhaken out of our minds.

Be≈øides the≈øe, two things more are yet nece≈ø≈øary for our pre≈øervation from the plague: Fir≈øt to take heed that none of the pe≈øtilential ≈øeed be attracted; Furthermore, if that happen, we being ignorant thereof, our bodies ≈øhould be fortified again≈øt it.

Fir≈øt therefore we ≈øhould endeavour that the Ayr wherein we live be pure; The Ayr how to be purified. and therefore fir≈øt publike places are to be clean≈øed from all filth, and the ayr ≈øhould be purified with fire, principally of the wood of Juniper, Oak, Pine, Bays, and odoriferous plants being kindled; furthermore, every one ≈øhould avoid company, and therefore ≈øolemn and frequent meetings are ju≈øtly forbid by the Magi≈øtrate. The windows likewi≈øe towards places infected ≈øhould be kept ≈øhut, and the ayr (as I newly ≈øaid) with burnt woods, or with vinegar bezoarted, being poured upon hot bricks, or with ≈øuffumigations, or with pyrion powder kindled, ≈øhould be purified.

No man ≈øhould go abroad until the Sun be an hour or two high, How every man ought to fortifie him≈øelf against the Plague. neither fa≈øting, nor unarmed with alexipharmacal things, therefore balls of Amber, Nodules, ≈øweet Limments mixed with Treacle, oyl of Rue, Znezedoaric, Angelica, Citron, Juniper, and ≈øuch like ≈øhould be held to the no≈øtrils, and under the tongue convenient troches ≈øhould be held, cordial bags ≈øhould be applied to the region of the heart.

Amulets likewi≈øe of poy≈øonous things are commended by many, Amulets as Ar≈ønick, powder of a Toad, Quick≈øilver and ≈øuch like being prepared, de≈øcriptions whereof are every where extant: which what≈øoever they do, without que≈øtion they perform in ≈øuch manner, that they draw the venomous poy≈øon to them≈øelves, by the ≈øimilitude of their own ≈øub≈øtance, and turn it from the heart; as tho≈øe that are wounded with a Scorpion, with the oyl thereof being externally anointed, are forthwith healed: yet you mu≈øt take keed that tho≈øe bags, or ma≈øs of ≈øuch things be not heated by motion, le≈øt the ≈øtrength of the poy≈øon ≈øhould be communicated to the heart through the pores of the skin.

But the greate≈øt hope of health and ≈øecurity, Alexipharnicks. is in medicines that re≈øi≈øt poy≈øon, out of which tho≈øe are to be ≈øelected which by long experience have been approved; The ≈øimples are, Angelica, Valerian, Tormentil, Carduus Benedictus, Sorrel, Dittany of Crete and white, Rue, Swallow-wort, Scordium, Scabicon, Divels-bit, Burnet, Ol≈ønicium, Fluellin, Vipers-gra≈øs, Marigolds, Wormwood, Tan≈øie, Zedoary, Ma≈øterwort, Gentian, Juniper berries, Walnuts, Hartshorn, Bolealmanick, Terra ≈øigillata, an Emerald, a Hyacinth.

Out of which are various compounds; among≈øt which tho≈øe that excel, and are approved by long u≈øe, are Mithridate, Treacle and Confectio Liberantis, as al≈øo that antidote which is a≈øcribed to King Mithridates, of which Pliny lib. 23. cap. 8. as al≈øo Theriaca Diate≈ø≈øaron, to which the moderns have added many more, as the Electuary of Saffron, or of an Egg, as 'tis called, Dio≈øcordium, Traca≈øtory, Antidotus Saxonica, Antidotus Guidonis de Cauliaco, Pulvis Cae≈øaris rubeus, and Gry≈øeus Electuarium Camphoratum Kigleri, and many more, which the Tracts of divers Authors concerning the pe≈øtilence afford ≈øuch as are profitable, as well for pre≈øervation from the Plague, as for the cure thereof; ≈øo that it becomes us to be more ≈øolicitous about the choice of them, then the ≈øtore of them here: And among≈øt ≈øo great plenty, 'tis more ≈øafe neverthele≈øs to depend on tho≈øe that have been approved by long u≈øe and experience, then ≈øuch as are newly invented, what colour or pretence ≈øoever they afford them≈øelves.
But becau≈øe tho≈øe ≈øtrong and hot medicines are not proper for women with child, nor children, they ≈øhould have medicines of Harts-horn, the bone of the heart of a Stag (or Deer) the roots of Tormentil, Pearl, Bole Almenick, Coral, Bezor, and precious ≈øtones: And ≈øince that there is no ≈ømall difference among≈øt Alexipharmacal Medicines according to the qualities they have be≈øides their occult ones, every one of them doth not agree with every age and ≈øea≈øon: for in a hotter Ayr, medicines that are not ≈øo hot are to be u≈øed; which mu≈øt al≈øo be ob≈øerved in tho≈øe which in regard of their age or con≈øtitution of body are hotter, le≈øt that humour ≈øhould be kindled, and a Fever from thence ari≈øe afterwards; or if ≈øome are hotter, they ≈øhould be prepared with Vinegar, or taken with Syrup aceto≈ø. Citri, Sorrel great or ≈ømall, Pomgranates.
For there is no depending upon one medicine again≈øt poy≈øon, but they are to be varied, le≈øt that nature ≈øhould be accu≈øtomed to it, and thereby can receive little benefit by it.

div.head: CHAP. VI. Of the Cure of the Pestilence.
div.p: IF in any di≈øea≈øe in the world, certainly in this an exact way of cure is to be u≈øed, Cure. ≈øince that the ≈ømalle≈øt fault being committed by any, may become an irreparable damage: But becau≈øe the right rea≈øon of Cure depends on indications, and ≈øeeing that the Plague is an occult di≈øea≈øe, and its nature con≈øi≈øts in an occult quality, which by its peculiar force is mi≈øchievous to the heart, and is very contagious; but that is introduced by a cau≈øe endued with the ≈øame quality; Hence 'tis manife≈øt, that that occult quality indicates a medicine alexipharmacal contrary to it, and ≈øhews that the cau≈øe in the body, whether taken by breathing in, or contact, or by what means ≈øoever contracted, ≈øhould be removed and eradicated; But how that ought to be done, is controverted among≈øt Phy≈øitians.
For fir≈øt, ≈øince that neither Phlebotomy, Breathing a Vein. nor Purgation are indicated by the pe≈øtilence, quatenus 'tis the pe≈øtilence, whether they are to be u≈øed or not is controverted.

Fir≈øt, Concerning the opening of a Vein, ≈øince that it neither cures the di≈øea≈øe, nor takes away the venome, nor the cau≈øe, 'tis rarely to be u≈øed, and in that Pe≈øtilence which is occa≈øioned by evil Diet, 'tis wholly to be omitted, as al≈øo in that which ari≈øeth from a pe≈øtilential con≈øtitution of Ayr, unle≈øs there be very
great ≈øtore of blood which mu≈øt be dimini≈øhed, and its heat mitigated: But if the Plague come by infection, and there be that plenty of blood as may cau≈øe us to fear le≈øt that a putred Fever ≈øhould happen, which may become no le≈øs dangerous to the ≈øick then the Plague it ≈øelf, or that it be ob≈øerved that the blood flows violently to inconvenient places, and that the ≈øtrength is rather oppre≈ø≈øed by its plenty, then di≈ø≈øipated, you may breath a Vein, yet only bleed what the ≈øtrength can well bear with; and that ≈øhould be in the beginning, for when twelve hours or more are pa≈ø≈øed away, 'tis ≈øafer to omit bleeding, becau≈øe the ≈øtrength being debilitated with the violence of the poy≈øon, it cannot well bear it. Concerning the place for breathing of a Vein, ≈øuch a place is to be cho≈øen, as may help the motion of Nature, not hinder it, and may together divert the pe≈øtilent matter from a noble part; Therefore if a Parotis break out behind the ears, or a Bubo under the Arm-pits, or a Carbuncle in the ≈øuperiour parts, a Vein ≈øhould be opened in the Arm on the ≈øame ≈øide; but if a Bubo come in the Groyn, a Vein ≈øhould be opened in the foot on the ≈øame ≈øide. But if a Carbuncle ≈øhould ari≈øe in either of the Legs, ≈øeeing that u≈øeth to cau≈øe an inflammation, and great pain, by which the ≈øtrength is weakned, 'tis convenient to open a Vein in the contrary leg; for neither is the motion of nature hindred by this means, but the matter is drawn from the ≈øuperiour parts towards the inferiour, and a great flux to the part affected, and the increa≈øe of the inflammation is hereby prevented.

Moreover Purgation al≈øo is not indicated by the pe≈øtilence, Purgation. nor can the ≈øeeds of the Plague be eradicated by any purging medicine, unle≈øs perhaps a great di≈øturbance of nature being made, which mu≈øt then be joyned with danger: and for as much as Nature for the mo≈øt part expels the pe≈øtilent venome to the outparts of the body, this motion of Nature by Purgation is hindred, and the pe≈øtilent venome is drawn into the internal parts, and is more mixed with the humours, and the motion of humours being ≈øtirred up, mo≈øt dangerous, nay deadly vomits and ≈øluxes are occa≈øioned: And therefore not in purging, but in medicines that re≈øi≈øt poy≈øon, principally, and next under God the hope of health and ≈øafety is to be placed.

Wherefore it will be ≈øafe≈øt for any one that ≈øhall think him≈øelf to be infected with the Plague, U≈øe of Alexipharmicks. having fir≈øt implored the a≈ø≈øi≈øtance of almighty God, to fly to tho≈øe medicines re≈øi≈øting venome, mentioned in the fifth chapter before, and to take ≈øome one experienced and approved medicine; and in ca≈øe it be vomited up
at the fir≈øt, then 'tis be≈øt to take of it again forthwith; nay, in ca≈øe it be retained, it will not ≈øuffice to take of it but once, but the Alexipharmacal medicine ≈øhould be repeated thrice in the ≈øpace of four and twenty hours, and ≈øo to continue for two days, until that the force of the poy≈øon ≈øhall be broken. The medicine being taken, the ≈øick ≈øhould forthwith compo≈øe them≈øelves to ≈øweat, e≈øpecially the ≈øecond time after taking, they ≈øhould keep out the cold Ayr, and if the ≈øtrength will bear it, they ≈øhould continue their ≈øweat for two hours ≈øpace: The ≈øick ≈øhould by no means ≈øleep, until he hath ≈øweat twice, and between the ≈øweats ≈øhould be refre≈øhed with Con≈øerve and Syrup of Ro≈øes, Sorrel, aceto≈ø. Citri, of Pomgranates, red Goo≈øeberries, with cordial and odoriferous waters applyed to the No≈øtril, and ≈øprinkled about the Bed-chamber. It ≈øhall be profitable al≈øo to take warm bread out of the oven, and fill a hollow part of it with Treacle, and apply it to the Navel, or to the Arm-pits, that it may draw the venome to it; The ≈øweat being ended, the body ≈øhould be rubbed and dried with clean warm linnen clothes, being careful that no cold ayr be admitted, and the ≈øheets and coverings of the beds ≈øhould be changed. After the ≈øweat, the ≈øick ≈øhould be nouri≈øhed with meats that afford good juice, and ea≈øie of concoction, yet taken but in a ≈ømall quantity.

When the ≈øick hath ≈øweat once, if there be need of opening a vein, let it be done in that manner as is already heretofore expre≈ø≈øed: And when the Alexipharmicks have been taken of two days by the ≈øick, and the body is Cacochymick, or the Plague depend upon ≈øome internal default of humours, and that great danger of a Fever be to be feared, it will be convenient to admini≈øter a purge, that ≈øome part of the matter putrifying and increa≈øing, the Fever may be abated; ≈øo that Nature may overcome the re≈øt more ea≈øily: they ≈øhould be gentle, as Syrup of Ro≈øes ≈øolutive Tamarinds, Rhubarb, Agarick, Pe≈øtilential Pills, Tryphera Per≈øica, Syr. Dia≈øercos.

Afterwards if it be not needful to cau≈øe ≈øweat (which neverthele≈øs ought not to be hindred if it come on a critical day) ≈øuch medicines are to be continued as hinder putrifaction, re≈øi≈øt a malignant Fever, and extingui≈øh the flames in the bowels and humours.

And then we mu≈øt be wary how we u≈øe Treacle, or any of the other hot medicines, without any re≈øpect of the di≈øea≈øe, nature, age, and other circum≈øtances; wherefore when the Fever hath ≈øet upon the body, ≈øuch things are not to be exhibited, unle≈øs they are mixed with cold things, or el≈øe cold things alone may be
given, ≈øuch as Syrup, aceto≈ø. Citri, of Sorrel, Pomgranates, red Goo≈øeberries, rubi Idaei, as al≈øo Pearl, Coral, precious ≈øtones, Bezoar.

But ≈øince that Nature for the mo≈øt part u≈øeth to ≈øend the mo≈øt venomous part of the matter to the out-parts of the body, Cure of Buboes. and occa≈øions Buboes and Carbuncles: If the venome perfectly, or mo≈øt part of it be driven out into a Bubo, which may be known by the remi≈ø≈øion of the Fever and Symptomes, we mu≈øt expect ripening, although not perfectly, as in other tumors, yet it mu≈øt be helped by all means; for if either a Bubo come not enough out, or be encrea≈øed over-much, and ≈øtill the Fever and ≈øymptomes abate not, and the ≈øick no ways mends, we mu≈øt endeavour that a way may be opened for the letting out the venome.

Therefore either ve≈øiccatories mu≈øt be applyed, or the skin mu≈øt be ≈øcarrified, that the poy≈øon may freely expire, and the pe≈øtilent humours fly out; a young chicken al≈øo, or pigeon, the feathers about the rump being pull'd off, ≈øhould to the great advantage of the ≈øick be applyed to it, although no inci≈øion be made, and that ≈øhould be often repeated; or a dryed Toad being moi≈øtned with wine, ≈øhould be applyed: afterwards we mu≈øt endeavour that the re≈øt of the matter may be brought to maturity by proper medicines de≈øcribed every where up and down; into the place opened by Inci≈øion, convenient dige≈øtives ≈øhould be put; and if the inci≈øion be not made deep enough, and the quitture be ≈øtill therein detained, the tumour mu≈øt be opened with an Inci≈øion knife, and the Ulcer mundifyed with proper medicines, and it mu≈øt not be healed up, until all the venome be come out.

But Carbuncles are forthwith to be ≈øcarrified, Cure of Carbuncles and that deep enough, that the pe≈øtilent and corrupt humour may come forth, afterwards ≈øome convenient plai≈øter mu≈øt be applyed, ≈øuch as may be of the ≈øoot of a chimney, and others, de≈øcribed up and down in Authors: Some apply the plai≈øter de Magnete Ar≈øenicali, 'tis proper to apply a dryed Toad al≈øo, being fir≈øt powd'red, in wine, to the places adjacent, le≈øt the venome ≈øhould return to the internal parts; ≈øome defen≈øitive of cooling, drying, and binding things mu≈øt be applyed; ≈øome make a circle with a Saphire ≈øtone about the Carbuncle, le≈øt the poy≈øon ≈øhould creep farther, and thereby extingui≈øh the ≈øame; and if the Carbuncle be too much encrea≈øed, and cau≈øe great pain, a vein ≈øhould be opened under the ≈øame, that ≈øo the corrupt blood may be evacuated, and to abate the heat, a plai≈øter of Hound≈øtongue is to be applyed.

When an E≈øcar ≈øhall be generated, it mu≈øt be taken away with a convenient Unguent, and the Ulcer mu≈øt be mundified and
cured in due manner; but during the whole time of the cure, twice every ≈øeven days a potion of the temperate medicines that re≈øi≈øt venome ≈øhould be drunk, le≈øt any of the malignity ≈øhould remain in the Body.

div.head: CHAP. VII. Of the Nature of a Pe≈øtilent and Malignant Fever, and of the difference of them from the Plague.
div.p: FOra≈ømuch as the highe≈øt degree of corruption of humours is in the Pe≈øtilence, we mu≈øt as it were a≈øcend to it by the malignant and pe≈øtilent Fevers: of them therefore we will now ≈øpeak, in what re≈øpect the≈øe three, the Pe≈øtilence, a pe≈øtilent and malignant Fever differ.

That the pe≈øtilence con≈øi≈øts in a certain occult quality meerly adver≈øe to mankind, and that it is infectious, The plague pestilent and malignant Fevers, how they differ. and that a Fever is not of the ≈øame e≈ø≈øence therewith, but yet commonly accompanies it, is already ≈øhewed: And therefore the Plague it ≈øelf al≈øo, when it hath a Fever joyned with it, may not without cau≈øe in ≈øome mea≈øure be called a pe≈øtilential Fever: yet other Fevers al≈øo are called pe≈øtilent without the plague, wherein the corruption of humors hath not yet attained that high degree which may con≈øtitute the nature of venomous pe≈øtilence, yet they contain in them ≈øomwhat like to that venomous and malignant pe≈øtilence, and moreover either are not pernitious, or contagious as the plague, if they are both of them, yet they are le≈øs de≈øtructive then the plague; for the difference of a pe≈øtilential Fever, ≈øo called in particular, and of the venomous pe≈øtilence (≈øince the nature of them both is unknown) betrays it ≈øelf in this, by the vehemency and contagiou≈øne≈øs of it, which is perceived to be le≈øs, not only in ≈øporadick Fevers, but in epidemical pe≈øtilentials, then in the plague it ≈øelf: But concerning malignant Fevers, although they by a general name ≈øignifie truly pe≈øtilentials, yet in particular tho≈øe are called malignant, wherein there is a le≈øs degree of corruption then in tho≈øe that are truly pe≈øtilential, and wherein the humours which kindle the Fever contain in them ≈øome occult quality tending to veneno≈øity; whence there is le≈øs de≈øtruction and infection, ≈øomtimes there is none.

And that the matter may be handled in few words, if it appear by the ≈øymptomes in any Fever, that be≈øides putrefaction there is a l≈øo ≈øome occult and maligne quality, and yet but few die thereof, whether they are epidemical Fevers, or ≈øporadick, or
contagious, or not contagious; this is the fir≈øt degree of corruption, and ≈øuch a Fever in particular is called malignant; but in ca≈øe many die, and yet others are not infected, or although there be ≈øome contagion, and ≈øome de≈øtruction, and yet neither the contagion nor de≈øtructive power have attained to the highe≈øt degree, and many continue well in health, 'tis a pe≈øtilent Fever in particular. La≈øtly, if ≈øo be many which begin to be vi≈øited die, and that mo≈øt every where are infected, and that the contagion be ≈øpread over remote places, 'tis the plague.

div.head: CHAP. VIII. To what kind of Fevers Pe≈øtilent and Malignant ones pertain.
div.p: MOreover ≈øince there are three kinds of Fevers, To what kind of Fevers pe≈øtilent and malignant ones belong. Ephemeral, Putred, and Hectick, and again of putred Fevers, there are ≈øome differences: 'tis now enquired to what kind of Fevers malignant and pe≈øtilent do belong, or whether malignancy and pe≈øtilency belong to all Fevers, or to ≈øome certain kind only.

But we have already determined that there are no Ephemeraes nor Hecticks pe≈øtilent and malignant, becau≈øe that in all pe≈øtilent and malignant Fevers, there are manife≈øt tokens of corruption or putrefaction of humours, although that malignant and pe≈øtilent humour have likewi≈øe a manife≈øt antipathy with the ≈øpirits, and may ≈øtir up a dangerous Fever.

But all putred pe≈øtilential Fevers are continued, ≈øince the force of the venomous putrifaction is ≈øuch, as that it can ea≈øily diffu≈øe it ≈øelf into all the veins and arteries, and may ea≈øily corrupt the humours.

But malignant Fevers in particular ≈øo called, may al≈øo be intermittent, as experience ≈øheweth: Neither is it impo≈ø≈øible, that even in the fir≈øt pa≈ø≈øages of the body, the putrifying humours may acquire ≈øome malignity; and ≈øeeing that in ≈øuch Fevers the force of the venome is not ≈øo great, nothing hinders but that Nature may appoint certain excretions at appointed periods.

Continued pe≈øtilent and malignant Fevers, are particularly addicted to no ≈øort of them, but according as putrefaction happens into this or that ≈øickly preparation, ≈øo this or that continued Fever is ≈øtirred up, ≈øomtimes a Synocha, ≈øomtimes a periodick; whence various ≈øymptomes likewi≈øe do ari≈øe, according to the ≈øickly provi≈øion.

Moreover concerning the differences of malignant and pe≈øtilential Fevers, The differences of pestilent and malignant Fevers. ≈øince that in every ≈øuch Fever there are found two things, the putrifaction it ≈øelf, from whence the Fever ari≈øeth, and malignity; in re≈øpect of the≈øe al≈øo, do the Fevers differ. For ≈øomtimes equally from putrefaction and malignity, danger is at hand; which Fevers, if the putrifaction and malignity be great, are exceeding dangerous; but if neither the malignancy nor putrefaction be much, the Fevers are not dangerous. Somtimes there is more putrifaction, but the malignancy is not much; and then the Fever comes neerer to the nature of other putred Fevers: but ≈øomtimes the putrifaction is not much, but the malignant quality vehement, and ≈øuch Fevers ≈øeem to be milde but they are mo≈øt fraudulent and dangerous.

Concerning the nature of Pe≈øtilency and Malignity, although it be occult, yet from its effects we may apprehend a certain variety, whil≈øt ≈øomtimes ≈øpots, ≈øomtimes Mea≈øles, ≈øomtimes wheals come forth; ≈øomtimes too great ≈øweats, ≈øomtimes Catarrhs, Pleuri≈øies and other evils, according to the antipathy which the venome hath with this or that particular part.

div.head: CHAP. IX. Of the cau≈øes of a Pe≈øtilent and Malignant Fever.
div.p: AS for the cau≈øes of the≈øe Fevers, Cau≈øe. becau≈øe their malignancy is le≈øs then theirs of the pe≈øtilence, and through this, as it were by degrees, we a≈øcend to the Pe≈øtilence, tho≈øe which are the cau≈øes of the Plague, for the mo≈øt part, are the ≈øame with tho≈øe of malignant and pe≈øtilent Fevers; but more mild, as principally ayr, heaven, cour≈øe of diet, and contagion.

Namely malignant Fevers in the fir≈øt place do ari≈øe from a ≈øickly provi≈øion of the body; for it ari≈øeth from meat that is bad, fit for corruption, and very obnoxious to putrifaction, whereof Galen may be ≈øeen, in his book of Meats affording good and bad juice, and the humours may be ≈øo corrupted in our bodies, as that they become venomous, of which I have ≈øpoken in the In≈øtitutions in the ≈øecond book, part 2. cap. 12. Furthermore from common cau≈øes likewi≈øe, namely unprofitable con≈øtitution of Ayr, as al≈øo from the influence of Stars.

But pe≈øtilent Fevers ≈øo called in particular, have the ≈øame cau≈øes, but more grievous, which at length if they are increa≈øed, produce the pe≈øtilence; whence Fevers malignant and pe≈øtilent long continuing, at length turn to the plague.

div.head: CHAP. X. Of the Signs of Malignant and Pe≈øtilent Fevers.
div.p: IN the ≈øame manenr is it about the Diagno≈øtick ≈øigns: The Diano≈øtick ≈øigns of pe≈øtilent Fevers. for in a pe≈øtilential Fever peculiarly ≈øo called, the ≈øame ≈øigns almo≈øt appear as in the plague, only fewer, or more gentle; and ≈øuch Fevers are not ≈øo dangerous nor ≈øo infectious as the Plague it ≈øelf.

But as to the ≈øigns of their differences, if both malignity and putrifaction be very much, the ≈øtrength will be much weakned, and grievous, nay the mo≈øt dangerous ≈øymptomes appear: If the putrifaction be very great, the malignancy little, the feveri≈øh ≈øymptomes which accompany putrifaction are vehement enough, but the ≈øtrength is not ≈øo much debilitated. But if the putrifaction be not great, but the malignant quality vehement, the ≈øymptomes which accompany the Fever are gentle enough, but the ≈øtrength is exceedingly weakned.
